Ratings.comment: Lectures/Labs were great, the grading was strict, and make sure to use those office hours to ask questions.

Hardest CSE class I've taken so far but he was really nice and willing to help you learn. Looking back, I wish I had gone to more office hours and put more effort into the class because he really was willing to help you if you needed it. Grading was fair with the final exam 30% of our final grade. Take advantage of lab time and office hours!!

Solid teacher overall. Was approachable outside of class and responds nearly instantaneously to any emails sent. Software 1 is just more of a weeder class (very harsh project grading and tests) but Piyush is definitely supportive and knowledgeable enough to assist you throughout it.

Gets back to students very fast. Was willing to help and the lectures were good. His class was following the OSU standardized cse 2221 template (all have the same lectures, labs and, homeworks). Just a pretty solid guy who was always open to helping out students. Always open to questions and helping your understanding.
Good professor with good teaching skills

He's helpful but doesn't really challenge students with programming experience so the class can be boring at times. It's an easy A if you read lecture notes carefully and take time on projects and labs.
Very generic professor, very easy course. Xiaofeng
Overall decent teacher. Helpful when you go to him with questions. Standoffish at first, but get to know him.

Networking is tough but Jim breaks the content down in a way that is understandable and easy to learn! Quizzes and exams can be tough cause there is just generally a lot of material but still doable! Read all the bullet points in the slide go to class and you should be fine!

Best professor I ever had! He explains the material clearly and while you might not get it in class if you record it and watch it during your own time it's crystal clear! His quizzes can be tough but they help broaden the scope of what you need to study for the exams!

Jim is such a cool professor to have. He's very sociable, both during lectures and office hours, and gave good feedback. There's a lot of things to memorize throughout the course, and the quizzes can be tough, but he allows cheat sheets on the midterm and final, which help a lot. He's also very understanding and willing to help.
Great guy who truly is passionate about the course. The exams are fair but the quizzes can be tough. Highly recommend.

Lectures were very clear and easy to follow. Prof. Vickroy makes sure to answer all student questions thoroughly. Material presented in slides is interesting and is accompanied by about 100 pages of reading per chapter . Quizzes and exams can be a bit tricky sometimes, but there is a participation and project grade to balance overall grade.
Frickin awesome teacher. Go bucks.

Jim is the greatest professor for Networking. I don't say that a lot, but he really made the class easy to understand. He gave lots of extra credit opportunities, an easy lab, and you are allowed cheat sheets on the exams. He is also such a nice guy and knows each and every student. Networking is a hard class with tough professors, but not Jim.
Really nice guy. Hes chill and good at explaining things. Very open to questions.

Probably the most split professor as far as students go for many of reasons in other comments. I learned a ton from this class that I wouldn't have otherwise learned. I pay a lot for these classes and I want to milk out as much knowledge as I can. Good thing with Wolf is that she'll talk endlessly about CS. And she's hilarious while doing it.
Actually the worst. Unbelievably bad. Getting an A in this class is basically impossible, even with the massive curve. Prof retiring this year though, so maybe no more students have to suffer.
Avoid at all costs. Don't trust reddit. ANY professor would be better than her. I'd rate her -100 if I could.

She is a good lecturer and does a good job preparing you for projects but not for her exams. Before the first midterm she told the class "My exams are probably harder than any of the other CSE 2231 professors". You can know the material really well and failing the exam. There was a failing average on both.
Average on final was 48%. Average class grade was C. Avoid at all costs

After switching to online classes she emailed us saying the 2231 dpt as a whole decided on weekly quizzes instead of Midterm 2 and final. Which actually stimulates online learning weekly. After that she told us that shes "bucking the system". Only professor in the course to do that. Both were impossible. Passing grade for final was a 30 Interesting

Lectures are not bad. Sometimes lost her train of thoughts and leaving the class confused about what shes trying to say. Has her own slides but stopped making them half way through the semester. Accessible and helpful during office hours. Exams are hard. She doesnt care how much you learn from the class. Just to trick you and make you fail.

What's there to say that hasn't been said. Her exams are painfully hard but she has really good lectures and tries to ham in the real important information. Final in this class is absolutely insane. She can be funny at times and does hint at the important exam information during lectures heavy. SW2 in general is hard though, do not slack.

She is the best professor that I had at OSU, she helps everyone. The materials in not her fault, it is a fault of unwise desitions some chairman agree to put those materials. NO University in the United States would agree with these materials because it is all wrong, and does not teach coding.

The tests were very based on theory that required a deeper understanding of the material. There weren't a lot of "direct" questions. They required you to think outside of the box. Her lectures were extremely helpful and provided essential information for the projects and exams. Overall, a very good teacher that teaches very well, if you work for it

My problems with Anna: -Uses her own slides, which are good, but she stopped using them about a third of the way through. Used text editor and chalkboard instead. -Missed many lab days, leaving the class confused. -Missed scheduled office hours many times with no reasoning. -Difficult exams with not enough time to solve the questions.

She knows the material very well and is willing to offer help outside of the classroom. She made her own slides. Her exams were not extremely hard but flexible. Her exams combined a lot of stuff from SW1 and 2, so you'll need to know every concept for the software sequence to do well in exams. However, there's a 9 points curve.

So the 2221/2231 sequence was specifically designed by bucci to do research on. I transferred from another school where the CS program is a lot more normal, sane, and less sadistic. Just take Anna,you're going to suffer whatever professor you take for this class,at least Anna is real and hilarious. Not to mention the smartest CSE professor by far.

She once said in class that she teaches the way she does to make herself more approachable to students after class so that they wouldn't be intimated. Go to office hours with anything you don't understand and her review sessions ready to listen and you'll pass with an A. At one of her review sessions she went over several practice exam questions.

I think she may be trying to change her teaching style. She still goes off topic quite often and cracks lot of jokes, but her teaching is very clear and and direct. She uses the slides more as a guide rather than simply reading off of them. Knowledgeable, very willing to meet with students outside of class/office hours. Rejoice if you get her!

It's easy to see Anna is a very intelligent and knows what she is talking about, and she does a relatively good job at articulating material. Her tests are much more difficult than other sections every year, and she grades them somewhat harshly, but there is a significant curve at the end of the class.

Either she works for you, or she doesn't. She gets off terribly topic multiple times a class. Some people find this amusing, others find it incredibly distracting. She also had to cancel class last minute multiple times throughout the semester. Some people liked missing class, others needed more class time to learn.

The strangest prof in the CSE dept. She's hilarious bc she disses the CSE dept, and cracks jokes a lot. But she's a horrible teacher because she rambles and goes on tangents very easily. She'll have slides, but never get past the first page bc she forgot about them. And she always mentions she's on drugs.

Anna is probably the smartest person in the entire department. She made her own slides for many topics (dissing the dept slides), teaches as someone who knows how industry works, etc. The only people I wouldn't recommend her for are those too sensitive; she's crude and sarcastic. Yes, SWII is hard. Not her fault. Favorite prof of college
Terrible lectures and confusing way of teaching. Rambles too much and doesn't provide information that will actually help you pass an exam. She's funny though

I completely taught myself this course. Wolf is a nice person and really does want to help her students, but not a clear lecturer. She does not use the official slides and didn't even make her own this semester, so it was difficult to follow what she was going over. I had to read all the official slides right before exams to learn the material.

I used to be against skipping lecture but I do that for her class now. If I could grasp what she's talking about in particular, then I would definitely go more often. The reality is, half the time, she's rambling. She also is a bit disorganized but she's nice and willing to help until she cancels her office hours. You'd be better off self-studying

Haha, well, she's edgy and informal. I like that about her. However, I cannot understand anything in her class. She doesn't teach off the slides and there's no structure to her lectures whatsoever. Wouldn't recommend her unless for giggles. She could be a comedian or whatever. That won't help your grade or understanding, though.

Wolf was hilarious, but I don't think I ever learned a single thing from her lectures. She never taught based off of the CSE slides, and she would often ramble on and on and get distracted, which was probably a side effect of the drugs she always tells us she takes. If you wan't to learn take it with someone else
Very laid-back and informal. Explains things well.

She's funny, but pretty unprofessional in the way she runs class. A lot of her lectures are pretty useless, since the tests are over the CSE department slides and not hers. Would avoid her if possible, but she's not the worst either.

Learned a lot from taking Software 2 with Anna. I would definitely recommend taking the class with her as opposed to a different professor. A lot of people don't seem to care for her teaching styles, but I think she is really good at presenting the information. Also, she's hilarious.

She tends to go off topic quite frequently, and is on a lot of drugs so tends to zone out a lot. She's not very professional, which some may prefer but I mean in a not caring way. She doesn't use the slides ever and the midterms are over the slides provided by the CSE department, so her lectures are kind of out there.

She was a really funny teacher, but if you're the type to get offended easily, you might not like her jokes. She can go on weird tangents during lectures, but she's really patient and willing to go over stuff students don't understand.

She's only the lecturelab prof*  She is funny and overall a great prof. Also helps students on the side that need the extra assistance. However, sometimes her lectures can be a little wild and I seem to lose track of what shes talking about. No worries here though, since all of the course slides are online.  I would defiantly recommend.

First, the good things: She is very funny, approachable, and helpful. She also seems to care about what she does.   The not so good things: She can be a bit scatter-brained and isn't the best lecturer, but certainly not the worst.  As a whole I liked her very much and would take a class with her again.

Anna has hilarious emails, and will communicate with the students on information she finds pertinent. However sometimes it is hard to get help with specific problems. She cancels office hours often and sometimes without notice. Other times she will meet outside her office hours (depending on if you beg and her mood). Lectures sometimes not helpful.

Lectures can be long and dense but if you can pay attention, he will explain everything in a very understandable way. Great at answering any questions you may have. For online, attendance was required either synchronously or asynchronously. Understand how to do all of the homework and the exams will come easier

Made every attempt to clear up the material in the lectures, but the class just wasn't interested or couldn't get it, myself included. He tried to make the class reasonable for everyone but recycled homework and exam problems didn't help. I ended up getting a higher grade in the class than I expected or deserved so he definitely curved something.

A great young professor who is extremely knowledgeable. Though the class was difficult, if you ask questions or need clarification he is sure to answer. He is very fair with grading, exams, and office hours. Overall an amazing new professor

She seems to rarely understand questions from the students and gives irrelevant answers. Class is poorly managed, the time limit on discussions and presentations were never enforced and we often stay 15-30 minutes more than schedule. It's only a 1 cr course and shouldn't be like this.

She provides no help for your question in class and she will tell you to email her after class. EVERY TIME she took longer class time than scheduled and ask you do not to leave early. Our class ends at 6:50 PM and regularly we leave after 7. This class material should not be hard so take someone else and you will still get an easy pass.
Annoying, condescending/superior attitude. Luckily most of the grade comes from the group project/what your team grades you. However, attendance is mandatory, even on days your group is presenting.

Pretty hands-off, each group presents on what they've done on their game every two weeks, i.e. most of the in-class time is spent listening to presentations. No real grading until the end of the class, except teammates rate each other every other week, which he will use to call slackers out.

Had him for the capstone course. A well structured class, where he encourages everyone to make a good game. Hammers down on people in groups who wont do their work (thank god). And yes, participation matters. Youre graded by your team, nearly no grade actually comes from him. Overall a lot of work, worth it for the output.
Dr. Crawfis's labs are extremely hard. You have to seek his help if you want to get through them, which he encourages you to do. Results you achieve in this class are amazing though.

Crawfis barely attempted to teach this class. Everything was out of slides, almost no writing on the board. Gave strange labs that were often cryptic to understand. Hard midterm, easy final. When he passes back practice exams you only need to understand the concepts on them. Also he assigns insane homework assignments so check online for solutions.
He is horrible, he gives hard labs, the average is below 50% in lab two he sucks. he he made the class harder the CSE 560.
Pretty good instructor, definitely above average.  The other comments are correct that the assignments can be hard, but I think that might be the nature of the material.
Dr. Crawfis is extremely laid back, and he wants all of his students to do really well. He does make you earn it, but if you put in the time you will enjoy him as a teacher.
Take every class you can with him.  You wont do well on the hw or labs but you will do well on the exams if you try the sample ones handed out.  The samples are exactly like the real ones.

When taking a class with Dr.Crawfis, you gotta realize 2 things: 1.)you need to learn EVERYTHING on your own, and 2.) he passes out points like an old man dispensing laffy-taffy to a horde of drooling infants at the park. He will help you if you ask questions, but his lectures seve are just glorified explanations of what he wants for the labs.
Hard but helpful
Extremely easy teacher. Didn't learn all that much, but Crawfis was just subbing for another prof. Very easy going.

Absolutely Horrible!  He is probably the most UNhelpful prof I have ever had.  I can think of two specific examples where I emailed him for help and got one sentence or shorter responses which totally bypassed the question at hand.  His lectures are also incredibly boring.

My friend who is also taking the class and I agree...he would be a good father, but isn't the best teacher.  The homework isn't bad, and lab 2 is pretty freakin rough.  Not a bad class overall.  Rog is very helpful if you bring any questions to him - really knowledgable guy.

Teaching out of powerpoint is rough, but still understandable.  He is tough and he forces you to understand the concepts of the course.  Labs are very cool and fun to do.  I would definitly reccomend him again.  Don't take this class if you are lazy!!!!
You wont like his lecture as its pretty boring, but the labs and hws are interesting and fun.

He gives hard exams, but i think the homeworks were alright and so were the 1st and last lab. The 2nd lab was a bit tough but solvable, yo just have to study hard for this class as it is not an easy course, the teacher is alright.
Avoid at all costs!

He teaches MATH straight out of powerpoint slides.  He does not shows examples hardly ever and when he does, they're VERY confusing then!  Average mid-term score was 65%.  Labs preversely complex.  Nice guy, bad teacher.

I took several classes from Babic, back around 1999. Most notably CIS675 and 676 (computer architecture classes). Remembered him randomly after a recent conversation, amused he's still a tough grader. Advice to new students: You will appreciate him decades later if you make it through. He'll be rough on your GPA but you'll learn a lot.

Avoid this class! This was the hardest class I have ever taken at Ohio State, and Babic doesn't work with students to even try to help. I would take another semester of college rather then taking this class with Babic

Avoid if you can. The class content is difficult enough, and Babic does you no favors in making it any clearer. He is somewhat condescending towards students and does not do a very good job with student questions. I will say that the labs and homework are relatively straightforward, so make sure you get these perfect.
Life is hard in quarantine. Life is even harder when you have Prof. Babic during the pandemic.

Labs are haaaard. Exams are haaaarder. I pass out every time this professor talks, especially with that projector fan giving off that noise that complements his monotone voice perfectly. Great place to sleep, horrible place to learn. Im a senior, I dont wanna go thru this freshman stuff. Let him teach freshies and put some fear into them, not me.
Babic is a terrible lecturer.

Avoid at all cost. Grades extremely harsh, TA's are more understanding. Can get negative points on exams, Also does not help he asks questions and then belittles the person who asked if they get it wrong

Extremely difficult to follow. I passed the class based off readings and online research. He is terrible at answering student's questions as he is often condescending and fails to understand what the student is asking.
Dr. Babic's lectures are hard to follow. However, if you can spend enough time to figure out the stuff he is teaching, you will be truly rewarded.

Very knowledgeable and clearly passionate about computer architecture, but fails a bit in the professor department;he's obviously more research focused. Lectures are 120min and tedious because he speaks slowly. A fun class, but despite Babic. I recommend you take this alongside ece2060 because the first half are similar. Accent Level: 3/5

Babic is a great teacher. Grading criteria are clear, and he's excellent at responding to questions. Assignments are appropriate and challenging. I wish more in the department were like him. For example, the "networking" professor I had was not even capable of ordering a decent book.

Professor Babic makes Systems II deceptively easy in the beginning. Projects are not hard at all. Homeworks are graded slowly, so you don't get a look at his grading until the first midterm. He doesn't give partial credit, and his test questions can award negative points. His tests are long and pedantic. His lectures are not bad.

Avoid at all costs. Dry boring lectures that don't explain concepts well. Tests are insanely difficult. The final exam had a question that SUBTRACTED points if you answered it incorrectly. Yes he is knowledgeable but anyone would be knowledgeable if they have been teaching the same content for 20+ years. Nothing at the systems level has changed.

Dr. Babic gives very boring, dry lectures. Often, he responds to students' questions a bit angrily, saying, "we've gone over that," before begrudgingly answering. Tests are extraordinarily difficult. He is a VERY knowledgeable, intelligent person. He is just an awful lecturer.

Seems like a nice guy personally, but an absolutely terrible professor. Arrogant and uninspiring. The subject material is definitely tough. I went to his office hours for clarification and he made me feel stupid for the question I asked. Sorry we are just learning the material and you've been teaching it for a gazillion years. Avoid this professor.

I might be the only person at this campus that thought Babic wasn't that bad. Far from my worst class and definitely nothing like I read here or on reddit. He mumbles, yes, but if you show up to every class it's quite easy to follow along. There are far worse professors on this campus than him. Never went to his office hours, so no opinion there.
AVOID him as possible. A shame of OSU CSE department.

Worst class I've taken in my life. The networking class was full so I had to take this class instead (DONT). The homeworks are way to difficult, the exams are as hard as homework, meaning you gotta memorize diagrams by heart and regurgitate them. Gives very little partial credit and the material sucks and you wont ever use it. Avoid this class.
Drop the class if you have Babic. I would graduate a semester later rather than taking a class with him and getting a low score.
This guy is terrible. Run and save your lives!
This professor is the worst one at the ohio state. AVOID his at all costs!!!AVOID his at all costs!!!AVOID his at all costs!!!

He teaches horrible and grades very harshly. He has a terrible accent and mumbles too much that it forces you to sleep. Worst professor I've ever had in my life. He is too old and senile that he doesn't understand questions. Avoid at any cost!
He is a disgrace to the computer science department. He doesn't explain things and grades very very tough. One bit mistake causes you to lose the entire question. I think it's time for him to retire.

Doesn't explain things well, and isn't any more helpful in office hours. A quote: "is easy, I don't know how else to explain it to you". Much of exams is diagrams from lecture - memorize them. Illegible handwriting during lecture. He runs into things at the front of the room, and will randomly sit and lecture to one person in the front row.

Poor lecturer. Rambles off-topic and is unclear when explaining key concepts. Not clear during office hours either. Exams are challenging, ambiguously worded, and harshly graded. Homeworks take a long time to understand but are graded leniently. However, he does give out handouts of the slides. Regardless, avoid this professor if possible.

This is a difficult class. I recommend taking notes on the optional readings before class. Babic's lectures are fine, but it is easy to miss important information if you get lost somewhere. He gives you printouts of the slides which is very helpful. He is also very accessible outside of class. You need a strong grasp of the material to succeed.

There is a direct correlation between how important the topic is and how badly he mumbles. He rarely does in-class examples. His homework is hard and tests impossible. All of that being said, he isn't as bad as these reviews make him seem. If you give effort he is willing to work with you. He is great in office hours and has a HUGE built in curve.
You have to ask yourself first what kind of a person is a professor, before anything else. This prof. is a bad, bad person, bad character. Avoid by all costs

Babic is, by far, the worst professor I've ever had. He's impossible to follow because he has a thick accent and his idea of "lecturing" is essentially just wandering around at the front of the classroom and mumbling incoherently. If you have the chance, drop his class. I'm sure that anyone else in the department will be better than him.

The biggest problem with Babic is that he does not recognize the fact that different students are differently abled and may have problems in class. He doesn't do anything to address this fact but if you are willing to put in an effort to reach out to him, then you will be greatly rewarded and you will end up loving this class.

Babic is easily the hardest professor I have ever had to deal with.  His exams never test the relevant, important material for the course topic, always something arbitrary that you skimmed over because of its lack of important. His labs can be tedious, especially considering the code given to you is horribly written. Tough class to do well in.

Get in a study group EARLY in the class to do labs and homework assignments as they are the only way you will pass. No partial credit on exams. You can get negative points on tests. The curve built into the class is the ONLY curve that will be applied. SWITCH IF POSSIBLE.

I'm not sure where a lot of the other reviewers are coming from, but I didn't find him as hard as everyone says. Everyone receives a copy of all the lecture notes and reading from the book was never necessary besides homework from it. Homework/labs and exams were challenging, but not unfair. His accent wasn't that hard to understand

For a student who use hardwork to complement intelligence like me: He is the worst professor I have ever had! No ability to give lecture, rambles around, too thick accent to be heard, and even rude with my effort! Studied hard júst to get a D+ in his exams and going to withdraw fron his class soon!

If you don't read the textbooks, you won't pass the class. His lectures are incredibly dry, and don't really explain everything that well, but most of the homework and labs come directly from the book. Make sure you put in a lot of effort on the homework and labs, because the tests are impossible.

Gojko Babic is the worst professor I've taken. Most students are almost always lost in his lectures, which include trail off sentences and information almost entirely irrelevant to tests and projects. It's rough, since he seems like he means well, but his difficulty is too great for how little his ability to teach is. Read the book, or fail.

While the grading criteria and feedback aren't all that clear, he is a fantastic teacher.  His lectures may repeat or skip some things, but he always gets to them in some form eventually.  The labs are hard but rewarding to complete.

This is an extremely difficult class. This professor seems to really care about making students understand and I feel bad giving such a bad review. The guy's English is pretty bad and that's a major problem when asking questions. I also found myself falling asleep in class which I really never do. This was a boring subject and needed a better prof

A true terror. He will fail you harshly (50) on the tests if he didn't like your answers, even if they are partially correct.  Homeworks and labs are medium difficulty, but take ages to complete.  If you take him, memorize all the slides and research the topics on your own, including practice problems since he gives none.  I tried hard but failed.

He lectures from slides, but the slides only have half the material so you need to listen. He makes it clear that he has more important things to do than be teaching undergrads. If you go to his office hours, he isn't very understanding when you don't understand something from class. Expect, "I said this in class already" and "Did you take notes?"

horrible! OSU should be ashamed of having this guy teach systems courses. such bad usage of English. such bad organization. terrible. poor teaching. I can teach better than him. gives points for attending: I don't want to attend your class Dr Babic because I can't stand you speaking. such waste of time. how unfortunate is that he teaches nothing!

You will learn a lot from him. His exams were hard, but if you study his slide and go through the homework, you will be fined. Offer extra credit. However, he said I didn't turn in final exam and gave me B- without any point from final! Problem is still not solved! Take photo with him when turn in exam! Or you will be blamed for not turn it in!:((
This guy doesn't even deserve a single star!!!  He should have been fired or assigned to teach 1000-level courses!!!

Most of his homework was not that hard. If you find that the assignment is hard for you, please drop this class because his exams are much harder. To people who concern his exam: 1. Don't put too much details on short answers. He will mark your points if you make mistakes on details. 2. Remember the slides! 90% is minimum request!
I am a student with gpa 4.0, now my gpa becomes 3.0, god bless me.

I took Babic for systems 2: OS, and contradictory to what everyone else is posting he was actually surprisingly easy. Although he is difficult to understand at times, the exams come straight from the slides. Yes, the information is difficult in general but I just studied the slides the day before the exam and did really well.

I took his CSE 2421 class and though i passed,  I would never take a class with him again. Its not that he's a bad person, he is just a bad teacher. He knows his material, however he is unable to relay that knowledge to you.  If forced to take his class memorize the slides well for first exam. Beware he offers negative points on the final.
Babic is the worst teacher I've ever had the misfortune to interact with
HORRIBLE

Would not recommend. When explaining what is fairly technical and advanced topics he is unclear and often trails off without explaining anything. Has a hard time realizing that some students won't understand material off the bat and is rude when answering questions. Fairly nice guy but is not a great teacher. Exams are hard too.

Extremely hard to understand, partially because of his accent, but mostly because he will trail off when trying to make a point. He is always available for help, but he usually isnt helpful, I got the impression that he knew how to explain things one way, but if you didnt understand that way you were kinda screwed. Avoid if you can.
Awful professor. I've had to drop two of his classes because he is so bad. Hard to understand and never finishes his train of thought.

Actually sticks around after class to help students, and doesn't cancel his office hours every other week, unlike other CSE professors I've had. His slides are sometimes difficult to wrap your head around, but once you do, you genuinely have a good understanding of the concept. His examples are well-selected.

If you are interested in low-level theory and willing to work without limit, you can learn a ton from him. I find his lectures to be reasonable, and he's always been helpful to me in office hours. I definitely know like 100% more about CSE in general than I did before his class.  However, his tests are exceptionally difficult.

Extremely difficult grader.  Marked me off 40% from midterm for drawing extra boxes on a few of the diagrams, which did not change the actual meaningreasoninglogic of the diagram (marked me off for putting TOO MUCH detail).  But, did not specify in clear English how to draw them.  Lab assignments take 15 hoursweek.  Probably withdrawing now...
Never take Babic's class! He is terrible... Dropped his OP Systems class at the mid of the semester. Cannot stand him any more.

Literally THE WORST!!!!, in every sense of the term. If you care even a tiny bit about your GPA, AVOID! Taking him even after so many constant warnings about how awful he is was the biggest mistake of my life. Not only he is a ridiculous teacher, he is mean, rude and deep down, just wants to fail you. Avoid by all means possible!

He's a great professor. Hard to understand due to his accent but 100% knows what he is talking about, obviously since he's been around for years.. Those who rated him poorly are probably just looking for easy A's and not looking to put the work in. He does grade hard but in a field where you should be graded hard.

He has a good heart if you go and talk to him during his office hours and genuinely want to learn. However, his exams are a bit ridiculous. The first exam was straight from the textbook and the second exam was nothing compared to the first exam, so you never get a feel for how he tests. It is hard to prepare for his exams but it is not that bad.
If I quit school it's because he is crazy and is the worst teacher ever. Projects are impossible and there is no place to go for help.

His lectures are dry and sound unprepared. He knows what he's talking about but that doesn't mean you will. Despite this and his accent, he'll test you on vocab from his lectures verbatim. Lab specs are riddled with vague language and typos, and clarification responses are slow. Known to fail over 30% of his class. Would not recommend.

Alright professor, his accent can make it hard to understand some topics. Really nit-picky about details for exams. If I were to take this class again, I would start the labs the day they are assigned, and then go to his office hours whenever possible. If you get stuck and don't know what to do, you're on your own. Replies to emails after due date.
Feedback on labs and homework nonexistent. His exams are unreasonable

He is easily the most nit picky grader I have ever had.  On exams, even if your logic is flawless, he will deduct points if you use a word that seems vague to him, regardless of how specific it is within the context of this course.  That may be fine for a research paper or code documentation, but not on a timed exam.  He is also insulting and rude.

Babic is a great professor. Ive had him now for 660 and 677. He is one of the most knowledgeable teachers at OSU. His classes are challenging but know that you will walk out of them with confidence in your knowledge about the topics you cover. The last statement applies to students who actually want to learn and push themselves to do better.

Very difficult professor, take class with other professor if possible. Labs were out of the difficulty scope of the class. Office hours are helpful to attend but not if you are completely lost in the class.  Exams based on small details of notes.
His tests are incredibly difficult.  The labs and homeworks are very time consuming and can be graded harshly.  Do not take 660 with Babic, take it with anyone else.

If you are academically ambitious and REALLY care about getting straight A's, then you shouldn't take Babic's CSE 660 -- take it with Mathias or Shareef or anyone else. If you don't really mind stressing like crazy and still getting only a B, then Babic's class might be fine for you. You have to memorize the slides - say everything the he wants.

Really one of the worst professors of all time, easily the worst in the dept.  Really without redeaming characteristics.  Incomprehensible, awful lectures that get no information across.  A ridiculously rigid assignment schedule almost no one can keep to with no flexibility.  The only truly awful prof Ive encountered in this dept.

I think he goes out of his way to put misleading details into exam and lab problems. For example, he has you code a process to print when an account doesn't equal 3000. So this implies that it should be possible for accounts to not equal 3k, so you code accordingly. WRONG! The 3k process should never print anything!

Babic really wasn't near as bad as everyone made him out to be. Yes, he was boring, but it's not like the subject is inherently exciting. His expectations were clear. He was willing to answer questions. His exams were very straightforward if you studied. There were no tricks in this course whatsoever.  The grader's the one you have to look out for.

As others have noted, the tests are straightforward IF you memorize the slides.  I studied about every other day for several hours and aced the course.  Someone else pointed out that his lectures were very unclear at the end of 677.  I agree!  Be ready to spend lots of time using the book to decipher the slides at the end of 677.

He knows the material but lacks the skills to explain it.  He has an accent(he even writes with an accent), but in general he's understandable.  The exams revolve around details.  If you can memorize the material and know what every IEEE standard is you'll be set.

Babic's classes is very hard and you pretty much have to go to class to understand the material; he also takes attendance. Buying the book is useless, as all of the information is on the slides. Be prepared to get rocked by the midterm/final unless you study every detail of every slide. Thick accent. I've taken 660 and 675.01.I wont take another.
Makes a relatively easy class somewhat difficult.  Much easier as taught by other professors.

Absolutely the worst professor I've ever had. Referenced tiny details on tests, gave little direction on labs. I was warned about him and didn't take the advice and paid for it dearly by having to learn everything by myself (as his lectures were useless).

Had this guy for 675 and 677.  If you can recall every detail of the lecture slides, the tests will be pretty easy.  It takes a lot of studying, however, to do this--don't put off studying until the night before the test!  Wasn't always very clear about presenting material in 677--I had to use the book to decipher a lot of the slides at the end.

Babic was pretty much the reason I changed my major. Take a couple classes from him and you'll know what i mean. First off, he lacks the communication skills that should be required in a college course. Also, he does not explain the homeworks at all, and most students are afraid to ask him for help because he will criticize you ever chance he gets
Don't believe all of the comments you read here. Professor Babic makes you work hard for your grade. As long as you work hard, you will do fine. Very knowledgeable and extremely helpful.
Absolutely THE WORST professor i have EVER had at Ohio State.

Although he's very smart, sometimes he doesn't realize how fast he's talking and it seems that everyone is too intimidated to ask a question. If you do happen to speak up in class, you better hope you're right or he will (unintentionally) belittle you by writing your thoughts off. I dare you to pay attention for an entire lecture.

a nightmare in true sense of word! knows how to screw up your grades. no matter how hard you try one cant follow what he is trying to teach. keeps correcting slides and his assignments would have atleast one question where he will ask you to correct a diagram/table in textbook. makes subject more difficult to understand. PLEASE AVOID if you can!!!

Tests & hmwks r mostly paper & pencil & involve lots of tedious detail and precision. (e.g. instr states in a processor across clock cycles)  Harsh grading--little partial credit.  Frequently corrects errors on his own ppt slides--I'm not convinced anybody can (or is even supposed to) master the material.  Very frustrating class.

He is completely unorganized.  We would spend a significant portion of each class just going over the corrections to the previous class slides.  The tests were written in broken english.  I one test I answered the question that was asked correctly.  He marked it wrong because the question he asked wasn't the question he meant to ask.

Pretty good teacher. Very descriptive and detailed slides. You end up learning a lot in the class because he forces you to study everything for the midterms and finals. His homeworks are pretty hard and tricky, but he will help you in his office hours if you have any questions.  Has great passion for the material he is teaching in this class.

He's hard, and a little wacky, but he'll make you smart. His exams are an awkward combination of concepts and memorization: make sure you memorize EVERY bulleted item on his slides, and know how to draw all diagrams from memory. Aside from that, his class is pretty easy. The homeworks aren't bad, and he'll answer all your questions succinctly.

He obviously spends a lot of time preparing for class; his slides are very thorough. If you actually go to lecture, he has a good way of making complicated topics more accessible. His homeworks and exams are challenging, but I think this is due more to the challenging material than to the professor himself. I have now enjoyed 2 of his courses.

Took an individiual study from him to learn unix network programming.  Basically just an intro thing.  On a one on one level he's a pretty nice guy.  More disorganized than most though.  He's weird, too, real weird.  I like him though and I'd take his classes again.  His accent is definitely strong but it is not in any way a problem.

Class left a bad taste in my mouth. His slides are terrible, he does not posses the skill of clarity and is unclear about what exactly he wants you to know. His tests are brutal. Don't expect to recant information learned from class; expect to invent computers, evaluate ficticious performance scales, and reproduce the most mind-numbing topics.
Not a great teacher.  He doesn't controll his speaking volume very well, either.

Explains the material very well: I feel like everything makes sense. Offers several optional bonus questions and makes himself very available to help his students. Always encourages students to visit his office if they are at all confused. His accent is very obvious, but it does not make him hard to understand. Attend class and you will do well.
Exams are completely disorganized. Very boring, speaks with heavy accent.
He takes a difficult subject and makes it impossible to understand. Most people came out with no better than C+ and few of us can actually program a working lab in assembly.
what a waste!
This guy is a teaching nightmare.  The material is chaotic, as is his instruction.
Avoid at all costs.

This guy is great! Totally crazy but very smart and helpful. Ask him about semaphores and it makes him so happy he cries. His office is always dark and he types with two fingers. Every time he hits a key, his computer goes boop.. boop.. boop... It's madness!

I truly wanted to like this prof. He genuinely does seem like he wants to help his students. But unfortunately due to his large focus on long drawn-out homework assignments and tests/exams, you had better be able to draw your circuits FAST and legibly. He isn't exactly lenient with his grading too.

His exams are insane. Tests you on obscure stuff in the book he never talked about. Helpful to a degree but if you have any trouble forget about it. Would rather criticize you than help you understand stuff. Lectures word for word from the handouts.

I found his class to be quite exigent.  The homework assignments and exams were not easy, and lectures were quite monotonous.  He starts off sentences in a shouting voice, trails off to mumbling nothingness, and then repeats this process.  I will never ta

The man is a terrible professor. Cannot phrase a question to save his life, but then wonders why no one knows the answers.  Absolutely terrible, take it in Spring or Summer with Mathias instead, he rules!

wow that was an experience... prepare for the quarterlong struggle to stop laughing when he jumps all over the room. The final was 13 pages! Talking about 'lucky' numbers... Paranoid about people cheating. Doesn't explain material well.

Heard a lot of complaints before I took CIS 660 & 675.02. Taking the class, I thought he was pretty easy. Exams and HW not hard, labs in 660 pretty challenging. Lectures boring, but handouts help. Has trouble explaining some topics, but tries hard to help
the material is difficult, but he is genuinely interested in helping students in the class. He does have an accent, but it makes the class interesting
Does anyone else think he resembles David Letterman?

CAN I SAY INTERESTING LOL. This guy sits in a dark corner of the class babbling in Babic speak. Writes chicken scratch on an overhead and then tests you on some obscure diagram in the book asking you to redraw it on an exam.

Dr Babic is a good instructor.  He has a good understanding of the material and is genuinely interested.  He is also pretty funny.  The other students who rated him poorly probably aren't great students.

What the heck? His final was 13 multipart questions across 9 pages... a total of around 45 questions or so... non-comprehensive. Half this stuff I don't recall him ever going over in class. His classes are dry and boring.
terrible teacher. everyday i zone out for the whole class.
I think he knows what he is talking about, he is just bad at presenting it.  The labs are confusing as hell too because his english is bad.  Don't bother going to his office hours.
I don't think he knows what he is saying.  No recommended, but you have to go thru him in order to graduate.  ha! no choice, good luck.
terrible at presenting the material. every day is a struggle to stay awake.

Supowit's lectures were often confusing and unclear and the amount of material in this class was vast. However, he was always happy to answer questions or go on a tangent about poker. Very funny guy and definitely likes teaching. He grades very harshly, and his office hours are life saving. Exams are killer. Study hard and good luck.

This is the hardest class I ever took, but the professor is great. I'm convinced that this class is the reason I was able to get an offer with Facebook--the highest possible offer available at my level because I "killed it" on the interviews (not my words). Soak up as much as you can from this man. It's worth it!

Gives the most difficult exams I have ever taken. Averages are 60% and curves are huge. Very difficult but absolutely brilliant. Amazing and funny lectures. I studied for days for his exams, but I'm fully convinced I got a job at Facebook because of him. Take his class but be prepared for the stress and make sure you have the time for it.

You will learn a ton from the class if you put the work in. Very very smart dude. Brutal grader, but curves significantly. Unclear grading criteria. You will DIE if you don't go to lectures. You can't memorize; Actually understand stuff. Class very difficult overall; You will have to work hard if you want a B or better.

His lecture style is very unorganized and often sparse on detail and important examples. (Became more apparent with online class). While he cares about students, he also is fairly intimidating. Homework is not too difficult, but is not representative of test questions. Average on exams in (C to D+) range. Note: This class is hard, but avoid Supowit

Very smart and funny guy that does a lot to help and make sure that you understand the material. Very difficult exams and quizzes. Extremely harsh grader, but gives a significant curve to the class. Doesn't give a lot of feedback unless you talk to him directly. Doesn't update grades online, so you don't know what your grade is until the end.

A horrible professor. I can't warn against taking his class enough. There is little point going to lecture because he just talks to the board and goes off on random tangents. He then ask you highly conceptual questions on the exams that require a deep understanding of the topic. Beware, he has no issue failing half of the class.

Amazing lectures, but you had better not miss anything because he does not post resources. His expectations are unclear and he doesn't post grades. A curve is guaranteed but there's no way to know your grade til the end of the semester.

Great professor. He keeps homework and class itself interesting. If you participate and take an interest you will find yourself enjoying the class. That being said his exams test your ability to take tests as much as your knowledge of the class if not more so. Good professor, but hard.

Disgusting homework and midterm. Disgusting stuff and question. Disgusting grading. You will not able to see anything include grade in Carmen until the end of semester. Never pick him if u have any other choice.

If anyone has his class, you will know how bad he is. A professor who talks trash talk on the class. His exam is most difficult I have seen. The average score for the first exam is 54%. You may imagine. And also the midterm review doesn't has any relationship to his exam. He will say "It lets me feel disguting" when you talk with him about the exa

He's okay, clearly knows the material and seems to care. However he's never released any grading criteria, doesn't put any grades online, and his tests are so wildly different from the homework that I honestly thought I walked in to the wrong testing room. Baffled by all the rave reviews, I think students like his attitude and occasional swearing.

Dr. Supowit is one of the best teachers Ive ever had. Hes visibly passionate every lecture and has more experience in CS than any prof Ive had in the past. His grading is kind of a mystery bc he doesnt specify category weights (and we just got back an exam today with 54% average), but honestly a really enjoyable class. Hope to take him again.

I've learned more from his class than any other class I've taken. He's inspirational in making you want to learn more. The guy's a freaking genius. That said, if all you're aiming for is a high GPA, don't take him. Tests are crazy hard and curve big, but may not bring you up to where you want to be. Be ready to take the B/C. NOT A BLOW OFF CLASS!!

Super cool and knowledgeable professor. His tests are very hard and there are definitely easier professors for this class, but I do still feel I learned a lot despite the tough exams. Very lecture heavy class that covers a lot of topics but well worth it. He does not post any grades online but there was a serious curve given my exam scores.

If you are in a computer science related major at OSU and you never take a class with Ken, you are missing out. His lectures are open-ended and conversational, which keeps them very interesting in my opinion. He is more challenging than others but really he is just pushing you to think more deeply and his generous curve covers the difference.

Recommended -- I found that he teaches data structures and algorithms well and in great detail. His class is challenging, but you'll want to know these concepts well to pass your technical interviews, so take Foundations 1 and/or 2 with him and don't blow it off. You'll be rewarded for it.

Prof. Supowit was one of my favorite professors ever. He's hilarious and has a perpetual smile. His exams are really hard, but it would be unfair to say that he doesn't prepare you for it. His examples and homeworks are equally challenging, requiring you to think for you yourself. Would recommend for in-depth learning, but not an easy grade.

If you like theoretical things, do choose this professor. If you just want to remember what was taught and pass exams, choose another one. He likes to lead you to think, to find algorithms on your own, and he stresses on this ability. CLRS is as really important for the course, and you'd better go through proofs in it carefully.

I really liked Ken. I think he does a good job conveying some complex concepts and keeps the class entertaining with his humor. Most don't like him because he doesn't post any grades online or outline a grading scale. He claims "it won't change how you study anyway". It didn't affect me but I can see how that would be frustrating to others.

First of all, funniest prof I've had. Insanely smart guy as well. Generally speaking he's very good at teaching the ideas and material as well. However I couldn't help but feel like he made the class quite a bit harder than it needed to be, relying on a huge curve at the end of the class. I felt like I learned a lot, but I really had to work for it
Supowit is a hilarious professor, and his class is pretty challenging, but if you pay attention in class you'll do fine!
The class is hard, but don't knock him for it. He is great at explaining algorithms and is an overall interesting person.

Foundations II is a tough, lecture-heavy class, and Dr. Supowit does everything on the chalkboard, but he's a very solid, passionate prof to learn from. His lectures aren't for everyone, but if you really try to follow and participate, you'll get a lot out of it. Note the pop quizzes. There are easier lecturers, but you'll learn much more from him.

Dr. Supowit is a nice professor. He prepared the class the well and tries his best to make the class interesting. After class, he is willing to help me with any question. But his exam is a little bit tricky.

He's smart and seems to be really interested in the material. He does everything on the chalkboard, so you have to go to class to get the notes. There is some textbook reading, but I never did it and was fine. If you do all of the homework, you should be fine for the exams. He gave a few pop quizzes and even gave one right before Thanksgiving break

He is a really good lecturer, and I found this class incredibly interesting. The material was hard, but going to his office hours was really helpful. He wants students to succeed, and is very lenient with partial credit. He was my favorite professor I've had at OSU so far, and if you have to take Foundations 2, I would definitely take it with him.
Nice professor. Very inspiring. Willing to answer everything in his office hours. The office hour is long. Don't feel afraid to ask him questions.
Do not take his course. He did not prepare his lecture well. His lecture does not help at all. However, if you are enjoying to debate a professor and have a good contestable skill, then try it.

Thought this class was going to kill me but it actually was my favorite class. If I can stress one thing, participate in discussion. Be present, its so much easier to learn if you just pay attention during class. He acts like he doesn't care about students but I think he does. He's a really good teacher and you can learn a lot from him.
He is an amazing lecturer. Explains every algorithm so clearly. Some homeworks are too tough. Mids & finals are easier than the hws. You need to work really hard for an 'A'. Try to response in class.
Terrible lectures, no online notes, difficult tests. And to top it all off, he gave a midterm the day after springbreak.....

He clearly had a passion for the subject matter and was very intelligent, but he would ramble and go off on tangents constantly. He was horribly unprepared for his lectures, he would ask the class questions that he himself didnt know how to solve and leave half of them unanswered as he moved to the next topic. Avoid this professor if you can.
Really smart professor, exams are tough.

Terrible teacher. He expected students to understand concepts that should have been taught as a part of this course. He also expected people to speak up when something didn't make sense, but even when someone did it didn't help anyone with understanding. Book is also useless and not needed. Switch out of this class while you still can.

One of the worst professors I've ever had. No syllabus, no online grades, unfair test questions, useless textbook and impossible homework. He often loses focus and trails off in lecture, has trouble solving his own problems, and insults the intelligence of less adept students. Do yourself a favor and steer clear of his class.

Absolutely no help with anything and expects you to know things that you haven't even learned yet. Very rarely described anything in full and test were beyond hard and reasonably challenging. Homeworks rarely helped with the learning of the material. Learned more from a grader from another class in 1 hour than I learned from him in a couple weeks
He is the worst ever!!He is arrogant! Don't take any classes with him..His exams are tricky and the home works are a pain, plus the book is not useful at all.
Tough class. He's very interested in the subject material though, and explains everything clearly and helpfully. A bit boring, but come on. There's only so much you can do with regular expressions.

I just paid attention in class... got near perfects or perfects on all the homeworks and exams... probably had the highest grade in my class (or for that matter, probably the highest grade he had seen in years). If you are sharp and like theory of computation and have a strong background in mathematical logic, then this class should be easy.

He is probably the best professor I've had, he is VERY hard, he however explain everything step by step and will answer your questions after class if you stay and talk to him. his homeworks are very hard and will require a lot of work, he however curves a lot, I thought I had a C but I got a B+, if you want an easy grade, take it with someone else.

Someone commented he is rude, that is exactly correct; And someone commented he treated coldly less-adepts, that is also correct; if you ask questions, he will make you feel stupid and waste his time, even if your questions are really pertinent. Take his class if only you already know well the materials, but hey, who bothers to take it in that case
He's a very hard teacher, but grades on a pretty large curve. All his assignments are very challenging. I suggest going to class and reading the book every day.

He is one of the most intelligent teachers of all times. I had fun attending his classes, his discussions are intellectually stimulating, homeworks and exams were a bit hard, but nothing outside of scope. It's always helpful to see him tackle the problems in class, and have us discuss different approaches for problem.definitely gonna have him again

a theoretical mathematician shouldn't teach a database class.  'Nuff said. Makes mistakes and the class has to corrects, doesn't know the material until he opens his book. Changes assumptions & grades differently from one quarter to the next (I had prior notes on the EXACT material graded differently.) Teaches relational calculus when others don't.

This is actually a math course, but it's offered by the computer science department. This professor is too old to teach. Roughly every other line he writes on the chalk board has a mistake, he catches 1/4 of them, and someone in the class usually catches 1/2. The rest show up later when you're trying to study from notes you copied off the board.

I had a great time in this class.  The entire class is just solving puzzles.  Ken goes over a ton of examples which really helps.  He likes to figure out problems on the spot which usually gives some insight into the thought process behind the solution, this also really helps.

Pretty smart guy, a little old fashioned (no course website/slides). 90% of the class time is discussion of solving various examples. He will wait till the class gets it right. Midterms are challenging and homework is very time consuming and a bit hit or miss. Late homework was allowed though. Not that bad.

Supowit made this class way harder than it needed to be. Often treated questions as stupid, but usually made an effort to make things clear. The midterm was ridiculous, there were only four problems. I got about a 50% and dropped the class. In comparison I'm taking 625 with Yusu Wang and got a B+ on the midterm. Avoid Supowit if you can.

Almost a complete lack of effort as an instructor. We never even got a syllabus. He didn't prepare well and wasted a huge amount of time trying to figure out examples which should have been worked out before class.
Terrible. He has NO idea what's doing. Avoid him at all costs. Terrible teacher, makes a ton of mistakes.

This is really CSE's advanced math course - you rarely get much more intellecually challenging in computer science courses; if you want more, register for a math sequence, fun stuff! Supowit taught the course well, but this course is just an introduction to computability, don't expect to go too deep into one topic or further than NP-Completeness.
his hw and exams are way too tough, omg!

Prof. Supowit is a very intelligent man, and this only sometimes translates well into teaching ability, depending on who you are. If you engage the discussions, and make class entertaining as well as fun, you will succeed, as he knows the material inside and out. Watch out for tricky questions, he loves them.

Wow, Worst teacher ever, the book that he uses is worthless, good luck on the homework. Exams are impossible several students didn't even get above 40% on them. Don't take this class with supowit it will kill your gpa.

Had him for 625, 725, and 541. His classes are not easy, and he never has a course website. Do not miss class. His midterms are sometimes weird. He makes a lot of somewhat funny jokes and gets distracted a lot, but not really a good teacher.

Here's the thing.  Your gonna get a B.  There's gonna be a total genious in the class, maybe 2.  He gets the A.  Theres gonna be a moron/creepy kid.  He gets the C-.  Everone else gets a B.  Yoour gonna get between a 50-75 on exams, but end up with a B.  Sounds a little insulting and is proud of himself when he corrects students. Kinda fun at times
Excellent professor, the absolute best I had while at OSU.  He was always willing to help, and was a lot of fun, too.  Extremely smart and entertaining.

He tends to favor the more adept students in the class and gives very difficult exam which he also grades harshly.  He also may ask questions on the homeworks or exams that he may not know the exact solution to, so that hey may see your thought process and your "approach".  It's a very difficult class, unless you are you are natural adept.

He does not use formal notations and expects students to use "his notations" for all the proofs which is quite vague.He also covers very little of this profound subject. I also strongly believe he will be seriously sad if he finds everybody did well in his class. He is helpful outside the class. Grading may be random and unfair.
Old-fashioned blackboard user. Not afraid to fly by the seat of his pants. Socratic, smart, and engaging.

I took cis 625 with him last year. I really loved his class. I found him to be the best teacher in OSU   Computer Science until now. I am taking 725 now and I am having a lot of fun. This is the only class where my attendance is 100%.
A VERY TOUGH GRADER, NOT NICE AT ALL.
I DIDNT LIKE HIS CLASS!!!!!!!!

His tacky attempts at "Simpsons"-injected humor and football jokes makes his classes cringe-worthy. Inconsistent in terms of the materials covered and sometimes he rattles on in riddles. As with a/m comments, he grades HARSHLY and does not seem to like explaining material to less-adept students.

No grounding in reality.  An all day chalkboard hieroglyph writer.  People either love him or hate him and it often has a lot to do with grades.  With (almost?) all the points coming in two tests, which are infamously hard, the safe bet is to avoid hi

He is very very rude, gets angry when he is unclear of someone's response and tries to bring out faults in you even if you are somewhat right. Horrible grader, not helpful at all. Also very strict with rules, no excuses.
Not bad, not bad.  Dorky but entertaining.  Tests were tough, though.
Avoid him at all costs!!
Nice sense of humor which makes for a fun class.
bad grader
Very hard class but his dorky sense of humor helped make the class very interesting and worth taking with him.

Very difficult class. Lectures are above average, with lots of examples shown. Often rude to students who are struggling or asking "dumb" questions. Rather leniant on those who are doing well. Unwilling to help/explain material outside of class.
Prof Supowit is my best teacher ever. The class was indeed challenging, but it was also extremely interesting and stimulating! I learned a lot from him.
Hard class.  Makes you know your stuff.  But, then again, I learned more from this guy than about any other.
Not helpful to confused students. Takes off too many points for small mistakes.
He does not explain things well. Tests and homeworks are impossible and long
I hate this man.  He is mean, he will not answer you questions.
Very Tough, plus He is a bit of rude to people, you need your luck on this one

She's very disorganized and all over the place, probably because being a prog isn't her fulltime job. Even tho she doesn't know how to teach or understand the material, it's possible to do alright in her class due to the fact that she gives you very generous deadlines and attempts to help when she can. Get help from classmates.

Bronwyn Altizer is the worst professor I have ever had the displeasure of having as a student. Her utter incompetence with the subject matter and utter lack of desire to help students in need was not only extremely discouraging but woefully infuriating. I am begging you to not take this class, please take the other professor, they're in-person.

Dr. Jones is great as a guy and his lectures are super engaging and teach you a lot. The group projects are free points and have no dead lines, so as long as you get them done you're fine. The biggest problem is he doesn't believe in partial credit on exams, so they are overtly difficult and scary. He did curve pretty heavily as well.

Professor Jones is a great professor. His lectures were enjoyable, he has great industry experience, and he is very accessible. He does give pop quizzes, so be sure to stay up to date on the material. The work is more than fair and anyone can get an A if they put effort into this class. Be sure to participate and engage, as it will help you a lot.
He'll let you memorize tons of formulas that you can simply get from Google. For a guy coming from industry, this makes no sense.

If you are planning for graduate school, avoid this instructor. He will literally curve your grade down. This course is all about memorizing terms and some useless projects. Projects are already graded subjectively so there is no point for curving down.
Make sure that you would like to spend tons of time and learn nothing before taking this class.
This man simply doesn't care about what he teaches. What you learn are pretty much useless.

I can accept a professor who's a tough grader but cares about his student, but I CANNOT accept a professor who doesn't care about his student at all. His slides are outdated, and you'll learn nothing. His classes are simply a waste of time.
This man did not even update his outdated material. You'll learn nothing from this class.
Learning news terms has nothing to do with security. Projects are nothing related to security. And they call it a security class.
WORST EVER instructor in CSE department. You've been warned.
Spent more than 1/3 of the time studying idealized cache management, which is tbh pretty useless.

When it comes to projects, grading, and overall Carmen usage, get ready for things to make absolutely no sense. Dr. Jones finds a way to make every aspect of taking the course ridiculous absurd. The grade in Carmen does not reflect your grade, as he has his own spreadsheet that he updates with your true grade. Wanted us to use GitHub for a PAPER!

Course outline has been changed again and again. I'm sure over 10 times. Lab 4 is such a joke, since there are major bugs in the .o files provided, and he said they are "features". He is such a prepared and kind professor, and I suggest ppl to take his class to enjoy his vicious hw, quizzes, labs, and exams.

This is definitely the WORST professor you could ever met in OSU. I don't why OSU still hires him, which lowers OSU reputation. I can accept a Professor who's a tough grader but cares about his student, but I CANNOT accept a Professor who doesn't care about his student at all. He clearly doesn't have the ability to understand other's feeling.
The info on this page WAS so MISLEADING. Worst instructor ever.
Interested in parallel programming techniques and best practices? You won't learn them in this class.
It's ridiculous he refused to provide answers to his quiz, homework, lab, nor discussed them in class. Terrible instructor.
This supposed to be a relatively "relaxing" CSE class, however, with Jones, you get the opposite. Imagine someone pretends to be nice and turns out giving you a fail grade.
If you have chance to switch to another section, DO IT NOW.
Literally the worst ever lecturer in CSE department.
If you have heard of horror stories from your friends about this instructor, they are true. Don't waste your time here and still mess up your GPA.
Save your time. Save your brain. Do something meaningful. This class is all about memorizing outdated terms.
Don't waste your time here. Find another instructor instead.
You have to memorize so much outdated and meaningless info for this course. Useless course, consider taking CSE5472 instead.
Generally, his course does not work for people that know what to do. Participation is required but meaningless.
I would recommend CSE department to stop him from teaching.
It's a waste of time to learn outdated things.
Don't. Just don't. You've been WARNED. It's literally the worst ever class you can have in CSE department.
This man never knows how smart a modern compiler is. Outdated material and not worth it. Don't waste your time.

You'd better ignore the recommended review by RateMyProfessor. It wasn't true. The online version is complete garbage, and you are very unlikely to get good grades since he will make tons of false statements to deduct your score. You've been WARNED. AVOID THIS PROFESSOR.
The slides were pretty outdated. Tough grading.
WARNING: Grading is harsh. Unless your GPA is good enough, don't take it.
Useless course and materials are outdated.
Grading is tough.
Unless you have a good enough GPA to waste on this class, don't take it.
Something about his teaching style rubbed me the wrong way. Tests were fairly difficult and graded harshly.
Avoid this instructor.
What's the point of quiz passwords?
Don't. Just don't. You've been WARNED.
Try your best to avoid any online courses from Jeffery Jones.
NEVER TAKE ANY ONLINE COURSE FROM HIM. THIS MAN IS ABSOLUTELY THE WORST.
Don't take any class from him. You've been WARNED.
Concurrency? OK. MPI? I wonder if it is useful for your career.
You've been WARNED: Never take any online courses from Jeffery Jones.
Jeffrey jones is a bad teacher... The lecture makes no sense and grading are tough. You've been warned.
Worst ever professor you can get in CSE department.
Completely useless.
You will never get a good grade. He will make tons of false statement and deduct your score.
Never take any course from this garbage instructor.

Jeffrey jones is a really good teacher... hes kinda qwerky and sometimes just bipolar and can turn at any second... but 90% just a pretty good teacher. His test/quizzes are all just memorized things from the hw... and the hw is multiple attempts but really just fact memorization. I want to emphasiz that he is a good teacher and his lectures r good

Dr. Jones was great. He knew his stuff, had informational but concise lectures, was available to help with issues and happy to change stuff around, had clear grading criteria, and just generally made it clear and easy to do what you needed to do to get an A (which wasn't actually that much).

Something about his teaching style rubbed me the wrong way. Tests were fairly difficult and graded harshly (and focused too much on some stuff I thought was useless and a waste of time to learn). Labs were interesting and somewhat challenging.

Professor Jones is a solid instructor. Topics are well-explained and he also makes some dry topics fun and engaging. In-class questions definitely help you understand the topics. Programming assignments are not hard but you should think about how to tune your program and get the best performance.

I took both CSE 2321 and CSE 4471 with Professor Jones, and I wish I had been able to take more; he's been my favorite professor of my undergrad here at OSU. Although the subject matter in these courses can be dull at times, Jones does a good job of livening up lectures with humor and anecdotes. He also seems genuinely interested in your success.

Im still surprised at the discrepancy in what this site says about Dr. Jones and how he carried himself this past semester. I found him abrasive and not well suited for the subject matter. Hes clearly knowledgeable but I could have gotten more out of a coursera course. I would recommend him for a concepts-based class, not a lab-based one.

Dr. Jones is pretty overrated on this site. He's an okay lecturer but his quizzes have questions that require you to memorize formulas and algorithms from the slides. For a guy coming from industry, it makes no sense to have students memorize formulas they could just google. Homeworks were graded too harsh and no partial credit was given.

Jeffrey is a solid teacher. Although his lectures can get a bit dry, he still keeps the class engaged and interested. The assignments for the class are very laid back and give the students a lot of freedom (which means easier grading). There are "pop" quizzes in the class that can be extremely difficult (full memorization), but manageable.
I've had the pleasure of having Dr. Jones twice in college, and he is a phenomenal lecturer. He makes dull subjects interesting and the homework is almost the same as the exams.

Every CSE student should take a class with Dr. Jones before graduating.  He knows how to take difficult concepts and simplify them to first introduce students to new material before ramping up the difficulty, fostering both confidence and an environment highly conducive to absorbing and learning.  Highly, highly recommended!

Best undergrad teacher at the Ohio State. Period.  Take Dr. Jones if you get the opportunity, and even though he dishes a healthy amount of homework and quizzes, they'll make studying for the midterms and final a walk in the park. Love this guy!!

Really nice guy! Class had a lot of quizzes and homework. We weren't always well prepared for the homework but the material was always made clear before the midterms which were both very easy. There were also a few programming assignments. Final was a bit more difficult, but overall a very manageable class.

Dr. Jones is a personable professor, passionate about sharing his extensive knowledge of computer science. He prepared us well for exams, quizzes, and projects, offering many chances for extra credit. He teaches not only the theoretical foundations, but also real world application of course material. I highly recommend Dr. Jones without hesitation.

Jeff Jones is easily the best professor I've had thus far at The Ohio State University. He cares about his students, loves what he teaches, and makes the class enjoyable to the point where I look forward to it on Mondays.

Pretty good. Some reading, light homeworks. Tests closely reflect homework. First security-themed research project and presentation was fine. Second group programming project and report was strange; this class does not teach any programming but the project was worth a good chunk.
Doesn't prepare you for Foundations II all that well, but lays the groundwork for many other CSE department things awesomely.

Jeffery Jones was always willing to help his students, and you could tell that he really cared. Homework assignments were pretty simple too. However, the programming projects were completely unreasonable, so much so that I asked a C++ tutor to help me with it and he couldn't even understand it

Dr. Jones is probably the easiest option for 2321. Homeworks and exams weren't hard and he gives extra credit constantly. Programming assignments were tough but he's really helpful in office hours. Go to class, he gives pop quizzes. The textbook doesn't matter.

The toughest part was definitely the pop quizzes, which are sometimes given before the homework! Projects are pretty advanced, especially given the fact that most of the students have never used C++ before (they've only worked with Java). Difficulty of exams is inconsistent, where 1 exam was super easy but the final was very difficult.

Good lecturer, very approachable. Gives fair projects for this course, and the exams were both fair and pretty easy. I learned a lot from him and he made class fun and engaging. I highly recommend him.

Amazing Professor! He gives homework and test are on the longer side, but he is very clear about what he expects from you. Relates Foundation I to programming which, to me, is much more useful than simply memorizing theory.

Assignments are a bit too demanding for what is taught before they are assigned. Course could be planned more long-term rather than giving out homework 2 days before its due. Funny guy, very interactive with the class.

Jones teaches the course way differently than most other professors for Foundations 1 which I thought was a bad thing. Gives a ton of homework and programming assignments, many of which have trick questions on them. In office hours he is really helpful and wants you to succeed, but I would've taken this course with someone else if I had the chance.
He is the only course with programming project in foundation1.  he is really good person, but i strongly urge you to take other professor's course

This guy is the best CSE teacher I've ever had. You could pop in his office anytime and he will help you, no questions asked. He has "pop quizzes", but he kinda tell you when they are ahead of time. Homework is fair, quizzes are fair, exams are fair. Cool dude.

Interesting professor, made an 8 a.m. discrete mathematics course as least painful as he could. His approach to the class is distinct from other professors, but I do prefer Jones'.  Gives a number of opportunities for extra credit, which is useful for the rigor of the course.   I find him friendly, constructive, and even hilarious. Do recommend
His class is much more work than taking CSE 2321 with another professor, and completely different topics covered.. Would take with a different professors if I had the chance..

The best professor I have ever taken! Almost everyone showed up early to class, even though it was an 8AM. Extremely helpful and wants students to do well. Some received over 100% on most assignmentstests, however, you still have to study like any other class. But, you will learn the material!  Take his class if you can! Bounds above any others!

Not the best teacher or the easiest but an upstanding man. He wants to see you succeed. Go to class! Most of the course was formulated week to week and for that reason sometimes the objective learning points become fuzzy.
