Tons of extra credit, some even for just showing up the day before and after an exam, but also pop quizzes. Exams are fair.

Dr. Jones is the best professor I have had at Ohio State thus far.  He is funny and creates an environment that is not intimidating at all.  He is just one of those professors that seems like he's on your side.  I wish he was teaching Foundations 2.

Jones walked into class and after listening to us talk for about five minutes, he gets our attention to start. He pauses and then says, "I love this job. You guys are so interesting and intelligent." Jones is a good person and a fair man. He genuinely cares about your understanding. He takes the time to make sure everyone gets the material.

Hands down, one of the best professors I've had. He's funny and really cares about his students. Stresses learning by doing, and gives plenty of opportunities to get extra credit by writing code in class. It's a hard class, but Tim made it enjoyable. If you get Prof. Armstrong for Systems I, you've won the jackpot.

The class environment was friendly, fun, and casual. Labs were fair. He was really good about making sure there was in class mini assignments to help teach concepts. I really loved having him as a professor! Sad he will not be teaching next semester. The only thing is that the exams were quite long. Wish more profs were like him in the CSE dept.
A real fake and is rude

Good morning everyone, I hope you are all doing well. Are there any questions before we get started today?

The above phrase has drilled itself into my brain. I have experienced countless nights of sleep paralysis, stunned by the demons echoing those words over and over again. I cannot shake these visions, for they are now one with my being. Run.
she made really hard exams.. a lot of staff in exam either not mentioned in class or very trivial
Mind-numbingly boring lectures. Exams are 10x harder than anything covered in lecture or lab. Tough grader not willing to give any extra points to students. Terrible teacher overall.

On the outside, Chris seemed very nice and promising but on the inside completely different story. Cocky and arrogant and will intentionally make hard exams. She also at the beginning at least seemed more focus on trying to catch those who cheat rather than teaching first herself. Lectures are basic but assignments are a totally different story.
Not good at all! Doesn't teach much, gives out tests totally different than whatever she lectures about, and grades assignments very difficultly.
Can be extremely rude when talking to her. Her class is not easy and it was made worse during Covid. Quizzes are totally different from lectures and there is no curve whatsoever.

Lectures are at such a basic level but the homeworks and labs were totally more complicated. Tests are totally different from lectures and lectures don't prepare you enough. Trick questions all the way. Also proctorio sucks!
Voice gets annoying as you progress through the semester. Tests are completely different than homework or slides.

The class itself is absurdly boring and the quizzes are difficult, but she actually is one of the better professors considering stories I've heard about other professors. The lectures don't help with homeworks or projects, so just keep that in mind..
Bad attitude when replying the email, spell the wrong name to show disrepect. The tests and lectures are totally different, and no curve for the exam.

She's an overall solid professor, nice most of the times and helpful. She's also very knowledgeable and breaks down ideas to make them easy to grasp. Her tests are very hard and make up most of your grade, and she grades those very harshly.

Ms. Kiel was a great professor. She was very helpful and really enjoys teaching SW2. However, SW2 is by far the hardest coding class I ever taken and also the class requires a lot of work. However, Ms. Kiel was a huge help and made the class totally do-able.

This class has the same content and assignments throughout all sections, but your best bet is with her. Very energetic, even in the morning. Gives good hints on what she expects on projects, labs, and homeworks. Also, tried to balance the quizzes out as best as possible.

This class isn't fun in general but out of all of your choices for SW2 teachers this may be as good as you can get. This class won't be anymore fun than SW1 but Kiel isn't bad. She's very enthusiastic even at 8am
Had a positive outlook going in and was hopeful based on reviews, but grading was often pedantic and lectures were usually almost too simple, feeling inadequate to prepare for assignments and exams.

Chris is great. She's decently engaging during lectures. She does make really hard exams, which is the majority of your grade. She's helpful during office hours, but she needs more office hours. She will ALWAYS complain if you use dark mode in Eclipse and annoyingly call it "Black Screen of Death" whenever she answers questions during lab.

Professor Kiel is one of the better professors I've had. Tries her hardest to prepare for lecture and answer questions well. Very clear about what she expects on exams and projects, and clearly cares about her students learning. Will absolutely work with you about any difficulty.

I loved Chris! She truly cares about her students and making sure that they do well. The class itself had a lot of work and her exams were tough but she does everything she can to try and make sure that the material gets communicated easy. She always has a lot of energy which can be a lot in the morning. Great prof tho

Software 2 is a very difficult class. Most lecturers have a bad rep and some are known to try to trick you on exams. That isn't the case with Professor Kiel. She was always super helpful and offered great hints during class. Go to her office hours too during projects to make sure you're getting the most out of it.

She is one of the best instructors in Software sequence. Take her section whenever if you can. She is full of passion, respectful to every student. She holds a lot of office hours, go to her office hour whenever you need. BTW sometimes the graders are terrible.

I would definitely recommend Kiel to anyone looking for a Software 1 or 2 professor. She is passionate about teaching and computer science which makes the lectures interesting. The class isn't easy, but the graders are fair and the workload certainly isn't unreasonable. Would recommend.
Class material is difficult but grades fair and gives good feedback. Exams are doable, is very helpful during office hours

I took her section because all of her reviews, but I was let down. I personally didn't think she was that good. I was never able to follow her lectures. Maybe she is a great lecturer, but I missed something crucial. I just felt that she wasn't the right professor for me.

Professor Kiel is amazing and she does a great job teaching. Her office hours are very helpful, and she always gives hints on projects during class. That being said, all CSE professors make their own tests, so you never really know what to expect with difficulty level. There doesn't seem to be any curving in the class, but you will learn a lot.

It really is hit or miss for Software I & II professors at Ohio State. I failed the first time I took 2221 and had an awful teacher. Chris Kiel was sooooo much better the second time around. The class is still time consuming, difficult, has a lot of homework, and attendance is mandatory. But you could be far worse off than to have Prof. Kiel.

I thought she was a great lecturer and super helpful during office hours.  She let you know exactly what material to study for the test.  However, this is a very difficult course, and I felt that I should have earned a higher grade for the amount of effort I put in than what I ended up with.

Chris was always in a good mood to teach. She always explained things clearly and gave clarification on projects when asked. The assignments are all standardized, but her lecturing made the class easier than other professors. There was a good curve at the end.

Great instructor who is always willing to help students with a smile on her face. Her grading seems to be tough, but it's worth since she truly cares about her students. She is also empathetic with her students' struggles and she has tried her best to alleviate our pressure.

I seriously love this woman and I'm happy to get up for her 8 AM. She's constantly got this smile on her face while she's lecturing and she just really cares. The class material can get really confusing and abstract but she explains it in an easily understandable way for everything. Would recommend her like crazy! She's wonderful. :P

Very nice and eager to help her students. The course itself can be pretty tough if this just isn't what your passionate about but since all Professors of this course have the exact same (A LOT of) workload excluding midterms and finals, I won't talk about that. Overall, above average professor, but don't jump through scheduling hoops to get her.

Professor Chris Kiel has been a complete pleasure to have as a teacher. Chris' lectures are absolutely amazing and easy to understand because she knows how to make things make sense for students. I have never once seen Chris come into class in a bad attitude; she is always happy and smiling and more then willing to help students when they need it!

Very nice and energetic professor. She is always very prepared for class and always tries to go out of her way to help students who are confused. I wish I could take more classes with her but she only teaches the Software Sequence at the time being. Take with her and you won't be disappointed.
Fantastic woman who goes out of her way to help you.

Love Kiel! In fact I am taking her for Software 2, that's how much i liked her. She is very passionate about teaching and tries to do so in the most simple way with examples. That being said this class is a lot of work and requires a lot of brain power. Don't put in the effort, don't blame it on her. She genuinely wants students to do good.

This woman is the worst. She just smiles and doesn't teach; don't take her class! Awful for an introductory teacher; she will just throw you in the deep end and start teaching advanced topics, tell you she will teach the basics later, and then never teach the basics later...

She is a great teacher. Helps students and her lectures are labs are very clear. She is excited about teaching and exams are standardized so I don't get people complaining about her exams. If you pay attention, it's clear what's going to be on exam and her grading isn't tough.

A great professor overall. She is good about being descriptive with the material and wants you to understand it. She's good at responding to questions and is clear about what she wants to see on exams and projects. Some students complained about about their code on exams working but not necessarily the best way to do it, so points were taken off.

She is fantastic. She is very thorough about her lectures and says everything clearly. She is excited to teach and wants to help you do your best. Only downside is she talks to the class like she is teaching kindergarten, but I think its better to have her talk to you like you know nothing than to assume you know everything!
She was awesome. Would take class again.

This class is frustrating and will break you down a bit. Assignments arent graded, so you get great homework greats BUT nothing is covered in class twice. Seriously, nothing. Its one lecture a topic and no review, including before the test. You will get a "review assignment" and it wont be graded. (essentially useless)
She's very clear and helpful, though sometimes it feels like she's talking down to you just a bit. Still definitely enjoyable.

Everything the previous reviewer said was true. She's totally clear, explaining ideas so well that they seem like you could have thought of them yourself. Also, she's always willing to help. I enjoyed her class very much, despite the difficulty of the material.

All CSE 2221 classes use the same slides, but she's an engaging speaker and very clear when explaining things. Hardly ever goes off on tangents, and is a fair grader. She's a sweet lady who's very helpful during lab days and office hours. She's very knowledgeable about the subject and manages to explain things very concisely. Learned a lot.

Like the other review said, he clearly is knowledgeable, but has no way to effectively convey topics to students. His lectures are boring and drawn out and cover little to nothing that's actually on the homework or exams. Textbook + other resources were the only way I learned anything. Avoid at all costs, there are way better 3461 professors.

Homeworks are not very clear (you don't know what he wants), but there's not a lot of them. Not a lot of work tbh. His lectures are very slow, but you can just read the slides and look online. Grades tests generously.

This guy is a networking genius but unfortunately lacking when it comes to the classroom. His lectures are long and dry; he would sometimes spend a whole day covering 4 slides, but even then it was hard to know what we were supposed to get out of it. Didn't communicate his expectations for the midterm clearly. I would not recommend his section.
I suggest not taking this class with Professor Xuan. He was not a good lecturer and the tests were difficult to study for.

He just read every slide in the lecture and never explain what the concepts really are about. Exams take up so much portion that if you get a calculation wrong, you might get 3% off in your final percentage.

Be prepared for an exam heavy class, as exams made up 65% of this class. His grading is questionable at best (for example he often gave everyone in the class the same grades). He is a nice guy, but the language barrier can make it hard to explain things.
very good

Heavy accent and speaks quietly. Generally a lenient grader, but inconsistent and sometimes a lazy grader. For example for the final group presentation he just gave everyone 4.5/5 despite fairly varied levels of quality in work. Takes attendance if a lot of people don't show up.
The language barrier is difficult but prof Xuan really is a nice guy. Class isn't too bad so long as you study what's in red on the powerpoints and do all the work!

The class was pretty informative. The JPEG lab was nice and insightful. The exam review was very helpful. He is a really nice person. But the class is very easy as long as you pay a little attention, so if you don't like easy classes, you will find it boring.

He is as nice as he is incomprehensible. Super pleasant to talk to, if you can understand what hes saying. Class was fairly easy, just talk to him, do the work, get your A. In-class discussions are complete babble.
Horrible horrible teacher. Worse English than your average foreign instructor. Has little to no actual understanding of the subject material.

Xuan is hard to understand sometimes, but it doesn't really matter for this class. Just memorize the red slides for his test and make sure you write your presentation and paper how he wants you to and you'll do fine. Don't buy the book, we didn't use it once. By far the easiest tech elective out there, good GPA booster.

Doesn't speak or understand English very well. He deducted points from my final because he didn't understand the vocabulary; it wasn't Korean (only reason I got an A-). Makes you participate in his pet research project to solve what multi-factor authentication already does well. Rarely in office hours. He is the only professor teaching the subject.

Great class, really easy, one midterm and one project at the end of the quarter. Midterm will cover his red slides, so make sure you know everything that is on the "RED SLIDES", trust me easiest CSE class at Ohio State.
This class was a joke, but he made it as difficult as humanly possible.
his speaking volume is quiet but if you try to sit in the front, its not a big deal...his class is pretty easy and gives some good analogies to help you understand...pretty nice guy too

Pro's: He had some good analogies for various networking concepts that helped me to understand them and do well on tests.  Cons: Unless you're sitting in the front of the classroom, odds are you *will not* hear him.  He doesn't speak in a clear, authoritative tone of voice, and that combined with his strong accent makes him difficult to understand.

Could not understand what he was saying in class, because no one could hear him!  Plus, he doesn't really speak English, so that makes it even more difficult to understand him.  Tests weren't bad, but was mainly writing down pseudo-code for useless crap.  Otherwise an interesting class.

Very low-quality instructor. He doesn't know much about the stuff he teaches & probably won't be able to tell you anything besides what you have already known. This guy doesn't even deserve a single star. He should have been fired or assigned to teach 100-level courses.

Let me be perfectly clear.  I am a CSE Junior with a 3.9GPA...I tried...every day to understand this person.  I studied every night to no avail.  If you ask him a question he literally doesnt answer because he doesn't understand.  I dropped he class after 3 weeks of trying my best.  Dont waist your time...

Don't take his class. Its completely non-sense & useless. He can't answer any questions outside what's written in textbooks. He doesn't really know about anything going on in the industry. Believe me, your just wasting your time with him.
It's not hard for me to understand him, but unfortunately, his class is kind of boring and useless. I don't think you will learn anything valuable after this class.
I thought I showed up for Chinese 101. DO NOT take the guy! You canna figure out a word he says.
Will make you work but enjoyed his class.

In one word - fantastic. Took network science with him -- he knows this material inside and out. Learned relevant basic linear algebra with him outside of class since most were graduate students (I was not) and this was used heavily. Also we were in the middle of a pandemic so online. Super caring and effective. Wish I had more like him at OSU.

Took a class with him several years ago on data mining and machine learning. Still use many ideas from this class today. I remember him as an excellent and accessible professor. Only much later, from folks at work, did I realize how well regarded he is in this area. Highly recommend taking a class with him!

Excellent course. Professor Parthasarathy was an excellent instructor. He veryclearly conveyed the ideas presented in the couse and did a great job of explaining the more complex ideas of the course so that everyone could follow.
Enjoyed the class. Lot of work but learned a lot when the professor was lecturing. Second part of the class involved paper reading -- a little too advanced for me, but learned from the discussion.
Good prof, prepares u for grad school or industry. Very practical approach to teaching.

I have had Prof. Srini twice.  5243 was introductory but still challenging. Clear structure and I really enjoyed the lab assignments. Grading criteria &lectures clear. 5245 was enjoyable in a different way. It is definitely an advanced class and therefore challenging in a different aspect. Accessible and excellent prof.  Project was intense.

Excellent course structure. I took this class on a whim but ended up being inspired by it. For a course that was taught for the first time it had a few things that could be ironed out in future semesters (clear grading criteria would be nice) . Great professor -- with a droll sense of humor.  Pleasantly surprised by my final grade but made us work!
Excellent instructor -- really conveys the subject matter well. Title a misnomer -- this is definitely a advanced class.
Wonderful course structure and great teaching skills
Stresses foundations. Clear lectures. Provides Context. Challenging course but came out of it understanding material.
Just finished the final exam. It was brutal but honestly would not have it any other way. I want to go to grad school, and this course was good prep. Fantastic instructor.

Prof. Parthasarathy is one of the best teachers at OSU.  The projects are hard work and the exams are somewhat busy but the grading is fair. His lectures are incredibly clear and he never appears in a hurry to finish a lecture giving ample time for questions.

Extremely clear while expressing himself. Classes are fun with quite a bit of interaction. Very friendly outside class as well, and enthusiastic about his research. If you're interested in data mining, don't hesitate to talk to him about working with him and his group on their projects.
Extremely knowledgeable.  Easy access and very helpful. Love his style of teaching both in class and outside. Plan to take his advanced seminar if possible.

This is not an easy class but the instructor is very knowledgeable. Personally, what I learned in this class directly helped me a top internship in the bay area. As one of the earlier raters noted getting an A in this class is not easy -- the prof is upfront about this-mentioned in the first class. That said if you do the work you get a good grade.

Really wanted to take this class. Hated it. The lectures are boring. The exams are not testing the knowledge of the material, nor the understanding of it, but small issues that were mentioned for two minutes  in class...  even if you really like the material, the chances of getting an A is small.

The homework are interesting... but of it the class is a disaster.. the exam is on how fast can you operate a calculator, and the TA just ruined the fun of this class (he can't help cause he don't understand either the material nor English..). In addition the classes themselves are boring, and I practically didn't learn anything new...

Did a good job at teaching software 1. Lectures were a bit hard to get during the actual lecture, but the slides contain all the info you'll ever need. He's super passionate when it comes to getting help outside of class too.

I found Weide to be a very solid professor for Software I. From talking to some friends who had other professors, it seemed Weide did more specific examples and would go over past lab/homework questions more. Very reachable outside of class in my experience, sent me a SUPER long email responding to my question, really going out of his way to help.
Extremely harsh grader for no reason
Great at explaining java.

Alan explains the materials well and ensures that most of the students understand them. He is also reachable outside the classroom. Go to his office hours with questions, and he is always willing to help. His tests were not too difficult, but requires solid understanding of the concepts.

He talks way too fast during lectures, and the material is so dense and challenging. Enough code examples are not given, and the code on exams are way tougher than anything you do in class. The course itself is ridiculously challenging, and I think that OSU should offer more CSE resources. Hes not that helpful during office hours either

Alan is really good at giving feedback and explaining concepts He is super accessible and very friendly and always ready to go out of his way to help students, and will work out things with you. He's one of the best CSE instructors I've had. I do have some problems with this class, but they are departmental and not his fault.

Really enjoyed his class, he has a very good grasp of the class material, and knows how to explain it. I would recommend going to office hours as he is very accessible, as well as attending lectures and labs as he answers all questions.

Alan is alright. He cares about his students, pretty good at explaining concepts. His only problem is that he can't help you beyond the class material and if you don't have the same thought pattern as him then you're probably not going to understand because he only has one way to teach. I don't think he's qualified to teach but he's not the worst.

Alan was a fantastic professor. He always planned class very well, never holding us over and allotting time to explain concepts in depth. He has thorough knowledge of what he teaches, and was very available outside of class.

Alan is a bit of a tough grader but you can always find him after class and he will work with you to understand problems that you may have missed. He may read off the slides a good amount but he definitely knows what he is teaching and cares about the subject and his students.

Alan is a graduate student and taught his first class well enough, but room for improvement.  To his credit, he was able to go through a lot of material quickly as the class covers a lot.  If you don't understand, go to office hours, and he'll gladly help you.  Wants his students to succeed and cares about the computing.  Nice guy.

In lectures, pretty much just reads off the slides but knows his stuff if you have questions. Really does try to get you to know the material and cares if you do or not. Tough grader, recommend going to office hours and asking him about projects if aren't completely sure what there asking for.

Alan only reads off of the slides. He has an inconsistent grading method and is very strict. There were multiple questions that he would give no points on. I even went to the course coordinator and on some of the questions he agreed that I should've received partial credit. The coordinator emailed him, and Alan wouldn't budge.

Pretty standard software 1 professor. I had him all online and he was available for office hours and made the content easy to understand. He was a great professor but you know, it's software 1. He is a chill professor who understands, would reccomend.

This can be a tough class at times but Mirkamil teaches it in pretty much the best way possible, giving clear lectures and offering advice on weekly projects. Very willing to help or even just chat with students.
Clear lectures with helpful examples. Doesn't answer questions day before projects, but otherwise very accessible outside of class via Discord/email. Otherwise pretty standard Software 1 section.

Good lectures and overall nice class. 

HWs are rough, labs are rough (write down any hints he gave in class helps a lot)

Exams are open book

Amazing Lectures. Very accessible to meet outside of class, but emphasizes figuring things out on your own, which to some can be very frustrating when he provides vague pointers. You will definitely need to open the textbook every once in a while. He's a very nice guy who really tries to make sure his students stress less and learn a lot.

System II is notoriously more difficult with other professors at OSU. Dr. Shafer does his absolute best to minimize your stress and help improve your learning. His exams were open book and fair. He is retired so can meet with you at almost any time and you can tell he truly cares about your success. Take him if you can!

Easy going overall

The average for the lab is high, usually 9/10

M1 was decent average is 40/50, M2 was overly easy average is 49/50, Final was rough average is 72/100

I honestly don't know how this guy is a professor. Always not organized and no one in the class knows why and what we are doing. Doesn't know his way around Carmen, and he will respond to your email a week after you've sent it and he will make you suffer with the most vague paper project that you've seen in your college career. Avoid at all cost.

Stay away from her classes. Her class is very lecture heavy but she is not a great lecturer, does a really explaining things. She went over a stats refresher in class and it left me more confused then before the class started. Very hard to understand when she is trying to get across so you will have to learn it yourself outside of class. Beware!

Professor Mcdowell was not helpful in lecture, and exams were extremely difficult with no curves. For some reason, his lectures were so boring, I think if lecture was better I would rate higher Homework made it difficult to prepare for exams in his course due to this. I would avoid him if possible, there are better options for this course.
The class is hard: expect lots of time-consuming homework and difficult exams.  McDowell is helpful, though, and makes a point of quickly responding to all questions on Piazza.
Good teacher, his slides aren't descriptive so you're going to want to attend class to take good notes to help with homework. The course itself wasn't very easy but still not the most demanding.
He is very confusing, with no curve and very difficult homework and midterms.

Second time through having RC as a professor, and just like last time, he's a good guy who gives hard exams and no curve.  Assignments are due almost every day.  The subject matter is very abstract and sometimes difficult to understand.

He teaches using PowerPoint slides with no notes on them. Even if you have printouts, they are not helpful as sometimes slides are just a random picture with no explanation/illustration of what the point is. If you don't take very good notes, you can't go back and check things. Also has yawned a few times during his own lectures.

Very good professor. Quizzes and tests were fair. Understands what its like to struggle with material and wants to help you succeed. I took this as an accelerated course during the summer. I think everyone was exhausted by the end of the course, but generally the energy of the classroom was good, he's very intelligent and can answer all questions.
Really liked RC. Nice guy, explained well, just a confusing class to grasp sometimes.  Always helpful in office hours, homeworks were harder than the tests

This was one of the more practical classes and is based around a single project that you build up throughout the whole semester. The professor is easy going and cares more about you getting the project done and learning stuff. You choose your own tech stack and at the end you learn about some cloud infrastructure which was cool.

Praveen was a very nice professor. In the section I took, lectures went for 2 hours and Praveen likes to go on tangents, which can be hard to follow at times. The main project for this course was fair for the most part, aside from a few diagrams and topics that were not well taught. Exams were sort of tricky in my opinion.

Great guy, even better class. Learned a bit, but its easy. A lot of stuff that can be used in the real world. Movable deadlines and clear criteria helped tremendously. Lax guy with a clear passion for what he does.
Super easy class, but I learned a lot. He's very lenient with deadlines and cancelled class like 6 times throughout our semester. Good professor and nice guy.
Nice and friendly prof. Just one presentation and one final exam with cheat sheet. Labs are a bit hard but he is an easy grader

Praveen is adorable. He seems to really care about you and provides good feedback on your project. He works in the industry, so we learned lots of real world things. The course is well structured, but he is lenient with deadlines. Exams are a bit hard but fair. You can end up with bad grade if your project group is not working well together.

Praveen is really nice and adorable but the class was pretty unstructured. He was fairly lenient with deadlines and regrades. The project requirements and grading scale were pretty unstructured as well - he told us we had nothing to improve, gave us a C, and then regraded to a B+ on semester project. Exams had a lot of memorizing trivial things.

Praveen is a good teacher that is easy to listen to during lectures. He understands that we are very busy students, so he does not make the class too overbearing. The class itself is pretty easy. Homework is easy, and exams can be a bit challenging but not too bad. The group project does not take too much work as long as you have a good group.

Although he is a really nice guy, his lectures are insanely slow and he often tends to deviate from the slides to answer questions, which can be good, but then he tends to go down these rabbit holes with each question for 10-15 minutes at a time and we barely get through half of the slides. Also not very helpful for projects or homework questions.

You can't enroll in 2221 expecting it to be easy. The class is based on how much work you put in outside of school. With that being said Romero is a fantastic Professor! He gives great feedback and really cares about his students understanding content and learning.

He doesn't know the systems material and when you try to explain to him he becomes defensive and disregards any statement (even if it's from textbook). He grades only by his narrow view on the subject. He also grades by "I feel this is wrong" instead of this is correct/wrong answer. Very strange professor.

Great class. Still currently taking but his lessons are very in depth and the labs are very helpful with the class. You need to show up and participate to receive a good grade, and this is one of my classes I have never missed and I enjoy going to.

He is extremely knowledgeable about the topics in CSE and does everything he can to help his students learn the material. He also answers questions very well and will make sure the person asking understands the answer.

Almost always late to class, once got stuck in traffic and emailed us that class is cancelled 40 minutes in. The lecture slides (which suck) are made by the department and lecturers are not allowed to stray from those slides, so you may as well not go and just read the slides at home. Except attendance is extra credit and boy will you need that 2%
Explain things crystal clear and use great analogies to convey the concepts. A knowledge and respected professor who can inspire students to learn the subject.

I didnt have any ML background whatsoever before flipping to AI and enrolling in 5526. Dr. Wang is truly phenomenal. I genuinely look forward to his lectures and he takes great care in the success of his students. Very intelligent man who is capable of conveying complex topics in ways new students can understand. 10/10

The name of the class(neural networks) is a joke. It covers early day stuff.(Yes. They are important but please teach us something new). The exam is just some random questions that is not related to what he taught. You can learn much more from Andrew Ng's course.

He did very tough for grading exams and without any curving. Also, his topic is out of data (did not introducing any advance network structure like RNN/CNN). Huge gap between the homework and the lecture he taught, which means they are useless to help you understanding the materials Only advice is not take his course at all.

Good lecturer. Great at helping break down tough topics. Exams were fair, and a little on the easy side, but the material itself was pretty complicated. The lectures lacked a lot of concrete examples, but otherwise he taught the class well. There is no way anyone would understand the material unless you went to lecture, so don't skip anything.
He is a very good teacher
The professor wrote the entire notes on the board. The lectures turned out to be very boring. The exams were ridiculous.

Good teacher and I really enjoyed the class. Wrote out complete lecture notes on board, for you to copy. Never used book. Homework not too bad - programmnig projects took some time but doable. Tests weren't bad, but contained a few random problems that strayed from the course concepts.

Throws random questions on the exams that have never even been discussed in class. Concentrates more on two topics, then in the last 3 weeks glosses over the rest of the material. The last few lectures are pointless, weren't even tested on them.
No Comments

Very cocky, & uses lengthy, unconstructive feedback as a poor attempt at a comedy act. Tears down students. My group wasn't perfect, but we were genuinely trying & made to feel like we weren't. He told us what was bad, but offered no help in fixing it, so we felt like we were drowning the whole sem. A very skewed grading scale was the only upside.
Professor Mills goes very fast during lectures but he is very resourceful outside of class. Grades all the projects very fairly and gives awesome feedback. Overall this professor rocks!

During class, professor Mills goes very fast, but will answer any questions as they arise. There are 4 quizzes that are fairly easy. The rest of the class is group-based, so your experience is dependent on that. I wish Mills would enforce that the team is following Agile and getting stuff done. He does provide good feedback in his grading.

Class could use some restructuring. No reason a prof should run out of material to lecture on before spring break. Scott Mills is fairly arrogant, most of what he does comes off as bragging. Claims to foster open discussion but not entirely true. Does give a lot of feedback but it can be vague and he wont really answer questions about it. not a fan

The first few weeks of this class are rough, because you have to try to learn version control and XNA basically on your own. Once you get past that, the work actually becomes really fun! He gives really good (and sometimes funny) sprint feedback quickly every two weeks so that you can incorporate it into your next sprint. One of my favorite classes

If you put in the effort and are willing to learn the material covered in this course, then Scott will reflect that in the way he interacts with you. His grading is straight forward so long as you fulfill the requirements of the project, which are very clearly laid out. If you ask for help, he will always set aside the time to give it to you.

Most of the grade is for the project itself, which requires a ton of time and builds on itself over the whole semester. Hardest part is the first few weeks when he expects to learn the game tools and version control basically from a few links on the class site. Quizzes are straightforward, some project points are vague but you can ask about them.

Extremely arrogant and refuses to admit when he's wrong. I don't think he understands the material well enough to answer questions, he just kind of reads off the slides he's given by the course coordinator. Extremely unclear on grading criteria.   Avoid him if you can, he's not good. The other CSE3902 teacher is much better from what I hear.

Extremely easy class. Exams are all take-home/online and he gives half the exam away in class so make sure you attend. The labs are a little hard but he helps a lot with them and are mostly straightforward. The group project takes some time, so definitely start early on it. Overall a super relaxed class

Course was graded based off of 5 assignments: a lab, a midterm, a group project, a final exam, and attendance (which I believe was only taken first day). Relatively easy grader as long as you show what you know, lowest grade given was an 83%. Average was almost always an A or A-. Had several guest speakers that were very distinguished people.

Worst professor in CSE. I thought I took an essay writing course. The lab is an essay. The group project is an essay. The midterm had 12 essay questions. The final had 5 essay questions. A tough grader and he never gives feedback on assignments. His lecture is also terrible; he speaks fast and did not like posting slides on Carmen.

very easy to get an A if you do the bonus homework (literally 10% bonus) she doesn't do examples and throws a bunch of equations around (doesn't really explain them) so you flounder around to do the homework (sometimes she basically ends up doing the hw in class) can't say I learned much

She seems like a nice person, but I 100% wouldn't take her class again. Her lectures are very very math/theory-heavy instead of explaining concepts using simple examples. If you can stare at a bunch of formulas and get it, you'll probably be fine. I ended up doing most of my learning from YouTube videos and learned more than I did in class.
Dr. Tabassum is a really helpul Prof. She was always available to email for extra aid. I think she really wanted to help the students and was definitely a good at explaining problem we have.

Avoid her for AI! I've never struggled this much in my life. Her answer to every question is to google it. Her lectures are disorganized, confusing, and impossible to follow. Everyone in my class was lost the entire time. Take AI with a different professor!
Sometimes she goes too fast in the class. Lots of coding in HWs

Professor Tabassum is the one of the best professor that I met in OSU. I almost went to every of her office hour, which is very helpful. She'd like to help students and she's friendly to all the students. Definitely recommend taking his AI courses!

Jeniya is the greatest professor for AI. I don't say that a lot, but she really made the class fun. She gave extra credit opportunities and you are allowed to use books and slides. She is also a nice person. AI is a hard class with tough professors, but Jeniya made it fun.

I can tell she really cares and tries hard to explain, but the lectures are just not very helpful and pretty dry. There were a lot of typos in the midterm (as well as the homework instructions), which negatively affected a lot of people's grades. There were only 3 homeworks. The lack of practice problems for the midterm was unfortunate.
Because one typo she made, our students who answer these question correctly get lower grade. If you take this class, be prepared to get crazy.
Avoid her if you can, the worst professor for AI.
Basically learning everything on my own. AI is not an easy class and she made it harder.
The worst lecturer I ever had. Stay away.
She is really helpful and knowledgable. She helps a lot to resolve my homework problems. The lecture contents are hard. Be prepared to study a lot.
The worst instructor for AI. She seems to be a nice person, but the lecture is horrible.
I can tell she is trying to explain the concept, but it is very hard to understand her lecture.
Save yourself a headache and take another instructor for AI
She is really good at explaining the AI thing with theory
the goat
Subhash is a G, best TA I've had.
Helps out with assignments and any questions that you have.

Subhash is a great help. He joined later in the semester but still was consistently helpful and always available to email for extra aid. He wants to help us as students and is definitely a good at explaining problem we have.

Subhash joined us as a TA halfway through the semester, and for jumping in on such a short notice, he's done remarkably well. He teaches difficult subjects very well, but won't outright GIVE you any answers; you'll have to think your way to a solution, but his guidance ensures that you're staying on the right track. Overall, a very good TA.

Sharkey was never available to answer questions outside of class, waited till the last 2 weeks of class to grade everything, and was rude and seemed to not care about helping his students. I would not recommend this professor, he made this class very stressful and his grading waa inconsistent and he got mad if you questioned anything he said.

Lectures were good and he loved answering questions. I definitely sent a lot of emails and learned a lot both during office hours and through email. This course was revamped this semester and the course coordinator (not David) did make the course more difficult. David handled these issues well. Tests were tough, but fair.

He's very understanding of students because he was a GTA, so he tries to make things fair and easy. HWs are a bit hard and time consuming, but there's only 10 of them. 2 exams: open note, no proctorio, limited timed window, fairly easy. Lectures are a bit boring but that's just the material. Shows neat videos to inspire students beginning of class

David is the best TA I've ever had. He's better than every lecturer I've had at OSU too. He is great at explaining things in a way that's easy for beginners to understand. He is available to help and is always honest about grades, assignments, etc. The class overall is annoying with a lot of work, but I wouldn't have done as well with another TA.

He's a really nice person. His guest speakers are amazing. It's likely because of his first time teaching this course the structure of the course is messy. But he'll improve as he is a reachable and sensible prof. And I hope he can improve on group projects to reduce the frustration caused by slacking teammates.

Good professor overall. I think I had him during his first semester teaching the course; the course structure was a bit hectic and some assignments required a lot of elaboration on his part. He had guest speakers come in from industry which I really enjoyed. Learned more from his personal experience than I did lecture material. Group project heavy.

Phenomenal professor. Lecture material was dry but he had a lot to offer in terms of relating it to the real world and how it can be applied. Fantastic feedback, he recorded videos of himself going over our project drafts. I think its just 4 HWs, 1 project & presentation, midterm, and final. Straightforward A if you follow feedback and rubrics.

Albeit he wasn't my favorite instructor, this class was very fun and easy. Only 4 group projects with a paper and presentation for each, no exams/quizzes/hw. Projects can be difficult without security experience but he kinda goes over the tools in class. Lectures can be boring but he tells cool stories about his job.

Steve is a fantastic professor. He has been doing security for decades and is incredibly knowledgeable in the field. If you simply do the work, learn from it, and present what you did and what you learned you will get an A. I'm not pursuing a career in security, but if you are you should definitely take Steve's class.

My only complaint is that I wish my other classes weren't so busy so I could spend more time on the material in this class. 4 projects consist of the entire grade and the focus of this class is to learn, not to test you and see what you know/don't know. Amazing
Great professor and interesting material.
One of the best professors at OSU by far! :)

This was the most intresting class I have at ohio-state. Learning how to compromise networks and machines on a network was really awesome,practical and fun. Steve did an excellent job at explaining our end-goal during the project as well as giving pointers on how to complete it.

This was an experimental class.  Steve did a super job constructing and teaching this course.  His knowledge is deep, and his patience long.  It was a project-based course, no exams, but the projects were lots of work, but extremely interesting and refreshingly practical.  Highly recommended instructor.

Horrible, terrible, mean, and does not care about you as a student or person. Will never recommend this professor to anyone. If you have her, DROP IMMEDIATELY. If I could give this professor a 0, I would.

Disrespectful, unhelpful, and condescending. I had asked for studying and test taking advice after doing poorly on a midterm. I also asked if there was going to be any extra credit or curve at the end of the semester. She replied with directing me to SLDS if I think I have a disability for extended time on future tests. No other advice or help.

Switched over to her section in the middle of the semester because my old professor had to leave. She did not explain anything to the students transferring and had a different method of grading. Terrible overall and I would avoid her.
Not the best professor to take software I with as there are better ones that will make your life easier, but I'd say she's quite average.

Software is a hard class. No matter who teaches it, you're gonna have to work hard for it. Dr. Bair gave great lectures and seemed to genuinely care about her students. She's crazy experienced and kept things lighthearted. But this is not a class you can slack off in. Work hard and you'll get a lot out of it.

The class is fairly standardized but she does midterms and finals instead of quizzes which honestly is better. She also offers extra credit on the final which is amazing. Otherwise she is very accessible outside of class and responds to all emails. Lectures can be boring since she moves fairly slowly but otherwise she is great.

Professor Bair gives amazing lectures and is willing to help out each one of her students. If there's something wrong with your code, either her or her graders are very good at giving suggestions to your code. Make sure you pay close attention to all of the project criteria otherwise you will be marked down. Overall a great professor.

If you get Bettina, you've won the CSE lottery. She really cares about her students and wants you to succeed. She gave us opportunities for extra credit, which she wasn't even scheduled to do. No reading required. Super knowledgeable, and really funny. Exams were fair and easy. If you pay attention in class and do the work, you should be fine.
Her lectures are quite dry, and her exams are unnecessarily hard. She can get a little annoying when you talk to her.

Bettina could be a bit snarky and sarcastic/blunt, but she did a great job of teaching and keeping students engaged. The labs are a MUST DO, even though they weren't mandatory they helped a ton with homework, exams, projects. On the projects, make sure you follow ALL of the guidelines and when in doubt, ask the teachers on Piazza for help.

I really enjoyed having her in class, she is quite sarcastic which i thought was funny and really knows her stuff. She will respond very well to you if you put in the work to do well, but she will be tough on you if you're slacking. Overall she really cares about her students and wants to see you all do well.
Not the worst tbh. Lectures were tough and homework were ambiguous in my opinion. She tries to be helpful. She's also super feminist lol be cautious.

Read the book and do the in-class assignments. Don't try to skimp out on anything and you won't even need to go to office hours to understand the material since the feedback on the in-class assignments are so thorough. The material was extremely boring to me but that is up to personal taste mainly.

One of the best software instructor available at OSU. Her lectures are best quality among other instructors. Her slides cover the material very well and gives lots of hints for homework and projects. Study over slides, do not skip classes, and you will do fine.
Exams were (much) tougher compared to other software 1 professor exams.

Bettina is a seemingly nice person, but don't be fooled. I went to office hours asking for help cuz I was struggling on projects, she looked at my grade said "yeah you're not doing too well" and left it at that. Her ta's grade harder than most other ta's on projects so expect worse grades than other classes. She is NOT a forgiving person.

One of the worst professors I have ever had at OSU. Her sarcasm and her "funny jokes" would prevent students from asking questions. She never really "taught" the class because all she did was read directly from slides the CSE department had. She never had a grading rubric for our programs and her reasoning for lost points were vague. Avoid her.

She is, without a doubt, extremely smart. But she cannot teach at all. All she did was read word for word on the slides that was given to her. Every now and then she would use her pointer to emphasize something she just read.

The best prof I've had. Has a lot of real world experience and actually cares. She does not do research, her priority is teaching you. Her jokes are hilarious and never offensive as some had said, very friendly. The class is hard but she is probably one of the easiest profs for it. If she is selected for your section congrats, you won the lottery.
She is very careless. She just talks about the slides and doesn't want to answer the questions. She doesn't know how to grade projects. She doesn't have clear grading criteria
She's lazy, doesn't care if you do well or not. Will give 70-80% multiple choice just so it is easier for her to grade. In class activity and group projects can be a pain as well.
She never gives a rubric, and doesn't answer questions nicely. She is basically very rude. I was only able to pass this course by using google sources.
She doesn't give a grading rubric, so be aware! She just takes off point from tiny thing. She is pretty sarcastic, but not funny at all, sometimes even offensive. Think twice before choosing her.
She doesn't care about anything and just makes the class harder than it is. The worst professor I've had in OSU

Terrible teacher. This is supposed to be a class for beginning coders, but she "teaches" like we should already know the material. Homeworks are due before you learn the content, and the book is nearly impossible to understand. If you have zero coding experience, I would not recommend Bettina Bair. She does provide the link to the textbook, though.

She is a really nice person and an experienced person in the CS business. However, I do not think that she is fit to be a college professor.  She just makes the lecture more complicated and grade tough just to make the class harder. But I like her personality. She is so funny.

Her grading system is ridiculous. The course itself is easy, but she just makes it harder. Also, she doesn't really answer questions properly. Her sarcasm can get offensive sometimes. Avoid if possible.

Professor Bair was great for databases!  Her humor may be described as sarcastic like other reviewers have mentioned, but if this bothers you, you need to remind yourself people joke in different ways. I thought she was very funny.  She was always eager, yet fair, to help any student with a question and very knowledgeable about databases.

Must go to class because worksheets are graded (and graded fairly harshly too). Her slides are kind of unorganized and the semester-long group project is kind of vague in its requirements but all that aside Bettina really knows her stuff and teaches it well. She's also pretty funny. Her exams are very fair. Would recommend.

Bettina Bair is a wonderful person and teacher. Her lectures are very easy to understand because she conveys the material so well. She is very down to earth and easy to talk to. The class itself is not very difficult, though it can be frustrating at times due to the structure of the course. You slowly work on a group project the whole semester.

In class, I would not recommend you to ask questions, because she may answer it while she embarrass you with her sarcasm. Also, criticizing her would get her angry, and you will be the one to apologize. Other than that, I think she is straightforward and clear, but tough on grading. Make sure you spend an extra effort on projects.

One of the better CSE professors, but everything is relative.  She has a dry sense of humor and is sarcastic, so that may rub you the wrong way.  Additionally, this class focuses basically on straight memorization, and the class requires a huge group project that takes up a ton of time.  Be ready.
She can be a little sarcastic but besides that she is helpful. There is nothing too challenging in this class if you do the work.

Can be a bit condescending at times but is overall a very clear lecturer. You can tell that she's been teaching this course for a long time (and early on she was probably very enthusiastic about it but now just seems tired). The difficulty of grading depends entirely on your graders; mine were super nitpicky about everything. Overall, good class.

Fairly straightforward class. Group project is worth a ton of points so keep up on it. Tests are more difficult if you don't study the terms but they are only worth a small percentage of your overall grade.

Don't be mislead - this isn't really a CSE class, it should be MIS. She gave conflicting info on expectations for docs and presentations, graded based on arbitrary decisions,  punishes a whole team for one member's failures while refusing to step in and deal with the problem members, and so on. Says one thing, grades you based on another. Avoid.

Bettina can be condescending and have a very dry, sarcastic type of humor -- which can be intimidating. However, I think she does want to help students and if you are willing to come to her. I never really did though, I just sought help from the TAs as well as Piazza. Do your homework assignments. Make it to class.
Good professor. Made a dry subject somewhat entertaining.
Attendance is optional, but as long as you show up you will be fine. One of the good CSE profs.
she doesn't care

Class average is probably a C+ or a B-. I picked her because she doesn't care about attendance. All the notes and slides are online, and with her, attendance is optional.   Her lectures are pretty average, and but she does explain stuff pretty well and stays after class a lot.

Bettina is a teacher with much passion in teaching. CSE 2221 is a fundamental course for CSE students and she can make you love your major at the beginning. The course is a little hard for me but very enjoyable with Bettina. By average 2 homework and 1 projects a week. 2 midterms and one final. Not a easy class but put your heart and you will enjoy

I enjoyed her class. The material, being a lower level course, wasn't difficult and attendance wasn't mandatory so I ended up not going often, but she was very helpful when I did go. Character-wise, Bettina seems to be the motherly type, but is surprising impersonal. Still very helpful though.

I have never had a professor care so little about their own presentation of the class material that cares so much about your presentation of what you have learned. There is almost nothing to gain from taking this class except basic knowledge of deprecated software design patterns.

It was an easy class, she explains the material clearly. There is mandatory attendance because of the worksheets in each class but those help you to learn the material, and you only need half of them. I would recommend her for this class

Terrible class to take w/ Bair. You read a lot and she doesn't actually teach anything at all. Class days are wasted. Learn to write small for the cheat sheets and hope you get lucky writing exactly what she looks for. The exams are terribly worded and she will not admit it. Class is structured horribly. Material easily learned w/ an internship.

Material was difficult and challenging. Homework was lengthy and challenging. Bettina explained most things pretty clearly but a few topics she hardly discussed at all - especially with the calculator project and html projects. Doesn't go over exams or homework at all - expects you to figure out your mistakes.

She is one of the most worthless prof I have even seen she knows what she is talking about but she basically refuses to answer any question or she just tells you that you have to figure out for yourself do not take her at all.........
Bettina is a good teacher who explains things well and has a good sense of humor. Take Bettina if you're going to take CSE 221.
Better than pretty much any other CSE instructor you could get.
I just don't understand assembly code at all, but Bettina's enthusiasm really helped.  Although I'm still bad with assembly code, taking 360 with Bettina is probably the best option.

Pretty easy for a CSE class, more like a business class. You have to put in a decent amount of time working on the project but the tests and the homeworks are pretty straight-forward. Much easier then her 360 class.
Worthless!!! She had no concept of what was going on with this court.  She rambled about buzz words and tried to link topics that had absolutely no relation to one another.
generally meh...lots of focus on specific languages
A very challenging class, but Bettina did a great job of keeping it interesting, well organized, and she was always quick to help/respond to questions.
Loved the class although time consuming.  She warns everybody of that on day one.  However, topics are very applicable to real world

Easily among the best professors in the CSE department. The lectures were entertaining and well planned out. She is incredibly helpful in her office hours and willing to help the students as much as possible. If you are taking 360, take it with Bettina.
she is very nice instructor and helpful big time in her office hour , i wish if she teach all cse courses.

Bettina is nice and very personal. She's helpful, will answer all your questions, and is an excellent orator. The class material is pretty simple, unless you absolutely refuse to pay attention in class, or suffer moderate brain damage.

Bettina was a fair teacher.  The course itself was very challenging and she did a good job of explaining things.  Attendance was not mandatory for this class, but it is highly recommended as you miss a lot of information if you miss.
Hard material to grasp in a short time, but she has fun activities and stories and warns/reminds you up front about tough topics. Hope she teaches 560
Very cool instructor.  Helpful too.

Not an easy class, must make time for it to learn the new concepts. As far as Bettina is concerned, excellent teacher with a good heart, I admire her work, wish I ran into her for earlier classes, could have made my experience better. Anyway fair minded and then some,the university needs more people like her,and if I may, she is a beautiful woman.

Very charming, down to earth instructor. Very cool. Will answer e-mail day and night. Good instructor who keeps the class entertained. Very willing to help students in office hours and in class. Very straight forward exams. Will not answer homework questions directly, but will give similar examples to the homework. Thanks Bettina.

Simple class if you follow instructions and do all the pre-labs. The tests can be hard because using a program and showing your ability to use them on paper is different. Just do all the practice tests and you'll ace this class.
Very helpful both in and outside of class.  She also seems to strive to make the class interesting.

Assembly language classes are not supposed to be interesting, yet this class was one of the few I consistently enjoyed.  I got an A- due to low exam grades, but that could have been improved upon if my attendance had been a little better.  Her anecdotal references to past programming experiences always kept class fun, and I felt her pace was good.
Very helpful and interesting.  She really tries hard to communicate the material in a helpful way.

Class had too much structure. Treated everyone like they had never seen a computer before or were an expert. No middle ground so you were constantly bored or stressed. I could not work at my own speed.
She is really cool! The course is interesting.  I recommend taking her for 616. There is a quarter long project, so take the class with friends, she lets you pick people who you want in your group.
Awesome teacher and class!  I learned so much in this class.  Bettina is awesome, and really cares that you understand the material.
No Comments
Very good teacher

class material was easy - tried to make class challenging with the quizzes and tests requireing specific answers - annoying.  conditions during midterm not consistent with other professors of the same subject.
The most annoying teacher!... Do not have her as your professor!
The class just flat out sucked, not easy, hard quiz which half the stuff she never went over. **** it was the easist class ever. THE CLASS IS A WEEDOUT CLASS! Seriously take mallon

Just average...the material is easy but she makes it very boring somedays. The TA's are the worst I have ever seen because they do not speak english and make you feel like a dumb ass for asking questions.  Although the computer room is always open to help and they do a great job.

Don't have to attend class, you can just read through the cop-ez packet because it contains all of the slides.  Tests were semi-hard, but if they didn't try to make them difficult everyone would ace the class.  Take this teacher instead of Debby Gross! (Debby Gross is hard)
ok

This has got to be the easiest class on the planet.  Hello?  Excel is not rocket science.  If you have trouble walking and chewing gum at the same time, maybe you should try CSE 101.  Bair shows a lot of patience with stupid and repetitive questions from students and she answers email day and night.
Unpleasant woman.  Grumpy and hateful, asked a question about a quiz and she ripped me.  Dont take this class if its not required.
Not a bad prof, class is lotta work
a very boring class. she did not seem to know much about what she was teaching outside of what was on the slides, and was not helpful at all when looking for advice on the actual project.

Bettina is an interesting professor that will keep you awake.  I agree with others that there is an issue between what the grader wants and what she expects on the final draft.  Exams were fair and came strait from the books and notes.
Cis 200 is the most boring class I have ever taken in my life. I fell asleep in lecture every day and i was still able pull of a b+. As long as you stay awake in class you should be fine
She's a great teacher who knows what she's talking about.  She's very good at explaining the material, and I would recomment her over any other CIS instructor.
She taught the class well and made it easy to understand, although her quizzes seemed to be a week to early for me everytime. She had a pretty nice bod for being well into her forties.

Easiest class I have taken so far was her CIS 200 class. I agree with the person who said cute smile, and beyond that she teaches the subject matter very clearly and seems to just wrap you into what CIS is all about. I highly recommend!!
Very thorough in her lecture discussions and very helpful & available when it comes to providing help outside of lecture.  She also has a very cute smile.
She was a very good teacher.  Probably the best in CIS 200 level.  Reccomend getting her over any others.

Nice pacing of class. Work is incremented each week, not dumped on you all at once. Grades only 2nd drafts, so comments made by grader on 1st drafts may not fit with what she wants. Personable. Interesting class.
She was a bit clueless at times esp. with her grading of project assignments. Good attitude though and I did enjoy the class more than most that I have taken here at OSU.
No slack in grading. Prelabs are forever long. If you can transfer the points from somewhere else, do it.
CIS 200 is very time consuming, especially the labs. However, if you go to class, you don't have to study much outside of class. The midterm and final were a bit hard, but overall the class was easy.
extra credit?  this is college.  I appreciate when I don't have to compete with whiners who think grading is a negotiation.  good teacher, no surprises, do the work and get through. cripes.
This course is hard if you miss a lecture but the in-class practice and prof bair's explanations really helps a lot.  Sit up front, too. The room is huge and you get very sleepy in the back.

Gives out more As and Bs than any other CIS200 instructor.  Twenty years in industry and really knows applications.  Still excited about computing, too.  Available for student appointments outside of office hours.
No Comments

Horrible teacher.  You think you understand it and can do homework problems, but then you take the quizes and you get so much points taken off for such stupid reasons. No opportunity for extra credit at all.  Makes students feel so stupid when asking ques
Boring lectures. Unapproachable and unwilling to cut students muchslack. No curve at all, no extra credit, and huge amounts of points deducted for simple mistakes.
very very strict grader, very little partial credit given, no curve or extra credit given
Great teacher, explained everything thouroughly - which helped a lot with assembly language and such.  And she's VERY willing to help students
I thought she was tough, but a good teacher. Willing to help and move at a pace that is comfortable for her students.
not bad, not great.  nice woman -  pretty tough subject matter to make interesting, though
DONT TAKE HER...STUDENTS KNOW MORE THEN SHE DOES
No Comments
Doesnt know her stuff.  Makes a lot of instructional mistakes, which the students then have to correct.
She did a good job, and it was very nice to have a female CIS prof.
No Comments
Tests were harder than the lecture would suggest
No Comments
Lectures are actually interesting
This instructor actually seems to care whether her students are learning.
No Comments
cares whether you get it or not, but tests are hard
Says she has 17 years exp, often seems clueless, gives wrong information
If you have to take CIS, take it from Bair

Great Professor! Easy to communicate with. His lectures are interesting and gave exam examples to help prepare for exams. Likes to make dad jokes. Just listen to his lecture, add some critical thinking, and you will get a good score.

Dr. Ramnath is an awesome professor, though if you've done an internship, his class feels kinda repetitive. He's funny and at least does try to make the (boring) content interesting. Pay more attention than I did in class and you'll be fine. There's a semester long project, a quiz every other week, and only 1 midterm.

Best. Professor. Ever. Taking Rajiv is the best decision you can ever take! Such a funny and approachable guy! Super knowledgeable and always has awesome advice. There are great professors, and then there is Rajiv. He is truly a man among men

RAJIV! I invented a new phrase cause of him! "Dude Professor!" He is such a helpful person and is always ready to listen to all of your concerns! ALWAYS! (Even if they are about your GF woes!) He is the most down to earth and the most knowledgeable person I know! Dr Rajiv, keep it up! It's unfortunate for OSU that you have now moved to the NSF!

Rajiv is the man! His Agile Development lecture was life-changing, quite literally. The lego demonstration changed the way I think about and work at my software engineering job, and was a key factor in my recent promotion. But the real treat is the man himself. Lectures are like free front row seats to a top standup comedy routine!

Raji is great. He really took the time to get to know me very well during his office hours. Ended up getting a good amount of extra credit for his class by staying after and visiting his office regularly to deal with really hard issues with my code. Just as well that he's really easy on the eyes, it made the whole process go down much smoother.

By far the most inspirational professor, and person, I have ever met. Ever. After taking his advanced computer science course I can finally say that I have a purpose in life. Amazing professor, even better role model.

Amazing and inspiring lecturer. It's impossible to quantify this man's brilliance and willingness to teach. The Lego agile demonstration not only reminded me of my oft forgotten youth and granted brief respite from the vacuous banality of adult life, it also taught me valuable lessons about consumer input and the evolution of species.

This man is amazing. Take all of his classes, absorb his knowledge, and worship at his feet. Absolutely brilliant lecture on Agile development, and the Legos made it even better! You haven't lived until you sit in a lecture by Professor Ramnath.
Inspirational lecturer. The hands-on Agile Development activity basically changed my life. You may not apreciate his humor (which I think is great, btw), but as he says, hey, the jokes are free.

Professor Ramnath's class on agile development was eye opening and life changing. He imparted such incredible wisdom upon me that I am in awe of the opportunities that were given to his son from such an early age. Truly a master in his field in all respects.
Best professor ever, Rajiv is my boy.
This class was frustratingly disorganized.  However, almost everyone got A's or B's, so that's a plus.
He overbooks his office hours.  Be prepared to wait in line with students from a different class or with one of his graduate students.
He did an awesome job teaching 560, made the class bearable. He is very helpful in office hours and calss.
This class is a lot of work no matter who your prof. is, but Ramnath taught this class very well and made jokes that are only funny at 8:30 in the morning.
Best 8:30AM professor ever.  always had a corny joke that was only funny when you were half a sleep to start the class.

While the class could be boring, Jenny is nice and always willing to help. Makes this class easy and understandable and tells you directly what you need to learn for the exam. This class is relevant and useful for every CSE major in my opinion. Jenny has plenty of experience in industry and her bringing those skills to the class made it engaging.

Chris is a great guy and will help you understand anything. He is lenient and really cares about his students so I never felt overwhelmed. Overall the content is hard but, exams and quizzes are open note. Go to class and ask questions you'll do well.

Professor Stewart usually does a good job of making complex topics approachable for students. Exams for this class are all open note but are still difficult because of questions that sometimes feel like they're trying to trick you. Overall, this class is very useful for anyone going into data science.

One of the most inspiring software classes I've ever taken. You can tell a lot of thought was put into the curriculum. Every class made me feel excited about the future of the field and encouraged me to learn and importantly learn from mistakes. Professor Stewart captures a broad scope of material in a practical and thought provoking way.
Chris is a fun professor. All of his quizzes and exams are open not with no time limit. He has them open for a week and you can go in and out without submitting.

Professor Stewart truly cares about his students and takes the time in class to help you understand concepts before moving on. However, this will only happen if you take the initiative to ask him questions in class, so your success in the class depends on your willingness to go to class and participate.
Intriguing course content. Patient teacher! Would take another course of him.
Really good professor. Interesting lecture, and assignments. Easily to get good grade if pay attention in lecture.

Chris is super patient on answering the questions, even exam problems. The material in this class has both great depth and breadth. Chris is always well prepared for the class. Office hours is super helpful as well. You can even play basketball with him: )
Great professor, difficult material

Great professor! I really enjoyed that all assignments in the class were take home and we were given lots of time to do them. This made the class a very low stress environment where I could focus on the material, and not worrying about a test.
Dr. Stewart is a great professor. Super kind and understanding with class assignments. Very knowledgeable about class content and industry.
He is very engaged in class and genuinely cares about how his students are learning and ensures that no one is left behind and everyone understands what is happening in class.

Professor Stewart is good teacher who is clearly passionate about what he does. It's clear he has relevant industry experience and he uses that to provide motivation for the topics in class. Exams/quizzes can be confusing and very specific, but there's enough of them to come back from a bad score.

Chris is really passionate about the subject matter and does a great job of explaining. It is easy to get lost if you haven't been exposed to courses like this, but you won't have a problem tracking him down and getting things explained.

Professor Stewart creates an atmosphere were you want to learn and can feel free to ask him questions or even converse with him. His class is structured well as topics are divided and there is a consistent amount of quizzes and homework across the class. You will definitely do well if you just show up to class!

Dr. Stewart is a great CSE professor with a lot of experience in data management, so he was able to clearly explain abstract concepts covered in this course. He was very accommodating to students when it came to lecture attendance and coursework, providing lots of opportunities to ask questions about material and assignments.

He really cares about his students. He taught difficult class materials in an easy way to understand. Quizzes and exams might be tough, but if you attend every lectures and take notes of examples done in class, you'll get good grades.

Chris is an extremely understanding and flexible professor who strives to grow as a professor. Assignments and exams are delivered online. Some questions are a bit vague at times. The later units did feel a bit unorganized and were sometimes hard to follow. Later slides are not really detailed so note-taking + attendance is sort of required.
Chris is one of the best professors the CS department has to offer. Homework, quizzes, and exams are all open note and easy to complete as long as you attend the lectures.

Chris is a good professor. Gives adequate time for assignments and plenty for exams (approx. a week and open notes). Grading is somewhat tough, some questions are weighed way more than others but gives partial credit back. Pay attention in class and you should do well.
Overall, a great professor. A fair amount of material on assignments and exams are covered only in class. Course was structured well into distinct modules.

Truly cares about students and gives many opportunities to do well and earn points. Lectures are very interesting, and helpful, but assignments can be difficult/tricky at times. There is ample time given to complete assignments but using the time is essential because they can feel difficult compared to lecture material.

Content could get confusing but Professor Stewart was willing to help students work through problems. Very much wanted students to think for themselves and think about Cloud Computing with a holistic mindset, focusing on more than just actual processes, but the ethics and other concerns data scientists must consider.
Chris was extremely knowledgeable about the course material, and always made an effort to relate each lecture to real-life professional applications.
Good professor with amazing lectures. Have many quizzes and homework but not hard if listen to lectures carefully

Chris is an overall decent professor. He cares about his students and tries to make the class as low stakes as possible. Exams and quizzes are online and you get a week or two to complete them. The class is also interesting and relevant to the real world.
The professor is really great. All quizzes, homework, and exams have no time limit. If you follow the professor in class carefully, you will get a good grade.

most questions are reused with little modifications. The slides have all of the answers IF you understand the lecture, they dont make sense on their own. All lectures are recorded and online plus some previous semesters. Answers to assignments given in class & office hours & explanations for partial credit available on midterms
Impressive course! The lecture files are very comprehensive and useful in all your assignments!

Would recommend taking a class with Professor Stewart. Material is organized well, easy to follow, and not too challenging. Exam questions can sometimes be a bit confusing but he offers a chance to explain your thought process to give partial credit.
