A good professor with amazing lectures. Many quizzes but not hard. Easily get good grades if you listen to lecture carefully.
Great professor and well organized course. The grading criteria is clear and quizzes, homework, and exams are online and can be completed with no time limit.

Chris cares a lot about his students. The course is designed to give a lot of flexibility for students as you can attend any class section, come on zoom, or watch a recording of the lectures. Every assignment and exam is an untimed Carmen quiz you can take on your own time. They can be hard, but the flexibility and unlimited time make up for it.

Made all assignments online

Recorded all lectures

he has a lot of homeworks but very clear on what is expected

midterms ger harder as you go and are worth more but have partial credit opportunities

Stewart made lectures feel very applicable to the workforce & the class as a whole felt like something that's genuinely useful to know. Some homeworks were given multiple attempts if students had troubles & you could always ask him questions if something was unclear

Take good notes in lecture, specifically the problems he does on the whiteboard. The test questions can be difficult but very influenced by those examples. Usually, just a few questions make up a large chunk of your score.
The lecture is clear and easy to understand and Prof.Chris cares about his students. He gave Extra Credit and always make sure you are getting good grade.

Professor Stewart is one of the most genuine professors I've had. His passion for the topics alongside the wellbeing and engagement of his students is clear. There's a lot of content, but the assignments are all not timed and open note, so the focus is more on the learning rather than grades. I would love to take another class with him.

Professor Stewart is extremely passionate, and he truly wants students to realize the importance of big data management and analysis. The course is probably a love or hate, depending on how much you care about this (somewhat niche?) portion of CS. If you're interested in Data Science, Data Analytics, Data Engineering, I definitely recommend!
Great professor, very understanding and accommodating of students' needs. Some homework/exam questions could be written better.

Prof Stewart is a great professor and you will get a good grade if you go to lectures + start assignments early.  Exams, HWs, Quizzes & Labs are opened days in advance, no time limit once you start. He's available and reached out to me after a bad quiz. I'd recommend attending class in person because he gives hints for assignments. Would recommend.

The course is very well laid out and structured. I enjoyed that the course is predominantly carmen quizzes that have clear grading criteria. Sometimes professors overdue it with the level of work for a class, but this was the right amount of work and incredibly manageable.
Overall fair and easy class - all quizes / homework were online
Great course

Professor Stewart is tough but fair.  The course covers a lot of material from Hadoop to database optimizes to Tensor Flow. I find all of it relevant to my career goals as a data scientist.  The exams are tough but the homework and quizzes make it easy to get an A.  Also, students to get partial credit on exam problems.
This professor cares about student success.  I found his lectures incredibly thorough and thought provoking.  By far the best professor at CSE at OSU.  I wish he taught more of my courses.

Lectures were clear, well-paced, and he gave time to ask questions. My biggest with this class were the exams. They are multiple choice and questions could be confusing . Sometimes questions had errors or some questions were too open-ended for a multiple choice exam. Quizzes and homeworks were more balanced. All assignments were open book
Not really cut out to be a professor. Lectures and slides are incredibly unclear/unhelpful. Quizzes/Homeworks/Exams can be very challenging due to this.

Genuinely nice guy that cares about students, but REALLY not cut out to be a professor. He tries to do trick questions that just don't line up with his teaching material, and he struggles with making online quizzes correctly. To make matters worse, he doesn't ever admit he is wrong and stalemates conversations in class about bad questions.

Feels like he has no idea what he is talking about half the time. Does not make his slides or exams and if we try go argue a point with him we often get stuck in a stalemate where he can't explain the concept properly or accept the students may be right/say why they are not.
I found the class to be pretty easy because Professor Stewart baked in a lot of extra credit. He clearly wants students to do well which is nice. I would take a course with him again in a heartbeat.
I found the content and course really helpful.

I found Chris's tests to be unfairly hard and not reflective of the slide decks. I found it extremely frustrating when he sent out an email to the class saying he would not answer any more homework questions over email. He is a nice guy and is very upbeat, but I don't think he's cut out to be a professor.

PRO: I can tell he genuinely cares about students and encourages us to think. CON: homework questions are way too tricky and you have to wrap your brain around it for hours. He seems unprepared and his lectures are really hard to follow, which makes homework even more confusing since almost nothing in the lecture can be explicitly referred to it.
Upbeat, down-to-earth, and very caring professor who always challenges his students to be the better version off themselves.  Plus, he wants to see everyone's smiling faces all the time haha!
He did everything to keep the classes "interesting". But his teaching was just disappointing. Slides are hard to read and he couldn't explain the materials effectively.
The class was way more interesting than I thought it would be.  The teacher tried hard to keep you involved.

Professor Stewart is really kind and patient.  I expected to get an A but ended up with an A-.  I am not mad.  The grading was fair.  The exams were tough but fair.  I wish more teachers were like him.
I learned so much about how to think in terms of computer architecture.  This was may favorite course by far.
Very good professor, one of the best CSE professors I have had. You can tell he has a real passion for the material. Homework and exams were fair. I wish I could take more classes taught by him.

Did not explain material very well at all. Tries to ask 'make you think' questions, but they're so poorly worded and unclear that much of class time is wasted with people just guessing at what it is he is trying to ask. Ambiguous and confusing questions on the tests. In class exercises often caused more confusion than understanding.

Good teacher, actually learned the names of the students.  Offers extra credit which is both interesting and helpful to the coursework.  Very good and upbeat professor, he is definitely very interested in having the students learn about computer architecture.

Regularly 10 minutes late to class. Currently at the end of the semester has not responded to an email I sent as of yesterday three weeks ago or one week ago. Workload is extremely minimal though unhelpful and unorganized.

One of the worst profs I've had, very very boring lectures that make you wanna fall asleep. Low test averages and no curve in the class. He takes a very long time to grade, you wont get your grades till after the final at the earliest. There is extra credit at the end but you have to do it during finals week and it is very long and time consuming.
He doesn't have any grader or office hours, only replies to your questions on campuswire, and would always tell you to look at slides.Still not grading exam 1 and grading labs very slowly.
He is awesome. Very informative and simplifies things a lot for the class. Although he works at IBM, he answers questions after class.

Baxter is an excellent professor for Systems 1.  He encourages discussion, thoroughly answering any question that arose during class.  Apparently his class is more difficult than other offerings, but IMO, well worth it as you'll really learn the material.  TONS of opportunities for extra credit, so if you don't get at least an A-, you didn't try.

Here's what you are here to know.  3 Exams - 20% each, the "final" is on the last day of class worth 20% cumulative Projects - 40% 9 of them. All but one of them were pretty easy Extra Credit - Up to 12% for extra credit projects (but they are VERY time consuming). Also can get extra credit on exams.  Slow grader. First exam back day before second.

Truly an amazing professor. You'll sit through class and find the lectures engaging, and before you know it, you'll have learned a ton of information. Van Putte gives great advice about the field, life in general, and has lots of contacts in the cybersecurity field. Take this class, you will not regret it! Thanks for a great semester, Professor.
Best prof ive had at OSU.

Amazing professor. I went into the class having never coded before, but professor Lamarr made learning java super easy. Attendance is not required, but I highly recommend going because example code shown in class makes projects, labs, and quizzes wayyy easier. He also weaves in useful info about other OSU CSE courses and real world applications.

He doesn't come off as a professor, he is funny and charismatic. He is relaxed and doesn't seem like he teaches by the book, he walks through copious amounts of code in a class to make sure people understand. Honestly just a great professor.

Dr. Dalton is an invaluable teacher. Not only he made Info Security extremely easy to learn, he even made it fun through some online educational videos. He prepares so well for the midterms and exams that getting an A becomes really easy if you put in some effort. I wish all other professors were like him.

He's a good lecturer, but the topic can be a bit boring sometimes. HW is easy. Final group paper/presentation was very easy between 4 people but he grades it pretty harsh. Exams were online, all multiple choice which required some book reading but majority of it was straight from the slides
Professor Vaughan is a nice and helpful guy but his lectures did not click with me. He understood the subject matter but had a hard time conveying it in an understandable way.
Great Professor. Very lenient grader. Decent lectures. Easy course.
LEGEND IF YOU HAVE THE CHANCE TO GET HIM TAKE IT GO DO INTRO TO JAVA OVER ANY OTHER INTRO CLASS IT PREPARES YOU FOR THE CSE SOFTWARE I WHICH IS A SHITSHOW JUST DONT GET BUCCI.

Wonderful professor to start off my CSE educational career at OSU. Very good at conceptually explaining how Java works and really seems to want his students to succeed. I've seen him sit after lectures for very long times just to help students out with their projects and assignments. I went in with no experience and learned everything very easily.

Peter was the best professor i've had so far. He cares about what he teaches and is genuinely interested in helping you. His lectures make sense and he teaches things in a way that makes sense. He is a good person and is more than willing to help you after class. There has been multiple days that I stay after class just to talk to him.
He is a nice guy, very lenient grading. Solid choice for 2123 data structures
Very helpful overall. Sometimes gives out great hints of exams in lectures.
Great instructor during his first year of teaching. Helpful, gives great tips on projects, always responsive to emails, especially during COVID-19, and always looks for feedback and ways to improve.

He's an admirable and accomplished professor. Lectures are quite dry, and he quite often goes on tangents talking about random stuff, though it's often entertaining because of his sense of humour. He is available and helpful with questions, but he isn't very approachable. Sometimes assumes a lot more things are obvious than they really are.

Lectures are a bit heavy, dry even. No exams, which is great but that only means homework is worth way more. A lot of HM I felt like I needed to learn on my own (googling to fully understand opposed to checking the slides). Homework was hard overall. You technically could never show up to lecture and still pass imo

The lecture is totally helpless. The topic is fun, but this professor does not care about teaching. A lot of typos on the blackboard and I even do not dare to trust my notes. You can learn it your self if you want and you can get an A easily without attending his classes.

Language Theory and FA isn't exactly most CSE students dream course, but Prof. Belkin is as good a professor to take it with as any.  His lectures are generally informative, and he's always willing to answer any student questions. His exams were really more than fair considering how difficult he could make them, given the material.

Belkin sometimes went off on weird tangents. His lectures weren't that helpfull and his homeworks were often pretty hard. The plus side was the tests weren't that hard, especially since he told you exactly what to expect in the review session.

Fairly easy; I got still got an A...but explanations are often hand-wavy, he is pretty busy with research and such, and tends to make mistakes on the board. Almost all topics from the book (except last few). Midterm/Final review sessions *very* helpful.
Informative class with interesting homework assignments and a very flexible project.
Smart guy who knows his stuff.

fairly pleasant guy but his teaching leaves much to be desired. all explanations sound like riddles , his office hours are only slightly more informative than lecture so maybe .5 on the useful scale. book is also worthless no examples
nice and easy ...

He's one of the most dedicated instructors I've ever met. Goes out of his way to help students all the time. He is so available, it almost seems like he doesn't have any other obligations, though he is a busy man. Has a good sense of humour and is very patient with students. Very thorough in explaining material and stops for any and all questions.
Prof. Fosler-Lussier is a kind teacher. Looks out for you. His knowledge of the material is solid (not the best but neither the worst).

Eric is one of the best professors I have ever had at Ohio State. He conveys lecture materials very clearly and is prepared to answer any questions. He takes his teaching seriously and knows the name of every student. Once he seemed to lose his cool a little bit because some student continued writing the exam after he asked for an end twice;)

Very interesting class, especially for an intro to AI.  Midterms and final were much easier than expected.  Homeworks were time-consuming but not very difficult.  It's definitely worth doing the extra credit programming assignment!

Nice guy.  However, lectures are a glossed over survey of book.  Tests and quizes much more in detail and can be shocking--very mathy.  Be prepared to learn the details of the book on your own--work the sample problems in back of each chapter if need be.

This was the best class that I ever took at OSU. Dr F sometimes tends to go too fast, but in general teaches an extremely well organized class. Extremely helpful both inside and outside class.The machine learning lectures were very useful and he also tries to strongly convey the mentality of statistical AI.
Good teacher overall, except that  the homework, projects and quiz/exams are too much.

Encourage in-class discussions and gave interesting programming assignments. My one beef was that the late policy of 1 point per minute was a bit extreme; I think 10 points per hour would have been a little more reasonable.  I actually slept through the final, and Professor Fosler was very understanding about giving me an opportunity to make it up.

Very nice, reasonable guy.  A good teacher who is willing to deviate from the lesson plan some if that's where class interest and discussion goes.  Pretty good at fostering that discussion too.  Some homeworks unnecessarily required way too much effort, some hardly any.  I learned a lot.  I heard 730 is about 10 times more time consuming though.

Two big projects are not related to class content and not fair for at least half of the students who dont have previous experience or extra support outside. TA and instructor didnt answer questions and provided almost no help. Also there are few HW or labs assigned to enforce the operating system concepts. Poor class.

Requires you to learn too much outside of the actual class material. Focused way too much on security rather than operating systems concepts. Projects were worth around 25% of the grade and had little to nothing to do with what we were learning in class. Not really a sophomore level course for what he expected from us.

He does have 2 very open ended projects, but if you start them early and write a decent amount in a report to explain everything you did they should be easy enough grades. However, he doesn't seem to realize it is a 2000 level class, or what the prereqs for the class are though. He is very focused on security and skips around a lot in his lectures.

While I do agree that he is a difficult professor, I do not think that he warrants a low score on here. His lectures are good and he explains a lot of the topics in depth. I think that he doesn't give as much advice on the actual projects (not labs) because he wants students to learn how to develop their own methods and be creative.

Do not take this professor. This is a sophomore level course and you need to know machine learning to do one of the projects, the other project requires linux kernel programming which was never taught. Doesn't answer any questions, hard grading, unclear lectures, take anyone else. This is not undergrad level work.

This man is a terrible teacher. He ignored student questions during projects, and explicitly said this too. He is difficult to understand, stammers a lot, and has a heavy accent. It really feels like he cares more about his research and grad students than us undergrads. Things got worse during the transition to online during COVID-19. Please avoid!
Very monotoned and boring lectures. You will end up teaching yourself this class.

You need to do practice problems to pass this class, this is not the type of class you can just study the night of, or not fully understand the material and take this exam. You need to study and understand the material but I enjoyed this class, since i have an interest in the course material.

This class is pretty structured so your professor is not that important.  My main criticism is that she talks very slow so it takes twice as long and sometimes we don't even get through all the material.  Otherwise the class is fine and if you keep up the work you should get an A in the class.
She is amazing. I think this was her first time teaching this course. Highly recommended!

Honestly, just horrible. She means well, but the lectures are horrendous, and very unorganized; as are her thoughts. Hard to follow anything she's trying to teach. The practice worksheets in class are always filled with mistakes, which she just ends up putting the answers on Carmen. Basically, be prepared to do many practice problems by yourself.

You will work for every point you receive in this class. Expect to spend the majority of you time working on prelabs and studying for tests. Expect to cry. Expect to scream. Expect to beg for mercy as you drag yourself into the final. It will be hard. It will be boring. And it's pretty applicable, but it will be hard to grasp. May God be with you
She's a nice person to talk too. She tries her best to make the class interesting, but the material is dry. It was tough for being a 8 am class.
Not the best at explaining things. Lectures not really helpful. This class can be time consuming but its pretty easy

Her lectures are pretty boring, albeit informative. Attendance counts, but I'd say 13 still skipped. There are weekly pre-labs which take 2-4 hours, and an in lab component which is like a watered-down pre-lab done in class. It's unfortunate tho that so much of our grade is based on written exams and not computer work.
Terrible lecturer. Terrible class. Insane that a computer science class bases the largest percentage of points on hand written quizzes and exams. If you get 2040 on a quiz, feel very special.
this class will make you want to drift across the yellow line while driving to school
Very detailed and a lot more computer science oriented than business oriented (But this is GOOD!). She can be a bit overly detailed but at least the point is put across for everyone.
This guy is just mean. I mean he actually is out to hurt your feelings because it makes him feel better about himself.
Class is standardized by CSE department so it's very well laid out. However, he's kind of rude/is condescending on Piazza, where you will most likely be asking for help on projects and whatnot.

The lectures, projects and labs are all designed by the CSE department and therefore are not reflective of teacher. Also CSE doesn't say who the teacher is when you sign up, so.... Read piazza before you submit your projects, because they're graded on really specific things and a couple of points can really make a hit on your grade.

Hes the worst prof Ive ever had, dont even expect him to show up during office hours. The material is not hard but the problem is that there is no way to know what topics will be covered on the exams. he tells you to study on something and he tests you on something else. Good luck memerizing every single word on the thousand pageslides he posts.

Bad lecturer!! He has a low voice and strong accent. You cannot understand or even hear him both in class and after class. Never reply emails or appear for office hours. He has extra credits and his slides help. But grading is tough and strange. If you want to learn something and communicate with the prof, don't take him!

He has four quizzes. Two are known ahead of time, and two are pop quizzes for extra credit. Lots of extra credit in this course. Boring lecturer. The content is so dry and boring, yet useful in CSE. Homeworks aren't graded. Quizzes/Exams are usually just homework problems and in class examples. Study the HW/in class examples and you'll get an A.

He's a little hard to understand and the grading system is just a bit confusing. His slides and practice problems are a huge help when studying. He put in a lot of bonus points this semester, so if you show up to class, it shouldn't be hard to get a B.
He makes this class way harder than it should be.  No review for exams or quizzes.  Like the other wouldn't take his class again.

Expect to write a group document of about 150 pages. Quizzes and exams are vague and poorly written. His accent is hard to understand. After exam he said we didn't email project but we did (150 pages mind you) and 3 hours after exam was done we all had A's. The guy we reamed on peer evaluations did too. Grades are arbitrary in this class.
He makes the class waaay harder than it needs to be.  All there is are quizes and exams.  He does not explain things well, DO NOT TAKE HIM!

His accent is a little hard to understand.  This class is an easy B but you'll have to work for an A.  Quizzes once a week are sometimes relevant, sometimes not.  Doesn't seem too interested in teaching.  Like the other reviewer, I probably wouldn't take his class again.

It's difficult to understand his idea, and both my friend and I found that he was not really interested in teaching. The quizes weren't hard but they are just too irrelevant to the materials he covered in class (or maybe he didn't cover the material he was supposed to?). Overall, I prefer not taking his class again.

The guy knows his stuff.  He's a working professional in the subject matter.  He is soft spoken, so sit at the front.  Make it a point to go to his office hours once or twice at the beginning of the quarter so he knows your name.  Ask questions if you don't understand something, do the reading, and you'll get an A in the class.

He's not all that great.  If you have previous knowledge of databases, you'll be fine just by reading the slides.  However, I saw a bunch of people struggle with this class because he's really bad at understanding/answering student questions.  His quizzes and exams aren't the worst though.

Demands students ask questions, but if you actually ask, he circles around and contradicts himself. If you ask (again) later on, he yells at you for not asking earlier. If students stop asking questions, he "punishes" them by making exams harder and more frequent. Doesn't appreciate being "disturbed" during office hours. Also, didn't appear to unde

Great professor. He grades a pretty easy and goes over everything multiple times until it is completely clear. Always answers questions. Has "pop" quizzes, but the dates are listed on the syllabus. Goes over everything you need to know for labs in lecture.

Very soft spoken, so make sure to try to sit in the front! Other than that, he is a very good prof. He is great at explaining difficult concepts in layman's terms, and is clearly very passionate about database systems! His quizzes are VERY easy if you have done the homework, and impossible if you haven't.

Yes he is somewhat difficult to understand but he tries to be as clear as possible. Told us everything we needed to study, DO ALL OF THE PROBLEMS AND PRACTICES MULTIPLE TIMES and it will be an easy A.  The average for his class was WAY higher than ALL of the other CSE, courses. TAKE HIM FOR CS&E 200 just sit in the front!
He's very hard to understand. The final review and midterm review are not helpful at all. Don't take his class
Well I will say that I think the material covered is useful. I feel like I can a will use it in the future. Again, most of your success hinges on your study habbits. This is a long and tedious class
Enjoyed and learned a lot lot. Everything he taught me are usable in real world.
Always available and helpfull to students.
Excellent Prof. He knows what he is doing, very helpful to students, and you will learn a lot if take the course with him. I would recommend his course for anyone wants to learn database systems.

First of all, dont take any grade you get back of something seriously.  He basically just gives eveyrone whatever he wants in the end, which is a good thing cause I deserved about a C- and got a B+.  LONG HOURS of diagram making are involved, and the client is kinda, well, nm.  For 616 hes a good guy to take it with.
Great Teacher.  Quizes were easy if you paid attention and study.  very nice guy and very helpful
For anyone planning to take the course with him, I would recommend not to take it. You will not learn anything useful about operating systems if you take it with him.

Taking this class is great if you don't want to learn anything about operating systems. Take-home midterm and final and 4 labs (you can get out of doing a presentation on something related to computers). Came out of this class with an embarrassingly small knowledge of operating systems. Convenient now, but in the long run, it'll hurt you.

If you come to class hoping to actually learn something this professor if the wrong choice.  He mainly talks about the news and tells bad jokes.  He also loves to talk about the history of computers and gives the 'ole punch card story.  Every now and then he interjects something related to operating systems.  Another useless professor.

The only thing challenging about this class is the project. Both the exams were take home and that was the only other grade. Make sure you have time to put in a decent amount of effort on the project and you'll be fine. Probably the easiest instructor to have for this course. Spends most of class talking about whatever is on his mind.

This class was really easy, the only problem is that you don't learn a whole lot about operating systems. One midterm, one final(which we got changed to a take-home), and one lab(which you can get out of if you did a presentation). He doesn't really teach, he just sorta talks about whatever he feels like.

Ethics class with Mathis kind of went like this: 1) Talk about how much potential we all have. 2) Talk about random things in the news. 3) Make a joke about current events that everyone gets but nobody thinks is funny and then get upset and pretend nobody reads the news when we don't laugh.
Most common Mathis quote: "What, don't you guys read the newspaper?"  Rarely talked about ethics, which is what this course was supposed to be about.  On the other hand, it was super easy.
Nice guy, has forgotten more about computer science than I'll ever know.  Likes to teach by telling stories.  Show up and listen and you'll probably do well on his tests.
Awesome prof. Easy going and easy to understand.
easy going, doesnt require much... reads the jokes he put on to the class like we don't know how to read and expect us to laugh
Bad lecturer. Always sleep on his class. So boring at all.

If you have him, DROP NOW. If your only other option is an 8am, TAKE THE 8am. HE IS THE WORST professor I have ever had in my entire life. I WISH I could give him a 0/5 rating. He's unhelpful, grades projects horribly, barely speaks English, and only reads off the slides. He's condescending and rude. Unless you're a master coder, you will not PASS.

Never choose CSE 2123 under this guy. He is RACIST, really bad at teaching and explaining things. All he did in class was reading slides like a robot. Even robots would be better than him cuz half of the class did not know what he was talking about due to his poor Eng. If you take his class, go to buckeyelink and drop it ASAP. TRUST ME!!

Would not recommend taking the course under him, he does not help you with projects saying its course policy that he cant help you and all that bad excuses... does not speak perfect English and anyone can barely understand him, only way to pass the class under him is if you are really good at coding or look up answers online

Worst professor ever. Does not speak English at all and literally cannot answer questions when you ask him about the material. I am so surprised he isn't fired. Do not skip class and study your butt off for the exams. Barely gives partial credit for coding projects. Overall the most terrible class and the worst human on earth

It's hard enough to take a course on programming because it is a new language but he literally speaks very few English words.  This class was impossible.  He would take off 50% if you missed a semicolon, never understood what he was saying, and he genuinely did not teach us.  The kids who did well in the class were the ones who knew how to code.
I had this guy for cse 1223 and he was great! Would recommend!
The computer science this man is really good at it and he also speak Chinese to help me.
Hard to understand his English, but it's not impossible. He also cannot pronounce many  English words and his examples that he uses are very confusing.
He is awesome!
Great teacher unless you dont already have some knowledge in coding. He can be tough but not unreasonably so.

Really practical approach to coding because he has industry experience. The content is tough if you don't have a background in visual c#, but he is always willing to meet with you and help you understand concepts or work on coding issues
Excellent advisor. Very helpful and understanding. I've had the best results from visiting the advising office in person to solve problems that come up.
CSE Survey is easy, just show up & do the work. Dr. Strader is super busy so emails may be stuck in the backlog, but she's very knowledgeable and helpful at advising hours.

The only reason she is not helpful is because she has many jobs in the department and simply does not have a lot of time to answer questions outside of class. As long as you show up for class and do the very few assignments, you will pass the class. Many people love and respect her.

Nikki Strader while a nice adviser in general is a general pain along with the rest of the OSU advising staff. I emailed Nikki once to no avail and had to send a followup email 3 days latter to get a response a week latter for an appointment set on a Thursday.  If your in a rush to get an appointment you can never expect fast service from OSU staff

Nikki Strader is an amazing advisor. She is very helpful and points you in the right direction. She is very enthusiastic and is willing to help you when in need. she is the best engineering counselor.

Nikki is an outstanding professor who really cares for the students that she advises. Time is well spent in her office hours. She's very helpful when it comes to making decisions concerning your choice of major. I would wish that any freshman could have Dr. Strader as their academic advisor.
Nice lady, more disorganized than most professors.  Not the most helpful of people, doesn't seem to care as much as she should.  Computer Science and Engineering head advisor.  Bad office hours.
The guy is clearly a genius and knows what he's talking about, but he wasn't able to convey it well at all.

Lee was great.  He teaches exactly what you need to know, not arbitrary topics that he alone is interested in.  He understands that not everyone in the class totally loves the material, but he makes it very easy to understand.  His exams are very fair, and as long as you understand the homework, you'll be fine.
Very knowledgeable; he was able to take straight up math and show how it applies to solving real world problems.  He worked at Bell Labs and is still active in the industry, knows what he's doing.

Uses a terrible textbook. Homework problems are extremely difficult. Boring presentation of material. Strictly follows his inadequate online notes. Makes it clear that being a professor is his second priority career-wise. Appears distant from the class; discourages visiting his office hours, does none of the grading, and doesn't come on exam days.

Very nice guy, willing to go over materials over and over again...but it can be very boring. Midterms and the final is pretty straight forward if did all of your homework and understood them. Good professor.

Took a rather dull topic and made it quite bearable. He understood that people were taking the class only because it was required, and yet he made it worthwhile by telling interesting stories and giving reasonable homework assignments. His notes were very clear and available online. If you have to take this class, look to take it with Lee.
Thick accent and he read the lecture notes verbatim. Didn't help that it was at 8am.
The class was very easy.  He taught the material well and was helpful.  However, his accent is very thick and was hard to understand.
don't buy the book and never go to class and don't waste your time even to take this course it's better to take cse494 it's better than this class and you will have credit for cse459.23
No need to go to class and no need to buy the book.  If you have trouble, go to his office hours and he will help.  Everything you need is online.

This instructor can barely speak english. He reads from the slides in class. He is helpful when you go to his office hours and ask for help on the assignments, but his in class lectures are very hard to understand. This makes going to class pointless. Don't take this class with him. It would be a good class if the instructor could speak english.
dont buy the book, its a complete waste, you can find all the information online...its also a waste to go to class, he doesn't teach, he only reads the slides.  this class is stupid.
Austin is honestly amazing and has lots to share for everything that ranges from both outside the class to inside the class.

Great supplemental content about real world stuff. Pauses & takes questions often during lectures to clarify topics. Assumes students has a solid grasp on content presented in slides unless they ask questions. Would take another class taught by him if available.

I had Bobkov for foundations 1 and 2. His teaching style takes some getting used to, but besides that hes a very fair professor. His exam were also very fair and he tells you exactly whats on it. He also lets you bring in a notecard of notes front and back. I never heard of any other foundations professors that did that. Would recommend him.

A pretty accessible and easy-going guy. He always goes through the algorithms in detail to make sure everyone understands, but his lectures are really dry, so sometimes it's difficult to get the intuition at first.

Some students say his lectures are dry, but I quite like his lectures, straight to the point. He is very helpful and passionate. Also, he is accessible outside class. All the questions on exams are fair. I would recommend taking him.

Very monotone, slow lectures. Rather than learning when to use which algorithms why time complexity is important (real-world knowledge), you will learn how to step-by-step walk through code and do rigorous proofs (useless). There's a ton of focus on the details so make sure you learn on your own how this will actually apply in real life.
She looks as confused as me about the lecture materials when I'm taking her class.

She's not great; her lectures seem awkward and at times unprepared. Some of the labs are quite hard. However, having retaken this class, she's a step up from Babic. The exams are a bit easier, it's just important to show up for the in-class assignments and do plenty of reading outside of class. Overall she's not terrible though.
Prepare to be a self-learner. She sucks

Brutal. Good luck staying awake during lecture. You'll be teaching yourself a lot. The only redeeming quality of this professor is the ease of the class. She is not organised and often seems confused when you ask her a question. I despised this class.

Systems 1 is a relatively dry class, but it helps when you have a caring professor who wants you to succeed. She has assignments for attendance, so make sure you attend. The projects are as difficult as the other classes, but she'll guide you, if you ask. The midterm was fair for what we learned in class, partially coming from ICA's.

Software 1 is not an impossible class, but the exams and projects are tough. Jackson did a good job of explaining the concepts and was helpful, but the course coordinator writes the exams. Course is definitely harder than CSE 1223. Be ready to study for exams, because they test specifics to see if you really understand the material.

A really awesome lecturer and class! There's only three grades: attendance, a research paper, a PowerPoint presentation. But he doesn't take attendance, and the other two are on topics of your choice, due at the end of the semester. Even though you don't really need to go, his lectures are still super interesting and worthwhile to listen to.
The best class  have taken.

He is super easy. You just have some quizzes which he sends the questions out a day early so you just show up and fill it out. He has required workshops but doesn't take attendance (but can be fun). Midterm and final are easy. Basically just a pretty easy class where you learn some useful things.

Do not take this professor's class. She does not even reply to your email, and the grade of the paper is just chaos. She does not even know why did she give the grade you received. She did not even read through the paper before grading it. The conclusion is that she is the worse professor I have ever taken in my life.
About the most disorganized person I have met in college, including other students

The pre labs take 6+ hours to complete. The exams are extremely hard and almost impossible. They are only 5 questions and she takes off points for the tiniest mistakes. Lectures are pointless and she doesn't give you clear notes.
Class wasnt unorganized like I expected it to be due to the reputation CSE has. Class was not too hard as long as you do all the worksheets, pre labs, and in labs.

Very disorganized teacher which allowed for a lot of take home quizzes and due dates being pushed back. If you make an effort and come to office hours she will help you a lot. Would be a good teacher but has a lot on her plate and can't handle it. Overall she is nice and tries to relate to students.

She is the most unorganized professor I have ever had. There were several mistakes made throughout the semester where she had to send emails out correcting her errors. She is not always on top of updating the Carmen page and my emails were ignored.

She's the course director for CSE 2111, and is horrible. Nothing good to say at all - lecture are boring, videos can be unclear and although Access is miles easier than Excel, she does a horrendous job of explaining it in her online videos, making it tough to study for the quiz and Access portion of the final

I take the distance learning course, and i love it. Lori is always there to help and if you need help or you are having troubles she is right there for you. but the class is a lot of work. It takes me a week to everything. Excel portion is hard and so are the quizzes, but after the midterm it gets way easier. DO THE WORKSHEETS YOURSELF!! it helps!

A wonderful source of joy as the butt of many jokes. Hours and hours of pre labs keep children like me off the dangerous streets of Columbus. Gave me hope that even if I lack a morsel of competence I can still obtain my dream job. Taught me the value of studying hard, even for exams that she'll probably lose anyways. The v-lookup changed my life.

She got a bad rap this semester but she is a great professor &always willing to help!! The midterm was dropped because one of the lecturer's was distributing the midterm from last semester to study from, which happened to be the same as the midterm we were tested on. This created an unfair advantage and Lori did what was fair. do the worksheets!
Easy a for everyone

This class was the most unorganized class I have ever taken. Two of the five assessments in the class were thrown out due to her errors, which made it difficult to know what material I actually knew and what I didn't know. Pre-labs were time-consuming, and the labs had many errors in the directions. Avoid if possible

UNBELIEVABLY DISORGANIZED. The class this semester was an absolute train wreck. The Pre-Labs are kind of useful, but take an immense amount of time. There are 3 quizzes, but the lowest one gets dropped.. Pointless worksheets. Get ready to get an email every 5 minutes saying she has messed up.

This was the most disorganized course I have ever taken at Ohio State. She was constantly emailing us about mistakes either she or her other lecturers made. The ball was dropped by her many times, for instance our midterm had to be retaken and then she did not even count the grade. Overall I feel extremely let down by this department.
Unprofessional
Gave us the wrong exam two times and made us retake it weeks later. I honestly wish I was joking here. She is a symbol of how ridiculously unorganized the CSE 2111 department is at Ohio State.

First time with excel. Posts videos online, very simplistic examples, unlike exams. Learned by working backwards via answers provided by her for worksheets. Toward end of semester, materials weren't provided, she didn't have time. Tough class for a first time excel user but an A is possible for sure. Seemed nice and wiling 2 help
Overall an easy class. Just show up and participate a little. Turn in a paper and give a presentation (both easy) and you're all set. She is good about generating discussions.

Only met her once; she is the course coordinator. Everything you need to succeed is posted online, and if you practice you should be fine. Class is mostly self-taught. Just put the time in and you'll do fine. Do the practice problems and exams. However, there were some mistakes on her lab instructions and practice problems that confused me.

I only met her once, she seemed very nice, but that doesnt matter. I took the class online and suffered severely for it. Supposedly if you take her actual class its much easier but without that its impossible. the content isnt too bad as long as you are decent with excel and access (I took a class in high school). Extremely tough grading TAs.

Worst professor I've ever had. I am certified by Microsoft as a MOS Master (highest certification) and I got bad grades in this class for "not doing it her way." My experience aside, my point is, she teaches you formulas, but doesn't teach you how to *think* about how to solve problems in Excel, which is the most important part.

Don't bother buying the textbook, you only need it for the Pre Labs which count for just 2% of your grade. You do need the MyITLab access code though, just not anything else (including the physical copy of the Pearson book).  Lori Rice made many errors on the lectures, videos, slides, labs, and even tests, so don't let that confuse you.

THE MOST unorganized professor I've ever had. Be ready to get at least 2 emails a day from her saying that she "messed up" and that new directions will be released shortly or that her video lectures will be ready soon... (when they should have been ready days ago)
very unorganized and full of busy work and quizzes, labs, and tests that we are not prepared for

Very disorganized, a lot of busy work. Forced you to buy expensive books and online access code to myitlab (sold by Pearson). Don't understand why she doesn't use Carmen, which is free for all OSU students.

Go to office hours! On every assignment, I had points taken off by the stupid graders. She always gave me points back and was so pleasant to talk to. She will gladly help you if you go to her.   Skip your lecturer, go straight to her!

Contrary to what everyone else said, when it comes down to it, she's a mom. She makes sure that you understand the concepts and spends one lecture of the week literally going through a practice worksheet with you. If you understand how to do the worksheets in class, you should be fine for the midterms. Final is long, but not hard.

Overall Lori Rice is a mediocre professor. She's not the best but not the worst. She definitely makes the tests harder than they need to be. Probably the most annoying thing about her is how she ALWAYS makes mistakes, whether its on her lectures, quizzes, even the FINAL had mistakes. If you have to take CSE 2111 shes an okay option.
This class is tough and she acts like it is her job to make it tougher. Practice material is often wrong.

Appallingly disorganized. Her homework assignments (pre-labs) come with at least two conflicting sets of instructions that keep you second guessing yourself.  She constantly makes mistakes in class, despite claiming she and her TAs proof read the materials (they've even consistently messed up the exams). Take her course if you want to feel scammed.

Lori's not as bad as people are saying. The only thing is she makes a ridiculous amount of mistakes in the practice problems on Carmen. Those problems are 100% necessary if you want an A in this class, though. I did each one multiple times and I was very prepared for each test. Very nice and helpful in office hours. Seriously DO THE PRACTICE PROBS.

She seems to be more annoyed by students that willing to help but i never went to her personally. assignments are sometimes long, difficult, unclear, and confusing. She is difficult and you have to put in the work, if you do the prelabs and work and tons of practice tests and you should get an A.

Disappointed is the only word to describe this experience. I put in the hours to do good and learn the material, but how can one exceed when the solutions in the practice problems are more incorrect than correct? Avoid
One of the worst out there. Terribly organized class even worse lecturer.
Great teacher......

I have never seen a lecturer make so many mistakes in class in my life.  Students correct her at least 3 times a day in lecture.  Proves she doesn't proofread what she does.  How am I supposed to learn about Excel and Access during lecture if I can't use a computer?  Makes no sense. She knows what she's talking about but can't teach it.

horrible teacher, class itself isn't hard, put it enough work and you'll probably get an A, but the class is terribly run, the TAs don't help and when she teaches her powerpoints are often wrong and she is corrected by students

Holy f*ck she is the worst. Easily the worst professor I have ever had at OSU. Her lectures are confusing because she is incorrect constantly and is corrected by students. She is not clear in the tests she gives, and they are graded as if she's an SS officer. Avoid her at all costs. An A is not realistic.

Insanely unorganized. Grading is not by rubric. TA's grade as they will. Solutions for practice problems are not correct. They basically set you up for failure. Easily the hardest class I've ever taken.

The class shouldn't be as hard as it was.  Terrible TA's that are completely inept and barely speak english (foreign).  They grade really hard and intentionally try to screw students over.  The class is poorly organized and run as well.

Lori Rice was very helpful in the lectures and when asked questions she answered them well. I would recommend her to anyone that has to take this course. This is not an easy course but it is very manageable if you study and do your work in a timely manner.

Very time consuming course. But if you put in the time and effort an A is within reach. Midterm is fair and easy if you study and don't get behind. Make sure you STUDY for the lab exam and final. They are much more challenging.
Most unorganized class I ever had. They gave too many people in between her and the student. None of the structures ever know what's going. Syllabus gets changed all the time. horrible.

The class is easy if you do the work and attend class. Class isn't mandatory but if you truly want an A it is. Out of class work is very time consuming. Lots of extra credit, but if you do the work and study once in awhile it is not hard to get an A

She's very disorganized and constantly changes syllabus dates and point values on assignments. She couldn't even have the decency to respond to a relatively important email I sent her. There's more than one bad typo in every project/prelab. Overall, the class is not super difficult, just really annoying.
She is very disorganized, and likes to make sudden random changes. Lots of assignments with mistakes. Instruction is often unclear.

this class you definitely have to work at and put time into, but if you do its not impossible. Gives extra credit. I found Access to be much easier than Excel. Pre-abs are very time consuming, though. You'll spend at least 3-5 a week doing these, at least.
First midterm I found very challenging, but overall the class isn't terrible. Feel like we learned really useful stuff, and she offers a decent amount of extra credit.

Not a difficult class. You're walked through everything in such a way that you understand it all by the end. Lots of extra credit, and exams are almost exactly like the in-class exercises. The only way to not do well is to not go to class. Seriously, you CANNOT skip this class. If you go, you'll have no trouble with it.

If you are a student that isn't experienced with Excel, take the 2111 course as the 1113 version moves really fast. My biggest problem was that many assignments were not returned timely and I had already completed another week's worth before I got any feedback on the previous assignment. She does give extra credit opportunities that are beneficial.
Pushes back lab deadlines all the time, gives extra credit, exams are practically like the excercises in class. Such an easy teacher.

Frankly speaking, it was a difficult class, but I am sure that if u follow the instruction, you will get A grade easily. There is a powerpoint presented in a classroom. i am generally satisfied with the way she taught.

He never answers students question, because he is unable to understand English well, and he cannot speak English well. The college should not let him be the TA for a fundamental course, he is wasting all the students' time. He always cannot run your assignment well and give you a deduction. All he does is reading slices, you can learn by yourself

drop this course after the first week. So hard to understand what is he talking about. he just read all the words on the slides without any explanation. Do not choose this him especially for this CSE course.

Is very hard to understand and is not very well prepared for class. Does not create course slides so he just reads off them and moves on. Very example heavy, just gives examples for students to do and moves on. Does not answer questions at all, very hard to learn, basically have to teach yourself.

He basically just read through the slides. He occasionally explained things but sometimes it was too difficult to understand because his English isnt good. Also, he probably wont understand your question so theres no point in asking during class. I recommend finding a friend to help you understand whats going on.
Quizzes were hard. Content was flawed sometimes, and doesn't understand the questions much.

Solid professor who really knew his stuff. The class was a little annoying because everything is so vague, but the content didn't lend itself to cut and dry lectures. Assignments didn't give much direction so you have to ask a lot of questions too, but Cline listened to feedback and adjusted the class as we went on.

Alan is a fine teacher for this class. The class itself does not have any lectures. The assignments for the class are not difficult and are pretty easy to get A's on. The main project can take a lot of work and time, but if you have a good group, it will be fine!

Nice guy but also a terrible teacher. Be prepared to never know when anything is due or what he expects. Staying awake during class is harder than it should be because hearing the same 4 or 5 stories over and over again makes for a great white noise machine.

Alan is a nice guy, but he is not the best teacher. He is very unorganized and does not know how to communicate well with the class when it comes to assignments. Homework has little guidance, yet he grades tough if you miss even the smallest things. The quizzes are difficult, but the good thing is that the exam is composed of quiz questions.

Disorganized. He seems to get confused between what he told our class and another class. He also didn't make the grading criteria clear and would act like he was really flexible about assignments when he really wasn't when he graded them.

He is clearly knowledgeable, but has no idea how to teach an engaging class. Never lays out the rules clearly, and will sometimes waste the entire class period telling stories that he thinks are funny, but aren't.

He's the most unorganized teacher here at CSE department. He is very mean at grading group projects. Any idea that is different from him is not allowed even if it is an  open project. He is never helpful and when you go ask him questions, he will never explain it clearly. And he always conflicts himself.

He's everything you don't like about Donald Trump. He's old, white, unorganized, has an unclear grading scale, says one thing one day and forgets it by the next. I guess he doesn't care too much but you get the sense that you are going to get a bad grade because of something that he messed up. I didn't vote for Donald so I wouldn't recommend Cline.

Quite honestly the most disorganized professor I've had. He seems passionate about the material, but we waste 10-15 minutes per class  when he changes deadlines every day and then forgets. Tends to contradict himself. Admitted the class wasn't effective and restructured the course 3 times in a semester to try and fix things. It didnt fix things...

Very easy class. Aside from mandatory attendance, if you put 2 hours into your paper and 4 hours into your speech, you should do well. His grading instructions can be confusing and contradictory at times but he grades very fairly.

I think this was his first course he's ever taught. He's very hard to understand so if you do go you need to sit up front. Attendance was mandatory (small portion of final grade) but honestly you'd be alright staying home and looking over the slides. This course isn't very deep if you have any programming knowledge.
Very professional loves feed back answers questions Thoroughly and And has very good experience with software engineering and knows what hes talking about

Professor Khaled was very knowledgeable in Software Requirements Analysis having worked in relevant positions in the private sector. His classes were interesting and he is very responsive to feedback in his lectures. Would take him again.

Attendance is such a big part of your grade, you feel like you're back in High School. Takes absences as a personal attack and will go out his way to make sure he remembers who isn't in class. His conduct is extremely unprofessional and he has no business in the classroom. Show up to class, but expect nothing more than reading from a powerpoint.

Mandatory attendance is the only reason people show up to this class. The mumbling and low volume make it hard enough to pay attention in the class, but the use of another teacher's slides that he does not know beforehand is embarrassing. He teaches what he thinks is important from the slides then gives another teacher's test which covers them all

THIS DUDE IS THE BEST. Honestly, he's like the best you could get for CSE. Rupen is a slow grader, but is also the easiest grader i've seen (you'll get like straight hundreds for everything). He gets off topic a lot, so be sure to go over the lecture notes for the midterms. He always emails back in 2 seconds and is great at explaining the content!
Do send email

He is a great instructor. If you have him, remember to always go to the lecture before exams. He is very good at helping you to know what is really required for exam purposes. The book covers much more information than the exam and labs......

Haseeb is arguably one of the best TAs Ive had while at OSU. His ability to create a learning environment where you arent afraid to go up to the board or participate in class discussions goes a very long way in helping to learn the material. I was not a fan of coding prior to this course but I left it with a positive attitude thanks to him.

Prof. Haseeb is a promising instructor, but I believe he was severely limited by the materials given to him. The course design is baffling, featuring 30+ slide presentations that cover basic concepts and exams that give you no time to complete them. If you have to take this course, Prof. Haseeb is a fine choice, but the course itself has issues.
Better than most TAs you'll come across.

Unless you like teaching yourself an entire programming language, trust me on this one. Some of the assignments due in end of August were graded in mid November, some have yet to be graded. Late to class, finishes reading off the lecture slides within 15 minutes, class over. boom. trust me dont.

First of all, he seldom grades our work, we don't even know how we did in the closed lab, projects, and homework since the third week. The lecture time should be 45 mins but he will finish it in less than 25 mins. The only thing he would do in class is reading slides without mention any important points nor going through the hard project.
Easy iff you stay on top of the material. Nice guy, knows his stuff and communicates well.

Very good professor. Knows what he is talking about and won't move on until 80% of the class knows what's up. 5 homework assignments, no labs, 1 midterm, 1 final. Don't procrastinate or you will struggle.

Radu's computer architecture class was very insightful. His assignments and exams were very fair. There weren't any programming assignments in this class so it was a good break from the norm. Highly recommend. Class taken in SP2009

Derek was a really nice and cool guy, but a really tough grader. I know for a fact that other professors grade easier, Derek really makes you work for it. He explains things pretty well, but if you want this class to be easier look for someone else.
The best teacher in OSU, he explains everything in a such clear manner!!! He is such a caring and knowledgable professor, and also enjoys teaching. I enjoy what I've learnt in the lecture a lot.
Extremely harsh on grading, trust me, you never want to put yourself in his class.
Best professor both in terms of teaching and relationship with students! 10/10 recommended, best professor at OSU

Absolutely the best professor I've ever met in OSU CSE department. He knows what he is talking about, and his class has rich information on graphics. However, the exams are not as easy as I thought. Try to get full marks and extra credits on your labs, you will be able to get a B+. Otherwise might be hard to get to a B because exams are hard.

Best professor in Ohio State. He teaches well and cares for students. The labs are well designed and the professor is keep updating his course. For example, his 5542 class is using WebGL instead of OpenGL now.

He's a good prof if you interested in Graphics stuff. Unfortunately, I thought I was interested, but in reality I wasnt too interested, and so did not pay much attention in class. His classes can get really long, and the HWs are quite a bit of a task.

Lots of slides, be sure to understand them before tests and you'll be fine. Labs, somewhat hard but I managed to pull them all off after some effort. You will learn a lot if that's what you came here for. Stay home and eat Oreo if you just want to skip classes.

I took this course expecting to learn a lot of cool staff and he taught exactly what I wanted. I must say he is by far the best Prof. here. He explains thing really well. Doesn't talk too much, he knows the subject very well so easily conveys the idea to the students. I would highly recommend taking courses under him.
He is a great prof. His lectures are very informative and helps understand the subject quite well. He has genuine interest in teaching.

Great professor with genuine interest in teaching. Explains concepts really well and in a concise manner. Labs are not too hard but requires a lot of time but they make you understand the subject well. I would prefer taking my other classes any day and would recommend others too.

He was a good professor and definitely knew the material well; however, the fast-paced nature of the quarter made it extremely difficult to pick up on the concept of ray-tracing and then be able to implement it.  DEFINITELY start labs early if you don't want headaches by the end of the quarter.  Utilize office hours EARLY.
Goos Prof. Stuff are quite easy to and fun to learn. Labs and homework are not very challenging

Great guy. His teaching style is good, he is very expressive and puts forth a lot of effort into teaching things he knows like the back of his hand. Labs are fun and doable. Make sure you start 3/4 days before its due. Mid-term was very problem heavy, final was short answer good class. Get all the x-cred you can!

Very good teaching style.  Clear, concise, and to the point in lecture.  Exams not very difficult, but make you think, nonetheless.  Labs time-consuming, but allow you to really get to know OpenGL.  Wish I could take another class with him.

One of the few classes that I got me TOTALLY into programming my labs. Learning OpenGL under Dr Shen was the best experience I had for ALL my CIS courses taken! I hope I will be able to work and learn again under his tutelage in future. 3 thumbs up!

Good professor and is really good at explaining things, and while the material isn't super difficult (especially with a solid stats background), it is a lot and isn't always always easy to digest if you don't go to class regularly, but all notes are posted online. Homework isn't super hard, but make sure you go to class and don't procrastinate it.

Jason is a decent professor and is very willing to help. The class itself has a lot of content. The homeworks are time consuming and difficult to figure out how to code. The exams are easy and he lets you use a typed formula sheet. However, you may get unlucky if you leave something out in your formula sheet.

I'm not too sure where these reviews are coming from. As someone that had Jason for both Foundations I and Data Mining, I thought we was a well-spoken and fair instructor. Exams never deviated from course content even remotely. If you attend class and understand what he lectures on, you will do well.

Material is tough, but he doesn't make it much better. His homework was the worst part. If you can't make it to his or the TA's office hours to get help for them every week, you're screwed. The exams were okay compared to the homework, but he grades differently from the TA.
worst class i've ever taken. Don't take it with him.
He is very new to teaching. Material was not fully organized.

Kristen is an incredible professor and explains things well, though this is masked by how incredibly boring and repetitive the class gets (especially if you've taken 3231). But she does her best to make things manageable and her slides are well-written enough to use as study tools for the exams. Exams weren't super challenging.

Porfessor Elliott is one of the best instructors I've ever encountered. She is so passionate about teaching and guiding students. The class material itself is a little boring but she tries her best to make it enjoyable. She brings guest lecturers and makes the lecture interactive. Easy A if you study for the exams. The semester long project is easy

Prof. Joshi is very coherent with lecture topics and when answering questions during office hours. His tests are fair, with similarities to the lecture slides. Some projects are difficult, but he is willing to help, but will not give the answer (as he shouldn't given that this is coding). There is a lot of homework though. Overall, great class!
He will care to explain you as much as you care. So do your part of research and ask good questions.

You need to be an expert if you want to get a good grade. Have to make lots of assumptions to answer those ambiguous questions. During the lecture, He constantly asks questions and waits for students' responses. If no response, he continues waiting. And students are also waiting for him, which wastes lots of time. No curve. Average is about 75/100

He is a great lecturer that really cares about teaching and goes step beyond to make sure you understand the core concepts. Obviously, you have to attend class cause this is college and you are an engineer. If you show up to class, listen, and participate in the activities you should end up with a good grade. This is a class that makes you think

I first saw Swaroop's rating on RMP a few weeks before class and was scared. After going through a semester of SWII with him, I would say these reviews are inaccurate. His lectures were thorough and he put 120% effort into making sure your questions were answered. The RMP score speaks more to the difficulty of SW rather than his teaching!

His lectures could be a bit bland but if you came willing to listen and actually participate it would be pretty easy to pick up the material. He is also great at answering questions in person and online. He definitely did his best at making a dry topic interesting.
Okay lecturer, a little rough on the grading for tests.
Wired accent, tough grader. Worst CSE ever. 41 people in class, 14 failed.

This might be the worst class I had ever taken. Especially the Program writing questions in Exam, he always minus points at very small problems. A lot of friends of mine and I have to switch major because he give us too low grades.

I took Dr. Joshi for 2221 and I really enjoyed his class. It was a bit difficult as I had no prior Java experience (C++), but he genuinely cares about his students and his lectures are very in-depth. His accent is not an issue, and his expectations are very clear. I would absolutely take him again. Prior to a COAM incident, I had B in class.
Hard grader no curve low average

He taught the material pretty well, and he's helpful in labs and outside of class. Only complaint is the hard exams. Our class's average was significantly lower than other classes. The multiple choice was worth too much and he grades other questions hard. Overall a good choice to take, just study a lot for exams.

This is a tough course, regardless of who is teaching the class. Each professor reads from the same lecture notes and the homework/projects are the same for every class section. Joshi is very informative and is great when you approach him with questions. However, he is quite a hard grader with low class averages compared to other class sections.
Hard homework; lecture is boring; no curve

Try not to take this class if you are not very interested or expected in CS. He is professional in Coding to answering you a lot but if you can get it depends on you. Recommend some people who are talented. However, he might not be suitable to be a professor who teaches. Like said above, Other class's average grade is about 15+ more than ours.
If you want an A you are going to have to work very hard for it.  Goes above and beyond if you attend office hours.

He is the worst teacher on earth. He cannot teach a thing and he is unfair in grading.   Other class got a much higher grade than ours. the best of our class can reach 87 while others class average is 87.
Was fairly easy, though sometimes difficult to understand.  I became very interested in CSE through this course,though more from the material than from him.
Pretty standard teaching, on the easy side. No surprises. Cares about students doing well.

Absolutely terrible lecturer, and the class itself felt super disconnected between lectures, labs, and homework. The in class quizzes all have laughable 1 or 2/6 averages, because no one learns anything in his class. I would have been better off teaching myself the content. Class is heavily curved.
really good guy good person . He is very kind to talk to me
Avoid his class. Heavily curved. Hard to follow anything in class.

He's good at lecturing, but he is 100% research professor. The one midterm exam is difficult, but has a generous curve. The labs are very easy if you have good hands on computer science skill. The homework isn't much more difficult. Was one of my easier classes this quarter.

This guy is a GIANT ****!!!! His homework have nothing to do with the test.  His lab require you to do so much more outside reading.  If this is the only CSE class you are taking then maybe you will be able to handle the workload from this class.  Or else this guy make you do some crazy project to help his own research.
360 is a hard class that you need to study a little bit everyday to do well in the class.
Reading the book was better than attending lectures. Class was fairly challenging just because it was dry.

You have a code due every week and they get extremely advanced later in the course. I had to go to office hours every week just to finish my homework. The tests are long and hard. You have to come to class or your grade will suffer. His lectures are extremely boring and unhelpful.

This man single-handedly and unknowingly stopped me from dropping out of college. The CSE program at OSU is abysmal, but Jeremy gave me hope and the strength to push on. He is as real as it gets, and you will learn valuable and relevant information to your career. And no, I am not apologizing for glazing, as it is well-deserved.
Amazing professor- wants all of his students to succeed and nobody left behind. Take this class

If you have been blessed to take a class with Grifksi, just know you are one of God's favorites. My only advice: don't slack off, take every opportunity you can to do better by resubmitting projects, visiting office hours, and completing the portfolio project.

the effing lebron of teaching

need i say more
Genuinely the best professor to ever exist.

Awesome professor! Gears the class to preparing students for the real world. He truly cares for his students and wants them to succeed. He's constantly looking for ways to improve the class to make it the best experience possible.

Jeremy is one of the GOATs of the CSE department. He was so good explaining concepts and was very understanding. His Software 2 section is also amazing because we use VSCode and Git instead of whatever the other sections use. Exams were online and we even got to do a personal project in this class to replace our lowest midterm grade!
I'm a straight man but I would marry him
Overall, he was a great professor!
THE GOAT! THE GREATEST TO EVER DO IT! Literally the best professor I've ever had

Best professor I've ever met. CSE2221 is a tough course if you are not familiar with JAVA, but Jeremy really really helps folks (he uses a lot this word) get through this class. Hopefully he can teach more classes.

Best professor ever; if you have the opportunity to take this professor, you should take him. He has a great knowledge of Software and coding, but he is kind and patient with all of his students regardless of where they start. He has great resources on his website and Discord he provides great extra credit opportunities. He wants you to succeed.

I had Jeremy for Software 2 (CSE 2231) he is the best professor in this department. He makes every class engaging and fun and I always leave class feeling like I learned something. He uses Discord to share important information about exams and projects. His exams aren't too bad, and if you go to his office hours and review sessions you will do fine

Easily best professor Ive had so far. Very ethical, in terms of making sure students know material. Not just do good on tests. Generally cares for each student, making sure they are excelling in class.

Jeremy is awesome and makes classes extremely easy and clear. His lectures are engaging and fun, he really breaks down the content, and genuinely wants everyone to get an A. If you want a professor who'll actually leave an impression and work with you, pick Grifski every time.

Jeremy is one of the best professors for this class he is understanding and willing to help you if you need it. He understands his students and how hard life and college can be. You can really see that he wants everyone to pass his class If you apply yourself and get the help when you need it you will be fine.

Jeremy is very friendly, helpful, and really wants everyone to get a good grade in SW1. He's always accessible outside of class on Discord and he's very flexible with attendance/deadlines. He's very engaged during lectures and you can tell he's passionate about what he teaches.

Geremy is an excellent professor who genuinely cares about his students' success. He utilizes Discord to provide prompt assistance outside of class and is always available to help. He emphasizes the importance of midterms and offers support to prepare. Reviewing the slides is highly recommended for exams.

Jeremy is easily the most helpful and engaging professor for SW1. He is very flexible and accessible, and does the best to make sure every student does the best they can in a class that is designed to weed people out. He also makes the content much more interesting through his group activities and lectures.

Jeremy is probably the best professor that I've had so far. He is super understanding and genuinely cares about his students. He is willing to give extensions on all assignments and does everything he can to make sure we succeed. Most of the negative things are about the course structure, and he was just as frustrated as we were about it.

I love Prof. Grifski. He is friendly, helpful, and wants you to succeed in the class. He and the graders are active in the class Discord, collects student statistics on exams and assignments, gives homework templates, and is flexible with attendance, deadlines, and giving points back. His section has a higher average grade than other sections.

Jeremy is the best professor I have had at OSU to date. He makes his own easy to understand lecture slides. He keeps statistics about how people did in his course. He provides homework templates for all homeworks. The passion that he has for teaching shows in his teaching style, enthusiasm and willingness to help students.
Jeremy took what the department had, and then made almost all of it better. Could not recommend enough.
Jeremy is really reachable professor. He is considerate to his students and willing to help students achieve their goal. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!!!

My grade in the class was my fault and could've easily been higher if I went to more of the classes.  Anytime I did attend class, Grifski was very helpful, he creates the slides and lectures himself and offers tons of resources on his discord.  He is easily reachable to ask any questions and answers them thoroughly. Highly recommend.
Super chill teacher. Really wants you to understand the actual concepts within Java. Will set you up for success!

Jeremy is the greatest professor I've ever met! He is so nice and indeed consider the whole things for student. I promise if you will be his student, you will learn a lot and maybe even love programming.

He is a very good professor that cares about his students and wants to see them do well. He teaches the content his own way which is really helpful because the department is mediocre slides for him to present.

Grifski was amazing. Super nice guy who genuinely cares about his students. He admits that Software I's curriculum and class structure is outdated and somewhat broken, but does his best to enable his students to succeed. He's also very passionate about computer science, which makes his lectures that much more enjoyable. 10/10 professor.

Jeremy was one of the best professors I ever had. He knows the Software 1 class sucks and that the course directors are trying to fail you, as a result, he tries his best to make sure you understand and succeed in the class. He is available outside of class, always answers questions, gives answers to the tests, and always willing to help you out.

Super nice, always trying to help the students by giving them credit here and there, gives lots of good advice when asked questions, lectures are fun and he lets students participate and go off topic a little, sympathizes with the students a lot on the annoying parts of the course, overall a super nice guy and a great professor

Easily one of the best professors, or instructors, I've ever had. The content was difficult and hard to keep up with at times, but he was extremely considerate and caring. The tests are a large percentage of the grade, which is my weakest point and nothing to do with Grifski.

Great teacher, tries his best to make a horribly written course easy to learn. Tries to set us up for success, good notes, easy to reach, but the exams are impossible. He understands how bad the software sequence is.

Jeremy really is a great guy. He cares about his students and relates to them very closely. He is there for you when you need him, and is more than willing to help you.  Any bad experience with Jeremy is due to the structure of the class through the department and not him. He tries to make the class less of a pain and succeeds.
