This class was extremely difficult and almost drove me to a point of insanity. Take another professor if you would like to actually learn the content.

A class that was meant to teach upcoming young software engineers was turned into a disaster. He made 100 hour per week labs worth 0.0005% of your grades and 2 impossible exams worth basically 100% of your grade. He is trying to "change the world" by weeding out like 80% of CS students.

Other reviews are robots and NPCs - If you are reading this Do not take this class it will throw off your entire four year schedule and graduation date. Save yourself and take Systems with another professor. No mercy on grading, projects, or tests. If you like spending 50 hours a week on projects and failing exams, take this- if not RUN

Professor Kirby is a great instructor overall. His lectures break down the content really well, making it easier to understand. While his labs can be challenging, as long as you put in the effort—even if you don't finish them—you'll still be fine. His tests are fair, and he's super chill when it comes to asking questions and getting help.

Professor Kirky is super engaging and makes lectures interesting with real-world examples. Exams are tough, but if you do the homework and go to office hours, you'll be fine. Be ready to do big labs.
Ignore the 1-star review, they probably failed the class or did not put in the work.
I failed this course due to the disgusting structure of the class. Shows absolutely no mercy

Projects that take 30 hours per week, but are only 2% of your grade. There are two exams that make up 70% of your grade. These exams ARE NOT EASY whatsoever! I have seen couple of my friends fail this course unfairly. I would avoid taking this class because this was easily the most irritating, difficult course I have taken in college.

Projects are extremely difficult yet only worth 10% of your grade so you will waste 25 hours on 2% of your grade, exams are 70% of your grade total with extremely tough grading. This class was extremely difficult to pass- professor doesnt round up anything DO NOT TAKE

Kirby is one of my favorite professors of all time. His lectures were super engaging and filled with actual industry experience which made them even better. He basically told the class what would be on the quizzes which made theme easy, and the project was graded very fairly. Also he was always willing to help outside of class. Amazing professor!

Professor Kirby is very good!  His lectures can be formulaic, but he knows his stuff for sure.  Labs are long, but honestly fine. First half of exams are from the slide decks and you'll know what to study after "review day". For how hard of a class people claim this to be, it never felt overly difficult and I feel good about my C and x86 knowledge.

Labs take a lot of time, but they help you learn a lot about how to code in C and Assembly. The exams are not hard if you complete the labs, and he prepares you really well for the exams. His lectures remind me of high school teachers because they are very interactive with the class, and they are effective in helping you learn the material.

I had Kirby for Sys1 and 3902. Kirby's class is HARD, but it is RARE to find someone who is a technical genius, an all-star educator, and a genuine human. His class is a gold mine for interview/career advice. He makes out of state tuition worth it. Take the hard route and please, do not pass on an opportunity to take his class. Go change the world!

Kirby knows this content like the back of his hand, and he really enjoys teaching it. Going to lecture he's able to turn the hardest CSE class at OSU into something digestable even for people with no prior C or Assembly knowledge. Lectures are content funny but also interactive and funny. He responds to questions on Piazza within a couple of hours.
Group based class but still made the lectures interesting and engaging.  Always willing to help outside of class, one of the better professors I have had in CSE.

Kirby is a really nice person and very enjoyable to listen to during class. There is a lot of material and hard to remember it all but coming to class everyday helps a lot. Kirby's labs are way brutal and way harder than other professors. On labs 2, 3, and 4 I spent over 20 hours. I highly recommend him and would take more classes with him.

Absolutely amazing professor. The lectures are fantastic and his energy and passion for the topics covered really shine through. As many have said, the labs can be time-consuming, but really help you get a solid understanding of the material and Kirby is more than willing to help during office hours. My favorite professor I've had at OSU.

BEST PROFESSOR EVER!!!!!! I had heard so many good things about him but I didnt believe it until I saw it! He is extremely articulate, and an all around amazing professor!!!!!! Just a really tough professor, and labs take 30 hours each, and youre lucky if you even get a 60% on them. Great professor tho, just really tough!

Kirby's labs are absolutely grueling (labs 2-6 easily take 15-25 hours each, with two weeks to complete them)... but his lectures are fantastic. If you show up to class and put time and effort into the homework/labs you will do well in this class. Definitely one of the best profs in the CSE department at OSU. But yeah, his labs SUCK.

He is probably the best professor I have had at OSU and certainly the best in the CSE department. He has very interesting lectures and very accommodating. His labs are challenging. You end up building a big project throughout the semester and he will challenge you to improve your skills as a programmer. Which I could take a class with him every sem
Some of those labs sucked my soul out. Despite this, the exams were pretty easy and Kirby is an awesome lecturer and super helpful and cool. He is the systems GOAT.

Kirby is very knowledgeable and a very kind and accommodating professor.

Class is very heavy on lectures and he covers a lot of content at once. He will clarify or slow down if you ask him too, though. Don't be afraid to ask questions. Labs are long and tedious but really do help you learn the content.

His lab's are long and awful. I had a lot of fun doing them and they helped me to truly understand the C and assembly content I needed for exams. He's such a great and caring person. Just study exactly what he tells you to, do the labs, and understand the homework's and the class should be easy. Always took forever but felt fair and doable.

Professor Kirby is the best Systems I Professor. If you have him you will realize he is such a G. A great human being and a great professor who actually cares and can actually teach. The labs are the most difficult of the class but he holds plenty of office hours and actually helps you with the lab and makes the content understandable.

Very good professor overall but the class is hard.
For labs, start early and go to his office hour
Exam is noncumulative and paper notes are allowed.
he gives out a lot of hints about whats on the exam
X86 assembly, I literally took his hints and implements for loop etc and printed it out, got A on the final

Kirby is an exemplary professor. Great lecturing skills, helpful advice in and outside of class, and complete knowledge of his subject material. My favorite part about him is that he will take time out of his day to just have a conversation with you. Oh by the way, find a group of competent programmers for this class or you're screwed.

Professor Kirby has been the most amazing professor that I've taken at OSU! He's a funny guy who cares for his students. While the class itself is hard, he makes it very manageable and fair. Overall W Prof. You'll walk out as a better programmer if you take his class. Just be aware to start the labs early and show up to class and you'll do great!

I absolutely loved Professor Kirby's Sys. 1 class. It is a very difficult class, but as long as you show up and put in the work, you will do amazing. He has these little knowledge checks where he asks short questions for everyone to respond and it was the most engaging zoom class I've ever had. He made me love systems.

Prof Kirby is amazing. His class is definitely more involved with the labs than other sections of the same class with different profs. The labs are hard no doubt and they are not worth much of the final grade, but if you do them you will be very prepared for the final. I did not think the final was too hard because I had gone through and done labs.

Kirby is a wonderful lecturer, and really cares about his students. For Systems 1, the class was very lab heavy, so be prepared to put hours in outside of class. The content isn't easy but he makes sure that you understand it. He was super helpful in office hours, and was pretty flexible with the grading structure when he made mistakes. Great prof.
Overall great professor. Care about the students and the quality of teaching. Give great feedbacks.

Fr my favorite professor I have had. He has the relevant experience to teach the course and makes every lecture exciting. You will get an A in this course if you do what is expected of you and do all the group work needed, which is a significant amount, but is easily doable considering it is all this course has. Take this class with him if you can.

Receiving a good grade IS possible but you have to be willing to put in the work (ie writing every slide deck line by line). Labs take some time, but there's an early bonus. Office hours help a lot if you get stuck. Homework and In-Class assignments are free points. Midterm & Final are heavily weighted so study!

Professor Kirbys class is probably the hardest class I have had, but one of my favorites. The labs are difficult but rewarding once you are done. He is very clear in his lectures and repeats topics that are very important. Some of the other sections might be an easier A but if you want to be the best I would totally recommend his section.

The labs will basically suck the soul out of you (6 of them spaced out that each take around 15-25 hours of work total) but get past that and the exam-heavy grade weighting and Kirby is one of the best lecturers I have ever had. Very approachable, very smart, and obviously learned a lot in industry if you ever get the chance to pick his brain.

Professor Kirby is an amazing instructor, and despite some warnings you may have heard (some of which are true), he is always there to help and will help you through the course if you ask for it. He will always make sure people are in good shape, but please please please do his labs and study for the midterm. You will thank yourself later.

The lab in his course is all created by him, and it will take a long time for you to do. There is a total of 6 labs, and lab 2, 3, 4 will take about 20 hours (for me it took 30). Be sure to attend the class and understand the detailed part of his lecture. Overall, he tries to help students and answers all the questions that students asked.
If you don't want to ruin your whole semester, you'd better walk away from this professor. Don't say I didn't warn you.

Really caring and nice professor who wants you to succeed and will go out of his way for you, that being said his section is nearly impossible to get an A in unless you work on personal C projects in your spare time on top of the insane labs he assigns, albeit fun. Many drop after the first and only midterm worth 30% of your grade. Study everyday.

The C labs were difficult. Professor Kirby intentionally obfuscates the lab requirements to make them harder to read and more like real life requests.. they aren't step-by-step instructions for a good grade. Some things in the course seem antiquated. The assembly section was fun and far easier than the C section. Go to class and ask for help!

Great professor, please go to lectures, if you don't you won't pass. The labs are pretty long but definitely doable, if you go to his office hours he'll help you debug and basically teach you how to do it. I loved his lectures, he's pretty funny too. Some of the exam stuff is pretty specific but I would say it's all fair.

This professor is terrible. You will spends a lot of time on labs and can not even get 5 points. It's almost impossible to get even a C- in this class. Also, really suspicious and easy to regard you as misconduct.

His class is much harder. If you take other major courses at the same semester, don't take his class. It's EXTREMELY time consuming. I admit that he's passionate and willing to help, but that doesn't mean anything compared to the difficulty of the class. Besides, don't expect him to understand your excuse even if it's real. Final warning: CAREFUL!
Standing there as if he is Steven Jobs. However, Kirby only matches Jobs in a negative way.

He teaches to a high standard, and the class overall is difficult, so people like to hate him. However, I really liked him. ZERO busywork. Labs worth very little but you WILL will do better on the exams if you do them. Not an easy A, but he has VERY clear expectations and 100% knows what he's talking about. Loves to flex that he has a Tesla.

My least favorite class at OSU. He makes simple concepts seem impossible and cannot write comprehensive directions. IMPOSSIBLE LABS, expects you to spend 30-40 hours on them (just get some of the points on the rubric and move on). Make sure to get all points on hw/in-class, they are each worth as much as a lab. Exams are not straightforward.
Excellent professor, great class.

Incredible instructor. Very, very knowledgeable about the course material. I'd consider myself much more skilled than my classmates in terms of programming knowledge, yet his labs gave me a really hard time. If you invest in his class, it'll pay off big time. Go to him seeking help and he will do his best to help you succeed.
Kirby is the best professor I've seen so far. His homework is hard but he very likes to help and would hold additional office hour. Take his class, if you would like to learn more!
Labs and Test are hard, but he is willing to help and available almost everyday. Test is hard, but as long as you spent the effort, you should be end up with a good grade.
nobody can get aeven hard to get c
If you're an international student, drop this class, you won't pass.

Attendance is not mandatory but if you skip lecture you'll fail. He's alright, pretty nice and smart guy, accessible almost everyday. However, many labs of his section is nearly UNDOABLE, but labs just a small trunk of grade. Overall I don't say people should avoid him, but his section makes life harder. His final exam kills everyone.
He is new to here, so not very good at lecture, but really willing to help.

Prof. Kirby is a solid guy. BUT this course is tough. Expect to learn SQL code without much help from him (I relied on youtube). His exam reviews are very broad and don't help much. His lectures are dry, his explanations of things are very complex. Youtube helps dummy it down. Basically rely on teaching yourself 50% of the info in the course

Instructor Kirby is a relative new instructor but he is very passionate about CSE. He might go on tangents if he has had to much caffeine. Exams were fair and assignments were relatable to what was said in class. Very generous for HW and In class assignments, Labs were different. If given the chance, TAKE HIM. He is one of the better instructors!
Took this class in Au23, great course though far more difficult than analogous courses. Only take this if you are willing and able to put a lot of work in. Makes you a far more capable programmer.

The three labs are an absolute nightmare if you don't have competent group members. Giles is a pretty mid lecturer but is a nice guy. The lecture material is very dense which results in the exams being quite difficult. I was really excited about this class coming into the semester but unfortunately I don't know if it's worth taking over CSE 3901/2.

Group based class and you don't really get to choose your group. His lectures can be unclear but willing to clarify and provide extra help if you need it. Projects can be confusing so start early if you can. Exams can be hard but he's lenient on grading if you talk to him with your concerns.

Took CSE 3903 with him. Pretty awful class. Far far too much writing and he gives really annoying exams and graded extremely harshly. I spent a whole semester learning about a made up system. What was I thinking taking this class. It's literally designed to be worse, less practical, harder, and more time consuming than 3901 or 3902. Stay away.

Bad lecture
Useless web framework

Groups are assigned via catme survey. You do not choose. Work load varies based on the group. Projects are stimulating. Lectures are EXTREMELY dense and I typically retained <20% of what he lectured on. However I still learned the most from this class compared to any other, due to self-learning/troubleshooting outside of class to complete projects.

Lectures can be dense, especially in the hour and a half format. Class is not terribly hard, dependent a lot on group work. He is willing to give help and is quite good at it. Wouldn't take again since I do not like web dev.

Charlie is a super chill down to earth guy and makes this class very enjoyable. This class is very group project heavy, and your group will have a pretty big impact on how this class turns out. Exams are fair and 80% is considered an A- in this class.

Take Charlie if you can. Takes a generally hard class and makes it as easy to understand as possible. Fair grading of labs/finals. If you go to every class and pay attention you will have no problems.

Very good professor.  Only teaches 560 in the summer(has for the past 8 years). Works for Sterling-Commerce as a Java Programmer.  His Midterms and final were hard, but they both had curves(10+points or more).  Would take 560 in Summer again.

Overall, a very good teacher who cares a lot about the material. The Exams were straightforward and as long as you attend class there should be no reason to have anything less than a B. For such a work-intensive course, he made it relatively fun and easy. I would take other classes from Charles if he taught them.

Very nice guy. Curved the midterm by 12 points and brought everyones final grade up a notch(B- to B) His exams are pretty straight forward, as long as you have an understanding of the lecture slides. He can get confusing at times because he tends to go back and forth on topics, making mistakes and correcting himself along the way.

Just took our midterm for this class… what a joke. Our section has about 15 students and ~5 show up to class. Virtually no midterm review and he did not show up for the exam (another prof gave us the exam). He is a nice guy but a horrendous professor. He does not understand the content and has painfully boring lectures. Just avoid if you can.
awful lectures, hard exams, No TA hired, obscure PowerPoints.

Most of the issues this semester were because he wasn't given a grader. Despite the number of assignments, he gave us HW and exam answers and graded the HWs on completion. Super understanding and receptive when we asked for extensions or curves and dropped the lowest exam score. Would def take him again with a grader.

Dr. Ilin is easily the worst professor I have had at OSU thus far. The dude does not know what he talking about and his slides were frequently incorrect. Also he doesn't hold any office hours and nothing was graded until 1 week left in the semester. He didn't even give us paper to take our exams on. Apparently that's not in the COE budget anymore.

Random pop quizzes, almost infeasible programming assignments, sometimes condescending. Dr. Ilin isn't a professor I could personally recommend. His exams are in-person and all of the questions are back-to-back, so be ready to bring your own scrap paper to write your answers down on as there won't be room on the actual exam sheet.

I had the chance to take Dr. Ilin for CSE 2321 during the SP18 term, and I was super excited to find out he would be my 3521 professor. Dr. Ilin is an incredibly passionate lecturer. If you literally just go to class and pay attention, you will be fine. 3521 is more conceptual than, say, 2321, so you have more freedom to show your knowledge.
He gave heavy programming assignments. And when we had questions on the assignment, he couldn't answer. It turns out that those assignments are copied. Worst lecturer I have ever had.
Roman is a nice guy, but he grades very, very harsh. Use the wrong variable typing? 0. He'll fail your assignment for not using a variable he didn't even tell you existed. Avoid at all costs.
GreatTeach more difficult than other professor but it is clear and useful!

Ilin teaches the concepts well and is extremely helpful. The tough part about the class is his testing style, where he tests over small points rather than the general concept. In addition, his grading is very stingy. This results in relying on a curve to do well. Lastly, he doesn't have office hours, which makes this class even tougher than it is.

He teaches the concepts, but will only do the most basic examples or none at all. His homework/quiz/exam questions are either too extreme, different, or abstract compared to the examples he does. He said he would curve the average to a B-, but I can't confirm because he didn't even post the final (as well as several pop quizzes) on Carmen.

Terrible professor. No office hours, and he makes his exams far more difficult then other professors. He didn't even show up for our final. He claims he gives extra credit for attendance but he only took attendance twice. Pop quizzes are random and harshly graded. It's sad OSU employs this low quality professor. His "curve" doesn't help at all.

I would recommend another professor if you have the option. His lectures are good, but his exams are too abstract and difficult. Much lower averages than other profs. Pop quizzes are harshly graded as well. His exams don't cover half the material you learn, so they can be frustrating. He doesn't post notes and doesn't offer office hours.

Roman is one of those professors that very much prefers to test over the tiny details and minor concepts covered, rather than overarching main ideas. The exams are hard and averages are much lower than other sections. He is GREAT at teaching the main concepts, he just doesn't test over them.

I found Ilin to be a good professor. He articulated the information during lectures clearly, and I genuinely felt like I learned a lot from Foundations 1.   His exams are fair, and some of the content can be difficult if you don't spend the time to learn it on your own. I wouldn't miss lecture either, as he doesn't post his notes online.
Lecture for this class was so incredibly boring, and she was not very helpful.
Her lectures are incredibly dull and go on for ages. If you are taking this class, skip the lectures, and watch a YouTube video on the topic, you'll save yourself an hour and a headache.

Youtube will be your best friend because she overcomplicates everything but as long as you know the functions and how to use them you'll be more than fine for labs and tests. If you do struggle during labs, the TAs are very helpful. She reads directly off the slides but she welcomes questions so take advantage of that.

Genuinely one of the worst instructors I have ever encountered at this university. Her course is horribly boring, she drones on with little room for questions and hardly ever stops to insure that students understand where the functions and information is coming from, if you can take this course somewhere else or with a different professor do it.

Directions are terrible for the most part. Some pre/labs took ridiculous amount of time, but manageable. Some more confusing topics were not explained thoroughly-had to teach myself quite a few things. I'm not good with computers, but don't think this class had to be as stressful as Grimme made it. Easy enough class, but really disliked the prof.

Overall an outstanding professor. Explains everything very thoroughly, as everything from the lectures is what shows up in the prelab/inlab/ exams so they are not overly difficult. Is always willing to answer questions, and really wants students to do well in the class, as this class will be really helpful, especially the excel portion.
Never once posted a key for pre-labs or in class labs, so you never know why you are getting points taken off of assignments, and doesn't give clear grading criteria.

She has a horrible attitude. She is very snippy when you ask a simple question, yelled at students for small things such as grabbing papers, or signing in before she was ready for you to do so. Rarely was able help with questions, and grades hard.

The class is composed of lecture and labs. If you go to lecture, do the pre-lab on time and do the lab you will be okay for the midterm and final. This class can be time consuming so spend time studying and reviewing. Overall a doable class, A is possible if you follow the syllabus and show up.
Cindy is great at explaining concepts and will always help if you need it. The class itself is pretty simple if you attend lectures and do your pre-labs!

Cindy was a good professor for this class. She runs her lectures and labs by following the slides and instructions closely, so it can be a little bit slow at times. But she is very helpful if you ask her questions one-on-one. The class is broken down into very managable lectures and labs.

Thought this class would be more difficult but Cindy is super helpful and breaks content down really well. Labs are more useful than the actual lectures and the midterm/finals are not bad if you study.

The class is ok I guess, if you don't know excel and access the class is beneficial but I feel like I learned more from the labs than the lecture itself. But the lecture isn't all useless. Easy class if you know your excel functions and basic access stuff it all pertains to the labs so if you know those you'll get an A. Super laid back overall.
Very nice person, boring lectures, but he does try to help students understand.  Assignments are tough, but if you ask for help he'll be really helpful.

Neelam is a very nice guy and his class is not too difficult. As long as you go to like 1 out of every 3 lectures, you're bound to get all of the information from the other 2 lectures you missed because he tends to go over the same slides multiple times. If you put in a decent amount of effort on the projects, you will do fine in this class.
Probably the few CSE classes I took where I left the class completely understanding what I learned. Records his lectures but I recommend attending regardless.
Dr. Neelam is a super nice professor, I would recommend.

The epitome of bad teaching. Easy A, but if you want to learn something valuable because you payed for college, this man is not it. He spends an entire day on a single slide, and speaking of slides, they are actually the worst I have ever seen. He moves way too slow because he is horrible at teaching the subject matter so he has to move slower. 0/5

First things off, he is not the boogieman I've seen people make him out to be. Pretty average professor actually and seems to be easy on his students. Projects are a lot of work but logic isn't too bad are actually pretty easy in comparison to other professor's principles projects. A little rude when helping students but it might just be his humor.

I was searching online for his slides (to review something for my work) and randomly come to this page. I don't why there are many negative reviews about this professor. When I was a graduate student at OSU and took his CS6341 programming language class (in 2015), I really enjoyed the class and learned a lot.

I absolutely get why people don't like him, his lecture style is a bit weird, and the slides say little to nothing on their own. But if you're willing to listen, he's incredibly passionate about what he teaches. The reward curve for this course is like a positive parabola, little improvement is seen at first, but dedication pays back in power.
Barely answers questions
Hardest professor to understand in among all the classes. Changing the grading policy on the very last day for grades to go in the registrar. Literally curving your grade down.

Changed the grading scale after the final exam from 92.8% being an A to 95.4% being an A. The scale that he posts after the midterm is 92.8% to get an A, he changed that scale to 95.4% almost on the last day of the semester!!!!!!!

One of the worst professors I met. Really heavy accent, you literally wouldn't understand what he says. The most disappointing thing is that he changed the grading rubric on the final day of the semester, from 93% to 95.4% to get A.

Mumbling lectures, logicless slides, heavy accents, and downgrading everyone after the final. That says it all. Awful. Plus, my previous rating got deleted. Obviously someone didn't like my comment haha...

For some reason, some bad comments disappeared. The rating you see is not the real rating!! Check the time for these posts. These are like comments from 10 years ago. And the course number even are not the same. DO NOT CHOOSE THIS PROFESSOR!

His grading scale is different than other professors in the school. To reach an A, you have to get 95% at least. So basically he curves down the letter grade for all the class. I did learn something from the class, but mostly by myself from the note he posted and google.

Fantastic Professor. Lectures are very interesting and tries to make lecture interactive. One of the few professors to make effective use of the board. As long as you pay attention to his class you should be good.

Everything in this class is based around his lectures so don't skip them. Is good about open class discussions, but sometimes his code in the slides has errors so you have to be careful about that. Overall a reasonable grader.

One of my favorite professors. He really knows the material well and takes the time to make sure you will, too. Have to come to class; he will give you his slides, but real material is just spoken. Homework load is light. As long as you pay attention, you should be fine.

Very knowledgeable but in limited areas. Asked students meaning of code on his own slides. Wants students to learn but will carry on for an entire class reviewing the same slide/topic. Exam reviews are only semi-helpful. Exams are concept heavy and you must know intimate details and be able to apply concepts very well. Does not post notes online.

Great Prof! He really knows his stuff and is genuinely interested in the learning of the students. He goes slow initially allowing the students to grab the basics of this course as strongly as possible. He is always willing to help students if you contact him either in office hours or thru email.

Very boring class. It is a total waste of graduate student's time. The professor rambles on and on without making the basic point. The course itself is antiquated and irrelevant. Slides and examples are childish but he starts asking real problems in the exam! He's never sure of what he's saying and keeps saying "I may be right/I think i'm right"

One of the best CSE professor's I've taken. The only thing is that he tests over stuff he talks about in class, and usually the details are in the slides so you have to go to class and pay attention. I would really recommend taking a class with him.

For anyone who has paid attention in any previous class his 655 course will be total review. Just try and stay awake cause all he wants on exams is for you to spit back what he says in short answer form. His labs and homeworks are straightforward. The problem is staying awake through all the reivew

His homeworks are a little tricky, his labs are quite tricky, and the exams are tough too.  He is a good lecturer and a good person.  He really explains the material very well and is VERY knowledgeable about the subject.  I would recommend taking 655 with him.
Great teacher, class was somewhat complicated, but he took the time to help and explain when it was needed.
Good professor. Explains things clearly. Gives lots of useful examples.

One of the handful best profs in the department! Only a little accent, can understand perfectly. Explains the material a lot, homeworks reflect lectures and the most important: he has a passion for the subject. You can see him getting exited about teachin
He will add his own experience using the material and good ways to be able to find the answers you need, versus just reciting back the way to do it. He is very personable and always willing to help.

I liked the fact that he showed enthusiasm and excitement when certain milestones or aspects of code or other features in the class that were new to us students were revealed to us, as if he was discovering new things with us at the same time. For example, first time some html code was executed and showed up in a browser.
Took his data analytics course for 6 months and it was worth it in the end
Wasn't sure what the course would be like but Grant was very helpful in knowing that it would be a lot but he took his time with teaching every step of the way. Had a great time!
Very kind and caring. Always ready to help those who have issues understanding.

By far the best professor i've had during my time at Ohio State. If you want to learn data analytics and have a professor that cares about your grade, take the bootcamp. This class would be extremely difficult without the help of grant. He will go as fast or as slow as you need and will help answer any questions you have along the way.

Highly recommend Grant! I gave his class a 4/5 difficulty rating simply because I've never taken a class like this before (not from a computer science background) - I'm sure other people in this course would have said it was easier! He was very patient with newcomers to the computer science world and was great at giving productive feedback. 10/10
He is very good at explaining what he talks about.

Grant is an outstanding educator who genuinely cares about his students. He is incredibly kind and understanding, always willing to go the extra mile. Rather than just giving us the answers, he teaches us how to find them ourselves. His patience, especially when answering multiple questions, is commendable. I highly recommend taking his class!

Awesome instructor, extremely knowledgeable on the subject. Goes above to help you understand the material and topics you are stuck on. Always accessible outside of class, will respond in the group chat outside of office hours/class. Super friendly, kind, nice and caring. You can tell he truly loves what he does! definitely recommend and take again

Grant is an excellent teacher. I have always found him to be very patient and helpful to students. He is knowledgeable about the subject matter and good at explaining even the most difficult concepts. There is never a dull moment in his class. I would take his class anytime and recommend others to take as well.

Grant is a great teacher. He genuinely wants everyone to understand and succeed. He watches for cues of confusion vs clarity. If you don't show that you actually understand a concept then he will find another way to explain it. He has an uncanny ability to sense when your ADHD brain begins to zone out and immediately refocuses the class. *nongraded
provides late feedback holds students to usa govt standards while not following the rubric provided by university, doesn't not understand  student issues
Talk fast, didn't care weather the student understand him. A little skeptical on Asians.
Talk fast, and sometimes blur what he said.
talk too fast, can't really catch what he's sayin
Awesome, very easy to pay attention to.
No Comments

Don't take with him if you are new to this topic. Boring lecture and not helpful. Only reading off from the slides with blank in the keywords and unwilling to offer the complete version of slides even it was copied from previous semester. Never answer your question after class. Homework and exams are difficult, irrelevant to lecture.

New at teaching. She has good intention and wants everyone to learn but sometimes the way she taught wasn't very clear. Very accessible outside class and willing to help. Large curve, helpful review session and could bring many cheat sheets to exam. Remember to really review your linear algebra and probability before any AI courses.

He's completely honest and cuts out all the useless information in slideshows. He gives great internship advice and cracks jokes during his lectures. He's great at explaining difficult concepts and gives amazing review material for midterms. Honestly, he's just great at teacher: easy to talk to, helpful, and knowledgeable.

For the midterm and final, he offered extra credit for drawing something funny on the first page. And gave 5-10 extra minutes cause why not. He spends 25-50% of classes having funny conversations with students and still manages to teach all the material. Exams and homework are easy, only 1-2 labs are difficult. Best CS professor I've had.

He is the best professor I have ever had for CSE classes. He is funny, super knowledgeable and really helpful. His exams are really fair, and his office hours are really great, he will help you with all the questions you have, most of the time.

Best lecturer I've had in the CSE department by far. He knew the answer to even the most obscure questions about the material and communicated it thoroughly. This class made me feel like getting a degree really was more valuable than just self-teaching programming. 

Homeworks were long but very educational. Exams were hard but not unfair.

Very young and fun professor willing to share a lot of knowledge about operating systems, he really knows his stuff. He also talks about real world applications and gives real career advice. Exams aren't too hard, but the third lab seems to destroy everyone. Study decently and you will do fine though.
This class taught me so much about OS and systems in general. I came in with just intro level knowledge and now feel like i have a pretty deep understanding of how systems work.
He is one of the best lecturers that I have had. The content of the class is somewhat advanced but the course is not very hard. I really got a lot out of this class.
Respectful!

Old-school lectures, a term paper, an essay based final. Relaxed and knowledgeable. Has been teaching this course for like 50 years, which works well for providing a wider, longer-term perspective on computing.
a really good professor! really knows the material!
Best and most helpful professor
Lots of assignments. His materials are hard to read.

Dr. Lai's lectures are good and really funny because he likes repeating things to emphasize it. He encourages you to think on your own. There is only homework (we only had 8 graded because we ran out of time for the last 2), two midterms, and a final. So it's pretty mandatory to do well on the tests.

I took Algorithms with Prof Lai and he was honestly great. The material is hard but he is very knowledgeable. People blame his accent for their poor performance but I think this a bit stupid. He is tough and you have to work. Let go of your ego when you take this class.
Amazing Professor, took his class before. This is a one of best professor you can have in CSE, he explain the subject really well, and teach really clearly.

Overall an informative class. The prof is understandable, but occasionally if you ask a question he seems to misunderstand. He gives info while lecturing that isn't on the slides, so you have to pay attention to get everything. Homeworks are basically effort-based, then exams are slightly easier questions but graded thoroughly.

Homework and exams can be very hard. He never tells you definite and accurate answers to your questions. If you ask unrelated questions, he could be very impatient.  Do pay attention to his discussions in classes, which may not be in his slides. Because he likes to ask those "as we talked in class" questions in exams, which can be very tricky.

He teaches well, but you have to really concentrate in his class. Its easy to find yourself drifting away for a couple mins in his class and by then you've almost pretty much lost the entire class, as there is little chance you'll get your focus back. Easy grader compared to the other Algo Profs.
Very good professor , learn a lot
Worst professor at The Ohio State University

Contrary to some of the other commenters, Dr. Lai is not difficult to understand due to his Chinese accent, he is difficult to understand because the material he presents is genuinely difficult. That said, Dr. Lai's lectures are engaging and enlightening given the inherent complexity of the subject material.

If you attend his lectures and do things his way which is what he wants, you will get a good grade, otherwise you will really hurt his ego  bad. In exams, beware of questions like "As we discussed in class, ...". He is incomprehensible, though he tries hard; beware of Chinese students who practice all his old exam papers and do well.
Lectures are pointless.  He rambles and gives terrible explanations. Homeworks are very hard, but fairly graded.
All round good guy.  Text not needed--he has well preped slides.  Hmwks relatively easy.  Tests harder--learn all the stuff on slides well & be able to apply to a "new" situation.

He's a funny guy and a pretty good teacher. The material is simple. His test questions are "algorithm riddles" to make sure you that you truly understand the material, and aren't just regurgitating solutions from memory. Make sure you understand EVERYTHING in the handouts.
this class isn't hard, you don't need the book.  his tests aren't easy but they certainly aren't difficult.  just make sure you go to class and try and understand what he says
Not that bad a teacher, but the tests are very hard.  Office hours are useless because he doesnt wanna "reveal the answer"
Lectures not very helpful.
best cse professor I have had. He keeps you entertained, and it's an incredibly boring subject(algorithms).
This class was highly entertaining. Prof. Lai is a good instructor and a likes taking the "i know everything" students down a peg or two. Highly recommended...
You hardly learn anything in this course. Scope of the course material is very-very narrow; lectures lack rigor and content. Not at all recommended.

He has a problem with his pronunciation and some speaking issues. You can't make out some of the words he utters, and he keeps repeating words which makes his lectures very painful. Course material is far too easy for a grad level course: I had learnt much more in my undergrad course.

Prof. Chao is a nice guy but not the best professor in my opinion. He would often assign us homework on content we hadn't even discussed in class yet, prompting the homework deadlines to be delayed by 1-2 days last minute. The class just kind of felt like a sh*t show to be honest. His exams were also quite difficult, especially the second midterm.

Lectures are good and professor is willing to work with students. Often extends deadlines for homework. Exams are tough but aren't unfair--if you do the homework and understand it you will be prepared. Lectures are not recorded. Homework requires a lot of work but isn't "hard". Probably my new favorite professor in the CSE department.

Best CSE professor you could get at OSU, very smart and knows how to teach. Homework could be a lot and difficult so work on them as early as possible. Bonus problems on the exam with hints. As long as you pay attention to the lecture and go to office hour frequently you should be fine.

He is an awesome professor, either inside or outside the classroom. Homework and quiz need more attention, which are the base for the final exam. I am working with him as undergraduate researcher, and he is really patient and inspirational. Take course with this guy:)!!

Super math heavy. Class attendance is a must, the slides aren't enough on their own. Lots of derivations and theory in my opinion. Cool and often fun homeworks. Exams can be pretty tough. Cheat sheets are allowed, but grading is very strict, small mistakes on exams can add up very quickly. You can tell he is very passionate about what he's teaching
The GOAT of a professor. Easily the best I've ever had. If you are here to learn, take him. Lectures and homework are extremely useful. Very knowledgeable and devoted to helping students.

One of the worst professors Ive ever had at Ohio State. Very tough grader and extremely inconsiderate to the needs of students. Doesnt really have much of a personality and just goes by the book. The man is literally a computer and doesnt have tolerance for mistakes. Stay away from him.

His lecture was easy, but since it was his first semester teaching it, he was disorganized. He is always worried about legal consequences. Does not reply to emails. only a few labs, each one worth 5 percent. he never replied to my midterm because I took that at SLDS, which was quite unfair. The Midterm was easy, but the final was hard! Cool guy tho

Lectures can be dry/confusing because he doesn't follow the slides so you might have to self-study, but his labs are easier than other profs'. Exams are too, if you use the provided study materials and understand the labs, and he's a nice grader. There is a textbook but it's unnecessary. I wouldn't exactly recommend him but he made the class easy.
His lectures were interesting. Accessible outside of the class.
Has great knowledge over the subject.

Made an interesting topic into an even more interesting class. Sense of humor is fantastic and is an all around phenomenal person that's not only super enthusiastic about their own work, but also with helping students, both with the class content and outside of it. He singlehandedly made this class my favorite that I've taken at OSU.

Amazing professor. The class was very interesting and mainly project based. There *are* a lot of projects (6 ish) and some take while to complete, but you usually get 1.5-2 weeks to do them. As long as you can keep up with the pace of the class, you'll be fine. Responds to emails quickly. Very sarcastic and funny guy too. There was a small curve.

Be ready to "implement" the concepts. Attend the lectures with full understanding and you'll be fine. Clear your doubts as soon as possible. Best professor I ever have seen. Extraordinarily knowledgeable. Sarcastic and nerdy humor. Always ready to solve your doubts. Stimulates thinking.

A professor with a good (and slightly sarcastic) sense of humor. Explains things in great detail. Encourages student participation in class. The project is worth half of the grade, but participating in classes makes that easy. Homework and the midterm has the same level of difficulty. Final was much harder, the questions would make you think a lot.

He teaches the subject well. He has a lot of knowledge in this particular field. Most times this leads to him going off on tangents about unrelated stuff in class. But his lectures are good and attending them makes it easy on the finals. The subject is boring. No doubt about that. But I would say that's mainly because of the syllabus is structured.

The guy is incredibly knowledge, but is far more interested in his own work than teaching. Going to office hours is useless and make sure you skim the midterm and final because he purposely tries to screw you over by putting long problems early (some require multiple pages of coding), though questions are easy. A lot of work. Pick someone else.

Very interesting class. Explanatory, organized, clear, excellent slides and handouts. He's clearly knowledgeable in his area of expertise (programming languages and compilers). A bit hard but very fun and useful project. You can easily ace the exams if you listen to his teaching and you carefully study his slides. Highly recommended!

This teacher is by far the worst teacher I have had a Ohio State, as a CSE major it sucks when you get a teacher as bad as him. His midterms suck, take this class with mathias he is a much better teacher. Rountevs office hours are absolutely useless good luck getting any help he will give you none.
Obviously knowledgeable about the subject and is quick to respond when help is needed, but the class comes off boring and the grading is VERY strict.

His project is the hardest.  For one week of your life, your going to spend 40+ hours writing an interpreter exacatly how he wants it.  Gives NO partial credit on tests and instructs the grader to , from the syllabus "liberally take off points."  Take it with Mathis if you can, and avoid the project.  CarCdrCar(I hate this class)

Most boring subject in the world.  Clear examples given in class (so most people didn't ever see them), minimal book usage.  Allows a cheat sheet on exams.  For the cheat sheet, shrink his slides onto a page w/ ms publisher you'll be fine (code examples and all that).  Test q's strongly resemble hw q's.  No studying needed if you pay attn in class.
Hated this class with a passion. It was painful to sit through. Although, to the professor's credit, it was mostly because of the subject material.
No Comments
No Comments
He sucks. Really bad teacher. His explanations are ridiculous. His grading scheme is very strict and his workload is huge. Definitely sucks!
Great Professor. Love his teaching style.  I learned and enjoyed the class. Attendance was not required, class video recording were uploaded also. Easy grading.

Thought he did a good job teaching the class. Assignments were reasonable, forgiving "OOPS" tokens for late work, and got to sample many different fields of AI. There was also a good balance of theoretical lectures/ assignments and more practical coding assignments.

Prof. Su is a nice teacher, but is still getting in the swing of teaching. He has good intentions, but sometimes it wasn't clear what he expected us to know for the exams, or what needed to be done on the homework assignments. I know he's still new to being a professor, and I'm sure he'll only get better from here.
Awesome guy!

Dr. Heym is the best Professor I have EVER had! Software 2 can be hard, no doubt, but Heym explains things well, is excited to teach, and knows his material inside and out. He is happy to make time to meet with students, is kind and empathetic, and really tries to help you do more than just pass. Ignore any negative review about him, seriously.

Wayne Heym is one the hardest professors to communicate with. In lecture and even out of lecture when you try to go to office hours for help. He just repeats the same statements over and over again and if you do not understand he just is not able to explain anything in a different manner.

I LOVE DR. HEYM!!! He was so incredibly helpful, accessible, and caring. I went to his office hours a ton.
Lectures are a bit boring and the material is hard but Dr. Heym cares about his students and their learning. Highly recommend him for software 2

He's one of the better professors than some of the other options for this class. Clearly cares about students and their overall success and is willing to help whenever you need it. Software is standardized and its difficult no Matter what but Heym is one solid choice.

I had to learn most of the concepts on my own. Is not a great teacher as he spends a lot of time during the lecture socializing. There is no textbook, so you have to be solely dependent on slides. If you want to do good in CSE 2231: SW2 then dont take his class. I had to do everything without any resources from him to get my A.

A lot of people tend to have negative comments on CSE 2231 as a course due to the amount of homework and tough concepts. With Dr. Heym, this class was very doable. It isn't very easy but it isn't too hard either. Dr. Heym has a passion for teaching and ensuring his students understand the concepts. If you take him, you are in good hands.

Nicest professor you'll ever meet! Very patient with his student and you can tell he really gets hyped up by what he teaches. Exams are pretty predictable and fair. Just make sure you understand the homeworks.

Wayne is a great professor! I really enjoyed having him for this class. He was super helpful with any questions, and all of the assignments (exams/homework/labs) were straightforward. He also was a very nice grader which I appreciated. I would definitely want to take another class with him in the future!
Dr. Heym is a very caring and friendly professor. He is extremely helpful during office hours. Exams are fair and really test your understanding of the course materials. Would take again.

Very good option for software 2. His lectures are just okay, some of them felt useless, but some were useful for projects and exams. Outside of that, he is incredibly friendly. Will never make you feel dumb, great at answering any questions and very smart. Also grades exams fairly. Our section also had a small curve, I went from a B- to a B.

Dry lectures and insane amount of HW. Wayne is incredibly nice and helpful. The class is difficult. He is one of the easier professors to take for SW2. Concepts are telegraphed for exams but they do require focus and diligence when studying and working on projects. Would take again, would study more!

One of the nicest professors I have ever met. One of the few teachers who made me feel cared for. He is easily accessible outside class in office hours. His midterms are hard though. Although he will tell you what to study, he will test you on smallest of concepts so make sure you have a clear idea of what you are studying. Ask questions in class.

I took him a year ago and his lectures were not great. He expected you to have reviewed the slides ahead of class and come with questions prepared. Often got lost trying to explain a concept but could convey enough for me to follow. Not a bad professor you just need to be able to think for yourself and ask questions if you are going to do well.

Professor Heym is a very reasonable grader and cares a lot about his students. The exams were pretty tough, but he always gives you an idea of what will be on the exams beforehand and the class was curved. Definitely one of the best CSE professors and a great choice for software 2.

I wouldn't have wanted to take SW2 with anyone else. It's a tough class, but he makes it manageable. He is an ideal teacher. He takes his time to learn everyone's names, offers great feedback, is encouraging and easy to approach, offers fair exams, and provides excellent office hours. One of the nicest teachers I have ever had.

Dr. Heym is super passionate and helpful, especially in lab and office hours. He spends a lot of time in lecture going beyond the course content and doesn't waste time reading slides. SW2 is a little repetitive and dry sometimes and the midterms were tough. His lecturing style isn't for everyone but definitely seek 1-1 help if needed.

Dr. Heym is one of the best CSE professors I have had. He is very accessible outside of class, and he is very helpful during office hours. I can't really speak for any of the other software lecturers, but Dr. Heym is definitely a good choice.

He's an alright choice but has a tendency to start rambling and going on tangents during lecture, making it hard to focus and learn.  Luckily, because it's software 2, all material is available online.  He's very helpful and an awesome guy outside of class though (as well as more easygoing with grading than other SWII profs).

This being a department wide class, it is very challenging. But, Heym is very caring and open to meeting outside of class to help you solidify your understanding of the material. It's better to start sooner than later with office hours. He cares about his students.

Possibly my favorite professor Ive had at OSU. Lectures mostly around student questions. Dude is very passionate about computer science. I can't recall being bored in class once. Exams are fair but definitely not easy. Only complaint I can come up with is that his voice is mellow so you could fall asleep if your class is early. Grades very gently

Dr. Heym cares a lot about his students and tries to answer every question. This sometimes means that lecture is a little slow. However, he is very clear with his explanations, especially one-on-one. If you are confused about something and ask him directly in lab or office hours; he is very helpful. Fair (but not easy) midterms, fair grading.

Took Heym for Software II. Part of the standard software curriculum so the course material wasnt up to him, but he covered it well. Makes student questions the priority in lecture. Exams were graded gently. Nice guy.

This material is definitely his passion. He's a very helpful, open guy who will help you until the world ends. With that said, his lectures are quite boring. He talks slow and pauses a lot which will definitely put you to sleep at 8am. Homework everyday, but it's pretty easy stuff. Tests are super easy. 4 big projects are long but straightforward.

idk he's an alright guy. but avoid for early morning lectures. I was already tired, and could barely considering he lost his train of thought, or dragged something so much i didn't realize what he was orginailly talking about. kinda puts himself to sleep. avoid if you want someone to read lecture slides *which is how i learn best, aurally*

Lab assignments were very interesting, but the lectures and homeworks were very dry and slow-moving. It seemed like the homeworks and exams only covered about a third of what we were supposed to learn in the class, so I didn't get much out of it. Heym is a very friendly professor, though.

Sweet old man that really cares. He's a good teacher in that respect, but this class just had very little material to learn, so it was very boring and slow. Good labs (writing an interpreter for a basic programming language), frequent homework that was easy and tests that were fair. Easy class, not much effort needed, but not very valuable to learn

Heym is a nice professor. Unfortunately, the class is structured so poorly that if you didn't learn that much Java before this class, you are doomed to a bad grade. You don't learn how to actually code; you just get taught the theoretical stuff before getting thrown to the wolves on giant projects you must code. Go to office hours!

Not a bad teacher. The materials were covered thoroughly before the midterm. The department messed up on some questions on a midterm making the class harder than it should have been.  Projects were graded leniently though. Lectures can be somewhat dry but he's very passionate and willing to help.

Great teacher. The structure and content of the course is rigidly dictated by the department. SWII is a class that has a wide range of student abilities and Wayne did a great job catering to those of us that already had learned most of the material and the people who were learning the material for the first time.

Homework was almost everyday, but it was super easy.  Almost used like attendance.  Lectures got very boring because it was very slow moving.  Professor really did care, but didn't push students to actually learn.
Great teacher for software - really straightforward.

He falls victim to judgement based on a difficult, standardized SW2 course. However, his lectures were a bore and generally weren't helpful. He used big vocabulary to explain hard concepts. I suspect he would be terrible at explaining how to make a peanut butter sandwich to a five year old. You can get him to spill the beans during office hours ;)

A wonderful teacher with an absolute love for what he does. Reasonable expectations of his students, and ample office hours. Can't make office hours? He'll happily meet with you anytime you need help.  Take any class you can with him.
Great professor in a difficult class. Final was hard but he's a nice guy and made the majority of the course much easier.

VERY SWEET! Do his lectures put you to sleep? Hell yea he even puts himself to sleep. But then you get used to it in few weeks and everything gets better. He is one of the most helpful People I have ever met. Office hours are very nice. And if you know how to ask correctly he might even give you the answers for labs, or at least a useful hint.

I have had Heym for three classes at OSU and that was on purpose. Like the other reviews already stated he is a great professor, soft spoken so he can make you sleepy but his office hours are great, he really wants you to succeed and learn the material. This class in particular was okay, do not procrastinate on the labs, all-nighter if you do.

Fair, helpful, patient, and incredibly nice. Wayne is an excellent instructor and offers excellent help in his office hours. With any other instructor, i wouldn't have made it through the Resolve class sequence. Highly recommended.

Hate CSE, I've decided. Wayne made this class bearable. I however fell asleep so many times, but office hours with him helped a lot! He is interested in teaching, however I didn't learn well from his teaching style.
Wayne is a good guy. He is helpful at office hours, he explains things slowly and clearly.

He was a very sweet professor, but he would definitely put me to sleep during lectures.  I would recommend going to his office if you are unsure about something and he will definitely point you in the right direction.

He is a very soft spoken person.  His midterms are based off of the homeworks and activities in class.  They are generally easy.  Labs aren't too hard, just start early.  Post's the slides to Carmen.  I was expecting a B or B- and got an A-
Class material was hard and time consuming, but Wayne was very helpful.  I'd recommend taking his section of any course if its available.

Heym was a really good teacher. He was clear, he knew what he was talking about and was really helpful. If you go to class, do the work, you should be fine. Especially if  you have a good partner. One thing though, the course final was really challenging.

By far the best professor I have ever had. I had him for 203 and 360. Although 360 was a challenge, he was incredibly patient with me when I would ask dumb questions during his office hours. He obviously enjoys teaching and helping students.
Wayne is one of the nicest professors at Ohio State, and he is willing to help all students with his knowledge.  He is a great teacher!
Awesome Professor, by far the best CSE professor at OSU along with Bettina. I wish more professors would take a good look at Wayne and see his joy for helping students.
Wayne Heym is easily the best professor I have had at Ohio State.  I also had him in CSE 321, and he was great in there.  Very easy to understand.  Always helps students.  Enjoys teaching.
heym is probably the only professor that enjoys helping students, he is always willing to help and pretty much outlines the exams for you, i would take all my classes with him if i could
He's a math guy, which would be nice if he were teaching a more theoretical course.  He's not a hardware guy, though, so he didn't fit this course too well.

He's very helpful during office hours, but only lecutures for 5mins during class, rest is group time. I thought I was going to get a C in the class, had a bad grade on the midterm, but I must have Aced the final- I ended up with a B in the class.  MAKE SURE to ask for study guides and check newsgroups for posting, exams are very close to them.
Can be boring at times in lecture, but very helpful during office hours.  Pretty generous with his distribution of grades.

He is a good guy, he does care and will not try to f%#@! you like someother so called cse teachers out there, just use his office hours well...you will need it. He is a bit unclear on questions...think of him like what if Mr. Rodgers were to teach a class where no one was really wrong and everyone was essentially right...confusing....nuff said.

I learned absolutely nothing from him. He does try to help, but he always goes off on tangents to any question you ask him. I passed the class, but I'm scared to take 321 because I feel like I have learned nothing from him. If you care about learning take Weide, Sawin, Sharp instead of this guy. He tries to help, but he just isn't a good teacher.

He is a very nice guy who knows SOOOOO much about subject...kind of unclear  when trying to explain things in class...I think he gets in a hurry and question s fluster him...He gets a little annoyed with them sometimes...make use of his office hours...he will be very helpful there.
No Comments
Cery helpful teacher. just come to his office hour and he will explain whatever you ask.

Great professor.  Really tries his best.  Contrary to other CSE professors, this guy actually gives a crap about you.  560 is hard because its a hard class, not cause of him, their all the same.  If your entering 560, get ready to lose any and all social life.

A lot of these people thinks Dr. Heym always gets confused, and the real case is hes trying to think of a simple way  to explain it to students.  If you go to his office hours and talk to him, he really knows his stuff.  One of the only CSE teachers that I think, I dunno, isn't evil.
This teacher makes you figure things out for yourself.  Which is probably the best option.  He is not very clear in lecture, so if you are confused visit his office hours.

He is always willing to help and seemed to care about his students.  The class really stinks if you're an experienced programmer (RESOLVE/C++ is a bloated version of C++) because you pretty much have to throw any old habits out the window.

Very nice and helpful. Will answer any question the best he can. Will sit down and help you if you're stuck on a lab or homework. Definately would take him again. Indirectly told us what would be on the test which left no surprises, overall a great professor.

Great prof overal. Does what he can to help a student understand. Like, if a student in class proposes a procedure that doesn't work, rather than saying, no that doesn't work, he follows through until the error comes up to show them why it is flawed. Great teacher, nice guy.
Had him for several classes.  Very nice and helpful and fair on grading.  Frequently scatterbrained though.  Always has a lost look on his face...
Very nice professor-always goes the extra mile to help students; classes are not the most exciting and he tends to get confused at times, but he always figures things out.
Good instructor... is very clear and helpful, but can sometimes be boring in class.

wow, this guy would get confused and sit there and wrinkle his forehead, it was HILARIOUS... I hated the class though.  Slept through alot of classes, and skipped quite a few.  Other than that, hope you don't get him for 560.

Dr Heym is a great instructor.  He goes out of his way to explain any questions you may have in detail.  I found him to be extremely helpful, you can ask him about anything, and he will give you a good, helpful answer.
for some reason he always seems more confused than anyone...can't answer questions at all...i'm dumber for having been in his class.  he is a really nice guy and tries to help though
No Comments
Very helpful, nice on grading, very knowledgeable.
Very helpful and cheery. His tests are hard, but the personal gain is worth it
Good attitude, very helpful. Enjoyed his classes for 221 and 222.
He is a good man,knows a lot, but sometimes short in memory and explations
knows a lot,

Meh? The course just feels kinda crammed and rushed but maybe that was because I took it during the summer. He also literally basically said that "I'm not going to be more specific about the requirements because in the 'real world' you're supposed to be able to figure them out yourself" even though he is the darn client technically speaking; ugh

Software 1 is notorious for being a weedout at Ohio state... With Dr. Boggus the class felt more even and well-rounded... He explains the tough concepts well and listens to what his students want. Grades very fairly. Overall I had a very pleasant experience in this class

There's basically no point in going to class. This whole course is just a big group project, so you need to get a good group unless you want to be stuck doing 20 hours of work per week. Dr. Boggus doesn't give very specific feedback and is a bit wishy washy at times, but he's very nice.

Get a good group. Professor doesn't matter much for the course. Though, Boggus was great. Fairly lenient grader, great at making sure you have all the resources, great about making his (reasonable) expectations super clear, great about leaving the specific details up to you and just caring about the overall ideas.
nice professor, want an A? join in a good group!

I'm conflicted on this guy, he cares about his students and his exams are not very hard because the material is easy compared to other 2221 exams - but he does grade very hard and his lectures are meaningless. He wants you to succeed but does not know how to teach at all and sometimes it seems like he gives up halfway through a lecture.

Accomplish the goals of each sprint and you'll get an A. If you have any questions, simply ask him and he will point you in the right direction. He's very easy-going and extremely knowledgeable about the subject. A big part of this class is your group, so that will affect your grade more than anything.

I couldn't have gotten a better professor for software 1. He was always available to help students. I felt he went above and beyond the requirements in his lectures and in labs. He even thanked us for taking the course and putting in the work. A professor who actually cares about his students.

Made the first level of Mario in his class. Very easy going professor, My difficulty rating of 1 is based solely on his extremely easy quizzes and exams. Your difficulty will vary wildly based on how good your group is.

This is a basic introductory CSE class. While the class itself was easy, the average grades were still quite low because a lot of people choose to not continue in the major after this class. As long as you catch up on all the lecture content and do all the assigned projects, you should be fine.

2221 has a ton of homework, but that's by CSE departmental design. Dr. Boggus is always looking ahead to what assignments are coming up and gives his class a heads-up to prepare them for success. The feedback he gives is insightful and really helped me understand my mistakes. If you get him, you're in for a treat.
If you get Boggus for 2221 then he will do a nice job explaining more advanced concepts and leaves plenty of time for understanding.

Lectures can be kind of boring, but otherwise is decent at explaining key concepts, especially if you ask questions in class. Cares a lot about the subject material and his students; always open to answer questions. Tests aren't hard, and grades very fairly
Definitely a solid choice for any CSE course he teaches.
He's a nice guy and the tests are not bad at all.

Overall a great teacher. He takes really tough material and puts it into a form where you can learn and understand it in your own way without getting overwhelmed in complexity. Encourages further exploration of topics if animation/game/graphics interest you, but realizes not everyone wants a career in that industry. Projects are fun.

Most of your grade will come from the programming labs, with a chunk from quizzes. His lectures aren't the most engaging, but if you're interested in the topic, the information is there. There are opportunities to get bonus points on the labs in case your quiz grades aren't great.

More of a gradervague assistant in this course (which makes sense given the context), but horribly communicates information on desired topics in project until too late. Doesn't bother to help on the simplest of questions and criticism ranges from alright to unfounded. Essentially an unnecessary element to an otherwise interesting class.

I took the game design class from Matt, so his lecturing wasnt a huge component. Regardless, they were very informative and he was always available for help. Quizzes were very fair and fairly easy. The course was a lot of work, but there is a huge curve to make up for it (A: 100-90 A-: 89-80 B: 79-70 C: 69-60, etc)

Not as great as you might think. Quizzes are lop-sided and cover a small, biased portion of the set of material that he says will be on the quiz.  Will avoid helping during office hours until the last minute and recommends methods that will not give full credit. Not as bad as his 3902 class, however...

Great professor and very flexible class. He gives you examples of best practices and allows you to solve the problems on your own in whatever way you see fit as long as it has good code quality. He is willing to help you with anything.
Excellent instructor, helpful, friendly, and knowledgeable.
Very helpful, keeps classes interesting
Really laid back teacher. Will answer all questions and is a fair grader. Highly recommend!! Super nice guy too :)
Great class

Was pretty clear about what assignments were due and when. However, was not clear about what he was expecting as far as the parts of the project. Kinda just talks through the whole class, but has a few days with fun activities. Overall pretty boring. Lenient grader.

His lectures are non-stop baloney with no actual educational content. He is egotistical and constantly brags about his career. He is very unclear about his expectations of students and rarely communicates anything about the course content ahead of time. There's nothing scientific or engineering about his approach to software engineering. AVOID.

If you enjoy watching someone poorly read pseudocode off the board and go over equations line-by-line instead of teaching any material, take this course with Tamal. This class as taught by Tamal is a joke.

Professor dey teaches algorithm in a very unique fashion. I had faced few difficulties at the beginning but with the span of time I cope up with the class. If you really want to learn algorithm, you should take the class. Exams are hard you need to think. HWs are hard but worthy enough. You also need to follow his class to get a good grade.

Tamal is clearly very intelligent and enthusiastic in the realm of theoretical computer science. However, he occasionally comes across as demeaning and somewhat intimidating. He grades his exams in a pretty harsh, all-or-nothing approach. Curves the average to a B at the end, which is nice, but perhaps look elsewhere for a 2331 prof.

Great teacher. Wants his class to learn and really enjoys teaching the class. He is very easy to talk to and really wants everyone to understand the material. Explains everything very well. One of the best teachers I've had at OSU so far.
Class is generally tough. Had a nice curve in the end, a C+ became a B+. Homeworks and midterms are graded harshly. 4/10 Accent, sometimes its hard to understand; sit close to the front of the room.

Caring, father-figured, helpful, and probably one of the best professors I have got during my college years. He is a true master of algorithms in terms of concepts and applications. His exams and homework-s are challenging but it's rewarding!

I ignored all the recommendations of taking this class with one of the other professors... it was a huge mistake... AVOID HIS CLASSES. boring, and exams that are unrealistic. he doesn't care - I emailed him questions through the semester, and he responded to less than 10% of my questions. also impossible to get an A.
Not helpful at all.Doens't explain the material and useless in office hours. don't take his classes...
I benefited from Dey's class on algorithms. He is a true master of the subject. Dont take his class if you are not prepared for learning conceptual materials.

Took the same class with another prof. that was much better. he's teaching approach is terrible in my opinion, and I did not benefit at all from this prof. I think that unless you want to work with - don't take his class - other prof do much better job... I suffered in this class, and not because of the material..

By far the best professor I have taken a course with. It was so interesting that I didn't even mind coming in at 8:30 in the cold. Is a bit stern but if you ignore that and listen to him you will love the class. If you are not looking for an easy A go for Tamal instead of other professors.
This course on advanced algorithm is a must for anyone who is serious to learn algorithms in depth. Prof. Dey is a superb instructor.
Teaching algorithms is not so an easy task. This prof does an extremely good job. He explains materials very clearly.
He just seemed like a mean person, and really bad at answering sincere questions, which he treated as questioning his authority.

The fact is that this guy becomes angry if you ask him a question which seems trivial to him. He is very rude and does not behave well sometimes. He  has studied the Cormen's book well and teaches it in a boring manner. He repeats questions in the exam. Hence if you collect past years question you will earn a free A grade which is definitely good
good prof with good teaching skill.
He explains concpts well, and forces you to 'think' on the exams (i.e. doing a known concept with a twist).  Overall, he is a good prof.
Explained concepts well.  Overall good prof.  Easy to talk to outside of class.  Anyone who complains about him never tried to take 625 with Supowit!

He hands out a nice set of notes, but is overall pretty mean.  He would scream at us "you need to ask questions."  Then when somebody would, he would scream "why did you ask this question???"  Makes you feel dumb if you are
No Comments
Hard to understand. Doesn't explain concepts well.

Overall, lectures were fine, just a bit boring. He sometimes didn't understand what students meant when they asked questions. It's very clear that he cared about his students and wanted them to succeed. Labs take a very long time so start early on them. Exams were very difficult but not unfair, and they were curved heavily (I think).
He is very caring and always willing to explain the content to those who may not be understanding or following along with the rest of the class.

Although his class wasn't the easiest, I learned so much from taking Networking with Professor Athreya. Showing up to class is very important and making sure you have the energy to keep up in lecture is as well. He was very good with clarifying things to his students. Exams similar to homework's but still tough.

Didn't respond to any emails the whole semester & Carmen was barren, so missing 1 lecture was catastrophic if you didn't have friends in class. Lectures were ok, but there were very few examples. He did them on a chalkboard, then they were lost to the void. You get a cheat sheet (& answer keys to hw) so the exams weren't impossible, but still hard.

Very knowledgeable, caring professor who can teach you a lot if you pay attention (dense lectures but never any extraneous information) and ask questions (he is fantastic at helpfully answering questions and taking the time to make sure everyone understands). Would recommend!

Lectures can be long and dense but if you can pay attention, he will explain everything in a very understandable way. Great at answering any questions you may have. For online, attendance was required either synchronously or asynchronously. Understand how to do all of the homework and the exams will come easier
