His midterms and his finals are very difficult and he is a really tough grader. If you want to learn a lot then I would recommend him. If you need a good grade though I would choose someone else.

If you want a solid understanding of the course material that you're willing to work towards, there couldn't be a better choice.  He grades very fairly; you get exactly as many points as you deserve, and he's an enthusiastic and thorough  lecturer. His dry sense of humor can be misinterpreted as rudeness, but in the end he just wants you to succeed

CSE 2231 was not the most enjoyable class, but Paolo did a good job. The tests were very easy and the grading on those was perfectly fair, but the labs were graded pretty tough. Messing up one little thing meant 10% was dropped from your grade. One of the best teachers in the department, but if you're looking for an easy A I'd look elsewhere.

The lectures in his class weren't very helpful since he moves so quickly, but all of the slides are posted online. The group projects went well. The exams were fairly difficult. There was a lot of very specific questions that require knowing very minute details, yet he says "focus on overall concepts". He's nice though and does what he can to help.

He would sit in lab and say: "Why are you guys not asking any questions."  When you ask a question h would respond: "I don't know how you don't understand it's so simple." I would never take him for anything. There is no help or clarification.

Not going to lie, Bucci is tough but he really knows his stuff.  He really wants to make sure his students understand the course material which is why seems to get furstarted  when students don't understand - however he if you show that you're trying he really takes notice and is here to help you learn

Software 1 with Bucci was unnecessarily difficult. The class average was lower compared to the other sections. Grades too harshly on projects and tests, and tends to be condescending if you don;t understand a concept quickly. Many students hesitated to ask hi questions because of this. Take this course with someone else

I liked 23 of this class and when to him weekly for extra help the other 13. He will set up time to meet with students who ask for help but he will explain the material the same way, so if you don't get it the way he explains it, good luck. Very difficult teacher, can be degrading in lectures (not purpose), and re-iterates its our job to learn it

It is clear that Bucci is passionate about computer science, however, his class is unnecessarily difficult for a pre major class. He grades way too tough on projects and tests, and his averages are always lower than other classes. Take it with someone else if you dont want to risk not getting into the major
His coding techniques are ou of date, and teaches some knowledge no one would use in real world.
Great to listen to, great at speaking. Nice voice and accent. Very comforting.

Paolo is extremely knowledgeable of the field of CSE and is very passionate about the subject. The downside of this is it seems that he gets upset when you don't understand a topic. However, he really does care about students and will gladly work with you. Takes getting used and grades are lower, but you will learn more.
Averages always higher with other profs. Just take it with someone else.

He is very knowledgeable in his field and does an excellent job of explaining material. He is also very passionate about his job, a little too much at times as he can gets all worked up when students do not understand. His class is rather challenging, but if you put the time in you will excel.

He is extremely knowledgeable on the subject and can sometimes not understand why you're not understanding. However, he is more than willing to help you with any question and meet outside of office hours. His tests are comprehensive and not overly difficult, though the grades are final.

He is a very good teacher, but can be a little condescending (in a good way) when it comes to asking questions. He comes with a funny Italian accent, but it is very easy to understand. I recommend taking his classes.

He means well honestly, and the curve was quite generous even in a class of only 46 people during the summer. It was tough, and he is tough on grading. But you will learn too, a good guy but a little unfair on grading in an intro software sequence. Projects were rough too on grading. It is up to you if you think it's worth it with him. He does care

This class had a lot of material to cover. The problem is not only that, the teacher is not approachable at times. He grades too rough on things such as making sure you only have one return statement, and some performance things. The grader was who to watch for also. Your grade will suffer if you are not persistent and careful studying.
Take this course with a different instructor.

Just took this class and learned a lot.  The set up is confusing, but it was the first 2231 class in semesters.  Bucci came off as rude sometimes but it's just his personality.  Can be funny, can be nice if you get to know him
Overall he was a good teacher and it seemed like he truly cared about the students/class. All the material was extremely detailed. He can be good but strict. You learn a lot with his classes.
Difficult class, learned a lot. Paolo is very straight forward about his difficulty. He is a great professor and gave all the resources necessary to learn for ourselves outside of class.

HIGHLY intense class. Weekly labs are really weekly projects. He teaches the class as if you've mastered the Resolve sequence and/or had java in high school. Midterm and Final are all multiple choice. No HW grades except the labs. You don't get to keep your midterm test to study from. Beware of the time commitment!

I felt like I understood everything and even though my labs were all seemingly correct, points were taken off so strictly.  A good teacher and knows what he is talking about, but if you want a good grade, DONT take if from him.

One of the few professors that I know I will never forget. He makes his classes hard because he expects the best, but he is very helpful and it's easy to learn enough to impress him.  He doesn't tolerate laziness or ignorance.  Some interpret that as rudeness, I interpret it as realistic.  Amazing professor.
Everything stated in the previous comment is true. However, be aware that your grade likely will suffer from taking Bucci. Take him to learn from him, not to get an A.

Paolo is a master of his trade and the designer of the SCE sequence. He will challenge you to be your best, and expects exactly that. If you attend every lecture, I see no conceivable way to fall behind in this course. He is a funny guy, with a very appropriate temper.  Easily the best professor in my three years at this school thus far.

Good guy, funny too. Is very clear. Really summed up all the concepts of SCE series well. Don't believe what anyone says about him being super rude, I think he was a little surprised by it himself and made fun of himself about this page in class. Tests are tough and labs are expected to be done to exactly to specifications. Fair though, learn a lot

Paulo is one of the best profs I've had at Ohio State. His class is not easy, and he expects perfection, but he teaches very clearly and tells you exactly what he wants. He is extremely helpful in office hours and answers emails promptly. 421 is a great class, and I highly recommend Paulo for the class.

Paolo Bucci is the man.  He's very strict and albeit condescending, you will learn a lot from him.  The only experience I had in Java prior to his class was in high school, but now I definitely feel a lot more confident and well-versed in Java.  But this knowledge doesn't come without pain!

He likes to explain things about 4 different ways, but just repeats himself. Be careful with what time your class is because you're likely to fall asleep during his droning on the same topic. He grades hard and the tests are very difficult. He is NOT good with questions, so pick it up on your own time since you won't want to ask him...
He talks fast, but he's always willing to slow down. He's obviously very passionate about his job, and he's also very good at it. He's not the easiest professor, but he is very fair.
Very knowledgeable but not the easiest man to ask questions to. 421 labs can be tough but are doable. Midterm and final were very difficult.

I can tell he is passionate about the material he teaches but he wants everything done HIS way no matter what, (even if it is purely style or preference). He acts annoyed when you ask him questions in closed-labs or if he deems the question 'stupid'. You can get through the class if you have to but if you have another choice- take it.
Generally people who complain about him are the ones who get terrible grades.  It's definitely not Paolo's fault if you do poorly, because he explains everything you need to know and is very helpful.

Bucci is a man at war. He is very testy, but he seems to feel bad about it at the same time. Like, he'll make you out to be an idiot for some of the questions you ask, he's so testy even when in good spirits, but then he'd semi-apologize. Your code is terrible, no it's not TERRIBLE, but it's so very bad, I mean I've  seen worse, but MAN this code!

Excellent professor.  I'm taking him again for 421 where he's still an excellent teacher.  Very practical and gets his point across well.  Awesome sarcastic sense of humor.  Kind of a tough grader but he'll help you as much as you need.  Highly recommended.

Had him for 421 and 321.  Great professor - especially for 421.  His labs are very practical but his midterms/final require lots of studying.  He can be a little bit scary. I would take one of his classes again cause he is a awesome Italian dude. fahey...

I strongly recommend NOT taking Bucci if you need structured lectures and are slower at understanding CSE classes. His lectures never seemed to get to the point and he always came off as annoyed and insulting if you asked questions. I guess some people must like him, but PROCEED WITH CAUTION.

Paolo is one of the best teachers at Ohio State, and probably one of the most knowledgeable guys in the department.  He explains the material well, and is willing to help anyone.  Some people might mistake his passion for computer science as arrogance, but it is not.  He just wants you to know your stuff.  Everyone should take a class with him.

Paolo is extremely tough and a hard grader and a very fast speaker who can come off as intimidating.  That being said, he's one of the most helpful professors I've had and is EXTREMELY knowledgeable on the topic.  I learned an exceptional amount in this class.
A lot of people complained, but I liked his teaching style and went over things many times if you had questions.

If you don't put in time, he probably won't like you. If you put in time, you won't necessarily get an A since he is a tough grader but he is more than happy to help you. He expects a lot out of everyone, and doesn't give as many points as most for effort. Tough but fair, my favorite CSE professor out of the whole 221/222/321 series.

I actually think Paolo's one of the best guys in the department.  If you put forth the effort and do your labs ahead of time, he's more than willing to critique them, give you feedback, and let you change them.  He's very helpful and quick at responding to students outside of class, and he's a funny, good-natured guy.  And he DOES have cool hats!

Hard grader and has high expectations, but if you're making an effort he has no problem giving you the time of day with plenty of suggestions. Also has a good sense of humor about the whole bugs language thing.

He is the worst in CSE department. He  yells at you if you ask question. The exams are extremely hard. He is also a hard grader, he will go after the grader he you get perfect score. RUN A WAY FROM ELSE YOU DOOM.

This guy is terrible. I can't understand him with his rapid speech and Italian accent. He expects perfection on labs (which makes it really hard to get a 5) and yells at the students if the class does not participate or have questions. The average of our midterm was 60 while Long's section was 83. Oh and Bucci doesn't curve so don't expect an A.

Bucci's grading system is the worst I've ever seen. He changes grades that the teaching assistants mark. He expects perfection, but he isn't clear on how to achieve what he wants. When something is hard to understand, he continues to repeat himself as if explaining the matter badly multiple times will help.
Difficult to follow, showed his emotions too much.
Very very helpful, but He will get loud at times and he is definitely a harsh grader, he expects dedication and perfection.. I would take other classes with him.

This class is rediculous in the first place but Paolo makes it sickening. He does not help you.  His tests are crazy crazy difficult.  I hate him and I don't usually hate professors. And I can't understand a thing he says, damn accent.

I knew day one that he was going to make me cry. He doesn't spare any expense making his expectations clear, and he makes them high. He expects a whole lot of his students, and he's not very forgiving. He's a nice guy, but a crappy teacher. He does help, but he's not always convenient.

This guy gives his students extremelly hard tests. He doesn't prepare the students in any way for the test, but he expects perfection from the students like they are born geniuses. Not even Bill Gates or any famous programmers would be able to pass his impossible tests. Good luck with this guy.
No Comments

I think that he makes the class artificially harder by grading ridiculously hard.  He definitely knows what he is talking about, but his teaching style is condescending and demeaning at times.  He kind of discourages input from students who don't know what they're doing.

I agree with the previous guy that i didn't like Bucci very well at first....He has gotten better though..He is funny at times and explains things pretty well...The homework is tough because sometimes homework is assigned before he actually goes over the topic...Overall, decent prof, although i like

In the beginning I absolutely hated this guy, but towards the end he actually seemed to not be so bad. Sometimes his help would lead me in the wrong direction so I would ask the grader. The exams seemed to be much longer compared to CSE 221 since I didn't seem to have enough time both exams.
yells during the whole class.  very intimidating

OK when instructing but harsh on the grading.  Expects perfection in code.  Willing to help you out in office ours, but you think everything is fine until you get your grade back and you get a D because you made some minor mistake...
No Comments
No Comments
He gives very clear and thorough explanations, but sometimes he makes you feel guilty for making mistakes or not answer questions thrown out during lectures.
odd balance of grading hard (lots of points off for stupid mistakes), but going slowly and not expecting people to understand simple topics. Energetic and fun to listen to. Does explain things well.
Very energetic and knowledgeable. Bug's world game was a fun lab.

Dr. Bucci is an excellent instructor.  I'm not sure why anyone would have a problem with him.  He presented the material in a very clear manner.  He is an energetic, enthusiastic lecturer and was always willing to help.
He is very intimidating and has a short temper with coding mistakes, like there shouldn't be any...
I didn't like his style at all, almost 'mean'...
great teacher. very knowledgeable about the material. although he is helpful debugging your code, he makes you feel like an idiot while he's at it.

He's a great guy and good teacher. He accommodates to most requests and grades easy. His English is not the best so you might want to read the slides yourself. Other than that I think he does a great job and I like that he codes live in class instead of just reading the slides.

Idk why he has so many 1/5. he's one of those professors who makes you laugh in class. i never found myself staring at the clock wondering when class is over. i will say though, that he isn't the best at explaining things and sometimes is even wrong about content. but 3901 has really easy content to understand so chatgpt was able to explain better.

Fall 24 is when Baha started teaching this class. It's not hard to get an A in the course despite him being vague about the content you'll be tested on. He is not quite the best explainer, but everything can easily be answered with a Google search. He is really not that bad as the other reviews make him out to be.

Professor Amayreh is a great guy, he's nice, but a bit confusing. There's weekly reading assignments,but the topics would be covered a week after it was due. This made me feel like I didn't really learn anything. Attendance is mandatory(he loves tophat). I believe it's his first year here, with some improvements I'd enjoy having him as a professor.

He is a really nice guy, but I didn't grasp anything. Everything is through Zybooks. Every week, we have a reading assignment that we need to complete, even though the material will be explained the following week. His slides and PowerPoints look great, but he often explains Zybook content or sometimes skips over material.

Look he is a nice guy with a big heart at the end of the day and grades leniently.  When it comes to exams he gives very BROAD details about it so you have to know every slide and put a lot of time outside of class because you can be thrown with anything. I highly suggest avoiding him.

He seems like a nice person and probably is but it feels like nothing is covered in this class. It doesn't help his sentences make no sense most of the time and he cannot convey ideas at all. If you take him to get an A, you probably will, if you want to actually learn web dev AVOID HIM. You will leave every lecture only more confused.

Nice guy, grades very leniently. He will take up any amount of time available to him for lecturing from the moment the clock hits the time to start till the end he will be talking. Will take attendance, No time during class for project, test are based heavily off of in person coding examples. Pick a good group otherwise this class is draining.
Genuinely the best professor I've ever had.

Professor Pork is a very generous grader. Most assignments were graded on participation, but the final required 100% completion. Weekly quizzes included one bonus goon worth an extra 10%, but my refractory period was way too long to qualify. I sprained my wrist during the second midterm, but I still finished utilizing Dr. Pork's effective methods!

Professor Pork is a great instructor who brings a lot of enthusiasm to GOON1100H. His lectures are engaging and well-organized, and he genuinely cares about students understanding the material. He's always available during office hours and responds to students snaps quickly. He actually might respond too fast... he keeps on calling me.
Dr. Pork was a very tough grader but was very helpful through emails and office hours. The class itself is very difficult so be prepared to be challenged, but it is very rewarding after finishing.

Literally people who are complaining are those who never focus on classes or those who never bothered to ask questions. This is a class that is 1. difficult but not impossible, 2. easy if you are willing to spend that little five minutes at the end of the class to study. If you can't get an above B plus (89 - 100), go be a business major.

Speeds through lectures and doesn't really seem to care about doing his job that much. Tried to be funny, except this meant calling out students for doing badly and making fun of them. Be prepared to teach the entire course to yourself and have rough exams.

Gomori explains concepts pretty clearly during lecture. His attendance policy may seem annoying but it's for your own good to go to class because you learn a lot more in person compared to if you just go through his slides on your own later. Both MT2 and the final had relatively poor averages but if you do all your work and study it's not bad.

He will help students with any questions they may have and he definitely knows his stuff, however his lectures are pretty confusing and he is not very good at explaining concepts. The midterms are much harder than other software 1 classes. He is a very nice and funny guy though. If you put in the work, you should be fine.

Steve's great. Does a good job of explaining concepts in a way that makes sense, and good at explaining things in more detail if you have questions. He isn't a super tough grader, and his exams aren't super difficult, but sometimes they can trip you up if you're not super up to snuff. He is very friendly and approachable

Professor is a great professor. You will have to put in the work tho. If you ask questions, complete homeworks, labs, and projects, then you will love Professor and be successful. He answers questions ALWAYS. He actually appreciates when students ask questions. His lectures are VERY clear and informative. He's one of the best professors I've had.
Steve is genuinely human and one of the funniest professors I've had the honor of meeting. Is he perfect? No. But damn it, he cares-- and that's more than most.

I'll start off by saying that he is nice, who will work with you and try to help in any way he can. Still, I will say that he does a terrible job at explaining things, goes on tangents that end up confusing the class, and covers the baseline of what you need to learn with no examples. 90% of the class is self-taught so you'll need to work/labs.

I really enjoyed Professor Gomori's class. It's not an easy class but as long as you study, you should be fine. The lectures are long because it's a summer class, but we usually get off half an hour early. There are milestones throughout the semester, which are done in groups of 2-3 people.

Horrible. Gives zero feedback, barely helped anyone with the final project and gave students 2 word responses. Clearly hates teaching and will barely look at material that you show him in regards to homework/projects. Goes on tangents during lectures that don't matter and slides are ripped off of wikipedia. Teaching software 1 in the fall, AVOID!

I really enjoyed his personality, he was always very real and upfront about everything. The quizzes were always easy, more like an exit ticket style. I recommend going to office hours for the labs because they are super helpful. He is really helpful if you go up and ask him questions, and I think the class was one of the more enjoyable CSE courses

Steve is a genuinely good person. However, he isn't the best instructor. The language isn't difficult to pick up, but there is a significant amount of programming involved in this course. You will have to learn alot of the material on your own. My suggestion is to use the book, attend office hours, and start the labs a week or more in advance.

His class just involves reading off the lecture slides, which is basically the information you'd find on Wikipedia. No study guide or whatsoever for the midterms, and you are required to know 10 slides per exams, each of them with 50-70 slides. Only had one homework assignment before the first midterm which pretty much didn't help

Worst instructor ever, teaching nothing in lecture and test EVERY single sentence on the slides. Even test with something he never taught. Homeworks are useless for your test. Group project required. Avoid him at all cost.

Easy class with lots of extra credit. Requires you to think pretty hard about the code since COBOL is a limited language. but its well worth it and you come out a much better problem solver! 10/10 would recommend!
Hes an amazing guy who is here to help! Overall and amazing Professor! Also with basic effort the class is a breeze.

No passion about teaching at all. Really hard to learn something important in class because of short lecture (usually class ends within half an hour). And he did not highlight key ideas during the lecture, and most of exam questions are about small texts on the corner of the slides. Not Recommanded

Super boring lecture, his slides is just copying from Wikipedia. As an assistant prof, it seems that he didn't care about his class. He has 2 final sections with different questions). For everyone I have known of, the 2nd section's average is 10 points+ lower than the 1st one, and he didn't even curve it. Not ez and you will learn nothing from him.
Exams questions are extremely specific, study every sentence of the slides even if that content wasnt emphasized in class. Lectures arent useful. Didnt feel like prof cared about the class.

Steve was a great professor. Really cares about his students, and if you put the work in youll get the result you want. Attendance is not mandatory but if you go you learn more and get to know him. Not an easy language, you might hate the material but you will be okay.

In the top 3 best professors I have had. He's just a really good guy who wants you to succeed. He is from the industry and has cut out everything that isn't practical. Lectures are rather boring but I would go because he's generous if you're a regular and appear to work hard. Exams are very hard. Labs are eh. Pretty easy language to pick up.
So class was really tough. But if you are looking for a teacher who will care about you and your success then he is the one for you. Go to his office hours and ask questions.

The class isn't terrible if you put enough work into it. Quizzes and exams are fair, study the slides for quizzes and labs for exams. Work on things well ahead of time. Go to office hours - he wants to see you learn and be successful. There are opportunities for extra credit if you show up to lecture and not many people are there that day.

This class is tough, you need to study hard for the tests, start projects 4-5 days early (Office Hours are mandatory to get good grades on these projects), and keep up with the material.  You don't need a textbook and you don't have to attend every class as long as you read the slides and keep up on the material. You can get an A in the class.
He is a very nice guy. A lot of people who drop the class is because they don't like the language not because of Steve. I struggled to get a good grade but learned a lot from this class.
Honestly one of the best teachers I have had here. Steve will go out of his way to make sure you do well in the class, just ask! He's real world, no theory

Great Prof. Actually worked in the field doing this stuff. Topic is not easy per se but he is very fair and more than willing to help you outside of class. He answers emails from home and will go over work during office hours. Everything comes from notes. Exams are a bit tougher than quizzes/labs
Knows what he's talking about; has real world experience; very helpful if you have any questions.
He is real cool! COBOL is not a fun course anyways, however his quizzes are easy. I recommend taking him for 314. He is understanding if you have a problem.
Down to earth and funny. Does hurry a bit through notes, but willing to help during office hours and via email. I really enjoyed his class.
Actually a very nice guy
Great Class. Great to have a teacher who actually knows what he teaches. He works in the industry so he can explain realworld problems

Extremely easy class if you stay on top of the readings and homework. Everything is well organized and it's easy to stay ahead, if you do that and go to lectures, you'll get over 100%. John is clear and helpful, and extremely knowledgeable about C++.

Wilcox is easily one of the best professors I've had at OSU. If you're passionate about learning C++, Wilcox is your guy. 

Highly recommend!
Strict but fair. He teaches decently well but honestly everything can be learned just from the homework, besides maybe classes and pointers. Go to lecture for that. It probably helps.

This class was okay, material was heavy and hard to understand. Professor Wilcox is an okay teacher and he lectures well. Answers questions and is clear with grading criteria. However, he is a tough grader so keep this in mind.

He's an old guy who's retired. Doesn't care or have much passion for his job. Lectures are worthless attending, just use Zy books. He does however give a cheat sheet for some projects if you attend class. Projects and labs are what you spend time on, but only worth 30% of grade. Quizzes are the most important for your grade. The final is free.

Assignments are very consistent and at regular intervals. Lecture assignments are easy but take a long time. Labs and projects are graded somewhat harshly, be sure to read the rubric. Despite what some people say, most quizzes are not that difficult. They are open note and mostly involve copying code structures used in the weekly assignments.
He's nicer in person than he was online but he is unfriendly to students and not understanding or particularly helpful. The class was okay and his prerecorded lectures were better than his in-person
A strict guy with a heavy emphasis on exams, but I really learned something in his class.
Difficult class, but I really learned a lot about programming, so I give him a good rate.

The hardest class I've taken so far. The quizzes are sometimes tough, and if you can't get the coding part right, the score is going to look REALLY bad. We can't even look at the code we wrote on the quizzes after the TA grades it. The lectures are useless for me personally (He usually just reads the slides). I learned mostly from the zybooks.

Pretty simple class if you have prior coding experience. The weekly quizzes can be challenging at times but the final was really straightforward and graded way easier than the quizzes. My personal tip: Try to finish the weekly labs before you take the weekly quiz bc the coding portion on the quiz might be really similar to the lab.
The class will be easy if you have coding experience. For me, he was a pretty good professor, was able to understand everything.

Mr. Wilcox is a solid professor. His lecture could provide clear introduction for the C++ knowledge. However, the C++ course is a little difficult because of the tricky quizzes and final exam. However, if you put enough efforts on your labs and projects, you will be no problem. Even the C++ course is not an easy A, I still recommend Mr. Wilcox!

Professor Wilcox really cares about his students, and wants them to learn the foundations of C++. He is understanding of outside circumstances that may impact student lives, and will almost always accommodate as long as you have a valid reason. The content of this class is difficult, but everything you need to know is in the ZYbooks readings

Don't go to lectures unless you don't understand the material. Read the ZYBooks and do all assignments as early as possible. Copy and paste everything from ZYBooks into a word document. Lecture slides can be used on quizzes (USE THE SLIDES). For coding, look up a tutorial on getting c++ setup on VSCode, also get a auto documenter plugin.

A very solid professor. Although the course is a little difficult, I real learnt the C++ without any previous basis. If you want to get an easy A, here is not good; if you really want to learn C++, choose John Wilcox!

He would just read the powerpoint and boast about his successful life. If time was tight, he would quickly go through the rest of slides without any concern about whether the students were keeping up or not. 
Not a good course for beginners. DO NOT TAKE HIS COURSE.

A very solid professor! His lectures were not compulsory, but they were well organized and the points could be trodden on with precision. Although the weekly quizzes would be a little tricky, it was not very difficult. The final exam was online invigilation, be sure to ensure that the network is smooth.

Quizzes every week which are impossible, average is usually around a 50 or lower and never curves. Projects and labs which are extremely hard and take lots of time. Lecture problems are 100 times easier than quizzes, and he is not very good at explaining. TAs are there for help, but are also not very helpful. Wouldnt recommend to my worst enemy.

I was brand new to programming, and thought that Professor Wilcox explained concepts very clearly. The reading assignments were tedious, but usually pretty easy. Yes, you get a zero for the assignment if your code doesn't compile but you are able to resubmit as often as you need until the deadline. There is also extra credit for labs and projects.
He cares more about people cheating than he does the students ability to actually learn the course material. No feedback, and glitchy testing systems.

He's not the friendliest professor and can be a bit intimidating. However, he still teaches quite well. He gives out donuts and food for doing well on coding problems. No reason for there to be this much hate for this guy. Not the best super engaging and outgoing professor, but will still show you the ropes for C++!

I don't think this guy has the right attitude to be teaching but his explanations are decent and you don't have to interact with him much. Hopefully you don't. Quizzes are almost all gotcha questions. Class uses zybooks which is tedious but has good coverage of material

I don't really recommend this professor. I didn't feel comfortable talking with him one-on-one because he is somewhat intimidating. He posts pre-recorded lectures and all of the class slides on the Carmen at the beginning which is very helpful. His lectures were fine and have in-class exercises/quiz information not in the prerecorded lectures.

All lectures had a recording available, so missing wasn't a big deal. Explains material pretty well. Quizzes are every week and are more annoying than difficult. Make sure your code compiles and you'll probably be fine.

Take the time to do the coding assignments and understand how they work. This makes tests and quiz problems easy. This class is also better taken with experience in another language, and can be more challenging for new programmers, but not impossible. Wilcox can come across as condescending but not because he feels that way, it's just how he talks.

He taught the course as well as he could have. If you sent him an email, he would respond quickly.

My only problem was that the lectures were quite boring, and I would frequency skip them.

I really can't understand his marking criteria for the final exam, 70% of the marks are for one-question programming, and once the program can't be compiled will not get marks. The content of the class was very different from the assignments that needed to be done and the PowerPoint given was not very helpful. It is really awful.

Wilcox is a very poor lecturer. His ability to explain concepts is god awful. If you have never coded before, try to avoid having him be your first experience. He is randomly loud and sounds frustrated. I just worked on other homework during his class.

One of the worst professors I have ever had at OSU. He always has a very rude tone in emails and always seems annoyed by you. His exams are the worst as most of the grade comes from a coding portion and if it does not compile, you will fail the exam. His assignments have instructions over 2 pages long twice a week. (Not counting the homework)

This has been the worst class I've ever taken. Lecture is absolutely useless. They expect you to learn coding simply by using ZyBooks. Extremely rude and condescending person. Would avoid if at all possible, or be prepared to teach yourself. TA's are cool but unless you have unlimited time to yourself there's only so much they can do. Have fun.

Useless lectures, after a few sessions I stopped going to them, never learnt anything there. Just watch the prerecorded lectures and that's all you would need to score well. Quizzes every week but they were alright. Wilcox doesn't actually teach, his graders and assistant professors carried the class.

I came in to the course with practically no coding experience and did very well in the course. The TAs were easy to reach, professor Wilcox cared about how we did, tests were based on the previous week's lecture and were open slide. Extra credit offered on all homework and labs. I enjoyed the course and would reccomend him.

Stopped going to lectures because he was so arrogant and condescending. This class is super easy is you know anything about programing, but the java or python class is probably more useful if you aren't that interested in C++.

I had taken multiple programming class before, and I thought the class was set up in a well structured way. In one email with the professor, he was slightly condescending, and I have seen that online as a trend. There were quizzes and homework throughout the semester that took lots of time to complete, and towards the end, homework could take days.
Very cold through emails, does not care whether if a student did or did not learn from his lectures.
Don't take would not recommend. Take the python course. It would be easier to learn c++ on your own than with him.

I failed during COVID thinking that was the reason, currently taking again and about to fail again. Awful. relies so heavy on online textbook. TAs not helpful, extreme quiz grading really tanks grade. Seems like material is out of order. reads off PowerPoint, the homework and labs require material that hasn't been taught. so unnecessarily hard, RUN

If you are required to take this class, I'm sorry. If you have a choice, definitely take the intro Java course instead (1223). The professor relies way too heavily on Zybooks and it feels as if he doesn't update his lectures much. Honestly way too much work and pretty harsh grading.
Don't take this class, take 1223 instead

Terrible class, doesn't make much sense. Lecture slides don't give useful examples of concepts used in class. Material feels out of order- you'll learn material in a lab after you already took the quiz for that material. TA's were alright, grading is harsh, professor feels inept.

Very cold in emails to students- he accused me of cheating when he had gotten the lab numbers incorrect, and had apparently accused a large majority of the rest of the class for the same reason. Barely understands how the textbook website works, and the TA's aren't very much help either. Extremely strict with quizzes and assignments, gives zeros.
Do not take this guy... Exams are 75% off one long question and if it doesn't run, you pretty much failed the exam

TAKE CSE 1223 INSTEAD!!! His lectures are ok, but you should watch a youtube video on the topic because he goes fast. If you get a good grade on the labs and homeworks you can seriously cushion your grade. He does not give a lot of time for midterms. The textbook is not necessary, you will teach yourself because the TAs are usually overrun.

Rude over emails, TAs are little to no help. Nobody in the CSE department has the desire to help students. If your code doesn't compile, you'll get a zero no matter how much you have done correctly. I learned nothing from this professor, lectures were prerecorded and live lectures just highlighted these lectures. Zybooks is also terrible.

Hes an okay professor. The workload was pretty heavy between quizzes, readings, lectures, labs, and homework, but it was effective at teaching the content. Biggest complaint was the lack of time for midterm 2, class average was 20% less than midterm 1. Overall not a bad class or professor but take java if possible.

This class is hardwish I switched to 1223. I am taking some really tough classes this semester, but this is my lowest grade and I am close to failing. Lectures are not engaging and do not provide enough information for the homework. Office hours are useless, so I usually dont do well on the homework. He is accessible outside of class though.

Cold and rude to students. Told the class incorrect information about the late work and quiz policy. His online lectures are so bad, only 20/200+ students choose to attend. Doesn't know the answers to some of his own quiz questions during review and his Powerpoints often have mistakes. Very unhelpful with exam prep.
useless online course, and I have no time to finish my code in midterms. why I take 1222 instead of 1223 ???

Wilcox makes things more difficult than necessary. You essentially learn everything from Zybooks, and his in-person lectures are essentially useless. He doesn't give you enough time for the online midterms, and Proctorio is a real pain to use. I'm halfway through this class right now, and I'm regretting every second of it. Please avoid.

Avoid this professor at all costs. Wilcox and Naeem Shareef are obsessed with trying to catch the tiny number of students that cheat. PROCTORIO IS USED FOR EVERYTHING. Wilcox is mean and unhelpful during office hours; I went for help on a lab and he got the logic wrong and then proceeded to get mad at me for trying to correct his mistake

John Wilcox is really knowledgable and makes the material easy to learn. I came into the course with no prior coding knowledge, and left feeling very confident about my choice of major. Proctorio is a bit annoying, as mentioned in the other comments, but if you have at least two brain cells then it doesn't matter. This class is an easy A :)

Basically what the other reviews said, also this guy wouldn't even give me a single day extension on an assignment when my roomate got covid and I had to move out of my dorm. He uses proctorio for anything and expects this class to be your entire world. Easily the worst professor I've ever had.

Do not take this man. He is a glorified TA that lets Zybooks and his actual TA do all of the work for the 2 sections that he teaches. Makes you use proctorio and be logged in to a zoom call for weekly quizzes that are open note. If you've ever wanted a class that is easy on content but hard on patience, here it is. Cannot wait for SEI's.

Easily the worst professor Ive ever had. He made things so much harder than they needed to be by using proctorio and giving you a zero on a quiz/exam if you got flagged (keeping in mind it was even open note). The book does all of the teaching for him.

Uses Proctorio which is an invasion of privacy and makes everyone do worse because it takes up time, is extremely stressful, and takes up lots of power. He cares more about catching and punishing students than helping them. The extra credit is very minimal and requires lots of time. He does not care about students. Avoid him, I certainly will.
She was an amazing professor, very sweet lady. She really does care about you and your success. Exams were a little easy, and she talked about potentially making them harder, so keep that in mind.

Fairly easy class, stopped going to lectures after the first couple weeks, homework is just two labs and a quiz every week, nothing too difficult.  3 multiple choice exams, easy if you just look at the "study guide" given and know how to do the labs.

The lectures and class itself is kind of boring, but Professor Kline is a very caring and understanding person. There are usually 2 labs and 1 content quiz every week. There are 3 exams total and are all multiple choice. The lab time is optional (only go in if you need help). Overall would recommend!
Very understanding of issues. Lowkey a boring class but I respect her ideals as a professor.
Professor Kline is very knowledgeable and one of the kindest teachers out there.
never answered any of my emails
very rude and never answers emails
She cared about students and answering questions. All you have to do is follow the lectures and keep track of pre-labs. In person labs were straight forward and guided when problems arose.

Dr. Kline is a really great professor and made the class very easy to understand. She is very caring and is always willing to help you if you put in the effort. Every time I emailed her with a question she responded within an hour often even within 5 minutes. Attendance is not required and I never went to lab and did good in the class.

Diana is very kind and you can tell she wants her students to learn the material. Her lectures can get a little boring and monotonous but she explains things in a lot of detail so it is nice for people who need that. The homework takes some time, but it is pretty self explanatory most of the time, and the quizzes are easy if you study a little.

The class itself is pretty boring but straightforward - a gen ed for all business majors. Most stop attending lectures after a while because the information is generally easy to learn solo. Pre-labs were probably the most annoying part, but if you get them done early, they aren't as much of a headache.

Dr. Kline is a very nice lady who genuinely cares about what she is teaching. The weekly quizzes are very easy if you read the course notes and the exams are also easy if you understand the practice exams. Pre-labs and In-labs are the hardest part about the class and are weighted pretty heavily but it is very easy to get help.
Show up to the labs and you'll be fine. The material isn't difficult to learn and most people stop attending lectures by the end of the 3rd week.

The information is fairly simple if you skip class to learn on your own but she makes sure you understand in class by great teaching and explanations. She is super nice and helpful and wants the best for her students.
Extremely caring and wants her students to be successful and enjoy the class.

THE BEST professor I've had @OSU. CSE has a reputation for being tough, but with professor Kline it was my easiest class all semester. She will go out of her way to help you and if you attend lectures and labs you will learn so much. The content is engaging and you can tell she genuinely cares about teaching. Don't be scared of this class!

Reads off the slides and doesn't really give much during lecture, all of which I slept through or didn't show up to. But the class itself was easy enough that I didn't have to have a fantastic professor to keep up my grade.
Very sweet and caring towards her students. Always willing to help and further explain.

Professor Kline was an alright professor. Not the best with tech but great at coding/excel. Sometimes lecture is a bit disorganized. If you know nothing about excel going into this course, you'll likely be fine if you take the time to put in the work. Consists of weekly pre-labs, in-labs, and quizzes. Couple of midterms, which weren't too bad.

Professor Kline is the sweetest lady! She really cares about her students and wants to help you with any questions. I personally did not like the class itself, regardless of which professor you have. But if you have to take CSE professor Kline is great!

I took her class online during COVID and she offered synchronous Zoom lectures, but aside from the first few weeks, I was able to just watch the videos she posted and learn the material from those and the slides. The quizzes and exams are open note and very fair, and the labs weren't too difficult, especially if you go to the lab tutor room (Zoom).

Diana is a very kind, helpful, and respectful professor. Lectures focused more on practice than new material, but her notes are extremely easy to read. Labs were fairly easy, and exams were easy as well.

I took this class online this past semester. It was the best one I took. I eventually stopped showing up to lecture because you can just go at your own pace. Each week is clearly laid out. Dr. Kline is also so kind and genuinely caring!!! She makes deadlines and expectations very clear. If I can get an A in this my first semester, anyone can.

She really puts in the time to make sure we understand the concepts. Grading is clear and your grade can be an A easily if you stay up to date and use the review material given. There are also tutoring hours to take advantage of.

Professor Kline is super nice and approachable! Attendance is not necessary for lectures, labs it is necessary. Lectures and worksheets are posted online and she explains them in class. Weekly quizzes are a breeze. Pre-labs/Labs are easy. CSE is something you understand easily or you don't. Never studied and got A's on all exams and labs.

Dr. Kline was definitely the type of professor that truly wants every student to do well. You can clearly tell that she cares about her students and their success in her class. Dont worry about showing up to the lectures when you spend the whole time doing a worksheet you can easily do them on your own time.
Boring lectures, easy material. The pre-labs and in-labs are STUPID.
Doesn't know to reboot a locked up computer. Teaches a computer course.
The class is very dry and boring, but she gave a lot of pracice problems and test prep problems. Exams are fair.

The sweetest human ever! Very approachable and cares a lot about her students success. Being successful in the class just comes along with practice, but overall it wasnt that hard. Definitely recommend taking Dr. Kline!!
Never take him!!!

Class went pretty smoothly, at the end there was a curve which was nice. As a professor he cares about his students and if you're taking the online version he makes it clear he is available in person if you need further help. Lectures were helpful and the order in which we learned everything made sense.

Software 2 generally is tough regardless of the professor, and Rob LaTour was no different. He's a chill guy, so definitely come to class. I would highly suggest against attending via Zoom because the Mediasite posts the lectures 2-3 weeks after the day of lecture. Be ready to spend multiple hours a week doing the homework/labs/projects.

Best lecturer out there at OSU, if you really wanna learn the material better take him. He made his lectures so interesting. Exams are not bad if you know the material good. He tries to trick you sometimes which kind of makes the exams interesting honestly.

Brutal midterms and projects, never got better than a 7/10 on projects and I worked HARD on them. TAs will take points off for ANYTHING, you need to go get your project checked by them before turning it in. That way if they takes points off for something arbitrary you can say, this TA checked that and said it was ok. This is the only way to do well

Teaches the material super well. Great at explaining the concepts. Had bunch of office hours and are very willing to help. Exams are hard but not impossible if you put in time and effort to study. Enjoyed the class very much.
Best professor ever. Loved his class will recommend him 100%. If you want to learn your stuff take him. He will make you suffer but you will learn a lot coming out of that class.

Consistently showed up 5-15 minutes late to class. He tries to make jokes and act like he's still in college. The jokes are funny about half of the time. 

Exams were hard but not terrible. The class is passable but not enjoyable.

Quizzes and projects are much harder than lecture examples. He does not have a syllabus posted on carmen. He takes weeks to post lectures - you have to rewatch them to take notes cause it moves so fast. Up to date lectures are not posted before major projects.

Good professor. Funny and cares about his students. Records lectures and uploads slides. Weekly quizzes/labs are hard - Rob doesn't really show coding examples, he makes real-life examples that help you understand but not actually do it. I wish he did practice quiz questions in lecture to actually see him code and see his whole thought process.

Rob is easily one of the best professors I've ever had. His explanations of concepts were so clear, and he had a great answer for every question. He had great analogies for everything. If you attend every lecture and pay attention and engage with him in class, you WILL do well on his exams. Although his exams are difficult, they were never unfair.

Nice person but DONT TAKE HIM. Long lecture without actually explaining anything. No examples of coding at all and tough grader on everything. I got A in other CSE classes but awful grade in his class...
Overrated

Can't believe he even has one good rating. Keeps trying to act like the "cool kids", is constantly late to class, and talks about nonsense that isn't even related to what he is teaching. Has no sense of professionalism whatsoever. Can't believe he is a professor clearly has no maturity whatsoever.

Rob Latour was an entertaining and kind person to talk to but he was not the best professor. He would consistently show up late to lectures and go on side tangents not related to school material. He created tough exams where the average was below 70, especially on the final where a 70 is needed to pass the class.

Rob is very knowledgeable and good with his lectures for what can be a tough class. Exams were tough but certainly doable with the right studying. I never had real issues with his teaching style or him being arrogant etc like some others say, but I can definitely imagine that happening sometimes based on his personality. Good overall.

Rob is one of the best teachers I have had but sometimes the lectures can be very long and boring. The exams are pretty hard and his exams consistently have very low averages. Only allowed to miss 4 labs and 4 lectures in the semester.

Thinks he's still in middle school. Has zero sense of professionalism and is extremely old school. Spends all his energy trying to act like a comedian instead of actually teaching. Is just using this job as a way to feel smarter than everyone else or as a stepping stone. Acts rude at times for no reason. Has favorites. Avoid! Take someone else!

If you want a professor who is egotistic, makes you feel dumb, does not want to provide any actual help without sounding like a know it all, or acts like a child then Rob is for you. If not, don't take him. He can be condescending and unnecessarily blunt when you ask him questions or visit during office hours. Not professional and acts childish.
Painful to interact with outside of lecture. Extremely condescending

Since he's a younger instructor he connects to students more than most. However, I feel like I ended up wasting so much time going to lecture and was better self taught. Exams were hard, and I feel like he didn't do enough to make you understand the material. I ended up not going to him for help because he can be arrogant and wasn't helpful.
Although Rob will make you suffer, he is one of the most geniune professors at the University. The course material is very tough, but you will come out having learned so much.

I just don't like his personality very much. He can be very arrogant and tries to act like the cool kids. Don't like those theoretical professors at all. They, and Rob, kept pushing others to follow covid restrictions and complained about others not doing so and acted like experts about covid when they weren't. They should stay in their lane.

Rob is the best! He respects his students and brings an energy to the classroom that really helped me follow the dense topics discussed in class. Rob is very accessible outside of class and makes communication as comfortable and humanizing as possible. He respects the material and grades tough, but with how well he teaches, it feels respectable!

Rob is extremely personable and makes a genuine effort to connect with his students. CSE 2231 was easier for me than Software I in general, but I will say that the final exam was extremely challenging. I'm pretty sure Rob is known for making a difficult final. I went into the final with a 94% in the class, and will be lucky if I get a 60% to pass.

Best professor I've had so far at Ohio State. He's extremely accessible outside of class and will explain concepts in a bunch of different ways to try to get you to understand. Not only this, Rob actually teaches you how to problem-solve and will make you a better engineer and computer scientist. Could not recommend him enough.

As a person, he is alright. I know alot of people like him, mostly because they play online games with him. As a professor, however, he's not very good. The exams are written and pretty difficult, lectures are unhelpful. Labs also be difficult. He's an okay professor, but he doesn't know how to help students who are struggling with materials.
Had a great time in this class! Rob keeps lectures entertaining and informative, and class work rarely feels overwhelming.

Rob's lectures are bomb and they really enable you to learn and understand the course content, even though the course itself is pretty tough. The only real grief I have about him is that he would sometimes make condescending comments towards students. He's definitely one of the best if not the best Software II professor right now.

If your about to take a class with Rob, you have nothing to worry about. CSE 2231 is not an easy class but Rob gives really good lectures and is open to being asked a lot of questions before and after class. He does floor the projects and typically doesn't give half points, but out of all the SW2 professors, he's probably the best one.

Rob is such a good lecturer and really teaches you the material well. Hilarious and helpful both in class and in office hours. If you can, I would snatch a class with him! One small thing: he is a bit slow when trying to message him outside class, but he makes up for it by being really understanding of situations and open to giving extensions.

Rob is an amazing lecturer. He makes the lectures fun and relevant. He also cares about how students are doing in the class. Rob tries to help out every student. He is very understanding when life gets hard and you need an extension on assignment.

Phenomenal. Compared to other professors I have taken, Rob can explain the material very well. He is really funny and entertaining.

Main issue I had is he takes quite a bit of time to grade tests and respond to emails/messages (which is not a huge deal).

Yes, he gives decent lectures. If that's the only way you plan on interacting with him, then you'll be fine. But if you want a professor that responds to emails, helps you learn outside of making himself feel smart/funny, and actually cares about teaching, then don't take him. He only cares about feeling bigger and smarter than his students.
Rob is a funny and cool guy, younger and relatable to students. I highly recommend Rob as your professor for any class.

Rob genuinely cares about his students. Apart from being a genuinely nice person, he is very understanding and funny. He made going to lectures enjoyable and was very knowledgable about the topics he was teaching about. Exams made up 70% of the grade, which was tough, but he gave out many opportunities to improve scores.
Labs were pretty brutal due to the short turnover times but Rob genuinely cares about his students and is a really nice guy.

Rob is a really great lecturer and is really engaging and hilarious. I never wanted to miss class because I really like learning from him.  Also lenient about extending deadlines and missing class. However, don't expect him to check his emails. The best way to reach him would be through discord.
Rob is a really great guy and his lectures are entertaining. I never thought about missing a class, because I genuinely enjoyed learned from him.
Rob is a really cool guy and you'll definitely be entertained in class. Don't be surprised though if you're waiting in class for 10 minutes though because he's always late. His exams are very tough.

Compared to other Systems I professors, Rob is relatively new to teaching this course and was still learning the ropes. Labs are hard (especially one of them) for my SU20 class. Lectures were really engaging and packed in knowledge and humor, and personality like a Wagyu steak. Passionate about CS and helping out students.

Rob is awesome. I took his first-ever Systems I class, and though it was clear he was learning how to teach the class effectively, he made sure to take our feedback and he worked with us on everything. He's an engaging professor who made a mind-numbing class interesting for me, and an even better dude. Be sure to study for his exams!

I think my biggest gripe with most professors is their care towards being a teacher and not a researcher that is required to teach courses. Rob is a great teacher, something that is hard to come by from my experience in university. He cares for his students and if you are struggling his office hours will get you out of a tight spot. Ask questions.

Hilarious? 100%. Caring? 100%. Passionate about teaching? 100%. Amazing lectures? 100%. Rob is my favorite prof at OSU and very much a dream of a prof. My only issue is that there wasn't a solid schedule for assignments but it's understandable since it was his 1st time teaching it in the summer. Extra credit on labs, MT, final. No curve.

Rob is seriously one steller guy. If you have a choice for systems, take him. The class is difficult and frustrating no matter what but he's one of the few instructors that can make the material actually interesting and easy to learn. The labs are tough so ask for help if you can. I would instantly take him again in a heartbeat.

Rob was awesome, only reason he didnt get a 5 was because he was horribly disorganized, he never knew when labs or homeworks would be so they were always a surprise. Besides this he was really passionate, caring and super fun. Ask lots of questions and be prepared to go to office hours though. The labs in Systems 1 are no joke.

Rob was a decent professor for SW1. He clearly knew the material and was engaging during the lectures, which was helpful online. However, he took forever to grade quizzes/projects and left no feedback. To make things worse, he graded quite strictly on them and would never go over homework/projects in class. I felt on my own in this class a LOT.

Rob genuinely wants to help his students learn. He'll meet with you basically any time of day he can to help you out (especially if you are international during the pandemic) and his personality is comedy S-tier. As for lectures in software one, they're pretty straightforward and follow the slides. No curve, quizzes aren't bad if you pay attention

It was instantly clear how genuinely knowledgeable Rob was on all of the content, while the material itself isn't the most interesting, his lectures are well-paced, fun, and thorough. He was quick to respond to any emails outside of class and was always very supportive and helpful in answering questions or clarifying any confusing concepts.

Rob is super down-to-Earth and makes lectures amusing. He's great at answering questions and loves getting questions. Quizzes/tests can be a bit hard, but just go to class and review the lectures, and you'll be fine.

LaTour is a very kind and understanding professor. Don't be afraid to ask for a bit of extra time on an assignment. His grading is not very kind, however. He doesn't give partial credit on quizzes which makes it very difficult to ace them. Lectures are recorded and labs are not 100% necessary. Homework is completion so that is nice!

Rob definitely wants you to do well, but he wont make it easy. You definitely earn/deserve every grade that you receive. Hes funny in class and almost seems like hes your friend. But sometimes in office hours, he makes you feel like youre underachieving. Rob explains things very well, but if youre looking for easy A, you wont get it here.

His lectures are very structured and thorough. However, make sure you ask him a lot of questions if you don't understand something cause the class gets difficult at times. The quizzes were a bit difficult, but make sure you ask him questions during the quiz if you don't understand something! Really funny guy too, so you'll enjoy the class.

Rob is an amazing teacher. He is very understanding and flexible, especially with the pandemic situation. I cannot recommend Rob highly enough. He is by far in my top 3 for all professors I've had at OSU. If you have to take CSE 2231, take it with Rob.

Rob was a funny/cool guy, and was great at explaining material in lectures. However, exams are very difficult. Pay attention to the requires/ensures on coding questions, because they're complicated. In my opinion grading was too harsh, but it's probably CSE dept grading rules. Took off points for .length vs. .size, not using newInstance, etc.

Rob is hands down one of the best teachers that I have ever had. He is super friendly and funny and is very knowledgeable about the coursework. He makes every class as fun and engaging as he can. He truly understands the material he is teaching and goes beyond just reading off the slides. If you're able to, take his class!

Hardest and most tedious class Ive taken at OSU. Rob is a fine lecturer but gives impossible exams (averages in high 60s/low 70s). They try to trick you on every question and barely cover the material. Take somebody else if you can, few did well. No curve or rounding at all. If you lose the lottery and get him, good luck with a rough semester.

He's an hilarious guy and he teaches well. His classes are funny, but his grading is just horrible, without the "no curve". I wish he just curved, coz a very few in the class actually get above an A/A- in the midterms. His highest was in the 80's for midterm 1.

Grate lecturer. After college no one will care about who taught you, they will look at your grade and judge. Rob will teach you well but he will DESTROY your grade. This inst a joke or me just hating him. I really like his lectures but I dont agree with his grading rules.

Rob is the best lecturer for Software 1. You will understand the material extremely well with him teaching. However, if you only care about the grade and not the material, then I would recommend taking software 1 with a different lecturer. On the first day he says his exams will be harder than other lecturers, and he is not lying.
Rob has a real gift for teaching. I really enjoyed his lectures and he is very helpful in labs.
my dude

He's a really funny guy who stays on topic and offers his own spin on the general provided slides. I honestly remembered more from content his jokes in class (and fierce hate of nulls), then the readings that are available. He's a bit intimidating when approached alone, but overall I think he's probably one of the best instructors I've ever had.
Funny guy easy class to sit through.

Rob was an absolute goof during class but when I asked questions outside of class/in office hours he made me feel somewhat dumb. Despite that, I think he did a pretty good job explaining all of the concepts. He also refused to curve the class which was annoying. Overall though, Rob is probably one of your best options for SW1.

Some of the CSE 2221 instructors curve the class or offer extra credit. Rob does not and will not budge. The exams are very hard, but if you have prior coding experience it is a lot easier. Rob will gladly answer any questions outside of class, but he also makes you feel dumb.

Easily one of the best instructors I've had at OSU. I had him for 1223 which seemed to be a relatively easy course, so that may have helped. But even still, I had him during my first semester at OSU, and have yet to have another instructor whose lectures are as engaging as Rob's. (I just finished semester #4.) Absolutely phenomenal.
Great lectures! SW1 is standardized so they go off of slides from the department but he made them interesting. Very personal, responds to emails crazy fast at all times. Very helpful in office hours
Terrible TA, terrible instructor. They should really look into who they hire to work at OSU before they take my tuition money.

Terrible instructor, decent course. Didn't even show up to office hours half of the time, was consistently late to lecture meetings. Her TA was awful, Ani never showed up to office hours. Overall, not helpful at all and can hardly understand her terrible accent.

WORST professor in the CSE department. She gives NO hints for the projects, expecting you to listen to the lecture and learn everything while she CAN'T teach properly. Teammates in group projects do NO work at all, and even if you carry and do all the work yourself, you still get the same poor grade as them.

I don't really get all the negative reviews for Zina. Her lectures aren't great and she has a heavy accent but she's a nice lady and grades things pretty leniently. You get a few HW drops, exam averages were As, and you have a group project that isn't a crazy amount of work but make sure to get a decent group. Also cancelled class pretty often.

Her lectures SUCK. Do not bother. How to pass her database course:
1. Read the slides yourself at home
2. Work with your group to complete the project
3. Use the slides for the homework and the open-note exams.
4. Open zoom, enter tophat, sleep for 1 hr, leave

The project has a lot of harsh requirements, so make sure your group follows every step.

The worst CSE professor I have taken. She is a rude and stubborn professor. If you ask her about projects, she will give ambiguous hints. You wont be able to understand anything from her super thick accent and lectures are just useless.

The worst CSE professor I have taken . If you actually want to learn about databases do not take her . She is very stubborn professor who does not care a single bit about the student . You wont be able to understand anything from her accent and the lectures .
She has strong accent. Can't focus on her video for more than 10 mins. Slides are ambiguous. Should be anxious about being COAM reported even though you did nothing bad.
worst professor iveever had, do not taker her PLEASE SAVE YOURSELF . She probably couldnt explain 2+2 if she had to
super thick accent cannot explain anything do not take
she is terrible stay away
terrible lecturer do not take

If you want to be reported to COAM take Zina. She is genuinely the worst professor I've ever had and reported our entire class on the first lab. Thick accent and doesn't understand how to code in the slightest. If there is any way to take 2123 without her please do.

Part 2 of my review. This professor will COAM you for anything at all which happened to me (I was found not guilty). She made me hate computer science and almost made me unable to graduate. If you ever need to take this class, PLEASE DO NOT TAKE IT WITH HER.

I made the unfortunate mistake of not looking at this site before signing up for the class previously. This professor has to be the worst educator I have ever came across. She is unclear and unwilling to help her students. I will write a second review on here to add more reasons as to why she is terrible because of this word limit.

She always reads from slides during class and is unwilling to put in extra effort to benefit the students. She struggles to explain even simple concepts clearly. Her lack of dedication to her responsibilities warrants a low evaluation. The assignments and the course are disconnected. Additionally, she tends to come here to remove negative reviews.

Honestly wish they had another professor for 2123 she is the only one available which is rough. Will report you to COAM if your code remotely resembles anything online or AI which does not make sense as there is only so many ways you can write code for this class. Avoid at all cost.
Twinkle twinkle little star, how I wonder what you are. Seriously. Awful and will COAM you if you even breathe. Stay away.

A very bad professor is never a curve, even if you are only close to upgrading. It's very strict. It takes a lot of points. The accent was so severe that you could hardly learn anything in her class. Never take her class.

She made me lose all passion I had for CSE. I genuinely have never had a worse professor and it makes me sad that so many students feel the same way. She is known for reporting students to COAM for no reason and getting them on probation. Never take her classes if given the opportunity. The class is easy if you don't get reported. Good luck!

Horrible professor. All she does is read off lectures slides. Her feedback on the project sucks, basically just tells you that you did it wrong without explaining what needs to be improved. The class was online so the midterm was easy but if you don't get a good group for the project you are in for a tough time

Please stay away from professor Zina. The group project was absolutely abysmal, very easy to lose points and feedback was completely useless. Each project is based on previous one. She would not say what specifically was wrong but would say that there were "lot of problems" and we should find what's wrong by ourselves. very very tough grader..

There is no point to going to the REQUIRED lectures because we are expected to watch amazing videos by Jeremy Morris. Its like he is teaching the class, overall this class is kinda easy if you like java just a lab, project and quiz to do on your own time(DUE AT 8PM??). Just remember those are cse labs and projects so it could take like 2 or 5 hours

Slow and boring, while also being unreasonably tough on grading. The entire class material felt subjective and based on nothing but the opinions of the people writing the slides. She would consistently grade project parts so no one in the class did better then a 90%. It always sucks when a professor ruins a class I was genuinely excited to take.

Zina is OK. Lectures are pretty useless but are "mandatory" despite no participation grade. Expect lots of homework, but it's easy. The project is very time consuming. There are 3 graded checks to keep you on track. However, she gives very brief and vague feedback at first, so expect to have to continually tweak something you did two months ago.

Please stay away from professor Zina. The group project was absolutely abysmal, very easy to lose points and feedback was completely useless. Often times she would not even say what specifically was wrong but there were "logical errors". She will also not curve grades even though I was under .3% from an A-. She DOES NOT CARE for her students!

Her lectures are boring and useless yet mandatory; you'll learn so much more from just reading the book, and in less time. That said, the midterms are extremely easy, and if you get a decent group for the project that's not bad either. Thankfully she moved the class online so I didn't actually have to pay attention.

Complaints of her accent are greatly exaggerated in my opinion. I also felt that her lectures were really helpful and were much better than just reading the slides. There is a lot of homework, but each assignment typically doesn't take too long. You can choose your group for the year-long project. Choose wisely.
Really easy professor, but that's mainly because the course content is easy. If this class was hard in the slightest, then she would probably be a terrible professor.

the professor is completely not engaging, reads off of slides, does not explain the material well, so you are pretty much on your own. It's difficult to book appointments with her, and sometimes you wait for a reply to your email for a really long time. Attending is class is mandatory but completely useless, extremely poor teaching. It was bad

Very disappointed with her lack of understanding of my questions. To get through the first 2 pre-units I had to go back and forth with her over email arguing that the items requested were done correctly, I sent her screenshots of the same thing that was submitted. Project 4 she gave me 0 points instead of letting me turn it in late and helping me.

By far she is the worst instructor I have ever came across . I had to drop the class because she was not doing her job as instructor. terrible at explaining or answering question. she is just not easy to understand. DO NOT TAKE HER CLASSES!!

She has a really think accent that I found very difficult to understand. Even though the attendance is mandatory, all of the classes I just can't follow, because I don't understand what she's trying to say. She does not seem to be bothered about reading chat messages, and has a lot of assignments and is not very responsive. Defo wouldn't take again

Professor Pichkar is one of the worst professors I had at OSU. Firstly, she is hard to understand since she will contradict herself at times during lectures. She does not use many examples during class that apply to your work. Its very much learn the basics in class then teach yourself the rest. The grading scale in this class is very odd as well.

She's nice and helpful as a person but as a professor, not so much. The lectures were pointless as she wouldn't even read the chat or answer questions. And when she did, she would literally read off of the slides. Hard to understand at times and it seems like she may not even know how to code since she couldn't answer my questions half of the time.

Nice person but she doesnt try. She is not accessible outside of class and doesnt have office hours. She copies many slides and diagrams from the textbook verbatimthen reads them word for word like Siri (Siri would have been more interesting as a teacher and also pretty sure this is plagiarism). Would rather get a C with a better professor

Once you get used to her accent, you'll find she is really clear and organized about the course materials. Midterm is open book. She is kind and responsible, I would like to do other courses with her if possible.
Awesome teacher! Really enjoyed her.
Shes an okay teacher but hard to understand at times.
She is kind and warm-heart. Sometimes you need time to figure out what she said.

she makes me want to drop out of school and pursue a job in the fields in remote romania to work with cattle. and just thinking about doing that sounds like an absolute vacation compared to having to learn to code by reading a textbook. it makes me angry just thinking about walking into lecture and having to hear her ramble for 55 minutes about bs

The class is fine as long as you put in some effort. I got an A and don't have any CS background. She is a good professor, the lectures are engaging. But, she is unapproachable. There are stupid questions and she will make it clear if you asked a 'stupid' question or answer in class.

She was boring but was clearly passionate about the material. Please go to office hours; sit down and go over the quizzes/homework. TAs were average. She doesn't mind using AI to help you but don't depend on it. She uses AI to generate quiz questions lol. Quiz and Projects alternate every other week. Tip: include projects in your portfolio.
Quizzes are the hardest part of the class, but as long as you do the work you can still pass with an A.

Treats students like middle schoolers when no one answers her questions. Lectures aren't helpful whatsoever (she rambles). The hw for the week is for the lecture a weekish after it's due, so you get lectures on topics you've forgotten. Ended with an A but only after proving her wrong through TEN EMAILS that she gave me the incorrect grade. AVOID

Any time a student would get a question wrong or asked a question she would look at them like they were absolutely clueless. When emailing her, I felt that her responses were a bit rude and she was unable to comprehend simple questions. Class structure was also not ideal, if you have no coding experience it's even worse.
Lectures are a waste of time. The structure of the class is ridiculous. Homework is due before you even get a lecture about the topic. Didn't learn a single thing.
