She uses a flipped classroom teaching style, and lectures are not that useful. Having taken programming classes beforehand, it was not difficult. During lectures, she treats students like middle schoolers whenever no one answers her questions. No final exam, only hw, labs, and projects, nothing too difficult. Acts entitled, try to get another prof

She is degrading to students in class and humiliates anyone who has a wrong answer, while at the same time getting mad when nobody answers her questions because they're scared of getting humiliated. She acts like a middle school teacher. She has a temper. She is not a good lecturer. She was not that helpful the one time that I went to office hours.

Her lectures are a waste of time, and you learn nothing. She assigns pointless tasks and doesn't create a good learning environment. She's critical whether students talk too much or too little. The class is easy, though, so it doesn't really matter.

As a first time java learner this class did not teach me anything at all. She uses a flipped classroom so get ready to teach yourself everything through a online textbook. The good thing is there are no exams, instead there are bi weekly projects and quizzes which are very time consuming if you don't already know how to code.

You learn everything on zybooks so lectures are pointless other than the random participation assignments. The "labs" are just computer rooms where you do homework independently. Both should be optional but attendance is graded. She's super inflexible as well. Not too hard to get an A but even missing one week can drop your grade down.

This professor is extremely difficult and is very inflexible. She was very unclear with how she was grading the attendance. Once she actually put in her "participation" grades, my grade dropped significantly despite showing up to every lecture and lab. Do not skip out on any of the tophat questions or try to take this class with another professor.

Not happy with this class one bit. She put us into groups from the beginning and none of my group mates ever showed up. Had zero coding experience beforehand which didn't help. Zybooks is stupid, the professor just relies on it to teach us the material then the labs do not correlate to the reading. Complete mess. Made me cry on multiple occasions.

DO *NOT* TAKE THIS PROFESSOR! If you want to learn, you won't; her lectures are useless and weeks behind the quiz/textbook material. She grades for participation: attending class was 1 point for the first nine weeks. After our final quiz/project, she began cramming in 5-point questions to deliberately fail students who didn't go. Inflexible. Awful!

The most challenging professor I encountered at OSU was incredibly unhelpful. Her teaching style lacked effectiveness, and she seemed unwilling to offer any guidance.she exhibited rudeness, making the learning environment uncomfortable. she was not accommodating when it came to assignment extensions, for students who missed deadlines.
She doesn't teach whatsoever, and you can't understand her. Would never take a course with her ever again.

Professor Atiq was awful. I had an issue with my projects not being graded and instead of being apologetic and trying to solve my problem she brushed me off and made excuses for my grader. She couldn't remember who I was and she said it was asking a lot to have a different grader grade my work and she can't force the graders to do their job.

The "flipped" classroom that Professor Atiq uses is not a conducive learning environment. We were always a week behind the lectures compared to the assignments. Didn't learn anything in lecture and she would get side tracked very easily. Would not recommend taking an intro to Java class with her.

Although she is passionate about what she teaches, she often goes on rants about things off topic that tend to make her lectures confusing. Definitely go to the TA's office hours and lab blocks as they can often explain things that are confusing during lectures.

Super disorganized and often gets distracted during lectures. Posted all the slides and lectures online and relied mostly on those and the online textbook to teach myself. She is incredibly forgiving though and will give you reasonable extensions if you need them. Poor and disorganized lecturer, but a good person.

Not the greatest lecturer but a very forgiving professor as long as you show effort. I would recommend utilizing her and the TA's office hours when you can. If you don't have an interest/expereince in coding, this class might be more difficult to you due to the flipped classroom way of teaching, but still manageable.
Prof. Atiq's class is designed to be online but is now instructed in person with no changes. She gave projects and reading assignments over spring break.

Most programming professors hand you a textbook and say "email me if you have questions". This woman actually teaches the content. She goes over concepts in depth in a way that everyone can understand. A+ professor.

Her lectures are a week behind when she has the associated assignments due. Also, she doesn't really answer emails and her lectures are not very helpful. The quizzes suck and they're trick questions rather than testing your knowledge. She is disorganized and often doesn't even know what is on the homework she assigns through Zybooks.

Ok professor. As long as you teach yourself well with zybooks, you're good. She seemed kind of mean at first but once I got to know her better she wasn't all that bad. The deadlines and grades are pretty forgiving if you reach out. The TAs for the course also helped a lot.

She does not answer emails and is an awful lecturer. This is pretty much a self teach class... the TAs are helpful and she has office hours too but it simply isn't enough. The flipped classroom format is awful at such a big school.
Please don't take her class. She teaches nothing and is extremely rude

The course was disorganized. We used an interactive website called Zybooks and basically you learn everything on Zybooks. She assumes that students have a previous knowledge about programming which makes it hard for students to keep following her. No exams, you just have to finish the projects so thats nice. Be prepared to study on your on.

First programming class, I ever took and it was a struggle. Primarily used Zybooks with barely any help from her. Should've bought Zybooks on my own and taught myself since that's what happened anyways. I asked her for information on getting a tutor and she told me to go to her office hours for help, then didn't show up.

While not my favorite professor, she is absolutely a solid choice for learning Java. I had no coding experience before starting, and now I understand most concepts with only a slight bit of hesitancy. Zybooks was used quite a lot, but her quick lectures and self-checks are actually useful. Overall I'd say 8.5/10, would take again.

If you have to take this class, Dr. Atiq is a great option. I think I listened to her teach on Zoom for maybe 5 hours over the whole semester so this class is very self-driven but extremely doable with office hours and the internet. If its your first coding class give yourself a HUGE advantage and practice with a free online java website before!

Dr. Atiq was a great teacher and I really enjoyed her class! She was very forgiving wehn it came to extending deadlines. Super nice and made sure she took time to explain things if you were confused. I had no coding experience before taking this class and she did a great job teaching everyone from scratch.

Dr. Atiq was wonderful! I never talked to her much, I usually communicated with TA's, but she's great to have in class. I was in the first CSE 1223 class to be taught entirely online, and I think she did a pretty good job handling it.

I honestly forgot I had a professor for this class. All she did was host the zoom meetings and send us to breakout rooms for online group projects. We learned everything from the online book (which isn't helpful) or videos that she uploaded of another professor. I learned everything from the internet by looking it up than from her. Hard projects.
If you have no coding experience youll be fine in her class. Shes willing to help you and shell drop your lowest lab and project.

I had never programmed before in my life but it honestly wasnt that bad. She very obviously is trying her best to help students learn. If you have any prior experience at all in programming should be an easy A and if you dont you can still more than likely get an A.
He was really good at explaining material and answering any questions that were asked.

Always was able to answer questions fully and thoroughly. Great lectures that made perfect sense, sometimes a little boring in terms of content; however, Kishore is passionate about getting the material across to students.

Prof Kishore is an amazing lecturer! Explains concepts concisely and clearly. He is very helpful and easy to talk to. His office hours are EXTREMELY helpful before exams. Projects are not too hard, beware of trick questions of exams. Bucci makes most of the exams and he has tricky questions, but not that hard. Easy assignments & graded attendance.
Professor Zweben is passionate, kind, and overall the only professor I would have wanted to take Intro to Java & Software1 with. Her teaching style is clear, effective, and very respectable.

Naomi is passionate about computer science and is very patient in explaining material. Her office hours are accessible and she goes above and beyond to make sure that her students learn. I 100% recommend you to take her class.

I don't normally write reviews but I must let everyone know that Naomi is an amazing professor. She is extremely lenient when it comes to grading and deadlines. She's also almost always available outside of class during her office hours. If you are stuck on a project or topic, she will spend as much time as she can to help you one-on-one.

I have nothing more to say, hands down the best CSE 2221 in the department. Each of the midterms and final had very easy extra credit points and the tests weren't so bad themselves. She's always quick to respond to emails and will always give a helping hand. Lectures are also recorded on zoom as well.

Great professor. She is the best professor I have ever had because she cares about her students and wants them to learn the material rather than focusing on deadlines. Very lenient on deadlines and wants her students to succeed in the class. The exams were also very fair.

CSE 2221:

Definitely a great professor I had for my first Semester at OSU. She is VERY lenient when grading exams and does not take crazy amounts of points away, especially for the coding questions on exams. Very lenient. Make sure to always do the hmwrk assignments and be 100% with attendance as those grades will be big boost to the final grade.

Naomi is the best professor I have had by far. We need more professors like her. She believes in test anxiety and is flexible with deadlines. I had to retake this class because I really struggled my first time because of the professor(and other classes), and Naomi made the class so much better. Explains concepts as if you never learned them. ICON.

I've had the pleasure of having Dr. Zweben for Software 1 and I can confirm that everything said about her here is 100% true.

She gives extra credit often and is very understanding of circumstances. She usually has a 12:40-1:35 section so take that if you want to get her for the 2024 spring semester. 

Makes CSE 2221 1000x easier.

Gives easy extra credit on exams in lieu of a curve, gives good hints for upcoming exam content, and really wants you to succeed in the class. She responds to emails pretty quickly. Just make sure to attend class as attendance is a portion of your grade.
Ms. Zweben approached each topic in a way that was easy to understand. She engaged with students during lectures and often would walk through things, step-by-step.

One of the best CS professors. She actually cares about her students and wants you to genuinely succeed in her class. She will help you if you reach out to her. This is a tough class with the material had to grasp but she is the best teacher to go with for this class.

She is a great software 1 professor. She emails back very quickly and is always willing to provide additional help with anything you may be struggling with. Her exams are not too difficult and she is very lenient with partial credit on the coding questions. The projects were hard but going to her office hours was very helpful.

Very great professor. She would work with you and checks her email a lot. I highly recommend her if you are going to take software 1. This is a relatively difficult course and I had a big learning curve to adjust to but her office hours are very helpful

Super sweet and one of the best professors I have had so far. Had her for cse 1223 autumn 2023 and she always recorded lectures, and gave helpful hints and feedback on projects. If you can have naomi I would definitely recommend her!

Naomi Zweben is the best prof I've ever had in my first year of college! She's a very caring instructor and generous grader. You would expect 3 or 5 extra credits for each of her exams (with full score of 100). She frequently holds office hours and answers questions clearly. She also writes fair exams so that there won't be any tricky questions.

This is my second time having Professor Zweben and she is just as great in SW1 as in Intro to Java. Great help on your projects and she is very good at explaining ideas or code logic if you are struggling on a concept. If you show up to class and ask for help if you are struggling, she makes this sometimes challenging course very fair.

Professor Zweben was fantastic. Her exams were very fair and she made it easy to succeed in the class. She clearly cares a lot about teaching and she even gave me an A in the class even though I was a percentage short. Highly recommend!

Awesome professor. The material was pretty boring, but she was able to make it interesting instead of reading straight from the slides. She really wants what's best for you; will give you extra days to work on projects in case you are sick or are confused on them. Also responds pretty quick to messages.
Dr. Zweben was very nice. She was very lenient regarding extensions, and her assignments were all quite easy. Even if you have no programming experience, this class will be just fine.

Great person and best professor I've had at OSU across two degrees. 2221 is a lot of work but she's amazing at explaining things and helping students when theyre struggling. Exams are tough but fair and won't make you feel like you're being tricked. Unlike other professors she understands the point of teaching is to help her students grow and learn

Dr. Zweben is super understanding and communicates the content well. She takes students' needs into consideration and recognizes that we have a life outside of class, which from my understanding is not common in the CSE department. I had her for CSE 1223 as well and I think I got a very good understanding of Java and coding practices from her.

Zweben is the best, and you definitely want her for Software 1 or any other CSE class. She is very accommodating to due dates and makes the midterms easier than the rest of the professors. She genuinely cares about your well-being and health and grades.

Naomi cares about her students and tries to know them more in depth. She is also very lenient with her extensions and exams and cares a great deal if a student is having issues. The class is very boring because of the materials but Naomi always approaches them with a happy attitude. The midterms and final were fair. Definitely take her if you can.

I absolutely loved her. She is my favorite teacher at OSU, she is so understanding and caring and genuinely wants her students to succeed. Whenever I asked her a question she would respond in a good manner.

Had her for SW 1 and I can say she truly cares about your understanding of the material. Easily reachable through office hours or email. Exams are doable. Will give you extensions to make sure you understand how to do the projects. Definitely recommend her regardless of coding experience.

Although Zybooks is mostly all that you need in this course, she really helps when its needed and understands that you have a life outside of class. She does a good job of trying to explain and also engages the class sometimes during lectures. Best professor I've had regardless of subject.
Amazing teacher, highly reccommed. The class is not difficult and if you find that it is, Professor Zweben is very helpful!

She is a decent lecturer but her saving grace is the way that the class is set up. It is really well set up for people to learn and succeed. The content is pretty easy for me so I did not show up to labs because I finished them beforehand but they have labs for help.

I was already comfortable with Java prior to taking this class, so it was pretty easy, however I thought Zweben was a great professor. She had informative lectures, always answered students' questions, and responded to my emails quickly. Can't really complain about anything.

Her lectures go over the material well and she answers pretty much all of the student's questions. She also answered emails in a timely manner and helped me out quickly when going to office hours. The material is all through Zybooks which is pretty strict on odd things.

A terrible professor who has no idea what he's teaching. His lectures are vague and unclear, and he refuses to answer any student questions. Avoid taking his class or choosing him as your advisor—you'll regret it.
A terrible teacher with poor speaking skills, clearly unprepared for class, and showing no respect for students at all.

The worst professor I've ever encountered—disrespectful, unapproachable, and unhelpful. He avoids student questions, dismisses concerns with sarcasm, and scolds anyone who emails him. His lectures lack clarity, exams don't align with class material, and he can't answer basic questions. Avoid his classes and never choose him as an advisor

Dr. Nandi is clearly very passionate about what he does and it shows in lectures. The class taught me lots about databases but I never felt overwhelmed by the work. Feedback on homeworks and projects is always very thorough and precise.
The grading is generous, but it's hard to follow many concepts during class. Problems in homework are not consistent with what he taught in class.

Arnab was an excellent professor for introducing the world of databases. After taking his class I left with a substantially different viewpoint on data. He provided a very intriguing and inclusive lecture style which was nice. Exams aren't easy so much sure to study

Arnab is a computer science GOAT. He is inspirational and makes you want to study databases as well as improve your skills outside of class. He knows what he is talking about. The tests were difficult, but at the end of the class he curved HEAVILY and everyone walked out with a very good grade. I highly recommend taking this man.

Dr. Nandi is very kind but also seems to not care too much, but maybe because our class was a bit quiet. The class is just reading 1-2 papers for each class, running a class discussion for one of those days with your group, and a semester long group project. Quizzes were a bit confusing but graded easy.

Arnab is my favorite prof this semester without a doubt. His lectures and slides are really useful and the homework is a good reflection of what we talk about in class. He does a lot of examples and has even done a few days where he just shows the results of different SQL queries. Very funny and relatable.

A good intro to databases and SQL and has a semester long group project. HW is graded on completion and exams are graded lightly. Really nice guy and pretty laid back easy course. Highly recommend trying SQL on your own, helps a lot with the material. He will love it if you make something in SQL and show it to him and also participate in class.

I wish I would have learned more in this class, but it's such a big topic to cover in a single course. Arnab was super chill which I appreciated. Graded very generously. If you really want to be proficient in SQL and database topics, in general, it's going to take a lot of outside work to gain that. He gives you a starting point, you go from there
Good lecturer. Class was relatively easy. Did not feel I learned much.
He is a very good professor and very helpful. He answers questions clearly and simply and respects excused absences. The class itself is very difficult, but he made it enjoyable and understandable.

Don't walk - RUN to take this class with Dr. Morris. Might be the best lecturer I've ever had in the CSE department. The way that his class is structured forces you to learn whether you intend to or not.
His flipped classroom style actually works well, and his exams are very fair for the content. Ask questions - you'll always know what to expect.

Great professor! Allowed me to reschedule an exam due to a last-minute conflict. His flipped classroom model, videos, and quizzes were super helpful for studying. He's an expert in the subject and truly cares about student success. Even curved my grade despite having the lowest attendance. Highly recommend—he's the GOAT.

Morris's exams aren't too bad, as he answers questions about exam content pretty thoroughly. The quizzes are a great help to your grade and also help you stay on track. The inverted classroom model can be time consuming but it does end up working out.

Great professor, exams were fair and gives ample opportunity to improve, like shifting weights of the first midterm if you do significantly better on the other two exams. Flipped classroom is done alright, lectures are pretty good, in class lectures feel a little redundant though.

Dr. Morris is the best professor that I have had thus far. He made this class approachable and was always available to answer questions about projects or homework. The tests consisted of slightly changed lab coding questions and other topics that we have already covered very well. No question ever felt unfair. Take Dr. Morris if you can.

Overall Morris is a great professor. The class itself is time consuming, especially in the flipped classroom style, but I feel like it helped me understand the content better. Midterms were difficult and long but nothing was unexpected.

hes a nice guy, he will explicitly hint at what will be on the quizzes and midterms. there is a lot of homework though and he does a flipped classroom model which I was not a fan of but it was very useful to have the videos to watch back on for studying.

Jeremy is one of the best and most kind professors I've ever had. He uses a flipped classroom, which I enjoyed, and constantly gets student feedback to improve the structure of the course. The recorded lectures come with mini quizzes and are super helpful in learning the material.

Software 2 is a very time consuming class. This time instead of 8-hour long projects like in Software 1, you now have near-daily homework that can be deceptively difficult and time-sinking. Dr. Morris is great, and the flipped-lecture style is great, although I really don't know why the recitations are mandatory. Nevertheless, very good professor.

Very good at communicating information. The projects are graded extremely strictly by the course TA's, but Morris directly grades quizzes/exams. He is a pretty relaxed grader, I definitely scored 5-10 points higher on my exams than I should've. Can sometimes be boring, but overall a pretty good professor.
This man deserves a medal. He is approachable, kind, and able to communicate complex ideas well. If you are lucky enough to win the class scheduling lottery and have him, you're in good hands.

The only reason I said that class is not mandatory is that the actual lectures are videos. The in-class lectures were mostly just explaining questions submitted after the videos. He definitely knows the topic and how to explain it, but I didn't love the online format. However, he was always willing to help and further explain if needed.

I would say Professor Morris is very patient. We had over 100 students in this class and he tried his best by trying to answer as many questions. This class maybe a lot if youre new to programming, but seemed like he was giving his best to help the students understand the materials.

Awesome at explaining Java to beginners. Exam material was based on class lectures. Course it challenging towards the end and this course requires a lot of practice with java and eclipse. If you ask question he is always ready to answer. Strongly recommend taking him as your professor for this course.
Morris is a great guy and cares a lot about his students. You will do well if you show up to class and take the class seriously. He's very accessible out of class and helps a lot.

Dr. Morris is a very good lecturer. He stayed on topic but didnt necessarily stay 100% on the slides, which I liked. He was extremely kind and helpful in office hours. I learned so much from this class and I really feel like I understood everything. Its important to study but manageable. Dr. Morris is definitely my favorite professor so far.

Dr. Morris is a great professor. To provide context to a complaint I noticed, he specifically said not to use the old tests to study, because the class is not covering the same material as last year, but was still willing to go over any questions in class from the test. He provided lots of other study materials. His class was a great experience.

Very clear lecturer. Let's you know what you need to know and what he expects of you. Also very friendly and always seems happy to help. However, he doesn't post solutions to the (single) sample exam he posts, which makes studying using practice exams practically useless since you won't be able to figure out what you do and do not know.

Professor Morris is great, one of the best lecturers I've had. He really knows the material, and if you're struggling, his office hours are helpful. His exams felt very fair. If you don't study for them, you'll fail, (learned that the hard way) and if you do study, you'll do really well.

Prof. Morris is a great professor and really cares about his students. The class itself is hard which is why having him made it bearable. He explains abstract concepts in a way thats far easier to understand and very helpful with projects in office hours and open labs. Would recommend for software 2

Prof. Morris is extremely caring and explains the concepts of this class in a very clear way. His tests are graded fairly, and he's very helpful in office hours. He genuinely cares about the students and helps as much as he can to make this difficult class, easier in terms of concepts. I would look forward to take more classes with him in future.
Lectures are boring af. Notes are useless and ambiguous. Not the best choice when learning AI. Courses available on Coursera are 1000x better.
Great guy, great professor

Professor Morris is awesome. His lectures are laid out clearly and it's obvious that he has a great understanding for the material. His tests are a little tricky at times but it's an engineering course at Ohio State, what do you expect? You get what you put in. Overall, he's a great teacher and very willing to help students out. Great in office hrs

One of the best CSE teachers at OSU. He knows the material and can explain it in a way that makes it clear to you. He's also a very good speaker so even boring lecture topics are palatable.  Assignments and exams are set for the course (like in 2221) so can't blame the lecturer for them being crappy.

He was a fantastic professor and was great at explaining himself and providing useful examples. He graded fairly, you get exactly what you deserve. He was also very helpful in office hours and genuinely cares. Great professor and a pretty good guy too.
He was really interested in AI and did a great job of explaining all topics
The best lecturer of OSU. One cannot be clearer than him. Enjoyed each and every class (although it was at 9 a.m....) exams well planned, allowing those who study to get an A.
The best lecturer I had.
Demonstrate things clearly. BUT,  harsh on grading.

He does a great job of explaining the material, in class worksheets so you have to go. He told the class that he didnt like that the first exam average was in the mid 80's so he made the second exam considerably harder and longer. average was much lower. Final project is really tedious and a lot of work under semesters. take it with another prof.

He's really patient and helpful. exams are fair. projects are really challenging, especially the last three projects. lectures are really helpful and clear. textbooks not required, they're all online.
Easy class. Got kind of difficult towards the end. Exams were very fair. Kept my interest for the whole time. Whole class based around one big project. Make sure you get a good partner early though.
great professor
Test we're very difficult.  Lectures not helpful.

This class was interesting and not difficult.  This was the professor's first time teaching the class, so the difficultly level of the assignments was a little imbalanced.  The first couple took significantly longer than the later ones.  The exams were honestly some of the easiest I've taken at OSU, but I'm not complaining.
Chill guy. Pretty monotonous but everything came pretty easy even considering I had little to no coding experience. Highly recommend taking 1224 with him if you have the choice.

Fritz is pretty chill if a little monotone. The class itself is pretty simple, and you could probably get away with skimming the notes and some of the practice problems, but I found going to lecture to be helpful. Tests are easy, and the grading scheme change meant I didn't have to take a final

I came into this class (prerequisite for my major) with no coding experience at all and managed to do very well. Lectures weren't really necessary, I went the first half of the semester and then skipped the rest and taught myself the material last minute. He claims you can't cram but I did all my studying last minute and got A+ on every midterm.

Mr. Fritz is very straightforward. His lectures are very helpful if you have limited or no coding experience. If that is you, I would recommend going to lecture and paying attention. His homework assignments and labs are helpful and relevant, and his exams were fair. Also responds quickly to questions and holds plenty of office hours.

Although this semester may be an exception, he was very understanding when the online tool we use to do labs and HW was no longer free, as he made them optional. He also made the final optional for people who did well on the first 2 midterms, which shows that he cares more about our understanding of the material. His lectures are also really good.
Hes so great and didnt make me take a final.

I found the coursework okay due to having previous Java experience. His lectures are quite good, he posts useful slides. He is understanding of students' time, is laid back and offers help when asked. Sometimes has a monotonous voice.

Overall he was alright. After the first exam, I figured out I personally study better independently, rather than following along with his lectures. The homework was fair and a good way to practice. You only had to attend labs if you hadn't finished the work beforehand.  The practice exams were comparable to the exams and final.
A cool instructor who doesn't waste your time. He is very laid back and was understanding of students.

Mike did a great job this semester in the face of health issues. He shifted to a participation-heavy approach (deciding not to do a second midterm or final), and lectures were always very engaging and interesting. I think a lot of us learned the material better that way than if we had been focused on memorization etc. Great guy and professor.

He gives clear and coherent lectures that are easy to follow and understand. The grading on projects is very fair and the midterms are not much trouble if you pay attention to lectures and labs (grading on exams is very generous).

He was a good professor, CSE 2221 is a very tough course and he did a good job teaching all of the content and was very generous about struggling with projects and content. He is overall a very nice teacher.

He was a good professor for an intro coding class, I had no previous experience with coding but he made it easy to understand and explained thing well, midterms and finals are both coding questions but he gives a ton of practice so you will be fine, labs are completion and homeworks are pretty easy if you pay attention in class

If you come for only credit, he would be a nice choice. I went to lecture everytime but never listen to that and only take picture of the code. As long as you have these notes you could do well on homework. The exam would be some kind of annoying for they are all on paper. He gives grade for steps however, even if that code doesn't work actually.

Mr.Fritz is the most generous instructor I've ever had, he once locked himself out of his office before a midterm and instead of postponing it he just gave 100 to us all. The class was on the easier side, and he gives amazing lectures despite treating for cancer and epilepsy at the same time, I really wish him a successful and speedy recovery

Very smart guy who does a good job of explaining and practicing concepts in class. Also not an excessive workload at all (seems significantly less than 1222 or 1223), and homework and exams are very reasonable as long as you keep up with the lectures.

I really re-discovered my love for coding in his class. He's very generous with grades, and does a wonderful job of lecturing about different topics and providing examples to accompany the topics. He has canceled class more than my other professors, but he's always very communicative and kind, and overall a pretty funny and really enjoyable guy!
Amazing! Only a few tests and homework without any low scores!

Super awesome guy and generous grader. He is very accessible and assignments do get bumped back, usually when he has to cancel his office hours to allow students to still have an opportunity to ask questions about assignments. He does cancel class semi-frequently but he easily makes up for it by being the most empathetic professor I've had so far.

Computer science is a concept that is best learned through actively practicing it. The professor had a set of lecture notes for students to study, and would allow students to actively write out examples during lectures. There was an ample amount of homework and labs, which allowed for more practice. A solid CS course.

You get out of his class what you put in. Lectures are optional but usually interesting, he's a fair grader, and he was pretty accessible outside of class if you have any questions. From what I heard about other software 1 professors, Mike is one of the best out there.
Michael Fritz is very disorganized and inconsistent with having notes in lecture that don't match up with online notes, answers on online notes not working, and he cancels class a lot.
In compare with other professor I knew, his grading was very kind. You can skip the lecture if you want.

Despite this class being about discrete math, he had us learn Python, which is overall completely unnecessary since we don't even cover the applications of topics until Foundations 2. What I dislike the most is that he gives no time on the quizzes that are purely based on rote memorization instead general understanding on the concepts.
Lectures were kinda dry, and he was making some stuff harder than usual. Definitely, there are better quality professors to take classes from rather than him.

Halfway through the semester, our class was switched into a different professors class due to health issues with Michael. While I had him though, he very nice and tried to get zoom to be as personal as possible. Labs were required to have cameras on and screen sharing. Even in lectures, he would ask people to turn on cameras.

Fritz occasionally provides very useful ungraded pop quizzes for us to take in class, which we go over together. He doesn't blindly follow the pre-made slides, instead he focuses on the topics that tend to be more confusing for the students, even completely deviating from the slides to help students learn better. I learned so much taking his class.
Great lecturer.

Fritz was not a bad professor, but it just didn't seem like he wanted to be there. This class is prescripted so he would often speed through two days of slides so that he could cancel the following class. Nice if you understand it easily but often left you with questions. Seems like a good guy but very short and somewhat uninterested.
Very laid-back. I took his class over the summer and it was not very difficult. I rarely had to go to office hours because he explained things very well in lecture.

though attendance isn't mandatory, definitely do not skip out on Mike's lectures. he's one of the few CSE profs I've had who actually knows how to teach his students. Even though the exams are difficult, he does try to do everything he can to prepare you for it. Definitely take if you can.

Had really high hopes based on these reviews, he mostly lived up. Best part about having Fritz is how organized the class is, with really well done notes posted to piazza on every topic. Lectures were also high quality. However, watch out for really hard exams. You need to have absolute mastery of all material. I had a hard time. HW is ez though.

GO TO CLASS. Fritz is an amazing lecturer and while his class can get a bit boring, his lectures are the best way to learn content for the class. It isn't hard to have a good grasp of every topic in the class just by going to lecture and completing the homework. The class isn't hard and the workload is low, but make sure you study well for exams.
Great lecturer, useful in-class work and discussions, so definitely worth going to class. Very helpful in class and during office hours. A master in the art of teaching.
Not the best, but I would say average

His explanation on concepts is crystal clear. Unlikely some other professors' hot mess, his learning material is REALLY well-organized. He is always at perfect lecturing speed. Even though the attendance is not mandatory, I highly recommend you showing up in his lectures. Trust me, it will help a lot.
Fritz is Amazing!!

By far the best professor I've ever had in college. If you can get a class with him, especially for Foundations I, do it, you won't regret it. He's the only professor I've ever had that made me want to go to chis lectures.

Prof. Fritz is by far the best professor at OSU. He goes above and beyond by giving practice interview questions. By far the most useful course I have taken at OSU. If you do exactly what he tells you to do on Piazza you will do well in the class.

Even though attendance is not mandatory I still attend since lectures are amazing. He's very clear about materials and instructions on homework, grading criteria etc. Definitely one of the best instructors in CSE. No curve given for the class but exams' average are usually around B. He might bump you up if you participate in class.

I loved going to this class. The material was interesting, and Fritz was very funny and explained things in a very understandable way. He always tells you exactly what will be on the quizzes, and the midterms were fair and pretty easy. Definitely a great CSE professor, and I highly recommend Fritz for any class.

Prof. Fritz is undoubtedly one of the best CSE instructors at OSU for me. He is super clear about what he teaches and what he expects from you in homeworks and exams. He documents material from every class and uploads them to Piazza. The midterms and final were fairly easy, and you would genuinely feel like going to his class. Definitely recommend!

Definitely a solid option. Lectures are interesting and expectations are very clear. The class is not too difficult if you just do the reading and work. Hardest thing was the homeworks which were long and graded somewhat harshly, but put in some time on them and you'll be fine. Tests are based 100% on what he talks about, no surprises. Recommend.

Great, clear, and friendly professor, explains difficult CSE concepts very well and is very helpful in and out of class. Fair exams and homework. Textbook (CLRS) isn't necessary but is helpful anyway. Would take classes with him again.

Prof Fritz is very clear about what he wants you to know for the projects and exams. In class he explains the topics very well and he is open to helping during office hours. Would definitely take him first if you have the option

Definitely go to class, because the majority of the material is only available in lecture.  If you go though, the class is very easy.  Exams and quizzes are straightforward and fair, and he's an awesome guy all-around.  Doesn't do trick questions, gives you plenty of heads-up on homework and quizzes, and is super helpful if you're confused.

Great prof. Takes time in class to explain concepts to students in clear, concise language. Grades very fairly. Treats students like adults, so attendance not mandatory. My only complaint was that on occasion he came off as a bit lazy with grading, but in terms of help outside of class, he was very willing to put in extra time to help. Recommended!

Fritz is one of the best teachers at Ohio State, hands down. Every class you need to graduate, if Fritz is teaching it--take his section. He cares about teaching as a profession in and of itself; it really shows in his classes. Prepare to feel like a respected student from a respected school. A top notch, world class professor.
I personally loved having Fritz as a teacher. The coursework was very easy but I still went to most lectures because of how entertaining he was. Try to get him for any course you can!

He is a great professor! He is extremely clear about what will be on exams, and is very fair.  I never found the exams to be too challenging.  He teaches the lectures concisely and gives a lot of review problems for exams that are very helpful.  He is always willing to answer questions from students.

Really didn't seem too friendly at all so I never went to his office hours but I still got so much out of his lectures; he explains the concepts really clearly and emphasizes what's important to know for tests and everything. Needless to say, I learned a lot from him, even though I took the class without much prior experience. I'd recommend him!

One of the best professors I've had. He's explains concepts clearly, and is very helpful when you need help and ask questions (especially if you go to his office hours).  His classes are laid back, and he is very interactive with the class. There's quite a bit of homework and projects, but that's more due to the structure of the course, not him.

Professor Michael Fritz was an amazing teacher! The material he teaches is challenging, but he makes it so much easier to understand! When in his lectures, you can tell that he really cares about the subject and the students and wants to see them succeed. Homework can be challenging, but he grades fairly and does not expect answers to be perfect.

Very clear instructor, makes the sometimes confusing world of CSE seem very simple. Some of the projects are quite a bit of work, don't procrastinate too much. The exams are very tricky, but if you learn to look for the "gotcha" trick in every question you'll do well.
Best teacher ever. Yes, he's a little slow grading assignments, but he's really helpful, clear, and understanding. If you can take a class with him, TAKE IT

Mike is awesome! I've attended three different universities and Mike is by far the best Computer Science instructor I have ever had.  He often deviates from the canned course power points to illustrate what he believes are the key and most practically useful points. Very laid back and funny class atmosphere if you engage him.

Friendly, helpful, one of the best professors I have met in Ohio State. Classes are not hard, he always interacts with students. Sometimes worksheets are hard, but they are just kind of brain teasers. Tests are easy if you study for it. Seldom checks for attendance. Not too much homework. All in all, 1010 would recommend. And, thank you, Mike. :-)
Lectures were pretty straight forward. Nothing surprising on the exams. Gave fewer quizzes than he initially planned, so he only counted them if they would help a student's grade.

IF YOU CAN TAKE A CLASS FROM FRITZ, TAKE IT. This is the second course Ive taken that Fritz has taught and I can say without a doubt that he is the best CSE prof Ive had at OSU. He is extremely organized, gives fair homeworks and quizzes, and grades fairly. He is very straightforward, explains materials well, and moves at a reasonable pace.

I really loved this class. The organization of the course material was very straightforward and enjoyable. He was willing to explain concepts and problems to the class. Homeworks and exams were not too bad. The course requires a lot of critical thinking, but Fritz was a very good professor.

Fritz is nice and is willing to answer questions. His Foundations class was nice in that he didn't force us to learn things we'd never need to use again, unlike the other professors. Definitely the easiest of the bunch and pretty good at explaining things.
Decent teacher. He is pretty lazy and takes forever to grade exams. Other than that, he is good at explaining the concepts and is a nice guy. Would recommend taking Software 1 with him.

Pooya makes a great Lecturer. Although the content is hard, I learned incredibly well from his lectures.

Attend lectures for the best value - although the posted notes are usually good enough. 

Most of your grade is from the exams. The grading scale in this class is VERY lenient to compensate.

He is also very friendly, and always a good chat.

Dr. Hatami for sure makes this course hard. But with the curves he gives on the exams and final grade he is very fair about it. I actually learned enough in this class that I barely had to study for foundations 2 or foundations of higher mathematics. Don't get me wrong the course is hard. But it's graded very fairly and you will learn a lot.

To be honest, this course comes with a lot of practice regardless of the professor. Pooya is a fantastic teacher. He can sometimes be blunt about his grading policies, but I'd suggest going to his office hours or email him if you are struggling. Compared to other CSE 2321 professors, he didn't have live Zoom class so definitely don't skip it.
The average grade was very low and he had no problem with that, grading was extremely harsh almost as if he enjoyed seeing his students fail.

He gives in depth lectures and provides a more rigorous treatment of Foundations 1 compared to other professors. Homework and exams are difficult but letter grades are assigned so that A = 80%, ... so the class is "curved". It is clear that he really enjoys the material and teaching.
Pretty good lecturer and taught the material very well. The grades were based mostly on the homeworks, which were difficult but manageable. The class material was pretty interesting as well.

Pooya is an amazing professor for Foundations 1. His lectures are engaging and motivating, and the grading always seems fair. He is super understanding with the COVID-19 situation as well. He is the best professor I've had at OSU so far.
Pooya is a very understanding professor. Hes always willing to answer questions, and his midterms seem fair. A great teacher.

Given that this is Prof Hatami's First semester teaching a class Compounded with the COVID-19 Pandemic I believe he has done as well as to be expected. The class itself is extremely difficult in general, but one thing I really appreciate about Pooya is his flexibility and understanding at how hard this semester specifically is for students.

Pooya is one of the worst professors I have had at OSU. He constantly makes students feel dumb for asking questions about material that he is incapable of explaining. He should not be teaching a near-intro CSE class, he makes everything 10x harder than any other prof teaching the course and it makes for an extremely frustrating time. Steer clear.
I don't really understand poor rating. Good Prof. trying his best to teach students.
Had an absolutely wonderful opportunity to know him well at MICxN.

The course was well-structured, and once I got into the rhythm of the material, it became engaging and easy to follow. Professor Soni was supportive and always willing to clarify doubts, making learning a smoother experience. Taking an active approach—regular revision, asking questions, and staying involved—helped me get the most out of the course.
He is good. Don't be fooled by the false first impression. I enjoyed studying with him.

The classes were rocky at first but then when I got a hang of the subject, relatively easy to follow. Professor Soni cared for my performance in the course and was happy to help with some doubts when I approached him after class. Once I was a little proactive (reading, revision, asking doubts, etc.), the course turned around for me.

Professor Soni is easily one of the worst professor I've had for the past 3 years. Not only is he teaching in most confusing way possible, but he also don't understand students' questions most of the time. His exams are weirdly worded, and you must match his sample answer exactly.
Half the class got lower than B-, avoid at all cost.
Cares a lot about the students' learning. Gives a lot of opportunities for asking questions. Fast responses to emails. All these make Prof. Byna an awesome educator.

The lecture slides/lectures in general are missing a lot of information we need to know for the assignments. Difficult to find the information needed. Also, the grading was all over the place. Some assignments would be graded very easily and others I would get -20 points even being close to the answer. The average on the final exam was a 58.

Avoid both Suren and Spyros. Take this course from Christopher. If no choice, take it in the next semester w/ Christopher. I mean it. Suren is unwilling to help during his office hour and TA doesn't know anything about this class.

Terrible professor, I did not learn anything from lectures.  He just read off of slides or worksheets that another professor made.  The content was easy to learn just by doing the pre-labs, but they take a long time.  Attendance is not mandatory for lecture or lab times, so you can really do the entire course as self-study, just don't forget exams.

Did a good job, I went to class about 75% of the time and never spent more than 2 hours throughout the week doing the class work. exams were easy and I feel I still retained good knowledge on how to use excel.
He was always very nice, and the class is pretty easy. The labs and pre labs give you detailed instructions on how to complete them. There are open hours of a lab where there are always TAs.

His lectures were sometimes a bit monotone, but it didn't make class that hard. The prelabs and labs can take a few hours, so don't wait until the last minute. He is a very kind person, and he is always willing to help if you go to his office hours.

Went into this class with no Excel or Access experience and was able to do extremely well. Going to the open lab is helpful for pre labs that can be stressful. Going to the in labs is super helpful the TA's will give you the answers and you can ask students around you. Exams were super easy I didn't study for any of them and got 100%.

Good Professor, you can ask him questions after class. The homework is heavy but is normal for CSE classes. 3 tests, 2 midterms, and 1 final, not bad, first learn by yourself, review each PowerPoint, take notes and remember the functions, practice hard, then you will definitely get an A.
He is a very kind professor and cares for students very much. If you have any problem with prelab, inlab or exam, just go to him and he will be ready to answer it.

Going to lectures and lab was not necessary; he just read off the slides. He was super monotone and I could barely stay awake during class. This class wasn't too hard though, I could easily teach it to myself. The pre-labs and in-lab assignments would take hours sometimes, so make sure you don't procrastinate.

The lectures aren't really useful (I stopped going to them a week into the semester) because you have to read the notes to get an A on the quizzes so I just studied the weekly note pdfs and slides and I did pretty well from that. He's a pretty good prof and easy to talk to, just not the most enthusiastic. I loved this class and I'd take it again.

Not a terrible prof, but also not an amazing one. Lectures are pretty boring and not necessary to learn the material. You can learn most of the content on your own through the weekly Pre-Labs and In-Labs. Most of your grade is decided by weekly quizzes, two midterms, and a final. As long as you do the work the class is super easy.

Personable and caring; his lectures are slow and he reads off the slides but he actively tries to make class more engaging and useful. Course is really easy and easy to self-study; lectures and lab aren't required to attend. He also frequently mentions using his office hours; he wants to see his class succeed! The best lecturer for the class.

Professor Jackson is a very good hands-on professor. He often is always welcome to help students with the homework if they ask and he will then walk you through how it is often done. Class as a whole is very organized but could be challenging for those who don't have some experience with Excel or Access. The class as a whole was taught pretty well.

Mark is just not a good lecturer at all but attendance is not necessary. Can learn most of the content from the prelabs. Lab attendance isn't required either but I recommend going because you can get all the answers from TAs and classmates. Overall the class was very easy and pretty useful. The tests aren't hard either, all multiple choice.

Attendance in labs and lectures is not mandatory. Pre-labs and labs are very easy, but they can take at least 1-2 hours to complete. Lectures can be boring and most of the material can be learned with very minimal studying and through the pre-labs. Do your work and you'll do well.
The class can be kind of confusing but show up to lectures and they will make more sense. Always very clear about deadlines and upcoming exams

The class was pretty simple. The labs take approximately 2-3 hours for both the prelab and lab which isn't bad considering you have a week to do them. Tests and quizzes are just multiple choice with straightforward answers. The course material seemed pretty intuitive. Pretty easy to get an A, just study course notes 20-10 minutes before quiz/test/

This class wasn't to difficult for me bc I had to teach myself thru YT videos bc he doesn't do great job during lecture&when you ask him a question he doesn't give a clear answer he has to go back and read his own slides, sometimes you get stuck and he doesn't know how to explain, however,he is a nice teacher. And exams are hard. good luck on labs
Seems like a great guy. Class is not difficult at all.

Very hard class with hard labs weekly. Exams are impossible however they grade them very easily. Mark Jackson was the nicest professor ever and really cared about his students doing well. Attendance isnt mandatory however I enjoyed going.
This class was not bad and i love mark jackson with my whole heart. Hes always so happy when u show up to class and there is a curve!! Labs r also easy--> tas will give u all the answers

Be prepared to self study a lot. The material isn't hard and you will get an A if you do the worksheets/ study yourself by watching videos. I left lecture feeling like I didnt learn much but after going back through it, the content isn't hard. The labs are very easy and the pre labs are really just time consuming. It's very easy to get help on them

Mark does a very poor job of lecturing. Half of the time he makes mistakes and the other half is him copying from his notes. The labs and prelabs of this class are extremely easy. There are three quizzes and you can drop your lowest grade. The Midterm and Final are tough but there are a lot of materials online to help you study.

Not the most interesting class. Lectures are very dull, and he doesn't really do that good of a job explaining w/o just reading directly off the ppt. I basically just watched the lecture videos online and didn't pay attention in class. Some pre-labs are difficult and time-consuming, but overall the content wasn't tooooo difficult.
Mark is a cool guy but is hard to understand if you are a visual learner. I could have learned more outside of the lecture on my own than what he taught me... the class itself is not too bad though.

Lectures not very helpful. I found course notes that are posted helpful. Some pre-labs are very time consuming. Three quizzes (one dropped), one midterm, and a final. Worksheets are more or less graded on completion. Decent amount of work, but easy A if you put in effort.

He will just read straight off the powerpoints that are posted online. No need to attend class. CSE 2111 is an independent learning course and does not require much use of a professor. Be prepared for long hours of pre labs and worksheets every week.

Very monotone. Nothing much to say about Jackson as I've been to class under 10 times. A few lectures and the quizzes and midterm. Everything you need to succeed is on carmen so you don't need to show up to class anyways. The way CSE 2111 is set up the lecturer doesn't matter much anyways so just put in the work and you'll easily get at least a B.

He was really boring and read the slides during lecture. since attendance wasnt required, it was better to watch the lecture videos online that the director posts. The practice problems on carmen are very helpful, and the practice quizzes are good too. overall this class wasnt too bad, but it was a lot of work to do well.

Mark Jackson is the best man I've ever been acquainted with in my entire life. His voice is like smooth butter, his lectures are absolutely fascinating. I look forward to coming to this class every week I wish I had it everyday. I would absolutely recommend this class.
He's very nice. He always answers all questions patiently.  He is a perfect professor after all!
He's nice
Unprofessional

I took this class for my major and hated it because I already knew the material. Having talked with people it seems that this class is either really easy or really hard. I rarely went to lectures because he just read the slides that were posted online and attendance wasn't part of our grades. When I did go he just read the slides in a boring voice.
Just a terrible professor who reads PowerPoint and does not know any of the material.

All this guy does is stand up there and read the power point. All the power points are posted online so, I usually don't even go to class. They have an attendance sheet, but it doesn't count for anything so i don't know why they do it.  The average grade for his quizzes are much lower than the same quiz with another lecturer.

He's a pretty good lecturer I suppose. I can tell he cares about his students because he's always asking if we understand the material and will always go back and (attempt) to clarify what anyone doesn't understand. He's quite boring though, so be prepared.

He is the lecturer for my CSC 2111 class. He is a nice guy and very easy going. He explains everything step-by-step and frequesntly asks the class, "does this make sense to you?" or "how many of you guys got that right?" and then he follows up with "If you got this wrong, does it make more sense now?" The labs are challenging, but Mark is a great

Good lecturer, friendly, and always happy to help with questions. The class does a good job of teaching computer science concepts. The teaching methods feel kind of old-fashioned (for a CS course) in my opinion, but the instruction is still great. I can't find anything bad to say about the program, course, or instructors.

I loved Laine when I had her. Very accessible outside of class, has office hours almost every day after class. Also very helpful when it comes to feedback with projects/labs. Definitely knows what she's talking about. Software 1 is kind of boring in general and she doesn't do much to alleviate that, but is still a good lecturer.

The class is pretty tough but Laine is very understanding. She's flexible with deadlines if you have something come up. I struggled with some of the concepts in the course, like recursion, but was able to do better on the final because of the practice problems she suggested.
Very knowledgeable about the material and great in office hours. The lectures are helpful, especially when we do practice problems.

Laine is a great instructor who really cares about teaching. She goes out of her way to give specific examples in class, which can help flesh out complicated concepts. She also gives advice for what do/what is on exams.

Laine really cares about students and always gives opportunities to turn in work late. She also hosts extra review sessions and gives practive problems in class that really help on exams. She's a great professor!

If you come in with lots of experience in the class then taking Laine would be best since she always ends classes early, just reads off of Osu's slides, doesn't bother making lectures interesting, and always suggests going to the TAs. Laine is direct which comes off cold, but for the most part, she was chill. Hands off in labs.

Would definitely recommend Laine for SW1, as she's a great lecturer and is willing to clarify topics outside of class or in office hours. She also gives good advice for studying for exams and is lenient on the attendance.

Her lectures were good, answers questions, stays on topic, and seems knowledgeable enough to help us when asked. Hands off in labs, lets graders run things and is lenient on participation grades. Can't say much about her office hours, only went once and it worked best for me when I made clear what I was thinking and what I didn't understand.

Fantastic professor, available often and gives very helpful feedback/advice. Make sure to start projects early and ask questions as they come up - the course changes as the tools used get updated so things may change from the examples and rubric. Super fun course, biggest focus is the semester project and that is fully led by you!
Carter is a chill guy

We only had six projects and they're not hard coding, mostly just using security tools to solve some simple real life problems.
For the final, there's no exam. Just a group project. And all my friends got high scores. Wish my other classes are like this.

Carter is one of the best professors I had. He's a really nice guy who knows what he's doing.

I didn't know anything about security before I took this class and I passed with flying colors! Each lecture talks about different stuffs in this area. 

Nothing is particularly hard and there's no math or anything in this class!

Carter is one of the best professors I have had at Ohio State to date. He takes so much time outside of class to ensure you understand the content, and is very passionate about his work. His lectures are full of his experiences in the industry so you learn so much more than what a textbook could provide. If you need to take 5472, take it with him!

I don't get why people here like him. A classic yapper and everything he says is common sense. Give off petty vibe as well. He looks like he'll take revenge on your paper/presentation grade if he finds out you don't like his class.

Second day in his class and the dude just loves to say the word "like" I can't unhear it. I have no idea if I will survive his way of talking. I sweat the bro says "like" after every word. I CANT UNHEAR IT

He's clear on what he expects of you. This class is purely based on a paper and a presentation, and attendence is HUGE. You're expected to get a certain amount of discussion contributions, and missing a class or not getting those will really hurt you. As long as you prep for the presentation and try for the paper, you can do decently.

This 1-credit course requires the effort of a 3-credit course. The grading is strict, with the average grade hovering around a B. Missing a draft slide deadline by just one minute guarantees a zero with no exceptions. It is hard to imagine how I ended up with B- in a 1-credit course, especially when I have received A's in all other CSE core courses

Doesn't give scores higher than 94 for the presentation and paper that are worth 60% of your grade.  Rambles about adjacent topics to questions, preventing students from getting 15 discussion contributions. Any single missed attendance counts off your final grade. Strict and very old-school with policies, potentially too much for 1 credit.

Pretty clear about what he expects from his class and expects you to attend class and participate. Overall great instructor who cares for his students and leaves detailed feedback on all assignments. Very paper / presentation heavy. Sometimes assignment expectations are vague and tedious to follow but he'll clear anything up if you ask him.

When he answers questions he always says so much that you don't know what he's trying to say. There was no separate feedback for the paper draft, and I had no idea how to revise the paper. attendance is very important. You must attend every class,which too strict for a one credit class. Please consider other teachers if there are other options.

Pretty clear about expectations for the class, and is friendly/approachable most of the times. A bit of a stickler about everything (attendance, format for e-mailing him). Agree with the other review about how garrulous he is. Would prefer it if he gave tighter lectures and made assignment rubrics and participation less tedious to follow.

Decent professor. Class is pretty easy and you don't have to know anything going in. I think that he rambles a lot  (think when you're trying to hit the min word count on an essay, but speaking) which makes lectures hard to follow since virtually nothing he says or answers is to the point. Fair grader and nice person, though.
You can not go wrong with Dr. Weaver. Tough grader but put in work and get an A

Did a very good job teaching us the subject matter and encouraging us to think for ourselves. Requirements are pretty lax and if you actually pace your work (ie not starting a paper due in 4 weeks on the last night), you definitely have enough time to do everything. Gave me real skills that I'll be needing for other classes.

Must participate course to pass the course. Dr. Weaver is alright, but the course makes no sense. Failed on both paper and presentation because I don't really what I should do. Again, Dr. Weaver is alright, just the course itself sucks.
This guy is a boss! An awesome prof who knows when to make a class easy. You have to show up and participate, but he makes the lectures engaging and relevant. Take him if you have the chance!

He seems like a cool guy but his grading scale is broken. You are only graded on 3 things so if you do average on 1 of the assignments it's really difficult to get an A. He grades very subjectively and expects far more work than a 1 credit hour class should require.
Fantastic lecturer with very reasonable expectations. Generated interesting discussion, well-structured and enjoyable course.

I took Dr. Weaver's course for my professional ethics course although I wasn't a CSE major. He's an amazing lecturer, really tried to engage and listen to the class. There are barely any assignments so it's really nice that you can just go and listen to him. Learning normative ethics at the beginning can be rough but it pays off in the end.

Dr. Weaver is a great teacher that helped to bring life to a class that is otherwise a bit boring and tedious. Sets out expectations very well at the beginning of class. Course is pretty reading-heavy but the texts are written at a level very acceptable for the course level, not too easy or hard. Has an appreciation for swearing, so be warned!

Dr. Weaver is a great teacher. He looks like a tough biker, but he's a really nice guy.  He really puts thought into the structure of the class. I really enjoy when he has us discuss as a class. Mandatory attendance, but you should be going anyways! His lectures are really interesting, and a nice break from all the math of engineering.

He's very caring. The tests can be tricky but at the end of the day it's just a math class and if you do the homework and practice problems you will be prepared enough especially with the curve. I think it helps to also be in 3345.

Nice guy it seemed, very generous curves but also hard exams. No slides so have to show up to lectures and you can't really prepare for exams well without feeling really comfortable with everything possible. Super generous homework policy and he does want to help. You'll be okay

Professor Rossi is a great guy, but a bad lecturerer.  There were a number of issues with the course, but most stem from how he graded the exams and his bad lectures.  You will not know what you're in for prior to the exam because he teaches it poorly and won't cover all the topics in the slides.  Study for exams using Professor Painter's videos

Intelligent, patient, and kind professor with great lectures who went above and beyond to help me. My only complaint is that the curve at the end replaces midterm 2 with your final grade if it was better, and no curve (I think) otherwise. Might be biased since this specifically hurt me but I think it's unfair for those who did better on midterm 2.

Dr. Rossi is great professor and I felt like I learned a lot. His lectures can get confusing as he can skip around and he makes hard homeworks. However, if you come to over office hours he helps a lot and makes the homeworks very easy. He gives good curves and his test are very similar to the homework.

Very nice person, very generous grader and curves tests. Lectures were a little slow paced and we covered less material than most other sections. He was also a little unorganized. Homework can be pretty difficult at times, and he did not always explain things perfectly so it was sometimes hard to complete, but the exams were a bit easier.

Caring guy. Helped a friend land an internship and another get into grad school. Was nearly convinced to chug a redbull at our final. Told us what was on the test in lecture. Generous HW policy and curves. Super responsive to questions online. Know the homework and quizzes and trust the process.

his lectures are no help, & do not correspond to the homework he gives out which are super hard so u have to start early. very blunt which comes off as rude, not super friendly. acts as if u know already how to do stuff & doesn't set up good examples. its hard to gauge what he expects on the homework & tests since he doesnt provide anything useful
His lecture is disorganized, content too messy. He is also unfriendly. Feel difficult to have a good study on his class, better to change your section as early as you can

Disorganized. Hard to follow. Lectures are scattered thoughts and his hand written notes are worse. Makes everything overly complicated and more confusing.

Avoid his classes.

He's a cool guy and generous on grade. But his lecture is not really helpful and there's not much material provided other than slides.(his slides just has some code but no analyzing and answers, so not helpful) And the questions on hw and exams are...weird. I gave him a 4 bc he is a nice person but hmmm maybe not a super good lecturer.

His class is not that hard. He is ALL OVER THE PLACE IN THE LECTURES though. He seems to come to class unprepared with materials and just lectures off the top of his head. Make sure you attend classes since there is no powerpoint slides he provides.

Professor Rossi is clearly knowledgeable about the class material, however he would often get distracted or side-tracked in class. This required some out-of-class review to accurately understand the material, which was manageable but a little annoying.

One of my fav classes! He's super chill and easy going. His curves are god sent, as long as he sees you understand the concepts, you'll get a more than decent grade. Hws graded fairly and his feedback is really helpful. He jumps around a lot in lecture (his ADHD really shows) so lectures can be difficult to follow if you don't keep up.

He will elaborate as much as needed to make sure the class understand the content thoroughly. Tests are pretty fair and curved tremendously. Homework is graded generously. Lectures are sometimes a bit hard to follow, but loosely align with his notes. If you are a good note taker or follow well with chalk board lectures, I would recommend!

Although I thought I had a pretty good grasp of the material, I thought there was fair test material such as more graph theory proofs, computing time complexity. But this guy has packaged a simple concept into a very difficult question, and the test is not at all about how well you learn, but whether you can understand the question.

Nice guy, really cares about making sure students understand what's going on. Tests are pretty fair and curved. Homework is graded generously. Only issue is that lectures are sometimes a bit hard to follow since he jumps all over the place, but not a huge issue at the end of the day. Would recommend!
He is a disorganized messed. Nearly impossible to read what he writes. Rambles. Explains a lot but says nothing. Avoid. Worst class I have ever had. How does anyone allow him to teach?
Very unorganized and frankly doesn't teach very well. I don't recommend taking his class at all.

His lectures are some of the most disorganized I've ever seen: his handwriting is atrocious, he writes all over the page, and he will go back and change what he writes constantly. He will go off on long tangents and his explanations only leave you more confused. In a subject where clarity is crucial (algorithmic analysis), Rossi could not be worse

He isnt clear when communicating in lecture and leaves a lot of people confused at the end. He does take forever to post anything. Trys his best to be helpful though. Cant say he succeeds but he tries.

Alfred was extremely accessible outside of class when I struggled with certain material. Lecture notes can be difficult to understand if you do not attend lecture so I heavily recommend attending every meeting. Great professor would definitely take him again
Tests were hard and graded harshly but curved well. There was a class discord that ended up being a super valuable resource for studying and doing homework.

Very nice guy. Rossi was very lenient for adjusting grades/schedule. Lectures help a lot, even if the handwriting is difficult to get used to. Homeworks are based on mostly lecture and textbook (attend and read). Tests were difficult, but mostly application from homework/lectures/textbook. I recommend taking the class with Rossi.
Assignments were fair and gave a VERY generous curve on all tests. Sometimes lectures were a bit unclear but he always answered any questions in the discord or in office hours

He's a very nice guy and definitely wants to help you but is not a very good teacher. Class lacked practice problems and the content was way to theoretical based. Not good with exam prep and homeworks were insufficient and all you could do was read about the concepts and not practice them like for the exam. Had to learn most of this outside him.

His notes are unreadble for people who haven't taken the class, and he will often stop sending recorded videos suddenly without informing the students. The algorithm is simple, but he makes the learning process very complicated.

He's a nice guy overall and definitely wants to help you be successful, but isn't the best at explaining concepts. Rambles through several concepts and struggles to get to the point. Not the best at test prep as there wasn't enough study materials or practice. I did like the content though and his industry experience is definitely inspirational.
Great professor. The material isn't the easiest, but if you put in the time you will be successful. Is much more theory focused so expect to do more discrete mathematics than other classes.
Tests are hard and grades tough but curves heavily and gives out a lot of extra credit. Genuinely cares that students are prepared for next class, is really helpful during office hours
Good lectures. Tries to engage class. Tests arent easy but doable.

Alfred works really hard to make sure everyone is doing well in the class. If you zone out or miss a lecture, you're going to have to put in a lot of work to catch up. He doesn't work out of a textbook and doesn't post notes regularly. However, in and out of class he's very responding to questions and happy to help you with whatever you're lost on.

She speaks in a strange manner but you can tell she is well educated and passionate about the material she's teaching. She's a good lecturer but you have to pay attention. She didn't write the assignment documents for labs but they're the worst. She has 4 midterms + a final. She often repeats questions from previous exams. Some extra credit chances

I had Professor Kelley for Systems 1 but I didn't see an option to select that course. This was one of the harder cs classes. Definitely be ready to spend a lot of time outside of class understanding the material. Lectures can be boring but I learned a lot. She splits exams into 4 instead of 2 big ones and she responds pretty quickly on discord

I agree with whoever said these reviews don't give her justice. Systems 1 is a hard class and i honestly think she did a great job of explaining it as simply as she could. She is very generous grader on exam and also allows for extra credits on homework. She's very easily accessible outside of class via discord and is so knowledgeable!!!

Dr. Kelley is the goat!!!! despite what all the other reviews say she's very forgiving, very helpful and responsive on discord. Her grading is VERY fair and the exams are a little tough but you get a cheat sheet. She's much better than what her reviews say, its just that she teaches a tough class.

Course is extremely backloaded which adds to the burden of finals week. Labs 1-3 are reasonable enough but after that they take hours upon hours to complete. The third homework is very tedious and isn't a fair assessment of students' knowledge. Dr. Kelley is nice but can be unresponsive at times.

her lectures can get dry and hard to follow but there were some in-class activities involved. her homework and exams were fair, her labs were confusing sometimes but she is pretty accessible via discord. there was just a lot to memorize in this class but she graded fairly and was always happy to help and answer questions

Kelley is not as bad as the other reviews say. She's dry and talks very slowly and quietly, but explains things well. There's so much content in Sys2 and so much to memorize, but her reviews are a great study tool. The homework was helpful but it was all due within a four week span..
