The labs are kind of weird, but she answers questions on discord.

I honestly can't believe the past ratings are from 2016...it's as if she has not learned any teaching skills whatsoever. Whether I went to class, watched her online lectures, or both, I would have to rely on the textbook and third party resources to learn the content. If you have her, use Neso Academy on YT to study and learn. Very underprepared.

Read the book. Like the other guy said, it seems like this is her first class, like, ever, so I feel bad going off on her, but her lectures are so bad. I feel like making this an online course would have been virtually the same deal, and would have saved me some gas.

Jaimie Kelley is a new at teaching and it shows. Though she is not very experienced, over the semester she has grown a lot in her teaching ability. Even so, the class itself is very difficult; mostly because of the lack of teaching ability and dry material. Jaimie does create helpful review sheets for the midterms though, which helped a lot.

He's a really great guy, most of the reading is really easy. Classes are like open discussions and he's very supportive of exploring different viewpoints. He's a younger professor and is very clear about how to get an A on assignments and in the class. Hard to do bad in this class if you complete your assignments. Groups are based on desired grade

Great Philosophy professor for CSE. Classes are built around group discussion and acts as a mediator for controversial topics. We read a lot of written pieces, book excerpts, and essays on the growing tech space. He's very flexible and not at all strict. Also just a wonderful person to talk to. Best 2501 professor in my opinion.

He's a researcher forced to lecture. The assignments and exams were fine, but his lectures are bad. He struggles to answer students' questions and often skips around problems and erases a lot of work when he makes frequent mistakes.
The course is online flipped course, and I have attended a couple of weeks and feeling I learned little things during the 1 hour 20 minutes class. The requirements of Labs are not well written.

Easily one of my favorite professors I've taken at OSU! I'm not super interested in networking, but his lectures were great and intriguing, and it being online is super convenient. As many have said, he is ridiculously accessible outside of class, and is always willing to help as long as you put in the effort!

Dave was my favorite professor I've ever had at OSU. It felt like he wanted to be teaching us (unlike most of the profs I've had at OSU). I honestly have zero complaints about him. Ridiculously available outside of class to answer any questions. Take his class if you have the opportunity, you won't regret it.

Great guy who made the class very interesting and engaging. The exams can be odd at times but he knows that he is imperfect with making exams and is willing to make changes after. The labs are not bad, but you need to start early. I recommend doing the online book exercises and watching the math videos he uploads. Very accessible as well.

He managed to make a completely online class in a topic I don't care much about (sorry!) really engaging. He's great at explaining difficult concepts in a way that makes sense to students. (Ridiculously) accessible outside of class and helpful. Lectures are great, but I would recommend reading the textbook beforehand to get a deeper understanding.

BEST professor during my time at OSU. He always found ways to make the material way more interesting than I bet it would've been with anyone else. Dave's the kind of professor who'll do everything he can to help you out. I can't say enough good things about him, both as a professor and as a person.

Always available for questions in and outside class. His lectures are super descriptive that pull from many analogies that really enhance the understanding of the material. Quizzes, midterms, and projects are  reasonable. Projects (2 of them) can be tough, but he provides plenty of time and help to get started on them. Phenomenal professor overall.

2 labs. the second one is tough but doable. 1 midterm, quiz after every chapter, a final, 2 easy hws. I attended both ogle's and the new professor's class for the first week and ogle definitely taught the material better. So take him if you can!!!! He breaks the material in a way you'll 100% understand. If you're stuck GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS. 10/10

Dave is a great guy. But the course is comprised entirely of labs, which have very unclear specifications and guidelines. Labs are tested all at once publicly instead of by the grader, which leads to unnecessary stress when code doesn't work. And your code probably won't work, due to changing requirements and unclear specifications.

As a senior in CSE Dave was my all time favorite professor. He is truly passionate and gets excited about the material and makes it interesting. Despite being completely on zoom I felt that I had a more personal connection with him than any other professor. Labs are tough but there were only 2 and if you start early they are not bad.

His networking class is fairly tough, the second project being one that requires a lot of effort. However, he is awesome and is willing to work with students 100% of the time and even willing to make time after hours. One of my favorite professors in a while.
Niceeee professor!
He tries to make this class more fun. Emails back pretty fast. Pop quizzes are easy. Quizzes are rough from time to time. Exams are fair.

Dave knows how to teach networking. He has some sort of uncanny ability to take difficult concepts in this course and effortlessly turn them into simple explanations and/or analogies that we, young adults, get. His networking course is online, but he really knows the online medium and utilizes to it's full potential.

One of the best professors! He's so passionate and uses the best analogies so everyone understands. The topic of networking is tough to keep up, but he makes it really interesting. Projects, quizzes, and exams are pretty hard and taken straight from the slides, but you have to really listen and read between the lines to get 100s. highly recommend

Honestly, I wish every professor could be like Dave. He legitimately wants you to succeed, and is crazy accessible outside of class. While he can't move the due dates of homework and quizzes, Dave will do absolutely everything he can to help you. I cannot say enough good things about him as a professor or a person.

Most caring professor I have had here. It is obvious he just wants to help you learn. He is an effective teacher too and attempts to use metaphors a lot. The course contents are predetermined by the course coordinator but he tried to clarify things. I never went to office hours but he always posted extra hours and still smiled at me in class.

Can't comment on my grade yet since i'm still in the first month of the course but Ogle is just a super nice dude. If you need his help figuring something out, he does a great job explaining things so that you actually understand. Even just 4 weeks into the class, he's one of my favorite professors so far. He really cares about his students.
Very chill and understanding.

Dave has been my favorite professor at OSU! He is an awesome lecturer, the exams and quizzes are super fair, and he is always willing to go above and beyond to help any student. I would highly recommend him to anyone!

Ogle is a fantastic professor. He really cares about students and is super passionate about networking. Exams were super reasonable and were very similar to the quizzes. Reading the textbook was also very useful to prepare for quizzes/exams. I thought the class was an easy A, and Ogle made the material enjoyable and interesting.

Dave is an amazing guy! He was high up at IBM that just started teaching, but his knowledge is immense. While his organization leaves a little to be desired, he's still probably my favorite CSE prof! The class is time-consuming being a capstone and all, but he does give you time to work on stuff most classes. FYI: He calls ppt slides "charts"

I enjoyed this class by the end. I expected it to be easy, so I ended up getting a little overwhelmed. Once I put more time into this class, it was easier to understand. The labs were a lot of fun to complete, but make sure you stay on top of them. They can save you if you don't do well on exams, as the exams are 150 points and only 15 questions.

Claire does a good job explaining the lectures, although they can become very boring. She is very helpful during her office hours if you need help. lots of HW and busy work to boost your grade as well in case you don't do well on a test. Just stay on top of the pre labs and in labs and you should be fine.
would not recommend her - rude, superior, no help when needed

Straight forward class with 2 exams and an online final test. Professor Claire is a nice person and willing to answer students' questions. However, she is somehow pushing fast in her lectures and you might need to do some self-study after class. The excel & database pre-lab and lab assignments are time-consuming but the attendance is not required.

A good teacher, very boring lectures however. Really monotone but good at going through excel, which can be hard to teach in lecture format. Overall good at explaining how to learn excel. Class itself is useful but very meticulous yet not hard, but each lab and prelab has very specific answers/requirements that can take a long time to complete.

Went to about 5 classes at the start of the semester. Excel really can't be taught in lecture form, so I just stopped going and figured out everything on my own. Really easy class. Accidentally missed a whole pre-lab and I still finished with an A. Quizzes are harder than the exams.

Very straightforward, rather boring lectures but easy to work with. Assignments are also straightforward and are related to the lectures. Two exams that are not hard at all as long as you've been paying attention and study. Just go to lecture, pay attention, do the labs, and study before the exams and it's an easy A. Feedback could be better.
so terrible

The way she designs her class is awful, it's impossible to do half of the things you need to because she doesn't explain anything and just uses the notes from the book. While she is nice and answers any questions you have, the only reason people go to class is to ask questions, not to pay attention. Basically, if you can avoid this class, do it.
Prof. Wang is very knowledgeable about the domain. He uses practical /industry examples to illustrate the concepts and his lectures are amazing and inspirational.
One of the best professors in OSU, and he definitely understands very well of the class and this direction.

Not bad, not great. Lectures were dry. Midterm was fine and I personally thought the final was easy. Didn't always give clear answers to questions in class (and sometimes didn't even know the answer). Labs were straightforward given the content of the class. If you get his section I wouldn't stress out trying to switch, but not a first choice fs.

He led the lab portion of the class. He is honestly great! He is very kind and is good at helping you when you need help. The only thing I thought was interesting was that he did occasionally recommend using GoogleAI for help.

Adil was a great professor and I really enjoyed his teaching style. It's a bit hard to see and understand things from the back of class but front row it's much better. The content was difficult but I felt like he did a good job simplifying things. Exams were also not easy but he accommodated for it. You definitely need to study a lot for exams.

Definitely the worst professor I've had. He showed up late almost every single day to lecture, and would often forget where he left off with teaching and re-teach slides he had already taught. "Teaching" is also a loose word because I learned nothing. He also graded nothing until finals week which made it hard to know what I knew. Definitely avoid.

He barely taught and when he did he just read directly off of the slides. Does not write his own exams or teach what will be on the exams. Had the audacity to talk on the phone with tech support (and had one of them come in too) through our ENTIRE final exam which was very disruptive. He will come up with a BS excuse for all of his shortcomings.

please just look at his Wisconsin RMP where he used to teach at. Same thing different school. Uses older midterms from other professors will tell you it is his own work despite getting it from the university repository therefore the content on the exam will not reflect what is taught to that point. Expect little help on hw or labs since not his.

He's nice but please don't take this section unless you already know the material. You will not learn anything that you don't already know. Asking questions will lead you to a tangent on something that was already discussed or will miss the point entirely.

If you want to learn something in systems 2 then do not take this class. His lectures are awful and you do not learn anything in them. His tests are completely different from what he teaches in class. His carmen material is also not good either. Just take someone else.

He is very caring, and is willing to listen to feedback on his shortcomings. Unfortunately, that feedback is frequently because he is not teaching well enough to do well on the homework or exams. He may have a lot of patience, but the rest of us don't.
I want to like him because he's a nice guy but his teaching is awful and he is disorganized

This professor is a really nice guy however, from my experience and students from other colleges that have taken him this is his shortfalls. 
- Inaccessible
- Tests do not equate what is learned or on homework (study ahead)
- loses track of what has been taught so you will go over the same stuff a bunch
- Does not know lecture content ahead of time
If I could do it again, I would definitely not take his class. His lectures are terrible and he doesn't respect others.

He's a decent professor, but his lectures are average. Won't learn much about WebGL unless you actively work on it outside of class. Great intro class for grad students in computer graphics. But, for undergraduate students, unless you have a really, really strong interest in computer graphics, I wouldn't take the class.

Some of the concepts were confusing and hard to follow in class, but the exams are very similar to the homework assignments. There is a group extra credit opportunity worth an extra 10%. The quizzes are all take home. I would highly recommend going to office hours for help on the homework and quizzes.
Great professor. He gave lots of bonus points as well if you actively participated in the lectures.

He does care about his students' success, offering a 10% boost to final grades for excelling in group presentations. His midterm exams are thoughtfully and creatively designed, though his class is often tougher than others. However, gaps in conveying core concepts can make the material challenging to grasp.

The content of this class is pretty dry, but he did the best he could to keep us intruiged. He is incredibly helpful in office hours and will make sure you understand the topic before leaving. The midterm was rough for me, but he made it up with an very fair final. He also isgenerous with curves, points and extra credit!

Lecture can be a bit boring but the professor is AWESOME. He is very considerate of students and replies emails really quick (I believe as soon as he saw it). The exam is very similar to the homework and other materials.
The professor is awesome!
Lecture can be dry some times but grading are very fair and knows what he's talking about.
Huan Sun is always ready to answer any questions during class or office hours. She is very kind and willing to help you understand the concepts at a deeper level.

Honestly some of the best lecture slides I've seen - the information was presented very well and easy to follow. She's also very helpful and caring when you ask questions. My only complaint is that there weren't a lot of grades in the class - one bad exam grade will kind of determine your whole grade for the class.
Programming assignments are a little bit difficult for students who have never used python. However, she is always willing to help you. You will get an A if you attend classes.

Very helpful professor. Lectures are well prepared and can explain theories clearly. This course I take is project-based and is not easy, but students have enough time before due dates to learn and ask questions. If you have further discussions with her after class you can find that she is really familiar with her field of study.
The slides are well prepared. Professor Sun also provides links to relative paper under the slides. She gave students inspiration about what is the state of art technique. Good professor.
Avoid her and you will be good. Learn NLP online by watching CS 224N is more helpful

She is a good professor and willing to give you guidance on project and presentation. But she demands high on you. If you did something wrong, she will criticise you directly. Taking her class needs a good machine learning background. Otherwise you will lost in the papers.

The course she offered was definitely highly demanding. However, on the very first day, she had clearly listed the requirements. It was a highly intense class with 2 paper readings per week. Thus it was definitely not meant for the faint-hearted. It was not a lecture class but more of a seminar/paper-reading class. The learning curve was steep.

Worst professor I have ever met. As a new professor, she has spent little time in teaching. She just let the student present papers every weeks. It seems that she does not know the paper very well. This kind of paper reading is useless. You can hardly learn anything in her class. Her grading standard is harsh on the final project.
Took this guy Spring 24, great guy. Go to his office hours and you will pass with a good grade. Got me in the major easily.

Logan is awesome! I went into this class with extreme imposter syndrome, but now that it's done, I am so much more confident in my coding skills. Logan genuinely cares about if his students learn and he wants them to do well. I always felt extremely prepared for exams and projects. Definitely recommend taking SW1 with Logan if you have the chance!

I saw someone write a bad review about Logan Frank, so I am here to set the record straight. Logan was an amazing instructor, easy to access outside of class though email, useful office hours, etc. He made it very clear what to expect for exams, and overall gave very clear guidelines for projects. Went over the top in teaching 2221, amazing guy.

Professor Logan Frank is someone who clearly cares about teaching, but his approach can be discouraging. While he's passionate about the material, his grading is extremely harsh, and he often leaves students feeling inadequate. Despite efforts to reach out for clarification or help, he rarely responds, making students feel ignored and small.

The pre labs and in labs can be tedious, but the exams are really easy. The only homework is online quizzes once a week, which are also very easy. Lectures are definitely helpful if you are struggling with the class, but after the first few weeks I only ever went for exam reviews and was fine just reading over the notes on my own.

I knew nothing about excel or even worked with computers but this class was an easy A. You grade consists of 9 prelabs, 9 labs, weekly online quizzes and 3 exams. No cumulative final! The labs were time consuming but fairly easy and the exams were very similar to the practice exams she gives out. Loved this class

Lectures are optional but beneficial and straightforward. No finals, grades are made up of three exams, 9 in labs and 9 pre labs, and weekly quizzes. Clair stays after lectures to help students with any quick questions they may have. Additionally, tutor rooms are open daily in case questions arise after class. This is a relatively easy pre req.
It is a very easy class if you do the work and practice the material. For the exams, the practice exam is just like the exams you take. Review that and you will get a 100 on each one.
Don't take this professor - take another one. course is good but prof is not. she will make your life miserable and is of no help when you have questions
This class is an easy A! Everything is easy and clear, and she helps you during office hours. I was surprised that she remembered my name at the end of the semester. and she is very helpful.
if you get her as a professor, head to the third floor of the union and say goodbye.
The class is pretty easy just make sure you stay on top of the work. You dont have to attend lectures and all the material is posted online.

Clair lectures are a little boring because it's a lot of talking but I would still recommend attending those because they are helpful for the exams and the labs. I honestly thought this class was gonna be harder but it ended up being okay. Clair is really nice and you can tell she likes to help and want her students to succeed.

For me, she was just average. Lectures were pretty boring, but at least they were structured in a way that made it easy to understand. Strict no-second-chance policy for late assignments which seems pretty harsh considering they're always due on weekdays, but I haven't run into any problems with it, just have heard of other experiences. Overall ok

Professor Farris was great, very kind and easy-going. Lectures were smooth and straight-forward. Exams weren't very difficult at all and she has exam reviews during the previous lectures. Only have to go into the labs for the first one and the two midterm exams, can skip them if you get the work done beforehand.

The course was very well organized. Mrs. Farris' lecture slides were very detailed and if I was stuck on an assignment, I could look back to the slides for guidance. She is very caring and always willing to help students before/after class and during office hours. This, like other CS courses, can be very difficult to teach, but she nailed it!

She is one of the most boring teachers I've ever had. Has no personality and her TA's are clueless, especially Aparijit (has no humor, gets mad at you if you ask a question, and his haircut is from Great Clips). It's not a hard class, but it's not taught very well.
Clair is a good lecturer, goes step by step over everything.  Lacks a little bit of personality, but if you can stay awake this class is very easy.

Clair Farris does a really good job with lectures and explaining everything step by step. After class she is always willing to answer any questions and for the labs, go on the zoom office hours. It's like a tutor room with all of the TA graders and they will help you with almost any assignment. Class was not difficult at all, just put in the time.
did not answer any emals
Nice but tough class.

Amazing caring teacher, she was always ready for my many questions after class and was always super nice about it. Only 2 test and the final that are exactly like the practice test. Highly recommend taking CSE with her.

This class is very boring, but Clair really prepares you for exams and for the labs. The TA grades the lab homework, and they can take off points for stupid little things sometimes. But overall, her exams are easy if you take her practice exam and go over the exam review powerpoints. solid professor imo
Horrible lecturer - just read powerpoints and used WAY too many props in slides.  Hard to follow.  Do NOT take this professor if you don't have to ...

Such a sweetheart and a fantastic teacher. Just do the work and show up to class if you need it. Also learning a bit of excel before you enroll in the class will make it a smooth transition. Clair is such an amazing and gracious teacher and I wish I could have her for every class.

Great lectures that helped me understand the concepts better. There is labs that take a good amount of time but arent too difficult if you watch the lectures and read course notes. The exams were pretty easy and straightforward. Plenty of opportunities to get extra help.

CSE 2111 is dreaded by many, but Clair's class wasn't very difficult. Her lectures were thorough, and she would take time to answer questions. She was clear in what she expected on labs and tests and prepared for us for what was to come. Her online format was very organized and clear.
I LOVE CLAIR FARRIS. GREAT TEACHER. SUPER UNDERSTANDING AND HELPFUL. SHE IS GOATED

The class itself is pretty tough the first few weeks, but once you get past that, you'll be fine! Clair is a great professor and is super helpful in her office hours and throughout her lectures! The quizzes and exams were not super difficult, and the labs (while quite time consuming) were great practice! Definitely take her class!
I loved Prof Farris, She is super accommodating and if you do the work, you should do relatively well. I didn't think the tests were bad at all but they were also online and opened note.

I loved Clair so much. Has a lot of time allotted for office hours and truly cares about students' success. Friendly lady and very knowledgeable in Excel and Access. Class was pretty hard for the first couple of weeks but it all came together!
Lectures are pretty boring and confusing. I learned better by teaching myself. Labs and exams are graded by TAs who were pretty lenient with small errors. Overall pretty dry and uninteresting.

This class is really, really hard. But Clair understands that and is always available and willing to help. Not necessarily a hard class, just time-consuming, and you have to study the concepts to really understand them. All the coursework is online but the exams are on paper which is difficult.
I really liked her. I thought the class was very fair and it was very easy to get help. I think that she explains the material well and she is very understanding with students.
Good fair professor. She is ready to help you, just go to class pay attention and ASK QUESTIONS IF NOT CLEAR! Overall good experience with her.

Very nice professor, relatively difficult class. Clair is very helpful with material tho and willing to work with schedule conflicts. Prelab work outside of class sometimes take awhile. Labs mandatory, lectures are not but they're helpful. Exams are a little challenging because they're on paper but everything in class is on computers.

Clair is the best professor you can have for this class (I had Mark Jackson and had to drop because he was so bad). She did a nice job of explaining the concepts and was available for office hours several times a week. The class itself is not too hard if you put in the work for it, but you will certainly have an easier time with Clair.

Clair is a great choice for CSE! It's not her fault, but the class is just boring. Pre-labs take a long time but usually aren't too difficult. Labs are the same but there are student helpers that tell you what to do if you ask. I was awful with Excel, okay with Access, and still got an A- so getting a good grade is not hard. 10/10 prof though!
Very useful class, and Clair is a really good instructor

She isn't exactly teaching a thrilling class so it can be difficult to make her lectures interesting. However she is a good professor and was helpful when asking her questions and visiting her office hours.

Clair Farris is by far the best professor I have ever had. Shes a real gem. I advise anyone who is worried about being in this class to use her office hours. She explains the concepts more and she is able to help you understand the material better. By far the best CSE lecturer at OSU.

Clair was good at explaining what we needed to know to pass the class. I didn't like how the course was set up that much and grading felt slightly inconsistent. However, overall she was great and as long as you put in the work and don't let yourself fall behind, you will do well in the class.

If you have to take CSE 2111, she is a great choice. Uploads all the notes and works through problems in front of the whole class. Takes the 2 best grades of the 3 quizzes in the class. Overall, she is sweet and willing to help.

Literally never went to class and studied on my own. Labs are easy since you do the prelabs beforehand. Clair is very nice and you can ask her questions during quizzes/exams and she clarifies very well. I didn't do very much with this class and still ended with an A. TA's are also very helpful during lab. I loved this class and doing the labs!
good teacher easy course

This class gets a really bad rep but it really isn't that hard, and especially isn't hard when Clair is your prof. She's very patient and kind, and her lectures are presented in a very easy to follow format. Some pre-labs are pretty lengthy, but take your time on them and do them well because they're a decent percentage of your grade.
Clair was a great professor who will set you up for success and make sure you're prepared for quizzes and exams.

Clair is a very caring prof and even allowed me to take the final on a different day. CSE is a somewhat dull/repetition-heavy class but she is a very clear lecturer and knows her stuff. CSE is very time-consuming so don't procrastinate. Pre-labs take time and effort. Midterm is very hard. Excel gets very difficult later on. Access isn't so bad.

Have labs in most weeks, but do not worry this in final weeks, do not have lab in final weeks. do not need to spend any time reviewing before exam, because it is too easy. Have 3 exam but drop the lowest, 1 midterm and 1final. Pre labshomeworktakes 3 hours each time, and harder than exam and in lab. Pre labs are fun.
Clair Farris does a great job at explaining everything you need to know for the quizzes and labs. The class is very easy as long as you go to class and do the pre-labs on time.

Dr. Farris is a nice lady but her lectures are poorly organized. The slides really don't help and definitely could be better. If you do and understand the prelabs and the concepts in there you should be fine. Easy class if you work hard
Good teacher and class as long as you do all the pre-labs and don't copy. The TA's grade most of the assignments easily and you don't have to go to lecture. Best CSE teacher

Clair is the best CSE professor by far. She really cares about her students and makes this difficult class make more sense. Though she can't influence what content must be taught, she is great at explaining it.

Clair is a great lecturer. CSE 2111 is a nightmare and whoever designed the course is borderline incompetent. However, if you're going to have to take it- take it with Clair. Her lectures are good pace and she makes sure you understand the material, answers questions, and just seems like a good person. Goodluck in CSE though...
Good mix of grades with prelabs, labs, worksheet, quizzes, exams, and attendance. Her voice can be annoying, but she is a nice lady. TAs usually are hard to understand. Useful material learned.

I was really nervous going into CSE2111 reading the reviews on here. But Clair is the BEST! She makes everything so easy and is super nice & caring. You definitely have to put TONS of work into the prelabs and worksheets but the prelabs are basically the same thing as the labs so its okay. Switch your lecturer now if you dont have Clair. Shes great

Great lecturer for a hard topic. Some of the formulas (for Excel) and queries (for Access) can be tricky, but she's very clear about each step when running through examples. She also puts videos of going through problems online in case you miss a lecture. The pre-labs take a long time, so split them up over a few days.

She is super nice and helpful. This is an easy class as long as you follow the directions. You'll have one homework assignment due each week that can take hours to an entire day to complete. Procrastination will make you fail for sure here!

Clair is very nice. You can ask her questions outside and before/after class, and she's pretty helpful. CSE 2111 is a generally easy course, as long as you do the prelabs and show up for lecture occasionally. All the slides are online so the only reason to go to lecture is attendance. Clair is an easy grader and usually dismisses class early.

Great teacher for a tough class. Makes the material clear and easy to learn, although this is certainly not an easy class. You HAVE TO  go to class and practice daily in order to get a good grade. Pre-labs are pointless and take hours at a time to complete. However, Clair made it as easy as possible and would make sure we knew the material.

One of the better CSE teachers. She goes over powerpoints in class and attendance is for a grade so you have to show up but she rarely keeps you the full 55 minutes. She posts videos of examples online that are extremely helpful so overall it isn't too hard of a class
Her lectures are boring, but she is nice and almost always ends early. She's also by far the easiest CSE 2111 professor so take her class if you can.

Great professor, doesn't get angry at repeated questions or if you show up late. She seems like she truly cares if you understand or not. Lectures are not mandatory but you do sign in so she knows who came and who didn't at the end of the semester when people want their final grade bumped up. Overall easy class, but don't underestimate the midterm

Clair is the best lecturer out of all of the CSE 2111 lecturers. She includes many helpful tips in every lecture that really help. She truly understands the way students think and does not assume that we know anything beforehand. Also, extremely helpful when asking questions during quizzes etc. :)

Clair is very understanding and always wants to help.  Class was very difficult to me probably should've gotten a C or C+ but ended up with a B due to extra credit and curved final.  Pre labs are a lot of work but definitely do them.  If class comes easily to you, easy A, if not can still end up with a B or so if you work at it.

Best CSE2111 class. The class itself is easy, but the pre labs take a ton of time. She is clear and really tells you what to expect on the midterm.  Most useful class at Fisher I can guarantee you that you will use this stuff in your internships and jobs

There is no homework for the class only prelabs. There are three quizzes and one gets dropped and a midterm and final with 11 labs. You can get 20 points bonus,  so this class isn't hard. Farris reads off the power points but will help you with anything. Not an exciting class but I learned a lot.

She did her job in that she just goes through the CSE power points. She is very helpful and approachable one on one. but in a big lecture its what you would expect. She often finishes early which is nice but you don't have to attend because the power points are online and all she does is read through them
Clair was a great lecturer! She was very clear in her lectures and always willing to help out any struggling students.

Mrs. Clair Farris is very knowledgeable on the subject, very helpful instructor. Always available and willing to help outside the class time. she make lectures very clear and gives real world examples. She is the best instructor you can hope for. Highly recommend her
Clair is an overall nice, helpful, and candid lecturer. She explains the content well and makes herself available if you need help. From most accounts, she is the best 2111 lecturer.

Truly bone dry lectures where he does nothing but talk at students. Often goes off topic to discuss tangential topics. Often times is unable to help with homework and labs or points students in the wrong direction.

Like everyone else said, veryyyy boring lectures there wasn't a day where I didn't almost fall asleep. He often goes off-track and talks about things that have nothing to do with this class. Start your labs early because none of the lecture material actually teaches you how to do it. Exams/homework were graded fairly easy though.

Most unhelpful lectures I've ever attended. 95% of content on exams I had learned myself because the overwhelming majority of lecture slides were just implementations of something in a mobile app written in java, then kotlin. I know he means well, but he's just not made to teach a class.

Made the intro to OS class incredibly hard to grasp for people with limited knowledge of OS. Brushed through slides faster than lightnings. Always went on Amazon websites and played dumb YouTube videos rather than taught students useful things. Minimal help in office hours.

Terrible class, terrible teacher and terrible grader. They did not give any rubrics and just reduced your points as they wanted! The course was very boring and just reading the textbook or material. Do not take it!!!

Champion's lectures are extremely long, dry, and boring. He tends to talk at students for the entire lecture, and sometimes goes off on random tangents that contribute nothing. He is also not really knowledgeable about the material he assigns for labs, and can't provide helpful explanations/answers in lecture or office hours.
Very passionate and really smart professor.

Not sure why all the awful reviews, lectures were boring but informative, homeworks/labs were easy and graded leniently, and exams were fair imo. Not my favorite professor or class but I would take it with him again.
Avoid at all costs that is all I have to say if you want to keep your sanity.

This class was bad and in large part because of Champion. Lectures were extremely dry and hard to follow and the lectures slides are hard to look at and study off of. The times I went to office hours to get help on assignments and I was never directly asking for the answer but the most common reply I would get is "try printing it out on paper".

Adam is extraordinarily smart, but he isn't a good teacher. His lectures are horribly dry, and he often goes on long tangents. There's only three homeworks and four labs, so the midterm and final are 50% of the grade. The exams and homeworks are full of "gotcha" questions, so you better memorize every detail from the internet and 700-page textbook.

Lectures were pretty boring and hard to sit through, but his exams were relatively easy as long as you read the textbook. Slides are pretty pointless as well and he doesn't post lecture videos. I went to his office hours and he is an extremely nice and caring person who I enjoyed getting to know. Exams are fair but a little lengthy.

Grading is pretty lenient. Dryest lecturer I've had, so I stopped attending class. His lectures are all taken word for word from the textbooks, and his labs from other profs. All of my learning done was from the textbook, and I still got an 88% on the midterm. If you can't learn from textbooks well, skip him.
Easy class. Easy labs. Stupid and boring lecturer.

Good professor, I like his class because of his knowledge of Operating systems. I went to every office hour to get answers to my questions. Labs are great and enable me to understand how to improve the codes because the second lab depends on the previous. I studied the book before the lecture and that help me a lot. Great Dr.

Adam Champion is like the Sheldon Cooper of Computer Science. Not the best professor I've had, but his class is fair. I would recommend occasionally glancing at the book and making friends in his class so you have a reason to show up for it. We made a bingo board with all of his quirks and phrases (and won within two lectures).

Basically all he did was read the textbook for 90 minutes straight. And he never put an assignment out that had correct info. Had to go on piazza and ask questions and he says oops Ill fix that. One assignment was missing an entire file of words he meant to use. Worst part is his lectures are the most dry lectures ever.

Dr. Champion is not a good professor, he is a good guy but his lectures have no sustenance in them and don't really set you up to do the projects or the exams. That being said the projects are graded very leniently, and he is a very forgiving grader on the exams. If you can get through the dry lectures and exams you will be okay, not too difficult.
I'm writing this review to stay awake during his lecture... So insanely dry and ridiculous amounts of readings.

He seems scared or bored when teaching. Very smart guy who knows his stuff. Very long awkward pauses and always goes off topic from the teaching material. 2 HWs are easy but 5 labs are average to hard. Exams are fair (83% avg). Struggles to answer questions live but is helpful on Piazza. If 2431 wasn't so boring, he would be alright I guess

Good: Recorded lectures, super receptive of feedback and cares that the class is fair, reasonable expectations, provides a list of topics on exams, follows books closely. Bad (that was his fault): Boring (albeit optional) lectures, half the labs are easy but half were super annoying (i.e. C string manipulation)

As many have stated, the lectures are very dry. Feedback is not given for assignments for over a month, so it's tough to tell whether you're on the right track in class. The good thing about his class is that he has Office Hours essentially every weekday, which is really convenient.

Lectures can be dry, but also sometimes hard to follow. There are many labs, but he will not look at your code in zoom, which is not good. Homeworks are fairly easy and the midterm was not bad either. The final exam was very hard.

Sure the lectures were a bit dry, but overall taking mobile app development with Champion was a straightforward and enjoyable experience. Exams were a bit tougher than average, but graded pretty generously. The average grade in the class ended up being an A-. Just put in the work to have the project ready for each checkpoint and you'll be fine.

Rather dry lectures along with exams that force you to memorize useless Google-able info instead of actually testing content mastery. It's probably better because this is a project course because less of your grade is dictated by his inability to teach well. He cares, but it doesn't show too well. I'm glad I have a chill TA who's actually cool

Champion is a awkward guy but his heart is in the right place. Hes willing to help outside of class and during class. His grading is a little bit harder than others. Two exams, incremental project gradings and small homework assignments. Its not easy but its not difficult if you put in the time its not hard to get a good grade.

If you can avoid him, please do. Lectures are dry, hes a tough grader, and at this point no one can get an A in his cse4471 class. Don't take him as a cse elective. His exams are memorization and his projects are graded very harshly because of his standards.
6 quizzes, 2 exams and 4 projects. Although Dr. Champion is always glad to help, he is not a good teacher. His lectures are boring. It is hard to get a good grade.

He is very awkward and often doesn't understand the intent behind a question, making him either sound demeaning or go extremely off topic with his answer. You have to be up to date on material all the time because of pop quizzes. Textbook was mostly helpful; he was open to answer any clarifying questions that I had during office hours.
Honestly, I learned nothing in lectures. Terrible professor.

All the labs were in python. We never learned any python. We had pop quizzes (exams) that took the entire class. Adam was awkward and couldn't answer questions clearly. Lectures added nothing to the slides, and the slides were pretty bare. The book was supposedly helpful for others, but I found it too boring to use. Goodluck!

Possibly my least favorite professor I've had the mispleasure of having at OSU. The class only happens twice a week yet there's a pop quiz every two weeks that takes the entire period. The topics on these quizzes and midterms range from basic principles to gosh I hope you really remembered that one obscure detail that was talked about for 30seconds

Champion is one of the few professors I've had that has actually helped me understand the material. He's a genuinely nice person and he always wants to make sure people are clear on the topic before moving on. Networking is a dry topic in general, but I think he makes the best of it.
His lectures are pretty boring and he probably knows that too. All his pop quizzes and exam questions are from the book. No homeworks and a few labs.
Sort of difficult because the lectures are dry and the book is also really dry. Averages are low but the labs are almost guaranteed 100% and the curve is nice.

Adam is a nice guy, but he is a HORRIBLE teacher. Lectures are worthless but mandatory; however, you either stay for a 30 min lecture or have a "work day" most days. Nothing from his lectures will help with the group project or the exams. The textbook for the class is really good and is the only way to really learn the material to pass the class.

This class was less of a "class" and more of "Teach yourself from this book because the lectures won't teach you anything." The book is pretty good, though, so if you want to teach yourself mobile app programming and get credit for it, you can make it through this class. The prof is nice but does not seem to know how to teach.

Champion gives dry lectures that are not aligned with the semester project. He is usually not helpful when answering questions and is just an awkward person. Attendance is mandatory, so basically everyone would work on their laptops and pay no attention to him. If you're interested in mobile apps and can teach yourself, though, the class is doable.

Words can't describe how awful of a professor he is, but I'll try. If you have a class with him, get ready to bear with learning nothing from and him and everything from the textbook. He doesn't even know what's going on, so don't bother asking him questions either. Highly recommend not going to class and just reading the textbook.

The best way to summarize my experience with Champion is to simply tell you about the first homework we were given. Nothing on the homework was covered in lecture, nor was it covered in the book. He gave us problems with no resources or mention of how to solve them.

Really didn't like this professor, it was so hard to pay attention in class and he goes straight from the book. I wish I skipped and just read the book and looked at his slides. One time he did go over a lab in class before it was due so we could see a similar example. Only time class was helpful. Hws taken from book. medium to tough labs.

A very socially awkward guy which makes him not the perfect teacher. The class itself if poorly organized though. The main point of it is the self done project, but the lectures don't match pace with the project well at all. You will be lectured on content that you won't use until a month later at times. Otherwise, he gets the job done
I had an awful experience in the class. Boring lectures, hard homeworks, hard labs, and hard tests. If you also aren't familiar with python, the class will be torture
Homeworks and labs  are easy. Exams are tough but Dr. Champion curves a lot. Lectures are not interesting and you have to learn by yourself.  Overall, an easy class.
Great curve!

Here's the deal.. I had a really good TA so it helped but between the project, attendance, and curve that he gives at the end of the class, overall it isn't all that bad. Like others said, lectures are BORING and the exams are difficult but just make sure you do well on everything else. The majority of the class bombs the exams so that helps too..

In one word: terrible. The only good thing is there is a decent curve in the class. Lectures are pointless to attend. Labs are tough and the exams are tough. Don't waste your time asking for help, because he has no clue.

For this class: Project is broken up, so most points are easily attained. Attendance is 10%, while Exams are manageable accounting for 40% of the class, which is easy if you attend. For other classes: His slides are color coded, anything in red or underlined will most likely be on the test. Study the red slidestext and his exams are fairly easy.
One of the worst professors in the OSU CSE department.  Avoid!

Did not know class material. When asked a question he would repeat what he said in lecture verbatim or would tell you to look it up in a book or would talk for 5 minutes, but never answer your question. Lab guidelines were sometimes vague. Did nothing about the terrible grader our class had (gave people no/wrong grades). Should not be teaching!

Nice guy but never helped with the labs if you had a question. He got confused frequently on the topics. Always told people to look up the book section...that's why we asked him though. Grader's okay, but not very helpful on labs either. Never graded harsh though. Adam grades too harshly on the midterm, so even with a curve it was tough...
Dry and confusing lectures, no lab discussion, homework that has nothing to do with lecture, and difficult exams.  He often seems to not know the answer to questions.  Avoid if possible.

Gives exams with short answer and does not give partial credit. Very harsh exam grader.  Very unclear lecturer and seems confused a lot.  Pretty much refused to help me at all on the lab when I came to  his office hours. Didn't seem to know what was required/expected for the labs he assigned.

A weirdly structured "project" class that seems to rely way too heavily on exams and memorizing lecture content. Provides no feedback throughout the entire semester and is not particularly helpful when asking questions about content or projects.

Sivilotti would a be a great professor if he graded more fairly. None of our grades for the projects were available until the literal day that grades were due, with no comments or feedback on the assignments so that we could understand where our grades were coming from. Exams ranged for fair to difficult and had an average of around 70 percent.

This class is A LOT of work - 6 projects, 2 midterms, a final, and 2 extra presentations. Be prepared to put in a lot of time, and try to get in a good group. This term, his TA stopped grading things, so we didn't see any project grades until the night they were due. There was a weird curve; some people's grades were bumped up and others weren't.

I had little exp. with coding and did struggle in FEH 1281 my 1st semester and worried for this course but Paul was able to help me tremendously! He does well explaining concepts in lectures, helpful in office hours, and a very passionate guy. I'm very grateful for his thoroughness with the course content and wish all professors were this way

Due to character limit, concise review

Pros:
- Adequate lecturer.
-  Uses Canadian GPA scale. 80=A-

Cons:
- Impatience during labs, seeking help useless. TAs useful.
- No show THREE LABs, relied on TA. 
- Exams: Challenging, tricky questions.

2221 review:
- 2221 course is archaic, forced to learn exclusive OSU libraries.
- Paper exams hi% grade.
An extremely passionate and caring professor. He was great at explaining the course material throughout lectures and labs, and his office hours were extremely helpful for homework and projects.

Professor Sivilotti is good at explaining difficult concepts using examples, which makes discussing problems with him a pleasure.He uses Canadian standard grading rules, which means that an overall score of 80 or above has a chance of getting an A- or A. Correspondingly, assignments and midterms will be graded more rigorously, which is fair.
He presented the lectures in a very interesting way and seemed genuinely interested in students. The projects were graded very strictly and lots of points were taken off for small mistakes
Funny, caring, and extremely knowledgable. Software 1 is a hard course by nature, but he makes it as palatable as possible. If you don't understand something, ask him and he will help you out.

Projects are graded very tough, office hours can help a little but lectures can be very vague and the criteria for the projects follow in suit. Expects you to have experience in front end despite telling his students he doesn't, expects you to be very on top of your work and if you fall back a little bit he will leave you in the dust.

Terrible professor. Doesn't know how to teach a course. Gives extremely difficult exams. I would avoid him at all costs as he does not care if his students succeed. A very selfish professor and does not care about his students at all.

Lectures were very interesting, but tended to be off-topic. There could have been clearer instructions and more guidance for our projects, but it did mean that we had a lot of design freedom. I would definitely recommend this course, but know that it might be more work than the other options. Exams were hard, but the course was curved nicely.

Easily the least well organized class I've taken. Sivilotti joked about teaching us what we need to know 3 weeks after we needed to know it (which was absolutely true and not funny). He never responded to emails and was terrible about giving feedback on assignments. He was rude and disrespectful and always ended class like five minutes late.

Dr. Sivilotti has been one of the best professors I have had at tOSU. He was always willing to help and answered questions. Exams were pretty tough but as long as you study and go to class you will be fine. Once again great professor and he inspired and challenged me throughout the semester.

Dr. Sivilotti is an inspired lecturer who takes the time and puts in the effort to make sure that students not only pass his class but walk away from the course enriched in the field of computer science. He is a firm but fair grader and his tests and homework ensure that students who consistently give effort will pass.
Amazing teacher! Make sure you find a good group though, and be prepared to put a lot of time and work into this class.
Very helpful. Learned a lot from him and grading was fair. Take 3901 with him if you can! Highly recommended.

I had Dr Sivilotti for both CSE 421 and CSE 560. He is the best professor I had and explains everything very well. The exams are fair and labs are interesting. It is very easy to get in contact with him and he also gets on Google Chat.

Very knowledgeable about Java and industry standards for the language.  Tough but fair (and completely passable) exams.  Slightly boring class, but the 9:30am time slot didn't help his case.  I learned a lot from him and would definitely consider taking him again.  Very easily accessible outside of class.

Definitely my favorite teacher in the CSE department.  His lectures are informative, he's amazingly helpful in office hours, and his exams are fair.  This is the second class I've had with him, and I'll be looking to take more.

One of the best teachers in the department. He gives the clearest and most exciting presentations I have ever seen. He really made me want to learn Java. This teacher truly has a gift for teaching. We are lucky to have him here at OSU. Definitely take him whenever you have a chance. You wont regret it! Believe me.
Good prof, I got lucky with 2 highly motivated grad students in my group, but his midterms were fair. looks like Michael Keaton a little.

The instructor really cares about the students' experiences in their progression through the major. Brought useful content to a class that he could have easily blown off.  He also proposed curriculum changes at several Curriculum Committee meetings (I was a student attendee) which clearly showed his passion for student learning.  Look him up.
I also had Paolo for CIS 560.  The department has plenty of great instructors.  He and Mathias were my favorites.  He is an excellent teacher, and 763 is a good class if you liked CIS 760.
He looks like Michael Keaton, and is Canadian. Made a hard class a lot easier. Interesting final exam, had a graded crossword on it.
This class has alot of work so its not easy.  Dr. Sivilotti is a very good teacher, is very clear and helpful and takes time to answer any questions you may have.
Very helpful to students. Makes material very clear. Good professor for difficult class.
Really great professor, made the 560 project easy to understand, and kept the lectures lively
The class is a fair amount of busy-work, but Dr Sivilotti keeps it interesting with his sharp wit.  He is one of the best instructors you will have at OSU.
No Comments
Class is a **** whoever you get. Paolo is a good prof though, good personality and funny Canadian accent
great teacher. very hard class, but he takes the time to help out. i learned alot

The entire semester consists of being lectured at with dry and slow slides. Assigns a few homeworks throughout the semester but weirdly they are primarily all coding which is never discussed in lecture and does not show up on exams.

Professor Barker is a pretty great professor. While his lectures are a little dry, they're very informative and leave you well-versed in the material. His exams are very fair and the TAs give good feedback on the HWs so that you are able to improve.

Best professor I seen in OSU. he is willing to provide inner depth concept about the lecture instead of read off. It helps you understand the idea instead of memorize things. Homework is easy if you follow along the lecture. lecture gives you pseudocode of homework which make thing super easy. Exam reasonable and easy (avg of 80 in my class).

Good lecturer who is obviously very experienced in his field. The homeworks are doable and I learned a lot of useful skills as someone new to Python. He does tend to be a slow grader, so prepare to not get your homework back before exams and get your exams back very late (we got the 2nd midterm back on the last day of class).

A good professor. He clearly knows the material. Pay attention to the lectures and make sure to get a good conceptual understanding of the material for the exams. He's accessible outside of class, so all you need to do is reach out and he'll try to make time to go over your concerns.

Wasn't boring at all: enthusiastic but nerdy voice but he didn't just read off of slides. Only hw was weekly online quizzes with unlimited attempts. Projects were very hard but there's only 5. Exams were fairly hard but you are allowed a cheat sheet. Study the slides, and you will be fine. Free points if you go to lecture and complete attendance

Class is a bit dense so probably only take it if you really like AI. Lectures are a bit dry and slow but not that bad. Exams and projects are fair and quizzes are unlimited retries. Chill and understanding guy that lets you argue back lots of points on exams. Overall solid class.

Reads through the slides at a strange and plodding pace. Tough grader on exams. Unreasonable assignments, lecture will leave you unprepared as there are no examples. The end is very tough, you WILL need to do statistics based math here and you WILL NOT get an explanation or examples on how to. Says he's a lecturer, not a prof... That is clear.

The majority of your grade in this class is from 2 exams, and they focus a lot on specifics from the slides. If you can memorize the slides and important algorithms you should do okay, but he gives essentially no partial credit so you really have to study. Lectures are kind of boring but the homework assignments/labs were interesting.

His lectures are the exact opposite of engaging. He just repeats the slides for the full class period. He stops for questions if there are any, but doesn't attempt to engage the class in any way. Very boring and difficult to keep up. His exams are fair and require strong understanding of fundamentals. Avoid if you want a good learning experience.

Barker does have a weird lecture style, but it didn't bother me because I just read the slides and ignored him in class. He almost preaches the slides at you which can be annoying, but he doesn't add anything to them so just throw in some headphones and flip through them in class. The slides were great and assignments were fair.

While he is knowledgeable and passionate about the subject, he has a very strange speaking pattern that I found super boring. He will pause a lot, almost every couple of words, so by the time he is done with his sentence you will have forgotten how it started. Takes attendance daily and homework/programming assignments due every other lecture.

Joe Barker is a nice guy and a decent teacher. He tends to get behind in the class schedule because he goes through the slides very slow (sometimes he is too slow and it gets really hard to pay attention and know what is important). The class itself is made up of homework and two exams. The programming assignments can be challenging and take time.

He was a decent teacher, but the lectures were often boring. He obviously knows what he is talking about, but he has a rather monotonous voice and draws out some of the material too much. Some of his grading is a bit too harsh and does not give any slack, even with legitimate explanations.

Good teacher overall. Nice guy, always very helpful and approachable. Very knowledgeable about the subject and seems to enjoy what he does. Pretty easy class if you just pay attention and do the homework.

He was a solid teacher, but the difference between the one midterm we had and the final was night and day. The midterm was the easiest test I've taken in the Computer Science classes whilst the final was very hard and formatted very differently to the midterm.

Feng is a pretty great professor. Minus points for using flipped classroom model (when he has plenty of time to lecture during class discussion anyway). Also, project rubrics are not published until after the due date which is dumb. Other than that, his lectures (both recorded and live discussions) were great. Explained stuff really well. Helpful
Decent instructor. Not too much homework and exams were okay. The grading seemed pretty fair.
Worst professor ever. Dont know how to teach. Couldnt explain concepts clearly. Obsessed with discussion and just want to make students suffer

Feng is great! He is super helpful and nice, and gives 2% extra credit for visiting his office hours. There weren't many assignments, which was both a great thing and a bad thing. I felt that having more assignments would have made the grading scheme more fair, but overall I would take him again definitely.

Good lecturer and very accessible outside classroom. Clear explanation of basic concepts regarding operating systems. Slides are well prepared, and assignment printouts are very clear about what he expects to be submitted. Will take another class of him.
Worst ever professor in the department..!!!
No Comments

THANK GOD.  Finally a CSE teacher who gets the basic concepts across first. Easily in the top 5 cse teachers I've had here.If you take Babic over this guy, your nuts.  I quote this from his own words "dont worry about the midterm" and it was fine cause people understand what hes talking about instead of ridiculous application problems.

Doreen was a very nice lady, and she cared about us doing well. However, I really didn't like her teaching style. The other foundation's classes did a lot more math-based proofs, which seemed more practical and useful than the work-based stuff we were doing. Her quizzes were difficult, and the graders graded all of the assignments very hard
I like this professor!

Close does well answering students' questions in class, but she doesn't provide homework solutions and grades exams unfairly, offering little partial credit. She also scolds students for not turning on cameras or making small mistakes. Her teaching lacks depth and fails to connect concepts like FSA, PDA and TM  to prior knowledge effectively.

She WILL NOT post homework solutions. Wants students to go to office hours or ask her directly regarding each problem. As a student in engineering and only taking this class for a minor, I do not have time to go to every office hours/stay after class to beg for homework answers. Material that should take an hour to learn SHOULD NOT take 3 hours.

Overall it's a okay class. Graders are tough points off from the smallest mistakes.Makes you feel stupid no matter how much you try. Doesn't get back to you .Attendance is mandatory and will go insane is your face is not showing. Throws out random quizzes and polls when you're not present. She's nice  but very passive aggressive at the same time.

Literally the sweetest professor I have ever had -- very obviously cares for her students, makes sure workload is managable, and homework/exam expectations are very clear, which makes it easy to do well.
The professor is nice. Even though it's an online course, attendance is required and tasks a large portion into the final grade. Quiz every two weeks. 1 midterm.

A good lecturer all things considered but she is crazy strict with attendance. Will get very angry if you zone out during her online lectures or have camera off even briefly. All homework graded very harshly, and the lectures sometimes don't fully prepare you for the homework / exam questions. Not a BAD professor, but certainly an annoying one.

She's a pretty nice lady in general, but she's a little crazy about attendance. When teaching, she doesn't give you a general way to apply the concepts. There were a lot of times where I wished that she gave us a general guideline to help solve some of the questions.

Doreen is a nice but stubborn old lady. HWs due at 7pm Fridays to "prevent cheating," threatens COAM if the camera's off. Had to go to the bathroom and she mashed the request camera feed button like her life depended on it, so now I use a virtual camera. Piazza, a dated LMS from 2009 (lol) is used for extra material. She is fair and easy if you try
she was a nice professor, lectures are recorded and the quizzes and midterms were exactly what was taught in lecture. definitely rewatch the lectures when studying and go to her office hours

Is absolutely psychotic about participation. Threatened to COAM me over an argument of the webcam requirement in her classes. Consistently messes up when teaching problems in lecture. Lectures are not her teaching the material, but waiting for students to answer the problems for her. Do not get on her bad side. DO NOT TAKE HER CLASSES!!

She's very nice and is always willing to explain anything you're confused on. However, she kind of teaches you what specific protocol to follow in certain situations rather than an overarching methodology to follow that would result in you knowing what specific protocol to follow, so you'll probably need to review in-class examples often.

Professor Close is great, she's great at explaining the material and at keeping up with questions asked during lectures and will often stay over class time to help out students who have concerns. The graders can be strict with giving you points and will often dock a significant amount due to simple errors, so that's something to watch out for.

Prof close is very welcoming and will never shame you for asking questions. Additionally she goes at a pace that is very mellow and easy to keep up with. Just make you are taking notes on what she says because a lot of the time it wont be in the slides.

Dr. Close is an incredible professor who maintains the perfect level of difficulty and ease for a mid-level CSE course. She cares about her students and is passionate about the content she teaches. She is mellow and kind. She cultivates a very inclusive environment and ensures that everyone is on the same page.

Took this course over the summer. Her lectures were awesome. Professor Close explains concepts very well and is always open to questions. Also very direct when explaining concepts. Exams and quizzes are straight forward, and the class is very fair. The exams are the same difficulty as the quizzes, and overall very fair class

Although maybe her lead-by-example style of teaching might not be for everyone, I'm very happy that I chose what seems to be the easiest section in what was a very tough class among my circle. Her posting the lectures and going through step-by-step made things a lot easier. Make sure to brush up on your summation skills before  this class though.
Professor goes through lectures very fast which may miss lots of details. Graders are strict about group discussion activities.

Didn't really teach a lot. She speaks very fast, just like we already know how to do with the problems. The way she taught was just providing solutions to some examples, making some students don't know what the correct answer should be when doing homework. She also made mistakes on calculation often.

Good professor. Always ready to help, and exams are easy if you put the effort into attending lectures. Office hours are very accessible. Quizzes and exams make up a large proportion of your grade. She is definitely the best professor for Foundations 1.

Professor Close is the best prof I've had at OSU. I struggled with some personal things during the semester and she met on Zoom with me to talk through it -- extremely caring. She delivers the material very well -- if you attend class, follow along, and take good notes, you should have no problem doing well in the class. Such fun material to learn.

Professor Close is a great person. She is nice and makes sure students are keeping up. However, it's very unfortunate that her HW's, Quizzes, and Exams are unnecessarily hard and unforgiving. Examples she gives in class are much easier than things you'll see in Quizzes and exams. Furthermore, her wording/formatting on exams is terrible for online.

Very tough grader, to get the full points on homework and midterm, you will need to match the exact wording as her answer. Extremely high late penalty. Very unfair about participation grade, lack of transparency in the participation grade calculations. Doesn't provide any answer keys or lecture notes on carmen. Nice person but very bad professor.
Very clear when describing course content. Respectful and nice to students. Content is difficult to begin with and will explain in detail when needed

Although the class was online, she made the lectures very interactive, went over lots of practice problems, and answered any questions even in the middle of the lecture. She is also very understanding and genuinely cares about your concerns.

She's the worst instructor I've ever met at OSU. She's almost neurotic about participation and will use unfair standards to judge your performance if you're lucky enough to be unliked by her. And try every way to deduct your participation points.

She's an ok teacher with a cult fanbase at OSU but the class is rote. Most of the quizzes were verbatim of her lectures. She makes 15% of the grade attendance, which isn't very accommodating to people who prefer different mediums. Pretty dry material like most algo classes but made even harder to take the material outside this 1 specific class

If you're smart, you don't wanna take this instructor's class. Doreen is nice, but she is very demanding and teaches her students like kindergarteners. Very demanding about homework and quiz process but not willing to provide solutions! If I can learn everything in this course in 10 hours, I don't want to spend 40 hours and have to get a B.

You have to write your homework exactly like her answers to get points, which is not encouraging students to learn at all, but just to follow the rules. The percentage of quizzes is much higher than midterm and final, which makes it easy for you to lose points because the answers are not according to her standards.

You need to go to class and pay attention, if you do this and take good notes you will be fine. Most assessments are open note, but timed, going to class and asking questions is integral. Professor Close cares deeply about her students and is very passionate about the material - she wants to see you succeed, however, your efforts are critical.
Doreen is a professor who truly cares about her students and makes an effort to make their lives easier where she can

Foundations 1 is not an easy class by any means. But Close is one of the best lecturers out there. You can literally stop her in the middle of her lecture and she'll clarify any doubts you got. Gave free points on exams and quizzes. Amazing lecturer and a very nice person. Would recommend any day

Professor Close was the best professor I have had in the OSU CSE department so far. She makes the content of this class super easy to understand, unlike other professors who over complicate things. She is the sweetest lady in the world and really cares about you in and outside of class. If you are taking Foundations 1 I would try so hard to get her
Foundations 1 is not an easy course, but Professor Close made it super interesting. Weekly homework, about 8 quizzes, two midterms and one final. Remember to her office hours and you will be good.

Close is a really great teacher. Her and I became friends because I was the class trouble maker, often skipped especially near the end, but she never treated me differently and somehow I continued to learn the content. Hard grader and I got a bad grade, but Im writing this because despite that she teaches well and cares for students.

Close is one of the best professors I have ever had. She is extremely lenient and you can tell she cares about each and every one of her students. She has amazing lectures and will answer any question you may have. She is kind of a tough grader but she gives good feedback and will always help you in office hours.

She is literally one of the nicest and BEST professors I have EVER had at OSU. If you are ever confused about anything at all, she will help you. She goes through the homeworks in class and will answer basically all of the questions. I promise you, you will love this professor.

imo. Dr. Close was one of my favorite professors, and I feel most of the poor reviews are just people salty over a bad grade. Clear learning expectations, understanding and willing to work with you, accessible, genuinely caring. You do need to know content but she is super clear about what to know. No real downsides that were her fault.
The most caring professor I have had so far in the CSE department. Tried to make the most of online classes and you could tell that she really cared for her students and wanted us all to pass.

Prof Close is a nice, experiencial and responsible professor. I like her teaching style and she really concerns for the students. Definitely would take her class again. Also, if taking her in-person class would be possible I can't wait to talk to her.

She'll take off points left and right if the justification for your answer isn't the exact same she has on her key. She doesn't give you the key to the homeworks or quizzes. The lectures are pretty dry. For the first week or two she repeatedly bragged about her teaching and the power she had in the department.
Best professor I've had at OSU. I really hope I get her again.

Can't speak for other classes, but for Foundations 1 I think she's been great. Lectures were really interesting, and she is very accommodating. First midterm was tough, and quizzes are fair but can be tricky, but with COVID19 I can't speak on how normally the other tests would go. I'd definitely take her classes in the future.

An amazing instructor. She is incredibly understanding and helpful, almost as if she is your mother instead of your instructor. The class is fairly difficult, but not without reason. She provides ample clear resources to catch up on any material. Lots of time in class for practice and to ask questions. She is also very clear about her expectations.

If you take this class expect to loose points. This class is as much about learning the material as it is learning how to think her way. Be prepared to memorize definitions, and loose lots of credit completely correct answers justified differently than how she would. That being said she is a very good lecturer and cares a lot about her students.

Dr. Close is one of my favorite profs and I'm lucky to have her again. It's a pretty tough class, but she has good explanations. Midterms are also rather challenging though. Only downside is that none of the notes are on Carmen, so you really need to come to class and do the group work to do well.

She wasn't super clear but she's fine. She's just super strict and quite awkward. She was actually bragging about how she failed graduating seniors on time to emphasize on her rules. The lectures were super dry and the exams were hardest. She's also very feminist like other professors in the department lol.

THIS IS THE BEST Professor for CSE 2321. I tried to take this course w a diff Professor earlier and I almost failed so I had to drop. When I took it with Doreen it was like night and day. I went to every lecture because they MADE SENSE. Shes also funny. Shes caring and if you see her at office hours shell genuinely try her best to help. THE BEST

This class was tough but Professor Close really enjoys teaching it and does a great job. Definitely one of my favorite classes/professors ever, and getting a good grade is doable especially if you come to class. She also really does care about her students and trying to be a fair grader.

Doreen is one of the better choices for 2321. She is very clear when explaining things and asks multiple times if anyone has any questions. You will need to attend lectures to get all of the notes she writes on the board in order to fully understand the material. Exams are fair. She certainly cares about her students as well.

I genuinely dont know what the reviews beneath this are talking about. Doreen Close is a phenomenal professor and probably the best professor I have had at OSU. Her slides are incredibly helpful, she does in fact tell you all of the answers to the homeworks, and she is super fair with grading. I learned so much in this class. 10/10 would recommend

She is the single worst professor in this class. The lecture itself is fine, however she will give no answer to homeworks at all. You will need to learn all by yourself. The final exam is extremely unforgiving by testing on something that she only touched for 10min in the class.

Slides dont have many useful things. Note are small with awful handwriting. Talk too fast and leave out many steps when solving problems and make you confused. It feels like you goal in her class is to figure out her hw questions. Always end class early. You have to figure out many things by yourself on YouTube. Not bad, but definitely not good.

Prof. Close is a very caring and solid professor, but the lack of structure and outside material in the course really hurts learning potential. You pretty much need to grasp everything from lecture and even if you do the exams are exponentially harder. It's tough to learn everything properly, and the way she designed the course doesn't help.

Professor Close is a great lecturer and she gives really helpful materials/worksheets. The exams in this class can be tough but she gives some extra credit and grades pretty leniently. She also really cares about her students and puts a lot of effort into organizing the class. She was even able to end class early almost every day, which was great.
A very great one professor. I paying attention in the lecture and quiz is just what she says. The midterm has more harder questions but is still very fair. I liking this class.
